great game highly recommend Great game Peak New York styled Pizza:
Pizza dough:
14 g instant yeast
617g water - 95F
950g all-purpose flour
19g fine sea salt
25g granulated sugar
American Pizza Sauce and Toppings:
1 tablespoon (14g) butter
1 tablespoon (9g) extra virgin olive oil
6 cloves garlic, rough chopped
2 teaspoons (4g) red pepper flakes
28 oz (794g) can of crushed tomato
2 teaspoons (2g) dried oregano
1.5 tablespoons (21g) granulated sugar
salt and pepper to taste
Splash of olive oil
2 cups (227g) low moisture mozzarella, fresh grated
2 cups (200g) Monterey jack cheese, fresh grated
1/2 cup (26g) parmigiano reggiano, fresh grated
American Pizza Dough:
Preheat the oven and a baking steel or pizza stone at 500F for 45 minutes before utilizing it.
Whisk yeast and sugar into your water, and allow it to sit for 5 minutes. In a separate bowl, add flour and salt and mix by hand to combine. Pour your water mixture into your flour and mix by hand until you get a rough dough, then transfer to a work surface and knead until it starts to pull away from the work surface and is relatively smooth.
Place your dough in a greased bowl, then cover with plastic wrap and let rise for 1 - 2 hours at room temperature or until double in size.
Punch down your dough and dive into 300g pieces. Form those pieces into balls and place them in a floured proofing pizza box, cover with a lid, and proof at room temperature for 3 - 4 hours. (If you do not have a proofing pizza box, you can use a floured baking sheet, cover it with an inverted baking sheet and wrap it in plastic wrap.)
American Pizza Sauce and Toppings:
In a medium sauce pot, add butter and olive oil. Set that over medium-high heat; once the butter melts add garlic, cook until fragrant, add pepper flakes, and cook, stirring occasionally, until the garlic begins to brown on the edges.
Add crushed tomatoes, oregano, salt, and a splotch of olive oil, boil over medium-high, reduce heat to low, and simmer for 12 minutes, stirring occasionally or until thickened and viscous‚Äîseason with salt to taste and let it cool down.
Assembly.- Place one of your pizza doughs onto a floured pizza peel, and flour your dough generously.
Punch your dough down in the center, working your way out to create a ¬º‚Äù wide. Pick up your dough, place it over your closed fists, and rotate it around, gently stretching to 13‚Äù to 14‚Äù.
Place a couple of spoons of your sauce, starting in the center, spreading in little circles, and working your way to the edge until it gets evenly spread out.
In a medium-size mixing bowl, place mozzarella cheese, Monterey Jack, and Parmigiano; mix until combined. Sprinkle your cheese mixture to your desire and place in the oven onto your baking steel and bake for 5 - 7 minutes or until the edge gets golden brown and the cheese melts.

name: Blokker
short_description: Move the blocks strategically until the balls find the targets. Simple yet challenging! This is Blokker.
reviews:
It's a nice, challenging game, worth playing to pass the time. Some levels were easy, others not so much.
I'd like to say I know exactly what I did, but I mostly solved them moving square by square and testing and getting angry when the angle was almost but not quite right.
Not my most calculating moves. [h3] Achievement Hunting Rating 5/5 [/h3] Solid puzzle game, just not my style. I will still give it the ol' thumbs up despite it not being for my taste in puzzle games because I can very well see it being loved by those that this IS their style. Very challenging but also worth playing, especially if its on sale
 Played on Steam Deck.

Short and sweet. The colors of the two cannons are way too similar not to have a colorblind mode, but for 59 cents I can let it slide. Would be nice to see a bit more polish in a few areas but overall a very nice single-sitting minimalist puzzle game. Mechanics are fine, but the game is not long enough. There are 25 levels which mostly just gradually increase in difficulty until they are really quite challenging. The game level design is fine however there is no ebb and flow to the difficulty like there should be, and the overall length is too short. There could/should be easier levels in between the peak difficulty ones as you progress to give you time to "breathe" between challenges, instead of "congrats, here's one even harder" each time. Great little puzzle game.  One of those where you spend ages thinking that there's no solution before it finally clicks.  Simple to understand and play and well worth it's low price.

It is only 24 levels so is quite short (took me an hour to complete but would take a casual gamer quite a bit longer I feel) but you can't fault that at it's price point.  Only real complaint I have is that the music auto-plays every time you start and doesn't remember if it was muted previously, but that's nowhere near a big enough issue to label it as a put-off in my opinion. Blokker can be a challenging puzzler. Round 14 took me several minutes to figure it out and I found it the hardest level. Took me about 80 minutes to complete the whole game and I enjoyed every second of it as I like being challenged.

The minimalist concept is a plus in this genre since unnecessary information can be distracting.

I definitely recommend it. Simple, minimalist and good game. Relax, config blocks and see the magic Blokker is an easy & enjoyable minimalist puzzler. Puzzles are basically about lasers and mirrors, but use less intuitive balls and walls instead.

I initially struggled with a few puzzles, but after coming back to the game a few weeks later, I blitzed through the remainder, so I suppose they weren't actually that hard and I just needed some distance from them. Also, puzzles aren't necessarily tight - in a few of the later puzzles, I always had at least 1 block left over. But I think I liked that.

Ultimately, this is a small puzzle game in which puzzles can be solved incrementally. That's good enough for me.

name: LET IT DIE -Special Pack-
short_description: Think your Tower of Barbs attack plan is flawless? This is a 1-time limited pack stuffed full with handy items to help you take on the Tower and return alive. 50 Death Metals 20,000 Kill Coins Tryptamine D: 1 (Use in the tower to return to the waiting room) Barbmeat Full Portion: 1 (Eat to recover full HP)
reviews: So... When are you going to lower the prices so I can buy more often?

name: Head To Hell ÈªÑÊ≥âÊóÖÂÆ¢
short_description: You wake up on a running train, everything is unfamiliar, except for a text giving you clues and guiding you to take steps. The answers might be found from every detail.
reviews:
I think this is a very interesting and frightening gameÔºåThe subtitle sound effects of the game are very scary
Looking forward to the next game Nice PT like game 
Little difficult to understand what the TEXT said, but still can play without the TEXT
btw how can I achieve Cool, Cooler, Coolest? This was one of the more confusing anomaly like games imo. Wasn't sure what to do after findin' some differences at times. All that bein' said, I still managed to finish the game. The atmosphere was fine and I found the floatin' Hell Company text to be welcomed amongst the creepy vibes. Solid for the price tag.

name: Falnarion Tactics
short_description: Falnarion Tactics is an SRPG that is reminiscent of classic Fire Emblem games. Take control of Felm and Momo as they separately lead the group of Shelminai into war alongside the allied kingdoms of Kessania and Inelda against the Garfarian Empire.
reviews:
If your into Fire Emblem and looking for something to play then this could possibly be the game for you as it wears it inspiration on its sleeve.
Falnarion tactics see us taking on the role of Felm and Momo who are leading a rebel force against your standard evil empire but there is secret about Felm and Momo which makes them a target as opposed to a nuisance this may lead to fighting against some darker.
Gameplay wise it a very typical tactics title and has all the features you would expect for something inspried by Fire Emblem. The main addition I enjoyed was how easy it was to bring up people to usuable no matter how late you get them in the game by being able to use one of the currencies as XP but as counter point to this due to the speed the story progress and sheer number of characters you get it can be difficult to decide on who to upgrade couple this with splitting the party and randomly removing people (I say randomly but it due to story reasons) it can very frustrating investing in a character to either not use them for a few mission or straight up never getting to use them again, this makes the side quest character very important as they are always with you.

Overall I found its little frustrating from losing characters to just how many people have something yet nothing to say and because of this you don't really get to know most of the characters properly. If you have a fire emblem sized whole to fill you get some enjoyment from this but beyond that I couldn't recommend it further This isn't a particularly good game, but I find it fun to speedrun at least. 

The game's sense of balance seems to be "let's throw huge waves of enemies at the player and have them go crazy." It can be fun, in a stupid way. This game is a blast to play, very addictive and definitely scratches that "one more round" itch. The story is interesting, the battles are thrilling + require tactics, and the level-ups and party management are in-depth. For the price this a wonderful little gem of a game. Strong recommend.      A very good fire emblem clone.  There will always be room for improvement, but it scratches that turn-based itch that is so hard to scratch these days with real time bullshot put out by the big companies.  I will be buying the other games in this series; both because they are fun and also to support this type of developer.  Thank you for some decent turn based games with soul. Its a decent game. If you like classic turn-based Strategy games like Fire Emblem or Advanced Wars then you will enjoy this. I recommend this title...with conditions. It has a strong Shinning Force vibe to it. The feeling of leveling your troops with limited resources makes it feel very well paced. The story is typical, basic "Good" rebels vs. "Evil" empire. It has been worth the cup of coffee it costs. With that said...
It isn't very original, like it was was made by a group of teens, with RPG maker. Maybe it was, I don't know anything about the devs. Also, I have a very modern computer. While this runs fine, it will just randomly glitch and freeze. This has happened about once every hour. Luckily, you can save often so its not much of an impeding factor. 
There is a "sidequest" menu where you play battles to get loot and companions. They also give you points for extra loot in the main campaign menu. I am not sure how needed it is to do, maybe you can ignore these and speed through the plot, I dont know. Maybe its to flush the game out.
I will end saying that I enjoy the battle mechanics, simple enough to hit the ground running, but each character has unique abilities. So each mission you want to look around before you start for a plan of attack. I will venture to finish the story. There are some "unlockables" on the main page. I have  seen a whole lot worse here on Steam, I would buy for a friend who is interested
 It's not the grandest or deepest tactics game but it's solid and I enjoyed it. In some ways, Falnarion Tactics feels like the most modern and fully-featured SRPG Studio game I've yet played, but its maps packed full of dozens upon dozens of enemies, often standing shoulder to shoulder, often opposing just as many NPC allies of yours, combined with a questionable story and very strange balance decisions, made it actually the least fun commercial one I've yet played.

On the bright side, it makes use of more SRPG Studio features than most, with a huge variety of equipment, two currencies, one of which can be used to buy levels for characters directly, a lot of side missions that you can do in between story missions, and a huge variety of playable characters. It's also by far the longest SRPG Studio game I've played, with Steam saying I spent 22 hours on it, and my final save file time being just under 15 hours. 

The story also ... well. It's another Team Syukino game, and you can really tell. A lot of very epic things happen, frequently with little buildup, so people will be joining your team and leaving constantly because they suddenly died, turned against you, or any other reason you can imagine. With only 11 or so actual story stages, the main story is just not long enough to make me care about most of the cast, either, so I pretty much just shrugged when anyone other than the main duo of Felm and Momo became unavailable, except if it was someone who had good stats. (This can also be a bit of a mechanical gripe, as well - you can invest a lot of stuff in characters who then become permanently unavailable. While some of it isn't so bad because you can just clean out their inventory when they're about to leave, bonus points and permanent boost items are lost forever.)

On the dim side, battles against dozens and dozens of enemies can be quite tedious, with a good handful of stages featuring over 100 enemies. Ones where you have dozens and dozens of allies on top of this change it up somewhat, but either you use the fast-forward feature and only get to see the aftermath of all the fighting, or you spend a lot of time watching characters not under your control hit each other. The game balance is also pretty bad, with some characters maxing out with frankly pathetic stats - Norma, for me, never even hit 15 in a single stat other than HP - while others will have 15 in their worst stat and the others mostly around 30. Thankfully, the abundance of revival items means that you can just throw everyone into the meat grinder and revive all the dead people, but the feeling that some characters are never going to contribute anything except taking a fall still remained.

Likewise, while there's a huge variety of weapons and other equipment available, the dev made the strange choice of limiting how many are ever available in the shop, so there end up being a limited number of good - or even tolerable - weapons throughout the entire game. In addition, durability is very low, with almost nothing have more than 20 uses, and many having as few as 10. (Healing staves are hilariously worse, with only 3 uses.) Given the length of the game and the sheer amount of enemies, this definitely contributed strongly to my frustrations with Falnarion Tactics, because I had to spend a lot of time managing people's inventories for the current deployment.

Ultimately, I don't recommend Falnarion Tactics simply because I had more frustration than fun playing through it. In some ways it's the best commercial SRPG Studio game I've played so far, but not in the crucial way of actually being a good game to play. It's fun and retro but not too stuck in the past. 

It really plays like fire emblem and Shinning Force. Love it Still very early in the game but I quite like it thus far, have never had the ability to play any Fire Emblem games but love watching/reading LP's of them so running across this had me very interested. Overall it seems to be a pretty faithful FE style of game, though it does have some annoying bits.

I think my biggest worry is the low durability on healing items, makes sense for the cure root but really wish the healing staffs had maybe 10 uses instead of 3. The weapons at least have good numbers of uses. I'm sure the healing issue alleviates some as the game progresses though and the heroes grow stronger (my Felm is already quite Tanky which is nice to see in the Lord character)

The UI is a bit awkward as well, took me a couple minutes of looking at the level up screen to be certain I understood which stats had leveled. Would be nice if moving things between characters and the convoy was a bit smoother too, can see that potentially getting even more time consuming as I gain more people.

Would be really good to have some graphical indication of which buildings on a map are visitable too, Can get a bit hectic trying to balance checking each building for an interaction option with keeping my formation intact.

All in all, while it could be a better game, yes, it works and it functions in all the ways I would expect from a FE style of game. Certainly looking forward to continuing to tackle the initial batch of side quests for more gear and people and then seeing what the next tidbit of story throws at me.

name: Cyber Control
short_description: Cyber Control is a 3D puzzle platformer game set in a dystopian future, where the player controls either Jones Murdock or Jenny Li, rebels who need to escape from the cyber-neural network of the Alphas, a class of superhumans that dominate society.
reviews: I'm glad I purchased this game on sale, so I didn't waste much money. This is an indie developed 2.5D side scrolling shooter with poor optimization. I was getting constant frame rate drops with an RTX3080 no matter what I selected in the graphic options, especially when the camera turned and enemies appeared. You also cannot access the options menu while playing and have to exit back to the main menu to access the options. There is also no manual save and checkpoints are sort of far away. The camera angle is also locked with some awkward auto-turning and bodies immediately disappear after killing enemies. The worst aspect however in my opinion is aiming with weapons. Aiming is extremely awkward and I was constantly getting killed because I could not aim to where it would hit the enemies. In fact, I consider the game basically unplayable due to how atrocious aiming is. Overall, the entire experience looks and feels like an amateur school project to me. I cannot recommend this game in it's current condition.

name: Darkness Within 2: The Dark Lineage
short_description: In "The Dark Lineage" you re-take the role of police detective Howard Loreid, a man tormented by the paranormal happenings around him. Howard discovers that his own terrible past has some connection to the madness that is about to swallow him, yet again.
reviews:
Its an alright horror game, but you almost need a magnifying glass to read the notes in this game Crashed I played this right after the first part which i like and it was a bit disappointing. Story sometimes feels like 
forcibly done because must do part 2 and are boring/not good and cliche.
Inventory etc. interface is very bad to use effectively and sound acting very poor. Game is very buggy too sometimes i fall outside of the game world and when Henry needs translate the book my character don`t mention anything that it needs to cipher even if it should have after i opened book and because of that i fear that game breaks but luckily loading save game couple of times and trying many many times i get it work. 
Some levels are boring and puzzles all not that good. Maybe 5/10 if you played first part and liked it and are curious how does the story progress from there i can recommended check out but this not very good game so little bit disappoint after first one and sometimes very boring. Well, this is a game.  I was expecting a sequel to the first one and I got...more of the first one cranked up.  The atmosphere is more, the controls are more, the puzzle difficulty is more.

I like this game.  While the first game tested my patience with the document system and clues in "order".  This game is more straight-forward and more BS.  Item interaction triggers can be a single pixel wide.  Acting required objects upon each other sometimes do not trigger resulting actions.  Logic has gone on holiday.  (I need to light up phosphorescent paint?  Cool!  Flashlights won't work but a camera flash will?  WTF?)

Over, this is a good sequel.  I liked the coherent story that you uncover and the cameo from the first game.

8 hours to finish carefully the first playthrough.  Another 2 hours for achievement hunting.

Overall rating:  7/10  (No shame for walkthroughs.) i really like the story of that game its just need a remaster.. Kept getting thrown off the map with no input whatsoever. As expected, the sequel to 'DW: In Pursuit Of Loath Nolder' is a Lovecraftian mystery adventure puzzler with horror elements. If you liked the first one, you will definitely like this one too, although there are differences and the original felt a tad superior overall. Basic difference is that this wasn't made in the classic point-and-click style, but instead you can roam around freely, which to me is a plus (but does cost a bit in terms of game performance).

[h3]PROS[/h3]
+++ Will definitely scratch the 'Painscreek Killings' itch, with a good amount of buildings to explore at your leisure
+++ You can save manually at any time and there are (literally) 100 available slots
+++ Multiple endings [spoiler] plus a secret non-ending (you will get it when you get there) [/spoiler]
+++ You can twitch the video, audio and gameplay settings to your liking
+++ Fast travel options for every available place (as long as you've been to said place at least once before)
+++ Same underlining mechanic as in the original, but more user-friendly
++ Has a pretty good atmosphere on its own, but a bit lacking if you (inevitably) compare it to the first game
++ The story is a direct link to the original and it comes to a conclusion. It is a bit whacky, but it's what you would expect considering what the previous game was about
++ Nice audio and sounds effects
++ Difficulty options and hint system available
+ Serviceable graphics
+ Passable use of physics

[h3]CONS[/h3]
- Puzzles are generally easier compared to the first game, but some are still pretty obscure and will most likely require a guide or a lot of your time
-- Interacting with items can be problematic at times. For example, smaller items aren‚Äôt always highlighted despite you having your cursor right on them
-- Too many clues just sit in your inventory, but very few of them are really useful and can actually be combined, which can be quite confusing
-- Too much dialogue at times, that -considering the already obscure sci-fi horror theme- can get tiring
-- The free walking around instead of the point-and-click style has its toll performance wise, fps drops are frequent especially in big open areas
-- Voice acting is pretty inferior to that of the first game (which I found excellent)
--- Pretty buggy - Make sure to save often and try not to go to places that you are obviously not supposed to go (or be prepared to no clip into oblivion, thus having to restart your game) - That said, if you stay on the obvious path you will be ok like 99% of the time

[h3]CONCLUSION[/h3]
Easy recommendation, especially for fans of the first DW game. Price-to-content ratio feels more than fair, as you will spend a good amount of your time roaming the available places, figuring out the puzzles and learning more and more of the story and lore as you go along. Despite being an old game (and it shows in various aspects), it‚Äôs still a more than decent mystery puzzler and imho a must for Lovecraft fans.
 A couple of strange game behaviors, but a walkthrough helped.  Otherwise, a very good 3-D, horror adventure puzzle game. Sadly i couldn't even make it out of the book store, super buggy and for a strange reason it would not save my progress so i had to start from the beginning. I tired 3 more times but same thing so i gave up. the story seem interesting tho, its a shame i cannot start or finish the game :(   Save your dollars and pass on this game. Story felt much easier to follow then the first, I also learned to slow down and really check everything for puzzles.

name: Cosmic Gunslinger: Alien Outlaws
short_description: Cosmic Gunslinger: Alien Outlaws is a pulse-pounding single-player video game where you, as the gunslinger cowboy Cosmo, and your trusty canine companion, must survive relentless waves of Aliens. Upgrade your weapons, collect crucial items. Can you outdraw and outlast the alien threat?

name: Koya Rift
short_description: In Koya Rift, the player must enter a hostile planet and destroy an alien race so the planet can be colonized. Each game, the player is dropped off at the surface and must venture into procedurally generated caves, earning upgrades and buying units as he goes along.
reviews:
-Way too easy, way too short.  I completed everything the game had to offer in 70 minutes.

-There wasn't any real challenge to it.


+Gun visuals are nice
+worse ways to spend 3 dollars and 1 hour, I suppose.
 I will flesh out this review over time. 

HOWEVER, PLEASE KEEP IN MIND: 

You get what you pay for.

This game is CHEAP for a reason...

PROS:
-Innovative Difficulty System. This was neat. I enjoyed watching my difficulty level go up as I played the game.
-Several weapon choices to choose from. This was also quite neat.
-Fresh spawns of enemies frequently. This keeps me busy.

CONS:
-This isn't flashy at all. This is simple, elementary gameplay.
-There is... Quite honestly... Only one type of enemy.
-The game is beaten extraordinarily fast. There is little to no replay value.
-Several things are NOT explained in the game. This is bad.
-The music you hear in the trailer? Yeah... That's not in the game.

Essentially, you are a... Human? With an arsenal of weaponry. You're trying to kill the Alien Race. This is nothing special. Nothing spectacular. There is no such thing as a "Story" in this game. Period.

The weaponry is basic and nearly everything is the same. It's nothing to gawk over. Different fire rates... Different power levels... But essentially the same weapon.

This game will be beaten once, then probably never played again, unless you thoroughly enjoy this type of game.

Overall.... 6-7/10, but ONLY for the price it is listed at. I can probably milk an hour, hour and half out of this game. I highly doubt I will get much more.

EDIT: This game is currently experiencing crashes. I'll update my review at a later time when these crashes are no longer persistent. Unfortunately, I will need to change my "Recommend" to a "Negative" Due to this aspect hindering gameplay. Beat it in 20 minutes. The "campaign" is about 10 levels. But you can't even do the campaign until you play "battle" mode a dozen times, which is the game's way of making sure you know the game before you take on the campaign. Not worth even on sale for $3.50. Maybe 0.99 cents it would be worth.
Koya Rift has a a bug where everytime you access the weapon color details page it crashes when you exit it.

The only thing that would extend this game would be to have more upgrades for your character and with that an endless survival mode. Other than that, the maps may be random but certainly not "procedurally generated" as the trailer boasts.
