name: The Hospital: Allison's Diary
short_description: "The Hospital: Allison's Diary" is a new horror virtual reality experience, putting the user alone in an abandoned hospital searching for the unknown with only the help of a single torch. You will face true fear in a way you had never thought possible.
reviews: The game is a little short and not really a game in the sense of having to figure out things. The game directs you towards where you need to go. Good usage of sounds/ music. Some cheap jumpscares, but also some really unexpected ones. Bought it in a package deal and was worth its money. for me this is first game got me scared love it It is a short experience and it could be actually good. There is a poor implementation of controls, view related only, which made me a bit motion sickened. However i could play through the game and beat it with no real issues on my Oculus Quest and am looking forward to play the next chapters. I got this whilst it was on a sale. I experienced all 3 from the trilogy. This one had a good atmosphere and probably was one of the scariest out of the three, however the third one also had a good atmosphere. Get it whilst it is on sale to support the people that made it, despite it is not the scariest of VR experiences, one of the less scary ones in my taste. Rise of Insanity in VR was much more scary at times and it is longer, for it is a game. Exorcist: Legion VR is what you want to experience to experience proper VR horror. I haven't yet, I am hoping for a sale, but if there is no sale, I will get the lot from Legion. As for this, I recommend it as an experience, put it in your wishlist and wait for the sell. A bit short. A bit rough around the edges, but it still has some moments I enjoyed. I wish you could move in the direction of the controller. Though using the thumb pad is always my preferred method of movement, the movement does not feel consistent, like it's not always moving at the same rate, and it would be nice if using the trigger while walking, sped things up a bit. Overall a bit weak, but still creepy fun. This game is short but i really enjoyed it. sure its wonky. I was never a big fan of horror games up until I bought my Vive. I got a bunch of horror games because there just wasn't that many VR things to experience. WOW! did I get sucked in to horror games and experiences. Sure most of them are super short. If I can make it through with no crashes I'm willing to overlook alot. This game is short but it scared me a few times. It's really creepy. Price is high at 6 bucks for 20 minutes or so but I feel like I got my money's worth. Sure it's not long & the graphics aren't eye popping & also the controls are a little weird but I really enjoyed myself. Just keep expectations low & you might be surprised at this one. I've definitely seen a lot worse. LOL, I know it isn't the best recommendation but it scared me, its creepy and game didnt crash & its only 6 bucks Pretty bad game. I thought the pictures looked good, so I decided to ignore the reviews and buy the game. The graphics are bad, movement is bad, gameplay is bad. It's a bunch of jump scares as you walk through a VERY guided path. Really not fun at all. One of the best Vr Horror experience i had until now ...Amazing game ..... It had a few unique jumpscares which I enjoyed...but it's over in 19mns. I enjoy seeing what people come up with in this new vr era. Horror is a big draw for developers because  if done right it can be  really scary like no way before.  This is short but I found it to be really heart stopping at times.  Nothing special but worth the cheap price.  I used a gamepad with Oculus and had no issues.  Be sure to look everywhere .  Events get triggered, so if your stopped in your tracks by the game look around.  2 Newer games in the series I'll be playing.

name: Islets
short_description: Take to the sky and reunite a fragmented world in this surprisingly wholesome metroidvania! Help Iko adventure across beautiful hand-painted islands, receive letters from a quirky cast of characters, and face powerful monstrous adversaries.
reviews:
I absolutely love this game, super fun platforming with a cute story and combat that's satisfying without feeling too repetitive or frustrating. 10/10! short, simple and satisfying Last year I played Crypt Custodian (another game by Kyle Thompson), and thought it was an enjoyable if basic adventure. After playing Islets, I can sense a running theme. Islets ticks a lot of the boxes most good Metroidvanias should have. Solid progression, fast movement, lots of fun boss fights, and a big world to wander about in. It's a very solid and well made Metroidvania that fans of the genre will sink right into.

However, I feel Islets lacks... anything more really. The characters and world are not especially interesting, and most of the unique mechanics this game does explore are not developed enough to see their full potential. It almost feels as though the game is afraid to get a little weird and clunky. I think there are glimmers of genius here and there, but never anything more. Again, I still had a fun time with Islets. It's a good game and probably worth your time, but I wouldn't go into the game expecting it to shake up what a game like this can be. I finished Islets! What a great game. It's a fun, fairly chill metroidvania that gives me big Hollow Knight vibes - but much easier. It's lacking a final coat of polish, and you can kinda tell that it's from one dev, but don't let that take away from the accomplishment. I fully believe it's worth playing, especially if you get it on sale for $13. It's cute, the writing is fun, the mechanics are solid, everything moves quickly enough to keep your interest, it encourages exploration while staying somewhat linear and without requiring needless backtracking, I had a great time playing it. I got 42/44 achievements in 14.4h, this includes beating the boss rush mode once.

Now my biggest gripe. Maybe this is just me, but seeing it sitting at 42/44 achievements grinds my gears. The last two achievements are for beating the boss rush on hard, and beating it without dying. Which is cool and all, but boss rush takes away all your powerups and doles them out on a boss by boss basis - so you know all those abilities you gained and moves you learned? You gotta start without them. So the boss rush is even harder than when playing them in game. On the other hand, you get unlimited lives/retries, but it just feels like a slogfest more than a fun post-game mode. It took me over an hour to complete the boss rush on normal. Sure, I'd do better next time, and I won't pretend to be the world's greatest gamer, I really don't want to do it again on hard. I've heard you can savescum the "no death" run but that sounds even more tedious. Ugh.

But, well, that's my biggest complaint. Getting the last two achievements in a post-game mode. The actual game is great. If you're looking for a relatively short, cute, chill metroidvania I strongly recommend it, and I'm really looking forward to playing the devs newer games! Very fun little metriodvania. Some new features and was not too difficult. played it through in 12 hours. I definatly got my moneys worth. Great metroidvania, some abilities are really unusual. Character is swift, and feel nice to control. Bosses are fun, and mystically took me roughly 15 attempts each (on hard), which is exactly the right amount for me: you need to git gut, but no need to start throwing things in frustration. I loved it. 
The boss rush mode is cruel, since it doesn't use the same build you made while playing, I really wanted to annihilate earlier bosses with my mighty late game Iko) i am worlds #1 GreyBird fan of all time Doesn't do anything new and exciting but what's there is polished and lots of fun. simple but so much fun
 This is a cozy metroidvania which is similar to Yoku's Island and Guacamelee 1+2. Islet stands out from its peers by being very chill and laid-back, and its humor is also what makes it stand out (and very chill music). Just remember, if you are a metroidvania fan, don't expect to be longer than average metroidvania length, which usually ranges from 10 - 20 hours. That being said, it is an easy and quality game I recommend it to players both new or familiar with the genre.

name: Z`code (VR for HTC Vive)
short_description: "Z'code is a First-Person Mech Fighting game in VR. Players will simulate driving armor in the fight on Earth."
reviews:
I HATE TO DO IT BUT DONT GET IT YET, IT HAS THE POTENTIAL TO BE GREAT, BUT AS IS IT MADE ME VOMIT, NO JOKE LITERALLY UPCHUCKED AFTER PLAYING THIS GAME, I DONT USUALLY HAVE ISSUES WITH IT AS I HAVE STRONG VR LEGS. BUT THIS ONE NEEDS TO BOB FROM SIDE TO SIDE AS IT STEPS AND HEAR LOUD FOOT STEPS. IT GLIDES RIGHT NOW AND THATS WHAT MADE ME SICK I wanted a mech game so I decided to try this game. With no reviews other than just negative votes, I felt I would step in for a text review. The review will be broken up into sections with "----".

----
You aim with your head and the controls seem standard enough. 
Left Controller
1) Trackpad : Movement
2) Trigger : Weapon Switch
Right Controller
1) Trackpad : Boost
2) Trigger : Fire Weapons

Movement is not teleporting as you're in a mech. Standard left controller trackpad movement is sliding at a steady speed. It is done by holding your thumb over the direction you wish to go, so there is no need to hold the trackpad down. I am a victim of motion sickness in some games with sliding movement, but not in this. I actually like the movement in Z'Code. Movement isn't to fast or slow so it works great. However, boosting might throw you for a loop with no trackpad experience,

----
Graphics are fair and I didn't have to many game performance issues. I did however notice a small dip in FPS in two areas of the game on a GTX 970. None of which were game breaking

----
Game Modes
1) Easy
2) Medium
3) Hard

I have only played easy & for whatever reason after finishing it, neither medium or hard unlocked. What's worse is you top it off with a language barrier for some people. If you can't read Mandarin Chinese you are out of luck. When you click on a locked game mode there is no English explanation.

----
AI isn't wonderful. I can slightly excuse this, but it needs to be pointed out. Once in the tracked distance of the AI they'll just open fire in a sort of straight path. Shots are very easy to avoid. This could be different in higher game modes, but as explained above I couldn't play higher than Easy.

-----
Game dialogue isn't voice acted. While playing a lady starts talking in large boxes of text in the bottom left corner of your cockpit. These mission messages disappear very quickly. Unless you are a speed reader and/or can keep the Vive in that sweat spot to read text you'll be missing a majority of what is said.

----
Weapons

Standard Weapons: 
1) Chain Guns/Rail Guns/Machine Guns : Take you pick in name. It's just a quick shooting gun.
2) Blaster/Energy Gun : A single round ball comes out both guns on your mech.

Power Up
1) Missles : Once you get enough energy these take over your standard weapon. You have little control over them as they simi-seek out enemies.

Special Weapons (This is the ones I remember and/or only got to see in "Easy". These are dropped randomly on enemy kills).
1) Power Blaster : Stronger than the normal standard blaster. Yet limited in ammo & honestly not to great.
2) Power Chain Gun: Again better than the standard one. Better amount of ammo than the Blaster, but some what effective.
3) Lasers : These seem very over powered. You shoot two beams out your mech to mow down a number of enemies like it was nothing. In fact, the final boss in this game can be destroyed with them. I happened to pick lasers up after one of the swarm of enemies before the final boss. I killed the boss in a matter of seconds with lasers. It made it literally no challenge at all.

----
Game Length is very short on Easy. I can't comment on medium or hard as stated before it wouldn't unlock. I finished this game in around 0.3hrs Steam time, or in other words about 18 minutes. For how short this game is & the slight issues I can't recommend this game for that alone.

----
Achievements seem to be broken. It's no biggy to myself, but it seems the old chivo's are broken, so achievement grinders want be happy.

name: Pajama Sam 3: You Are What You Eat From Your Head To Your Feet
short_description: Pajama Sam chases down some snickering cookies, only to find himself in the midst of a food squabble!
reviews:
I used to eat bugs for money in high school does that mean I am bugs??? Had this on PS1 os a kid. Randomly seen a video of a fella ragging on games, this one included, and then MEMORY UNLOCKED. Finally knowing the name, I found this and did what I couldn't at 3. Like beating it. What I like? It is untouched from what I can tell. Seems like a game stuck in the mid 90s. What I don't like? Man, I must've been a dumb kid to not figure this out... Kinda checks out for how the last 25 years or so have gone... 10/10 for the time capsule/nostalgia kick. ¬´Pajama Sam 3¬ª ‚Äî is the third installment in the beloved children's adventure game series by ¬´Humongous Entertainment¬ª, but unfortunately, it feels weaker compared to its predecessors.

Story and Atmosphere:
This time, Sam finds himself in a world of sentient food, where a conflict is brewing between different groups of edible characters. His mission is to help organize a peaceful conference.
In this world, food is self-aware, talks, and interacts, yet casually discusses its own fate in the food chain. The storyline feels mediocre, as if it was pulled out of thin air.

Gameplay and Puzzles:
The gameplay stays true to the series‚Äô traditions‚Äîexploring locations, collecting items, and using them in the right places. However, the puzzles seem simpler and less inventive than before.

Conclusion:
¬´Pajama Sam 3¬ª ‚Äî feels less well-thought-out and engaging than the previous games in the series. amazing game, literally no complaints, very fun and chill I remember playing the demo as a kid. The CD was from a cereal box. Good times. Game still holds up, good for kids. This game is good for a younger audience. I grew up playing the collection now I get to experience these games again with my own children, 10/10 wish they made Kids games like this again. BABAGA-BOOSH! Pajama chad this game remind me of my child hood so i desied to play this on my youtube channle https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D-uxdA_oomw&t=2s my favorite childhood game. I love playing it!

name: Ambre Bonus Booklet
short_description: A 30 page bonus booklet in PDF format that resolves all the mysteries behind "Ambre - a heartbreaking kinetic novel".
reviews:
I didn't expect it to be so deep and thought-provoking, but lo and behold, it sure is an eye opener. Especially since I let my re-read sink in for quite a few months by now. It even gave me new perspective on media consumption, how creators view their works, how they don't, and how it can all just be in our hands sometimes. I'll remember it for a long time to come.
Good stuff. I'm not holding out on a sequel happening at this point but the proposed ideas were awesome, I'd read that if it came to fruition Ambre Bonus Booklet, is very good as it delves deep into the inspiration and creation ofthe game and I liked how some of the theories I had about the game‚Äôs inspiration I talked about in my review were confirmed. Also I liked there are hints of a possible sequel which I really hope is made someday. While this booklet isn't free like the soundtrack I do recommend getting it, as it gives good insight into the game and it also supports the creator.

name: Primordium - Day Zero
short_description: Fight for survival in a sci-fi RPG! Take control of the Nexus' Commander and gather companions to grow your team, build bases using a vast array of AAA quality models, and customize your arsenal using countless combinations of modular attachments, items, armor, and weapons!
reviews: THIS GAME IS EXTREMELY BUGGED! even the tutorial is bugged! game kept loading and never completed loading, it would hit either 5% or 11% and start loading again after completing the tutorial when trying to use sandbox {regular} game mode. I will continue to try to play this game but just like a car if its giving problems when you first get it then expect the worst untill its fixed!

name: CRONEWORLD RPG ADVENTURE - 1
short_description: CRONEWORLD is a fantasy-story telling rpg indie game. It is a game about humans fighting wizards with flying robot 'CRONES'. It's world has Eastern culture, Western culture, science fiction and magics.
reviews:
This game is a sin against god. [h1]TL;DR:[/h1] There's seemingly a fairly appealing JRPG (this one is Korean, btw) beneath all the weird presentation peculiarities - like the cumbersome interface design and the unorthodox way the game runs and plays from a tech standpoint. Definitely not for everyone. Suggested for the technically inclined and geekily adventurous gamer, perhaps of the older crowd, who would not be averse to enduring some technical hurdles and the uncoordinated confusion (gameplay-wise) that is at least the initial part of the game as the player is getting up to speed with game mechanics.

[h1]In more detail:[/h1] Is it a bird? Is it a plane? Nah... Looks like a port. Or is it? The game plays by launching an HTML file in a self-contained browser. You can't get rid of the address bar even in Full Screen (F4). If you're after the episode intro [url=www.youtube.com/watch?v=rPvFM2Zqi0U]FMVs[/url], the game outsources to your regular browser and directs you to a YouTube video (that's some serious indie right there). The whole game is perhaps a big old Flash object or something? I wasn't in the mood to investigate, though, especially after exiting the application after which it covertly remained running, leaving no process behind to manually terminate. A good thing I caught on early - had to resort to restarting Steam, and it then turned out the game'd been racking up playtime while being in this limbo state.

The game itself is your standard lighthearted techno fantasy about some bad blood happening between wizards (humans with elf ears) and regular humans, with locations boasting a potpourri of architecture styles from medieval to early industrial and beyond - that doesn't mean gigantic airborne aircraf... I mean, CRONE carriers are out of the question, though. There's magic (or maybe just sufficiently advanced technology). Almost everyone owns an exosuit called a "crone" - unlike the hulking behemoths of BattleTech, these are of the smaller variety, a few meters tall, like a Heavy Gear from a less known Activision franchise. The crones don't look gritty and menacing - on the contrary, most are cute & colorful, like Pokemon. The pilots appear to be mostly the requisite teens and junior high students. There are supernatural flying talking tigers and dragons. A sinister rampant AI (or a collective thereof) is scheming, bent on eradicating humans. I wish I could enjoy the story further... Technical and gameplay design issues beset the gameplay as well - there is some minimal tutorial in the beginning, but certain things just happen too fast without explanation. E.g., in the first location, some giant monsters attack the town and there are alerts flashing up top that you're supposed to react to, yet the game seems to be running a lot faster than intended, an issue that some very old games sometimes exhibited when running on newer computers and operating systems. Some fights you initially get into, a few crone sparring matches, are over in a couple seconds, with battle stats or what's happening almost beyond perception - you are only apprised of the result when the fight is over. Oh, and there's an in-game clock, with one in-game hour clocking in around 20 real seconds or so. Some tasks later on are therefore likely to be timed - e.g. in one of the first few quests you're supposed to pick up a delivery after some specified hour. This instills a sense of urgency that's compounded by the fact that the animations are faster than originally designed. A player new to the game can't help but feel rushed, yet there is little direction or explanation.

Btw, a funny thing... The word "crone" being thrown around so much is unintenionally risible to the Western sensibilities - it almost begins to sound like homely irate old ladies are the centerpiece of this story.

[h1]My take:[/h1] I wouldn't mind tinkering with a technically challenging piece of work like this back in the day, but as it stands now, being somewhat strained for time, I'm opting to pass on this one. However, there seems to be a compelling story and a curious RPG system (the Crones even have various emotion levels) beneath the hood - if only all of it were more accessible to the casual gamer... Still voting up, I like the aesthetics of this Crone World and the story is alright, insofar as I could pick up from the in-game intro and the accompanying FMVs on YouTube.

name: PAYDAY 3: Syntax Error Heist
short_description: The Payday Gang tackles a heist on tech giant Scry Digital, an industry leader in AI technology.
reviews:
Idk why are people hating on this dlc. It is great and fun. You should buy this dlc in my opinion. Ofc houston breakout is better but it is still good its aight You spend time & do entire heist without seen carry all the bags just outside to get seen by all of those civs again so that you carry all bags down again to explode some wall to outside again for helli is quite bad design in my opinion,
Entire game is about heist, not carrying bags thru entire map.PD2 had same issues in some maps but this is not Payday2
I expected some changes in this direction but some things are kept same this is not nostalgic... it's just pain in the arse.

Out of 4 payed expension this is the only lame one even there is new enemy type etc. Replayibility of the map is all the worst everything is on the same place. I would say only buy this one with year expension or if its %50 off discount. Payday 3 is objectively worse than Payday 2. I will change my review when Payday 3 is at least as good as Payday 2.

If you care about Payday 3, then force Starbreeze to make it better by leaving a negative review to impact their sales.

Payday 3's issues since Day 1:

Barely any heists
- We have only 16 (10 at launch) short heists with little replayability
- Very little RNG elements in heists, especially non-dlc heists
- Why can't we have Payday 2 level variety on how to complete heists (multiple escapes/breaches)?
- Payday 2 has over 70 heists

No Multiday Heists
- Payday 3 should have been released with at least 30 heists, 10 being multi-day

Most heists are short
- I can solo most in under 12 mins on the hardest difficulty easily

Live Service only
- Even Solo mode requires a ping before and after the game, often failing
- Matchmaking was terrible, became bad and is terrible again now with crimenet
- Want to host a lobby? Get ready to wait several minutes...
- random disconnections, single lost network packet can disconnect you
- 150ms lag feels like 600ms lag in any normal game
- 5 min heist loading
- UI freezes when loading, sometimes infinite
- long loading if 1 player has bad internet
- Sometimes instant disconnection after joining a lobby
- Still have the can't ready up bug sometimes

Obvious game breaking bugs take forever to fix:
- Cook off has had crashing issues since launch
- Cook off escape van IS STILL BROKEN since 9 months ago (maybe fixed today)
- Diamond District stuck door
- Invisible enemies
- Countless stuck objectives
- UE4 is a decade old and very stable, bad Starbreeze code crashing game
- It feels like little to no QA is done before releasing and update
- Forget PD2 hotfixes, never had any

No heists with large maps
- At least a 5/30 should be large maps

Few interesting heists
- No real creativity for the jobs the gang does
- Execution (ie drilling/hacking) is also pretty boring
- Why are there still wifi circles after a whole year???

No Preplanning
- Can only order basic assets without placing them

Many missing PD2 mechanics like driving

AI teammates are stupid
- Cannot be instructed to wait and don't help with objectives
- Sometimes don't even revive you if you are downed
- Often broken/stuck (Fear & Greed)
- Cannot have their loadouts, weapons or skills changed

Enemies are bland
- Crowds of bullet sponge swat that do little damage to players
- Only new special is the Nader (who was broken for most of this year)
- Tasers are now called Zappers and are barely a threat
- Only one variant of Bulldozer with an auto-shotgun
- Bulldozers can only target a single player and are slow to retarget

Cloakers are too buggy
- Attack through walls/corners
- Always target players even if you're the last one
- Can't be heard that well (were silent most of this year)
- Can only be stopped by a one shot kill when they close charge you
- Spawn from the same closest location every wave end so are easy to expect

Heisters to play as are lacking
- Only 7 playable heisters, PD2 has 22
- Voicelines are bland and few
- Barely any situational voicelines and no banter between heisters

Skills are super bland and boring
- No drill skills, Inspire, Joker, Pistol Messiah or any interesting skills for that matter
- I personally hate the new Armor plate economy, PD2 armor was perfect
- No perk decks to make cool builds
- No infamy system/rewards
- Too easy to become 150, other players' renown levels hidden
- Edge, Grit, Rush effects are an unnoticeable 10%

Music is acceptable but worse than PD2
- Only dlc heists have good music + Diamond District
- No ability to change heists' music
- No access to PD2/PDTH soundtrack

The UI is still bad
- No number stats of weapons in UI, have to look these up online
- Can't move guns around/sell preset guns
- Weapons have same inventory icon regardless of which mods/skins are on it
- Way too many large buttons/text which lead to unnecessary sub-pages and submenus
- Can't manage party/other players directly from main menu/esc screen
- No value of items shown when grabbed/secured
- Separate control for marking than interacting unlike PD2
- Kicked to main menu after heist (can opt-in and wait 60s to form party which nobody does)

Few weapons
- No melee weapons at all
- No saw
- Very few guns and the meta ones are all DLC
- Same high fire rate and one shot kill weapons used for Overkill
- No weapon lasers nor flashlights
- Weapon sights cannot have the reticle changed at all
- Secondary weapons all crazy suck except for DLC ones since Houston Breakout
- No exciting weapons like Flamethrower, RPG or medieval weapons
- Since day 1 we've begged to get rid of the OVK weapon system
- No weapon skins that allow you to freely change mods

Few Throwables
- Grenade barely does any damage
- No cool throwables except the shock grenade
- Only get 2 knives which break when hitting a wall

Few achievements:
- Despite the little content, there should still be more achievements

Equipment sucks
- Ecms are now useless, except disabling one camera you can reach
- Infrasonic mines that you manually detonate to temporarily stun instead of tripmines
- No c4
- Sentries are now a deployable so nobody uses them over Armor Bags

Few masks
- Most masks are overdone and feel too ridiculous to ever wear
- Very few patterns to choose from
- Preset masks cannot be customized
- No interesting materials

No Deathwish
- Overkill is way too easy, never had to first play other difficulties
- FBI van is stupid easy

Modifiers can't be changed
- For the last few months, almost every heist has the 2 specials and blinding shield modifiers
- I would like to enable all of them for more pay, they can't be changed

Pros over PD2 (this is why I would accept at least 30 heists vs PD2's 70 at launch)
+ Graphics gorgeous compared to PD2 but very unoptimized (ppl with 4080s are getting lag spikes)
+ Mask off stealth has more depth but now stealthing is way too easy
+ More heists with code locks which are cool to guess
+ Hostage system is better
+ Final Wave mechanic to make securing all loot harder
+ Fixed Naders are a cool threat
+ Bulldozers can melee kick and charge players
+ Cool animations when doing most interactions
+ Microcams/motion sensors useful and pretty cool
+ Shields have window to take them out through ok who tf designed this heist
its badly designed and i cant even complete it
heist music is good tho Now that the price has been reduced, I can recommend it, the heist is nicely designed, even if personally I do not appreciate the loud escape.
Grab it on sale, or via the Year 1 edition. I picked the wrong year to stop sniffing glue‚Äîat least that brought me some joy. Payday 3? Not so much. What should‚Äôve been a thrilling, action-packed heist experience turned out to be more of a test of patience and willpower. Instead of pulling off the perfect robbery, I was left trying to figure out how to escape the clutches of bad design, unresponsive mechanics, and the kind of bugs that make you question whether the game was even fucking playtested.   

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In the end, Payday 3 feels like a crime scene itself‚Äîfull of near endless potential, but wrecked by execution. It‚Äôs frustrating because you can see the foundation of a fun, high-octane multiplayer experience, but it's buried under all these technical issues and design missteps. I get it, the life of a criminal is supposed to be unpredictable along with hardships, but this isn't the kind of ‚Äúwild ride‚Äù I had in mind.

Maybe if I‚Äôd never quit the glue, I would‚Äôve had more fun. As it stands, though, it‚Äôs a hard pass from me. Do Better. Payday has never been for the faint of heart, but I cannot even believe the %90 of people leaving a review left a negative one because they don't know how to beat it.  Very cool heist. Very worth it. Only remorse is not having every one of them yet. I need to tip this scale a little. Pretty good heist imo. Only problem is if you play stealth solo this, you have to be EXTRA cautious in escape. Because a stu*id developer thought that it is a good idea to adding the escape van to the across the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• street. But it is a skill issue :) The heist is itself is fun in loud and comes with a great soundtrack. I have no clue as to why others complain about having to move around bags, it makes me wonder if they've ever played the predecessor in that case

name: Super BOO Quest
short_description: Super BOO Quest is a lighthearted game suitale for every kind of player, from casual to hardcore. It is a mix of arcade, puzzle, and stealth, to be played alone or with a friend. The game is presented with 16 bit-style graphics, as a tribute to Super Nintendo.
reviews:
TOO SLOW and clunky, literally bored while playing it on 4x speed. I have autism Fun little arcade style game combining a Pacman with puzzles. Lovely pixel art, solid music with a smidgen of humor. A single character playthrough takes maybe an hour and the game changes with different characters but it's fun enough to replay anyways. That being said there is a 2 player mode and an additional master mode for a bit more replay value. Nothing special but exactly what I need on a slow Sunday afternoon. [i] My Experience [/i]

There really isn't a ton to say about [b]Super BOO Quest[/b]. It's a top-down, arcade-style game about dodging humans while building up the spectral energy to haunt these cursed locations. I appreciated the Super Nintendo-style graphics and music, as the SNES was the first gaming console I owned growing up.

However, the game is kind of exacting, and you'll likely have many failures and near-misses as you proceed through these locations. I also found it difficult to figure out exactly how large my "fright zone" was (you have the ability to frighten humans in a small area around yourself). The game mentions that you can figure this out by paying attention to a "violet ray," but this wasn't particularly helpful. 

I can recommend Super BOO Quest, but although I played it in co-op, I might recommend playing it single-player. With the game requiring the precision that it does, another player is more often simply a liability. Another game that I bought solely because it was played on LGIO. It's fun to play through a couple of time, but if you're a completionist, it get's repetitive - there are 5 unique characters to play with, though the levels remain the same. As a game where you collect orbs to generate spooky power to scare your enemies, and plenty of puzzles to overcome, this game is really great! There are a good amount of character selection with varying difficulty levels. The levels you are taken through each have their own era and theme, which keep progression fresh. I originally played this game for my Frightober series on Youtube because of the 16 bit feature, because my computer can't record more graphically powerful games. This game is a delight to play on those computers who can't play games like minecraft without lag. Its super fun, quick if need be, and challenging enough to make you think. Each themed level takes about 20 minutes, and is perfect for those who want to play a little at a time.

For a visual of how the game plays of the first level, my first video is 

https://youtu.be/_ZagSxJdtNg

For a playlist of my whole playthrough, that link is [url=https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL_c9AXFI9rSGYONzj27f3NkukncXLqhjZ] here [/url] A cute little puzzle-arcade game that is very simple yet charming and fun. It is not without faults, but there is so much to love in this authentic indie game, that players can forgive some of the gameplay ingenuities, or some sporadic inaccuracies of the control system (it's mostly the collisions against the walls that can be annoying at times).
It is especially enjoyable with the local multiplayer, like most of SEEP games.
At this price, if you are a fun of retro games, it is really a no-brainer... it will definitely give you some hours of honest, carefree fun. Very simple arcade-puzzle action where you have to get enough energy pellets to fill your "boo meter" in order to scare humans.  It feels less like an SNES game and more like one of those weirdo 90s arcade games that you've never heard of but you accidentally find and have a fun afternoon with. 

Surprisingly fun.  It's nothing amazing or something you should go out of your way to play but if you've got $2 to spare, it's worth a shot.  It's short but never boring! Pretty funny game with a various contents to unlock (characters, endings and other sfuff).
The gameplay is fine, graphics nice and sound mediocre (but the voice was very good).
So I think is a good game for kids and who love happy-go-lucky games in 16 bit pixel art.

vote: 7.5 [h1]Video (gameplay + commentary):[/h1] https://youtu.be/oyXUNumWNFo

[h1]Summary:[/h1]
A puzzle game that anyone of any age can enjoy. Considering how many jump scare horror and Halloween games there are out there, it was pretty refreshing to play something with a more relaxing pace. From what we played, the puzzles ramp up their difficulty logically, the retro graphics are nice, and the music is charming. A lot of variety to be had for just a few bucks.

name: RPGScenery
short_description: In the RPGScenery application, you can move around stunning live scenes explicitly created for TTRPG, change their weather in real-time, and switch to battlemap mode with one click.
reviews:
I open this up once in a while to see if I am wrong. But I can still not find any use for it. Very pretty though, but I can't see what use I would have of it.

 Cheaper than Roll20 assets. Looks amazing. Pretty expensive to have a library of scenes, but I like the versatility of scenes: you can change weather, time of the day, season, pan, rotate, change perspectives, change grids, and every scene is a number of maps. 
I often use these maps when my dnd party is travelling Just picked this up.  I really like the tokens and would like to have more of them- but even still- for me this is a great app.  I'm basically using it as a screen saver- and I love it for that- great for setting the ambiance.  And it's so nice- turn the dial to make the sun set and the campfire comes on.  Turn on the snow and the trees drop their leaves.  It makes setting a scene sooooo easy.  I can get what I want in about 5 seconds.  And for me- I think the DLCs are at a great price- I've bought about 2/3rd of them and am very happy with what I got for $2.00 each- kudos to the scene builders.  This one's a winner for me.

Edited addition- something else I really enjoy about this program that went beyond my expectations was the sound scapes that go with the scenes.  For me- this really adds a lot. -ITs amazing, but it will be nice to add some Tokens or at least images of the players... just with some Images it will be nice. Its nice, but most of the DLC is exotic locales and cant be used for any scenes in my world or any other world. The dev should be concentrating on more generic scenes. like a castle with simple interior. I cant use a war elephant, and if I did, it would see a one time use. The scenes of the dark castle have no interior? The ship has another ship beside it...cant use that. just wanted a single ship on the ocean. When I think of scenery, I think of a good location  for role playing, not combat. A tavern, a sitting room, a library, a bedroom, a living room, the captains quarters, a throne room, etc... DLCs are way too small for their price. refunded after realising i couldn't make my own map. This product has been a disappointment.  

The maps are pretty, have good animation, and good customization with light and some weather effects.  That's it for the Pros.  

The Cons are many.  
The maps are way too expensive for the use I get out of them.  I'm sure it took time for them and they deserve to be paid for it but they are asking too much.  
Take the farm countryside scene.  Due to the limitations of how far you can zoom, I can't get the full yard in one map, much less the farm house, yard, barn, field, and windmill all in one battle map.  This has no way to stitch scenes together to create it, so I have to find a way to do that myself.  
The Mine map can't fit the full map on one either, so again, I need something else to make it useful.  
The Crypt is small, still doesn't fit on one map, and would take an adventuring group about fifteen minutes to finish.  Not enough there.
The Camp is useless as a battle map.  It could create some nice 3D scenes to show players but as soon as you go to the only top down view allowed to create a map, everything is hidden by trees.  Sure, makes sense, but then it looks like a forest, not a camp!  
Pretty much repeat that for the rest of the maps.  They look nice and might get some nice 3D views of them but you can't put even the smallest of them onto a full map to export to use for a VTT.  

On top of that, it's dead.  No updates in six months, no communication.  I can't recommend. I bought this with the intention and hope of updates to allow more customization options... it's been months with no update after it came out and all the DLC is priced super high with just different scenes. Dead in the water. Do not buy. 

I'll change this review if anything actually changes.

name: Ikao The Lost Souls
short_description: Ikao, a little bluish creature, suddenly finds himself in the abyss of time without any memory. After coming out he has no choice but to travel the world in search of answers to the mystery behind his past.
reviews:
I give the game a cautious endorsement, but beware of an issue with this game regarding refresh rates. Set the refresh rate of your monitor to 60 Hz, or you will have a bad time. The characters movement speed is chained to the refresh rate. The higher the refresh rate of your monitor, the faster they will move. At 144Hz, the game isn't playable. First off, the game wouldn't let me tab out at all, which I consider kind of necessary. Like a lot of small games, there's no options menu and trying to set windowed from Windows and Steam launch options doesn't work. I had to use DXWnd to force it to a window. Works okay once you set up all the options, but it looks like that prevents Steam from tracking in-game time.

There are some other smaller issues, but I still enjoyed the game. This is one of the few games where I didn't hate the [url=https://i.imgur.com/7jf8p7R.jpg]Helicopter[/url]-style controls. It feels like you have way more finesse than you usually do. Those sections are hard, but at least it's [b]not[/b] because the controls are awful.

The platforming parts are pretty fun too, I liked the moveset. And the aesthetic is great! It's a good platform game, it looks like a lot of fun. I have somewhat mixed feelings about [b]Ikao, The Lost Souls[/b]. On the one hand, the game is a challenging platformer and I mostly had a great time with it. But the game is far from perfect. In is my opinion, the main issues are:
[list]
[*]The core game mechanics feel unpolished and would benefit from some tweaking. You play as two characters, each with a different skill set. The two-tailed fox can walk, jump, double-jump, and teleport (I did not particularly like playing as the fox). The ghost can walk, jump and fly (playing as the ghost is a lot of fun). These are basic skills you will encounter in many platformers. What I disliked was that the jumps of both characters (but especially the ghost) are always of the same height, there is no ‚Äòshort jump‚Äô or something similar. This prevents you from jumping in a lot of places because you would instantly die on the spikes above.
[*]The double-jump is not very responsive, if you try to double-jump too quickly after the initial jump the fox will not respond at all to your input.
[*]The fox will insist on completing his jump-animation (a roll) first before doing the double-jump, so the fox hovers in mid-air for a split second. This prevents you from doing some tight and speedy platforming around flying enemies, you always need to keep a large margin otherwise you will most probably collide and die.
[*]The hit boxes around certain hazards are a bit too large. All these issues make for a lot of cheap deaths.
[*]There are 95 proper levels plus and ending. You need to complete each level before the next level is unlocked. The game get progressively more difficult, which obviously is good thing. However, some levels are way more difficult than others. I found the levels 75 to 85 to be much more difficult than the final 10. I am almost certain that many players will get stuck halfway through the game without any possibility to tune down the difficulty, or skip a level. To be attractive to players of all skill levels, it would have preferable if for instance not all levels need to be completed one at a time to progress through the game ‚Äì it is often better to take the tried and tested approach where for instance there are secondary (but very difficult) objectives in each level, so skilled players are properly challenged but if you find the level too difficult you can just skip the secondary objective for the moment, go on with the next levels and return to the difficult level when you finally got gut.
[*]The story is a bit weird and after seeing the ending twice I still do not completely understand. 
[*]There are a few other issues, but these are only minor. I did not particularly like the art style, nor the music, but that is totally subjective. Another thing is that you can‚Äôt alt-tab out of the game, better not try that or you risk crashing your PC. The game also messes with high-DPI settings for 4K screens.
[/list]

I don‚Äôt think this game is for everybody. It‚Äôs a pretty challenging platformer for fans of the genre, and if you do not like bullet hell or a screen full of rotating buzzsaws (often both, plus many additional hazards), you might wanna skip this one. Rating [b]8 out of 10[/b] for the levels with the white ghost, 5/10 for the other levels. Ikao is a hardcore platformer/bullet hell game with a nice visual style, a minimistic story, and 2 different play modes.

You start the game as a blue two-tailed fox who has lost his memory, so of course the best thing to do is just walk to the right and hope you eventually uncover your memory and your purpose.  As you progress through the game you will randomnly run into a spirit and your character will somberly put his head down and have a brief memory of his former love.  Progression through the game slowly reveals the relationship between the 2 and what happens and eventually ends in a surprisingly somber tone that I completely did not expect.  I won't get into any details here but the story is told well enough and does not get in the way of the gameplay.

The gameplay is broken down into 2 different styles.  About half the game has you playing as the two-tailed fox, these levels play like a standard platformer. Your fox can jump, double jump, and stick to certain walls.  The other half of the game is played as a white spirit who can jump and float around infinitely by tapping the X button.  Although your character is flying the best way to describe the control in these levels is like an underwater level in a Mario game, but you can jump off of surfaces as well.  Control in both playstyles is super tight, and control of both characters switches back and forth.  So you will play x number of levels as the fox, then the spirit and so on.  

There are about 100 levels or so in this game and it is an incredibly challenging game.   The game starts out simple enough and has a pretty nice difficulty curve but it gets really hard.  Every level is riddled with spikes, buzzsaws that seemingly reach forever, and cannons that shoot endless streams of bullets at you.  The amount of stuff going on at any given time gives the game a very bullet hell feel to it, which is odd for a platformer but works really well.  The levels are designed that there are virtually no safe spots and everything kills you in one hit, you need to be both quick and cautious to navigate some of these nightmarish levels but the feeling of beating some of these levels is incredibly satisfying.  You will die alot, but the game offers instant respawns that make you want to jump right back in and give the level one more shot.    

There are also orbs scattered throughout the levels.  I have no idea what these orbs do and I typically am the kind of player who just ignores out of the way collectables but for some reason I felt compelled to collect all of these orbs.  I believe I got them all and I'm not really sure if it did anything, so maybe there is some greater purpose to them, or maybe they are just there for the completionist in you, I don't really know.

What I do know is that Ikao was an amazing game.  It retails for $2 and for that price I was expecting some crappy flash game but decided to give it a shot anyway and I'm really glad I did.  The game is very unique, very well made, and insanely hard.  Definitely worth a playthrough if you are into hardcore platformers. I gave this game a try since it was on sale and the price itself was appealing to me. 
Actually It's a very challenging game (went myself nearly to frustration but there was always the motivation to keep going). and I loved the design of the levels and such. 
If you love platformers and a good challenge, this might be your game. Gave this game a genuine try. There's some good aspects to it, and ideas present, but it suffers from the issue that plagues many indie games, in that it's just a bit overly "safe" without really ever impressing me. The movement mechanics are pretty bare-bones and the level design doesn't really allow this game to thrive, at least as far as I got (like the 4th little chunk of levels).

This is made worse by some mediocre presentation. Visually, the levels change very little in between, even when mechanics are added. The design of the levels is often pretty dull and overly simplistic. The obstacles changed very little from level to level, and there really wasn't much character to any of it; the character art in game really did not impress me, some of the animations just didn't sit right and weren't satisfying to use (the double-jump or the floating ability) and the minimalist storytelling did little to immerse me into this game (and the lack of a cutscene skip feature is kinda upsetting), and you end up switching characters with no real sense of rhyme or reason. Also, this game has some atrocious sound design; the sound effect for footsteps made me want to mute the game, and the music was just incredibly slow atmospheric/ambient music played ad nauseum, with no real soul to it. 

Furthermore the game seemed to have a bug any time I ran it where if I tried to alt tab, the window would open a couple seconds later, and this even forced a PC restart.

It is a 2$ game so I can't really say I regret giving it a go nor that I expected it to be fantastic, but it still didn't feel worth it. There was effort put into the game, but I felt it was missing any real soul to keep me interested, at least for the hour-fifteen or so I played it.

name: Time Tenshi
short_description: Join the Time Tenshi on their thrilling adventures through time! Make key decisions to influence the story's outcome... and maybe even go on a date!
reviews:
literally just ends for no damn reason. Goods 
-More detail in story(Like how the story treats the main character & the conflict around him)
-better character designs
-Like the romance options of the game 
-Remade the story in an interesting way 
cons 
-Very bad fan service & dose not stick to its roots of the original series well 
-no be 
-normal Ending
-Bit to short 
-Some ilustations are hard on eyes 
-The story is a remake from the original not a new story 
I recommend this game to anyone who like's there romance light novel but dosent want any fan service  

In my personal opinion  I prefer the original due to the be & the characters had more details on the characters them selfs. Another reason is price & due to not all content being in at launch After I finished playing the New Time Tenshi, I have to say that this game really catches me off guard. This game is interesting and unique. Not to say I don't have some ups and downs in this game, but this game really sends me on a wild ride through my time playing it. I'm already coming up with theories or what if ideas that might happen. To start off, I would like to talk about some of the ups and downs I have for this game, warning: there are spoilers ahead:
UPS:
1.	Kenji and Tensai:
This game did a really good job at portraying the main character, Kenji Johnson. Especially with his emotional states. When Kenji feels sad, I admit I would shed a tear or two as well. When he angry, I could feel his anger and understood the stress he is going through perfectly. What also made me like Kenji in this game is how analytical he is compared to the other characters. Literally, he was able to piece together who the ‚ÄúCommander‚Äù was, in either the main story or the alternate route. And when he is placed in an argument, he can not only keep his ground, but also contradict his opposition.
For Tensai, I would say he by far my most favorite character in this game, even more than the other girls and Kenji. I love how this version of Time Tenshi shows how stress or worried Tensai can be, I mean he also suffers from the fire incident along with Kenji. What made me like Tensai the most is this line, ‚ÄúNow this machine has taken another of my friends from me...‚Äù This literally made me feel like just how much of a father Tensai is to his team members, even when angry he still cares for his team.
2.	Choices:
I had a lot fun with this game choices, many of these choices are used to help Kenji find ‚ÄúSticky notes‚Äù and gain ‚Äúaffinity points‚Äù with any of the three main female characters, Kyo, Rose, and Michelle. And depending how much affinity point gained for a specific character, a new route is unlocked to gain a different ending for the game. I literally made a list to see if I can get all the dating scenarios and both ending for this game.
3.	Storytelling:
The story for this game is one of the best I have ever read. The emotions, the situation, the conflicts, and the argues all left me with my mouth wide open the whole time. There were many times when this game would have me jumping off my chair when playing. Specifically, ‚Äúthe china chase scene,‚Äù ‚ÄúKenji and Mizuki coward arguments‚Äù and ‚Äúthe bottle scene (either choice). These scenes were too perfect. I love how in the ‚Äúchina chase scene,‚Äù how this basically confirmed that a character who disappeared in the time window is still alive and how Kenji had his first argument with Mizuki. For the ‚ÄúKenji and Mizuki coward arguments,‚Äù there clash with the idea of who is more cowardly was really interesting. I mean we have an armed ninja vs an unarmed protagonist, and the protagonist was standing his ground even when threatens with his life, he did not even flinch. Finally, the ‚Äúbottle scene, whichever choices Kenji choice, there are two amazing outcomes that happens. Both outcomes left me with one of these two emotions, 
‚ÄúDrop the bottle in the bucket‚Äù https://j.gifs.com/yx24ME.gif 
‚ÄúAttack Michelle‚Äù https://64.media.tumblr.com/tumblr_m4dh4xcA2F1rn5beeo1_500.gif 
4.	Hidden Characters:
This game has me really excited for upcoming characters such as the ‚Äúcheerleader‚Äù and the ‚Äúprincess.‚Äù  I also like how this game made me curious about Petra, whether we will see her or not. Maybe Petra would be like the sixth ‚ÄúPower Ranger‚Äù or ‚ÄúSuper Sentai‚Äù of the group.
DOWNS:
1.	Characters nitpicks:
Mizuki and Bunni:
I love how this game adds a little bit more to these characters, such as how much Mizuki believe in the risk and how she keeps calling the good guys cowards and how Bunni is trying her best to hide her sorrow. But I just wish we could have more interaction with these girls a little bit more. 
https://64.media.tumblr.com/eb146691f4ebd54fce09a2dfc0fdaaa6/tumblr_nfa19goGhL1qc7cmzo3_500.gif 
Kyo and Rose:
For both Kyo and Rose, I kinda wish that their dating scenario with Kenji were a bit more meaningful, I think it‚Äôs because I was having a hard time trying to figure out when did these girls had a date with Kenji in this game compared to Michelle, was it during or after the main ending. For Kyo, I‚Äôll admit I kinda miss her pervy side in Time Tenshi 2. For Rose, I wish I could have seen her casual outfit more often.
Michelle:
My only complaint, her time effect scene was so short. Guess I am never destined to see Michelle‚Äôs reaction to a time effect (as I remembered TT1 and TT2). https://i.pinimg.com/originals/51/5f/c5/515fc550166bcd60a40ec39fa02c0176.gif 
2.	Illustration:
I will admit, I wished that this game had more illustration. I felt that this game mainly focused more on the texts and the characters sprites and special effects. Personally, I would like to see more illustration, at least that fit with the story. Just because my eyes get tired easily from reading too much, I blame my habits for my studying.
https://media1.tenor.com/images/1624fbe7cfd927495e81c52938dae8a5/tenor.gif?itemid=5428221 
3.	Time Effects:
My only complaint for the time effect is that I still feel curious. I want to know more about the new rules or laws that the effect has. Like are certain effects are more likely to happen to specific characters.  What effects are worst case? And will there the consequence?
4.	Too Short:
This game was too short, I need more. https://i.pinimg.com/originals/82/e9/e7/82e9e7713acefba2eccc892a0abe7493.gif 
Overall, this is an awesome game to play, I highly recommend it for anyone to play it. I really want to see how much Kenji will grow as a character. And how will the story progress in the next game.
Some wishes I have for the next game or maybe the third game:
Quantum Guard:
I really want the next game to reintroduce the quantum guards again, but maybe add some new features, such as maybe invisibility or elemental attacks. 
Kenji time suit and Quantum Guard:
Seeing how all the girl‚Äôs transformation a based on the magical girl genre, I would like to see Kenji transformation be inspired by the tokusatsu, such as Kamen riders, ultraman, super sentai (power rangers) and metal heroes. As for his quantum guard, it would be cool if Kenji‚Äôs guard would allow him to either fuse or make union with one of the girls at a time, for example, if Kenji fuse with Rose, his suit would turn yellow, based on her hair color, and it would take more of a knight like features.
Transformation example: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6niA6gfOTEo 
Michelle and everyone trust towards her:
Seeing how everyone‚Äôs interaction towards Michelle after the paradox, I feel that she is going to have a hard time gain the trust of the others. I would like to see how different many of the characters interact with Michelle compared to TT2. Maybe Rose and Kyo would have a hard time trusting her, just like a sibling betraying their other sibling. I could not tell if Kenji fully remembered the previous timeline in this game, but I would find it interesting if instead of having flashback of the ‚Äúfire,‚Äù Kenji started getting some flashbacks of the previous timeline, maybe in order to gain ‚Äúaffinity points‚Äù for Michelle, Kenji need to find ways so the others can start trusting Michelle again. As for Tensai, I have a hard time seeing Tensai acting cold towards Michelle just like in TT2. Maybe, when he is acting cold towards Michelle, he just tries to hide is worried for Michelle. Maybe in the next game a scene like this may happen to Michelle and Tensai.
https://media1.tenor.com/images/b114b6fb66a6434c095ab2b6e24253e4/tenor.gif?itemid=7680348 
Evil Kenji (introducing alternate timeline):
I always wondered if Time Tenshi would introduce the alternate timeline.Maybe there a Kenji where he goes crazy after throwing the bottle and he started going on a mental rage hunting down different Michelles from a different timeline. [ EDIT: I have gotten into contact with the author of the original Time Tenshi. His words are here and he provides his own damning insights on Silver Cow's nefarious business practices.
https://www.deviantart.com/mysteryguy9215/journal/Hey-Silver-Cow-855450980 ]

[ EDIT 2: I have also gotten into contact with the writer of this game and his confusing and unclear reasoning for what he's done.
https://www.deviantart.com/orionpax09/journal/Time-Tenshi-Reviews-856275226 ]

I'm a woman who writes erotica. I'm asexual, but sex-positive. As someone who played and loved the original, this is my take.

I believe that sexuality is beautiful. Sex can be cute, kinks can be great for story elements. Breast expansion is a rare fetish that I feel needs more positive portrayal. The original Time Tenshi was this. It had a great story that flaunted its sexuality while still being a good tale to follow.

I don't know why Silver Cow felt the need to remove the heart from their game. Perhaps they were misguided in believing the sexual elements were holding them back... Perhaps they didn't like them in the first place and they were only added for a reason out of their control. Perhaps they felt they wanted to be more respected as game makers who didn't make sexy games. Either way, I feel they were misguided.

As someone who writes erotic stories, I like to focus on how the sexuality can be part of the story. The world isn't a children's show. Red light districts, brothels, sex shops. They exist. But what would they be like in another world? What is the potential for perversion for this power? What is a story element that might make someone feel their sexual interest isn't so shameful? What things can the character get into that is sexy, but can also be fun, cute, and a story?

Stories can be sexy. That's nothing to be ashamed of. I enjoy putting lewd elements in my stories to make them wider. I also enjoy making those stories and worlds deeper and heavier even though they have lewdness in them.

Silver Cow removed the beautiful sex-positivity from this game. They replaced it with very little. Some slightly expanded story, romance routes, and some extra animations, but... At what cost? The game lost its heart. And what was added in doesn't actually make up for what was removed. More importantly, what was added doesn't justify the price compared to the original when the original still has its heart, even though Silver Cow crudely plastered a "(2015)" retroactively on the original, a crass act of defilement of their old work to show clear favoritism to the neutered remake.

Does it have some things improved? Yes. But the desecration its emotional heart wasn't worth it. The original had an amazing story with some beautiful sexuality to it. Now it's just an above-average story that was gutted in a misguided attempt to make it better or more respectable...

I enjoyed Silver Cow's work. Now I can't actually support them as a game studio who I thought had true artistic integrity when they're going to spit on their older work with a poorly-priced remake that retroactively stains the title of the original and removes far more than it adds.

There's also the dodgy Kickstarter behind this and the rather sketchy lack of transparency. Nowhere does this Steam page clearly state that it removed the sexuality of the original. They're not lying, but they're clearly being misleading through withholding information. It's entirely possible they may get a few extra bucks from people going in expecting a faithful and expanded remake, rather than a shadow of its former self made through misguided vanity.

I'll end this with a quote from the Kickstater campaign.

"Our goal with Time Tenshi is to create an entertaining, high-quality and well-told story-driven experience with a focus on character building, romance and a gripping plot. The focus this time will not be on breast expansion."

Not only with this quote squirreled away at the bottom of an FAQ section, but... This proves they're either lying or just incredibly misguided. Their game WAS story focused with character building and a gripping plot. Breast expansion wasn't even the focus, and you can have a breast expansion story with character building, romance, and gripping plot. In fact, that's part of what made the original Time Tenshi great: It had ALL of that. To mutilate their game while claiming it's better in every way... I would call it despicable if it weren't so pitiable to see them do something so misguided.

It's worth noting the team made videos for the remake advertising features that weren't in the final game, like voice acting. However, these features were relegated to stretch goals which weren't met, which suggests they intentionally removed features they'd already worked on to try and paywall them, and then when the paywalls weren't meant, they kept them out. I should also note that "Switch release" was a stretch goal, and even though it wasn't met, it still came out on the Switch.

I should also note how shady it is that Silver Cow refuses to speak to fans, not even Kickstater backers. They're an indie development studio. Transparency is their greatest tool, and they refuse to use it.

I'm sorry, Silver Cow. It was fun while it lasted. I only hope that your current path is worth the cost for whatever you hope to gain from it. Goodbye.

[ EDIT: Word from the author of the original game, again, may be found here.
https://www.deviantart.com/mysteryguy9215/journal/Hey-Silver-Cow-855450980 ]

[ EDIT 2: Word from the author of this game, again, may be found here.
https://www.deviantart.com/orionpax09/journal/Time-Tenshi-Reviews-856275226 ] Before I get into the review, let me get some things said now. This is a reboot/remake of the first game with no breast expansion and very little fanservice. My opinion on it? I prefer it. Sure, this franchise is infamous for BE, but I felt this series was trying to focus on the story more. This VN isn't a fanservice VN with time travel, but a story involving time travel WITH fanservice. However, I can see why people put more focus on the fanservice. Another thing is the failed Kickstarter and the things that weren't able to make it in the game. Things like Voice acting, more illustrations, and even romance routes for the villains weren't added in. However, I'm going to judge this game as to what we were given, not what it was supposed to be. Anyways...

Time Tenshi 2020 as stated above is a reboot/remake of the first Time Tenshi released in 2015. It has a couple of changes such as a page to listen to the music, more elements added to the story, and a SKIP and backlog button. Additionally, romance routes were added into the story in contrast to the original in which it was only used for like one scene. The story is the same: You are Kenji, a boy that is brought to his grandfather's lab after an unfortunate incident leaves you with no parents. With all of these things and more, it seems like Silver Cow wanted to improve on the original and focus on the story here. How did it go and is this better than the original? Let's find out.

[h1]Positives[/h1]
- There are a couple of characters that were handled here, but I'll talk specifically about Kenji and Tensai. While Kenji is the same character, this VN gives us more time showing that despite feeling inferior to the others, he has some intelligence as well. Adding on to that, this version gives a few more scenes that gives us a better understanding on how this incident is affecting him. As for Tensai, I like that he is more involved in this version. It may just be with some new changes or the things they added in this story, but I feel like Tensai is handled better here as well. 
- Speaking of the things that were added, I like how they implemented the new character in the story. She didn't show her model, but from what the characters say about her, I'm excited if we are able to see her if SCS is planning on rebooting the franchise. For the romance "routes", one was done in a very unique way that I wasn't expecting. I enjoyed it. Some of the effects are nice. My favorites are the energy flowing in the lab background, the animation on the text box and the binary code that shows up when characters are in the time window and are about to change outfits. 
- The art and backgrounds are done well. The character models look nice and their mouths move. It makes them feel more alive.

[h1]Negatives[/h1]
- I know I shouldn't judge the game for what isn't in it, but Mizuki and Bunni needed more screentime. I feel like I would've given this game more points if we were able to see what those romance routes given us. I'd imagine we could have gotten to know them a little better.
- Speaking of romance routes, I felt like most of them weren't handled well. I get what they were doing with one of them as it did a lot to make it unique, but it just makes the other ones feel inferior. Not to mention all there is from getting enough affinity points for a girl is [spoiler]a very short scene that's while nice, could've had a little bit more time to it. [/spoiler]
- In my opinion, I think Rose and Kyo were more memorable in the original. In the original, [spoiler]Kyo feeling inferior was done better there as they set the mood with the different background music.[/spoiler]
- Lastly, performance. I know my laptop isn't the best, but I have played a couple of other VNs and it ran fine. I encountered on two instances when I clicked to advance to the next line of text, but the game stopped for a few seconds.

[h1]Nitpicks[/h1]
- There were a few grammar errors that I came across while reading through this VN. For example, one line goes "They're even bigger cowards then you..." where "then" is supposed to be "than".
- While I liked some effects, there were some that I wasn't a fan of. One time window side effect of changing a character's skin could've looked better. Additionally, one scene where Michelle is listening to music didn't need the additional movement. It shows how stiff these characters can move sometimes, and it makes her move like a popsicle stick puppet.
- One scene had Kyo in her uniform, but she is wearing casual clothes in a CG.
- I'll have to get used to Michelle's design here. I liked the original design of her as she looked older. 
- The opening song was nice, but the visuals need a little work. Was the part where you showed Bunni's and Mizuki's character cards for like 3 seconds necessary?
- The art quality could use some work as there were some jagged lines when I looked at the illustrations in the Gallery. 
- The music menu looks a little boring. Maybe add something unique to it?

[h1]Overall Thoughts[/h1] 
That was nice. Time Tenshi 2020 adds onto the existing story while taking away breast expansion. In my eyes, they did a good job. While they weren't able to add everything they wanted, I think they did a fine job with this game. Despite my negatives like some characters not getting as much time as I'd like and the performance, I think my pros outweigh the cons. If you care only about fanservice and breast expansion, then you should buy the original. If you want a good story with added elements to make it provide a little more than the original and some neat effects, then buy this one. Want to buy both? Why not? If you are a newbie to Silver Cow, I DEFINITELY recommend getting it when it's on sale for a price that is to your liking. That is if you are interested in this VN. In closing, with the absence of BE, Time Tenshi gives you the same story as its 2015 version but with a lot of changes that make it the better version. Until my next review, thanks for reading and have a good day. If you are a fan of the original you will likely be very disappointed.
They completely removed the BE stuff which was what made this series good in the first place.
It's like if you remade PUBG without guns and expect people to buy it again.
Waste of money.
 Interesting take on the classic.

So, let's get the elephant out of the room.

There's no BE in here.

Yes, now that we have that out of the way, this is a wonderful story with memorable characters.

The story is told in a much more warmhearted and emotional manner than the 2015 version.

The music is very good

The animation is much better than previous entries. This game is only a remake of the first Tenshi from 2015, and the only difference is no BE?!? (And some little story differences)

Removing the best part of the game from the remake and replacing it with a magical girl transformation was the worst idea that Silver Cow could have done.

I feel sorry for Silver Cow, after the Time Tenshi: Paradox Failure and now this game...
Obviously some decisions were made at Silver Cow, which have a very bad impact on the Time Tenshi series.

Is it worth buying this game?

For someone who liked the old Time Tenshi's: 
Clearly wasted money

For someone who plays this game before the other Time Tenshi games: 
You can try it, but the older Time Tenshi's are much better and cheaper. I would not recommend it. A remake of the first Time Tenshi without the breast expansion.

This feels like a generic Anime visual novel.

Check out "Growth Academy" for great quality content for free.  I feel like there is a market for such things, but nobody wants to risk being known for making such things.

name: New World: Aeternum
short_description: Experience a thrilling action RPG set on the supernatural island of Aeternum. Forge your destiny on an adventure filled with danger and opportunity.
reviews:
its lowkey ass but a fun grind if u like leveling tradeskills like i do If you enjoy it, thank me later :-| Very nice game, but after 4 years on PC using like 10% of its potential, so there are a lot burnout oldie players who cannot be satisfied anymore.
My Opinion that the action combat of an MMO best on the market, but devs still don't know their own roadmap, and very very slowly add new stuff, which 2 of 3 times came with big mistakes..
If you are 1st time to experience it, you will enjoy it for sure, til you end up a meaningless circle after geared up for end game. Depends on you it can offer 200-1000 hrs enjoyable time.

+the detailful sound work is absolutely positive. If you‚Äôve ever played Neverwinter, the Dungeons & Dragons MMO, you might recognize some similarities in New World. Both share a somewhat simple combat system at first glance, but New World stands out by offering a more refined and rewarding experience. Unlike Neverwinter, which is often criticized for its problematic monetization and pay-to-win mechanics, New World manages to avoid these pitfalls, allowing players to focus on the game without constant distractions from microtransactions.

Combat System:

At first, New World‚Äôs combat may seem simplistic‚Äîat least in comparison to some other MMOs. However, the more you play, the more you‚Äôll appreciate the underlying depth. If you‚Äôve ever played World of Warcraft (or any other game with a tab-targeting system) and found yourself wishing there was a bit more skill required in landing those chaotic, powerful attacks, New World will scratch that itch.

The combat system is dynamic and engaging, requiring real-time positioning, dodging, and aiming. It's a refreshing take on the traditional MMO combat mechanics, and it provides a level of satisfaction that‚Äôs hard to come by in games that lean too heavily on a "press-button-and-wait" approach. Whether you're wielding a sword, casting spells, or swinging a warhammer, every action feels deliberate and impactful, making the battles feel more like a test of skill than simple number crunching.

Story and World Design:

One of the standout features of New World is its incredible world-building. The environment is amazingly crafted, and the level of detail in both the visuals and the lore is remarkable. From the dense forests and foggy swamps to the snow-covered mountains, each area has its own unique feel and atmosphere. It's clear that the developers put a lot of thought into creating a living, breathing world that‚Äôs rich in history and filled with opportunities for discovery.

The story itself is intriguing, though it serves more as a backdrop for the exploration and survival elements. That said, the world of Aeternum‚Äîthe setting of New World‚Äîhas enough depth to pull you in and keep you invested in its mysteries. Whether you‚Äôre uncovering ancient ruins or delving into the story behind the corruption that plagues the land, the narrative weaves seamlessly into the gameplay, offering plenty of incentives to explore every nook and cranny.

Crafting System:

The crafting system in New World is another highlight. It's comprehensive without feeling overwhelming. There‚Äôs a real sense of satisfaction when you gather resources and craft items, whether it‚Äôs weapons, armor, or consumables. The system is complex enough to feel rewarding but doesn't require excessive grinding or micromanagement. Whether you‚Äôre an experienced crafter or someone new to the mechanic, there‚Äôs something deeply satisfying about creating items that directly impact your gameplay. Plus, the materials and crafting stations are scattered across the world, making crafting an integral part of your journey, not just a side activity.

Overall Impressions:

So far, I don‚Äôt have a lot of negative things to say about New World. The game excels in so many areas: the skill-based combat, the stunning world design, and the rewarding crafting system all come together to create an experience that feels fresh and exciting. There‚Äôs a good balance of depth without overwhelming the player, and the attention to detail in the game world is evident in every corner.

If you‚Äôre someone who‚Äôs looking for a traditional MMO experience with more skill-based combat and a world that feels alive, New World is definitely worth checking out. It‚Äôs a refreshing change from the typical MMO formula, and whether you‚Äôre a fan of Neverwinter, World of Warcraft, or other MMOs, this game brings something new to the table without the frustrating pay-to-win mechanics. Terrible example of game design. Minning, Logging, Fishing The lock on ruined what made this game so good. Everyone in the community sais the exzact same thing. I absolutely love this game, However AGS is simply the worst dev team. I found an XP bug that gave infinite xp from simply restarting any quest. Made a video of the bug, then reported on the forums and to customer support. Next day I was banned for a week or so for bug abuse. What? There is also the issue of Angry Earth, You are basically paying $30 for the ability to use mounts, something which should have been in the game from the beginning. You also get a "new" zone however its just a re-skinned starter zone that is now for end game, instead of just adding a new zone altogether. 

AGS has made an absolutely fantastic game, that they simply dont care about. Its just there to milk money from the microtransaction store and expansions that add basic functions that should have been there from the beginning. They dont care about the game, they dont care about the players, and its starting to show as player counts hit all time lows even during peak hours.
