Circuit Superstars delivers a refreshing take on the top-down racing genre, combining arcade accessibility with simulation-level depth. Designed to appeal to both casual players and motorsport enthusiasts, it stands out for its attention to detail and focus on player skill. The game rewards precision, making each lap feel satisfying as techniques are mastered. While not perfect, its polished mechanics and charming style make a strong impression from the start.
Gameplay in Circuit Superstars is where it truly shines. The driving model is tight and responsive, striking a fine balance between realism and fun. Strategic pit stops, tire wear, and fuel management add layers of depth to races, especially in longer formats. The AI offers a fair challenge, and the online multiplayer provides an engaging experience, particularly for those looking to test their skills against real players.
Visually, the game boasts a clean and vibrant aesthetic that complements its top-down perspective. The art style is colorful and stylized, with each track having distinct environmental details that enhance the overall charm. Animations are fluid, and car designs, while not overly realistic, are recognizable and varied enough to stand out. Performance remains solid, even with multiple cars on screen.
Overall, Circuit Superstars is a well-crafted racing experience that successfully blends arcade and simulation elements. While it may not appeal to those looking for a story-driven game, its deep mechanics and polished gameplay make it a standout in the genre. The visual presentation enhances its appeal, creating a cohesive and enjoyable package. It‚Äôs a rewarding title for players willing to invest the time to master its unique style.
Circuit Superstars gets a 6/10.

Hope you enjoyed my review, god bless you I love this game:

-Good variety of AI competition for all skill levels

This is the best little indie game I've bought in a while, I've recommended it to all of my gaming friends. I've played a long list of automotive sims, and this somehow feels as good as many of them, but packaged in an exciting, fun, quick-pick-up-and-put-down game. Super well done, great work OFG! Very fun arcade-sim-like GP racer Online is pretty much unplayable - your controls become laggy and unresponsive when near other cars.

name: Digital Jigsaw Puzzle
short_description: A jigsaw puzzle game with 150+ puzzles with sizes up to 576 pieces. You can even load your custom image as a puzzle!
reviews:
bought a bunch of different jigsaw puzzle games to see which would be best for my SO to use. she loves puzzles. this one is easy to use and has four custom slots for creating puzzles using any image the player has available. she's loves using it to make custom puzzles of her pet pics. i'm loving it for creating custom puzzles of memes from Discord channels

even if you don't like that feature, it does have a lot of built in content. much more then all the others ones i got. plus, as i said earlier, it is extremely easy to set up and use This game is quite relaxing and enjoyable, though the UI feels a little unpolished. A tip is to hit ESC to get the close menu since I don't see any other way to close out the game while playing. This is great if you like jigsaw puzzles; and I really, really enjoy them. The pics are hard enough to be challenging, but if they are too hard for you on any one of them, just use your mouse to make the puzzle smaller or larger, and choose more or less pieces to suit your taste.  Really fun! I enjoy this one! Pieces are clunky and dull. I bought this to make my own puzzles, on sale, barely worth it but not really. Pieces are stretched to fit screen but only cover 1/4 of the screen for the small puzzle (8x8). The are a variety of options but they seem to just try to make the puzzle more frustrating to complete, not more complex. If they boosted the quality and fixed the size issues it would be a $10 program. The only reason I am posting this review as a negative is in order to try and get the developer's attention on something. I actually really like this game, it's a ton of fun especially since you can add your own custom images as puzzles. The idea that I have is for multi monitor support. The play area feels very congested on one monitor. It would be AMAZING if we can have the pieces on one monitor and the play area on the other. I will definitely change my review, even if I just get a quick response from them :) I like the clack sounds Arguably the best value jigsaw puzzle game I've seen on Steam. Hours of entertainment using the provided puzzles, and the underappreciated feature to add your own images to generate new ones provides a virtually unlimited number of puzzles to try.  The only negative I observed is that the aspect ratio is slightly off for the puzzles and they always seemed slightly squished. Unfortunately at this time the achievements don't count on Steam's totals. Perfectly servicable puzzle game.  I can't say I've ever used any of the included images - so I can't comment on them, I have enough of my own images that I don't need to rely on theirs.  That one item alone recommends this puzzle game.
Things I would like to see:  
1)  Puzzles that don't rely on resizing the image to fit the puzzle dimensions.  I won't ding them too hard on this - I fully realize the difficulty of generating a puzzle from what could be essentially a random sized image.  This game didn't cost 300 bucks or something, so the author deserves credit for what was delivered - but it would be nice to see a wider range of image sizes accommodated.
2)  Sounds.  This is an easy fix to implement so I'll be less forgiving.  The sound of pieces when let go gets SOOO annoying.  The ability to either change the sound or turn it off completely would be a welcome addition Aspect ratio is off on majority of the puzzles. Puzzle images can only be square, 1:1 aspect. Most stock images appear squished. Does not have 150 puzzles as it claims. Only has 50.

Not worth the price, even as cheap as it is. This was a great purchase. It sounds simple, but no other puzzle game/software on steam makes custom puzzles so easy. Not everything about this product is smooth or user-intuitive, but it lets you import your own pictures and create puzzles out of them! To do so, you'll need to go directly to the game files and add copies of the pictures. If you love puzzles and want to do virtual puzzles with your own pictures, grab this when it's on sale. You won't be disappointed.

Would work better as a straightforward puzzler... with better difficulty progression a well put together puzzle game that can be frustrating (in a good way) but very rewarding when you solve a puzzle Perfect Angle is a short but very nice game. You have to move around objects in order to find a shadow on the wall. Something like we did when we were young: make a butterfly with your hands. Or you have to turn around objects in order to find a new shape. Not really hard, most of the time. So it's an relaxing game. The story and the narrating gets bored after a while. As for me, it doesn't have any added value. But that's me. Perhaps it gives you more depth in the story. Rating: 8 out of 10. Very good game. Works perfect even on old hardware. Relaxing play and many things that you can think about. Excellent Game! Very thought provoking with a good story, alot of bad reviews cause it offers you to buy hints, But hints are given if your still having a problem after around 4 min. I think the developer just wanted people to try and solve the puzzles and if your lazy then buy some hints so you can zoom through the game if you want. But really you don't need to buy anything solving the puzzles is fun and this game is worth 2.50. Absolutely not the game I was waiting for. Boring and incoherent. About 25% of the puzzles are cool but the others...annoying. Didn't worth the EUR2 I've paying for it. If you can get it for free, take it but don't pay. Especially not for the ingame clues.... TL:DR at bottom above the *

I feel that a puzzle game should be challenging but intuitive.  Ultimately the player needs to understand more than the mechanic of the game/level.  They also should understand the goal of each level and game.  Now in no way do I think this means giving the player the answer*.  The player should be able to deduce what it is they are looking for.  The game is broken into these "series" and (I feel) these seires should have puzzles that flow together to form a "theme".... And they sort of almost acomplish this.  But I am still at a loss in each puzzle what I am looking for.

For example.  In one puzzle I end up making what appears to be a "Chess Pawn" and the next level I ended up with a comb.  Now it turns out that the "Chess pawn" was supposed to be hand soap on the guys Bathroom Sink.  But this idea and theme was not communicated till all the objects had been found. 

Ways to fix this.  The backgrounds instead of being used as advertisment space** should be used to help descibe the theme.  For the scenario above the backgrounds could have taken place in a large bathroom(s) with the broken pieces scattered in different bathroom looking backgrounds.  This makes me think What might I find in a bathroom and work from there. 

This allows the player to feel acomplished and know what they are looking for.  There were several puzzles (Especially the seahorse one) where I had no idea what I was looking for until the game said (unexptedly) I had the solution and showed me what I got.

TLDR: In short A player in a puzzle game should never be surprized that they got an answer.  This does not leed to a feeling of acomplishment but stupidity and shame. 

That being said Nice Graphics
Nice Controls

*(You can BUY "hints" to do tell you what you are looking for 'Cough microtransactions on a paid game Cough' but this isn't what my complaint is about)
** Oh Yea that too Very philisophical game which makes you see the beauty in the everyday, the light in that darkness, the clarity in the unknown. Follow someone through the different stages of his life as he tries to find the solutions to all his problems, only to find that they were around him the whole time. Amazing thought provoking game which can be slightly frustrating when you dont know what to look for, but dont worry, the game will give you hints.

name: FSX: Steam Edition - Kilimanjaro Airport (HTKJ) Add-On
short_description: Kilimanjaro Airport for FSX: Steam Edition covers the airport and the immediate surroundings, and also includes detailed models of Mount Kilimanjaro and Mount Meru, which dominate the area. These majestic landmarks provide an exotic and adventurous backdrop for a variety of aviation experiences, from commercial flights to bush piloting.
reviews:
No reviews yet?! Alright! Let me blow your mind with mine.

I don't fly in and out of this airport often. I bought it because I'm basically getting rid of most default FSX airports and adding the add ons for a more realistic touch while simming. 
Graphics wise, I don't really see a drop in it, even while runnning payware things like the Majestic Dash8, REX textures, or the Feelthere Embraer Jets (Which you can also get on steam now.) 
On the ground the airport looks nice as well. Approaching it is pretty with the mountain/volcano/oneofEarth'sbon3rs to the side of the airport. 

Is it worth what it's being sold for? Ehhhhh. Mostly yes. I say it would be nicer cheaper for most add ons but this one for sure. It's very nice, worth getting if you are willing to spend the money on it but not worth as much as it costs...so get it on sale if you want to fly in and out of it every now and then.

name: Sex Story - Cuckold Life - Episode 5
short_description: A steamy Visual Novel featuring high-definition graphics and realistic-looking characters set in beautiful decor. The story continues with Nikki at the office getting cornered by her asshole of a Boss, then seduced into a wild quickie while her husband is on the other side of a glass wall.
reviews: Finally, Hubby (Adam) leaves the apartment, stopping by his wife's (Nikki's) office to pick her up for dinner. However, she's busy in the Boss' office. While Adam waits in the office lobby chatting with the boss' knockout secretary, Nikki is bing-bang-booming the boss. With her naked silhouette showing through the boss' smoked glass office window, she works her way through  the usual paces and gets another "mess" for her hubby. The Boss confronts Adam and lets him know what he's been doing. Adam is unfazed, dinner is canceled, and our couple instead go home for a clean up. Observations: 1) We learn Nikki and Adam have been married 5-years; 2) Nikki's work clothes are similar to a cocktail waitress (at a strip club); 3) Not all of Nikki's thongs are red (today they're pink with blue trim and the Boss kept them as a souvenir).

name: ARK and ADE
short_description: ARK and ADE is an action-jammed VR FPS shooter in which you get to experience the glory of the 80‚Äôs arcade era in a neon fused setting ü§òüòé. Shoot your way through retro-futuristic levels filled with enemies, iconic over the top bosses and never ending bullets. Insert coin to play! ü§ñ
reviews:
Get rid of the annoying teleporter, or at least include a way to disable it, and  this becomes a thumbs up [h1]A TRON-like Bullet-Hell VR Shooter That Is Extremely Fun![/h1]

If you're a fan of stylish, high-octane bullet-hell arcade VR shooters, ARK & ADE is a must-play. The game impressed me right from the start with its TRON-like visual style, delivering a neon-drenched aesthetic that is both modern and nostalgic. The way you get sucked into the arcade cabinet from the basement, was just super cool to see in VR. The vibrant colors and simplistic graphics perfectly complement the fast-paced arcade gameplay and looks very pleasing in VR.

[b]Shooting Mechanics & Enemies[/b]

The arcade-style shooting mechanics are very satisfying in this game that give nods to various arcade games from the 80s and 90s. Weapons are given to you like Metal Slug, shoot the upgrade powerup in the air and you will receive the new weapon with limited ammo. Once the ammo is depleted, you get your main pistol blaster back. The difficulty is fair, striking a perfect balance between challenge and enjoyment. There are lots of enemies to shoot and enemy types have quite a lot of variance ranging from normal humanoid beings armed with laser pistols and shotguns to drones that shoot rockets at you. The game keeps you on your toes without feeling too overwhelming.

[b]Boss Fights[/b]

There are boss fights in ARK & ADE which are a highlight of the game, providing some of the most engaging and fun moments. Each boss encounter is uniquely designed for that particular level that give good variety to the gameplay and visuals. Boss fights are well designed and feel satisfying when you complete them.

[b]Gamemode Variety[/b]

The game offers a rich variety of content. With numerous levels to conquer, an endless mode that plays like Pistol Whip, and a survival mode where you battle waves of enemies in an arena, there's plenty to keep you engaged. Each mode adds its own unique twist, ensuring the gameplay remains fresh and exciting.

[b]bHaptics Integration[/b]

ARK & ADE has one of the best utilization of bHaptics I have encountered. Right from the moment when you select a level and you get sucked into the machine, the vibration of the vest and what is happening is VERY cool and gives a sensation that you are actually getting sucked into the machine. The vest vibrates as if your clothing is fluttering in the wind as you travel quickly forward into the machine. This alone is extremely cool and causes a bit of a thrill.

[b]Overall[/b]

Overall, ARK & ADE stands out as a top-tier arcade VR shooter. Its stylish visuals, fair difficulty, and diverse modes make it a game that keeps me coming back to. Highly recommended for anyone looking to immerse themselves in a visually striking and action-packed experience. Works on Reverb G2 with minor issue.

Retro arcade VR shooter with minimalistic visuals and frantic gameplay. It's quite short, but every second is filled with non-stop action.

Every shot is projectile based, both shooting and dodging feels satisfying. Strafing speed is slow enough to encourage real life side stepping to avoid damage from time to time. Enemies are surprisingly varied for such a small game, and there is a unique boss for every level, that will quickly turn the game into a bullet-hell. There is almost no down-time for action, feels like the game was initially designed as a on-rail shooter in the best way possible. 
The campaign can be beaten in less than an hour, but the game is good enough to stick around for replaying on higher difficulty and trying endless modes. Although, bosses become a bit too bullet-spongy on Highfor my taste.

Stylized minimalistic visuals look timeless in VR and perform well. And some effects(like bullet collisions and transition between main menu and levels) are quite beautiful.

Works on Reverb G2, but in-game hands are misaligned. Thankfully, it is barely noticeable when aiming with laser pointer Wow! By far the best arcade shooter in VR yet. I am a sucker for the style but really the levels, the musical score and the game play loop is really just so well designed. Each campaign level is an ode to a popular type of media of the time and the difficulty really emulates the challenge of games from the 80's. The game can get really physically demanding on harder modes, or you can play the game casually on normal. There is ton of replay value, trying to accomplish all the achievements (some which I swear may be darn near impossible) and the arena modes are the icing on the cake. There are leaderboards, a campaign, and the gameplay loop is just plane addictive. My only thought is that as far as I know, there is no pause button mid level, which may be a welcome addition for those that may need to pause mid level. Highly recommend. For the price you wont be disappointed. I am 5 hours through, only played the arena modes 4 times and just part way through the campaign on hard after beating the game on normal. Worth every penny! Fun game play, just a bit too short. The game only takes you about 2-3 hours to beat and the final boss was honestly the easiest boss in the game due to it being so easy to cheese. If you want the game to be longer, play on the hardest difficulty. The game could also use a better soundtrack, default music is fine but something like what is in Hotline Miami would fit the game very well. I also think some higher render distance would be nice on PC, but I understand this might not be possible on quest. If you enjoy Arcade style gameplay and a wide enemy variety, then this game is for you. If you come in here expecting a 20 hour campaign with a deep story line then you will be disappointed (But you probably already know that from the trailer). It's an alright game. Pretty sure I nabbed it on a sale but for the cheap price, it was worth! Just a fun game if you want something to shoot. LITERALLY AN ARCADE SHOOTER, BUT IN VR (this is a good thing) Do I like this Game .....No, I f****g LOVE it!
You tube review here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XG9aLX3NKAc

I've been waiting for Vr since "The Lawnmower Man" - and ive played a few games, but this, at just over ¬£7 is a masterpiece really. 
Its proper arcade shooter of the past In virtual reality. A lot of love had thought has gone into this, the bosses are great - the level design is great and the synth wave soundtrack is rocking! 
Replay value is high, why? Because it goes back to the roots of gaming. High score leaderboards! You have to get to the top of the world leaderboard - become the best. I'd like to see tournaments  in the future!  

 This game is terribly boring to myself, simply because it's just a game where you point and shoot, there's nothing to really move your body about in here, just standing still and pointing your pewpew gun at people. You can't sprint, no choice for manual reloading, you can't hold the gun with two hands for some added immersion fun either, since your off-hand is used for other abilities.

It's poorly optimized for such a pixelated game too. I'm not on a top-tier PC, but running on an i9-9900k with a 3060 Ti, NVMe SSD, and 32 GB of RAM isn't an issue for any other VR game I own. The kicker is then that they didn't add any graphics settings in the game, so you have no options for fixing it for yourself by downgrading a few things.

I'm not even gonna be able to fully review it, as I couldn't even make it past 6 minutes with the poor optimization and no fix for it. Returning it and will see if it ever improves later on for a potential repurchase. Hope anyone else has had fun, but if you have worse specs than me, then you're gonna struggle to play this game when it loads new chunks of the level. $3 for this one, tops.

Yeah... it was ok. I got this on sale for $9 and I don't think it was worth it. I don't really care/want to replay this. The replay mechanics don't really appeal to me.

The 'great soundtrack' tag got me, but I don't think that's the case. Repetitive enemies. Secrets that (for a first time player) may as well be totally random. Locked paths is annoying. Some cool weapons, some cool bosses, but I've played a lot of RPGs that have that, and also a compelling binding narrative and/or expansive beautiful environments. ArKAde has neither. It was just kind of a shooting gallery that you're supposed to be able to get through in about 5 minutes per level.

It's not that I disliked it, I just know my gaming time would've been better spent elsewhere.

name: The Night The Carsons Disappeared
short_description: On April 6th 2009 the Carson family disappeared from their home in Richmond, and were never heard from again. The last known communication with the family came when Mr.Carson contacted local police to report the occurrence of a series of unexplained phenomena.
reviews:
Like some other title from 6 years ago whose name will come to me later in this review, The Night the Carsons Dissappeared was one of the early commerical standing VR scare-shows. I guess you might consider them kinda sort sleep apralsysis simulators. Bad stuff is happening all around you and you can't do anything about it. [spoiler]I guess I can't remember the name of the other one. *Squeezes head* arrrrrg. Nothing. I reviewed it, it's in the pile somewhere.[/spoiler][list][*][quote]

If you look at this more like an animated horror film with about a half hour running time, it's well worth the asking price. I'm not sure why the husband never runs for it though. The first few things that happen could be written off, but seriously, most people, including me would have booked it. 

The clown doll was unique and the story line could be read several different ways. But where and why does someone get creepy life-sized dolls? How would a realtor sell a home with those assets to anyone who has seen even one horror movie? Still it's a clear tribute to at least one horror film and not half bad for its age.

 [h1]Played On: [b]HTC Vive[/b][/h1]

The Night the Carsons Disappeared is a horror "movie" that lasts about half an hour. Without spoiling the experience and giving too much away, it explores the mysterious and still unexplained 2009 disappearance of Katie Carson's husband, Michael, and her two children in Richmond, Ontario Canada. All in all, it takes elements from horror classics such as The Amityville Horror, Paranormal Activity, and The Strangers.

Since you, the viewer, are playing as Michael Carson, you will be seated in the living room of the family home. Keep in mind that this is the non-interactive version of the game, and therefore you will just be observing your surroundings. Around you, strange and disturbing events slowly unfold in both audio and visual form. Depending on how easily you scare, there's a good chance that you may quit before the entire duration is up. Thankfully, there are no heart attack inducing jumpscares, but rather a combination of subtle and in-your-face moments of terror.

There are a few downsides to The Night the Carsons Disappeared, and most of them are pretty major immersion breakers. Many times throughout the experience the audio plays through the wrong speaker channel; for instance, a door opens to the right of you but the sound of it opening comes through the left speaker. There are also many situations where it seems to take minutes for the next event to start happening. Additionally, the graphics are really, really terrible even by low standards, [spoiler]especially where the character and dog models are concerned[/spoiler].

For a buck, The Night the Carsons Disappeared isn't awful by any means. It has a lot of potential and room to grow, and hopefully the developer can iron out some of the aformentioned issues prior to the release of the interactive version. The set up for the story is highly believable, and I actually searched to see if it was based off a true story. For what it is, and for the price, grab it if you enjoy some mild scares.

[h1]Rating: [b]3.0/5.0[/b] - Average, can take it or leave it.[/h1]
The Horror Network [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/28221963/]Curator[/url] | [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/thehorrornetwork]Group[/url] Click for Gore
The VR Network [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/33182845-The-VR-Network/]Curator[/url] | [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/thevrnetwork]Group[/url] Click for More Good story, good concept but the lack of quality animations for the "main character" and the dog ruined it for me. It turned out better than I thought that I have to sit around and wait for events to happen, was like a interactive "movie" but like I say the character work should have been much better. Not bad, not great.  It was kind of like those scare house rides some theme parks have, except you aren't in a moving tram thing.  Game was about 25 mins long which isn't terrible since I only paid like 2 dollars.  The scale was way off for me, and I was floating way above the chair (I started the game sitting down as suggested), but it was still enjoyable enough. This game could be a lot more than what it is.

Unfortunately it simply ended up as one of the most boring "games" where you can't do anything and nothing really happens. Also, those spaced out 'scary' parts are just not enough to keep anyone away from falling asleep.

The voices are great tho. very spoopy A real must for anyone who likes VR Horror!  Great experience for anyone new to VR as the experience is very comfortable (except for the horror parts ofcourse ;) )  Dev is very receptive and listens to feedback and ideas and acts on them which is very refreshing.

Perfect timing for my Halloween party, I'm sure it will be the star of the show! Great horror experience that really plays with your mind!

name: Toziuha Night: Dracula's Revenge Soundtrack - Lydium Music
short_description: Lydium Music Selection
reviews: Toziuha Night: Dracula's Revenge Soundtrack - Lydium Music is an okay soundtrack DLC but the only problem is that I feel like it should be free instead of costing like three bucks but that's only me.

name: hexceed - Cessabit Pack
short_description: Unlocks a new world for hexceed: Cessabit brings 125 new puzzles with a brand new mechanic to shake things up!
reviews:
You think it would be jank, but it works. 
Plays way too many visual tricks on you at times. The larger shapes mechanic is something so obvious I'm surprised it took this long to get added to this style of puzzle game. I think my main issue is that they start out with a lot of novel and creative setups involving these larger shapes, but then kinda just... stop, once the other mechanics get reintroduced in later sections of the world. It does start to feel a bit stale by the end, and this is a fairly easy pack once you get the hang of the new mechanics, too, but it's a pretty fun one all the same. Fun new mechanic has been introduced! Absolutely love puzzly minesweeper-like games, and this one scratches just the right spot for my brain. This expansion introduces tiles that are shaped differently. The confusing part is that the number is displayed multiple times on those tiles. That still takes some getting used to for me, but the new mechanic itself is fun.

name: The Spatials: Galactology
short_description: The Spatials are back with Galactology! Design, build and protect your colony station from the many enemies you will make while exploring the galaxy and exploding their homeworlds.
reviews:
With a small station the game plays fine but I'm sure certain devices will get performance issues with larger stations. This is pretty fun in a semi-casual package. I haven't had any raiders yet but so far even visiting the nearby planets has gone okay, so long as I don't let my people get swarmed. There are numerious game breaking bugs. Such as resources are not collected from planets, characters stay in low "Mind" even though issue with payment was solved. Also music is so annoying and buggy. The Spatials: Galactology ‚Äì More Like Galacti-nahhh ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

The Spatials: Galactology promises a fun space adventure where you build and protect your colony. In reality, it‚Äôs a frustrating mix of outdated mechanics and tedious micromanagement. You‚Äôll spend more time fixing power outages and malfunctioning systems than enjoying the supposed galactic exploration. üöÄüí•

The graphics feel too simplistic for the game‚Äôs ambitious premise, and the lack of meaningful progression makes the whole experience repetitive. Exploding homeworlds sounds cool, but it quickly becomes shallow and uninspired. üíîüëæ

If you‚Äôre after a complex and engaging space colony sim, The Spatials: Galactology misses the mark. There are better ways to explore the stars. üååüöÄ

Score: 4/10

Created with <3 Man, I want to love this game - but I hit a wall every time I play it. Not because the game is bad, but because of performance issues. It appears to do most work on a single CPU core and, as soon as you have a "medium" station, you start getting stuttering that makes the game unplayable. I came back to give it a go with my Ryzen 3600.. it didn't fair much better than my previous Intel 3770k. Performance issues were also seen on Steam Deck.

I love this sort of game, and I am just sad that with 70+ hours played, I have never been able to build a full station. Had a lot of fun playing this colony sim several years ago.  Very much enjoyed the amount of content and the different mechanics at play, though in some cases half the fun was figuring out how it all worked.

If you're into colony sims and don't mind a bit of combat and are capable of braving the unknowns of space, it's certainly a game worth playing (especially at a price point below $15!). The game isn't too bad, but it feels like you have to learn a lot through trial and error. There isn't much in the way of information either inside the game or on the web. I played for 10 hours and I've still barely escaped the initial systems, and mistakes slow things down even further.

As an example- every time you recruit someone the next recruit costs more. So if you have a bad mission, or invasion, and lose a bunch of a staff you are now in a position where replacing each experienced staff member costs increasingly more, and you're replacing fully geared experienced staff with inferior unequipped, untrained versions. This forces even more conservative play as you slowly crawl back up. Game is fun to play even though it feels like early access. I would recommend however to buy the original.
The balance and bugs make the game a bit of a struggle but it remains fun for the most part. What is not fun is the game breaking bugs like resources no longer collecting properly. Great game! no I have to personally say no, so far.

name: Gacha Fever
short_description: Gacha Fever is a suvivors like in a cute and colorful universe. You will fight waves of monsters with various weapons, from the machine gun to the magical girl wand and the Bubble Tea Canon ! Just be careful of the area !
reviews:
A survivor game that is a bit rough around the edges. Multiple UI issues of showing the wrong items when hovering, little feedback as to how much items scale, strange item balance (all items are equal cost. Example of some items: "-2 life, +1% damage" vs "+5% damage, +3% movement speed"), and there's a gatcha option to get random items, but some items I would deem as cursed as they give huge downsides. Pencils for example give -25% damage dealt each, so you can brick a run pretty easily. I totally fell in love with all the mechanics and characters i got from the "gacha", hope more people will find out about this game <3 So much content! An excellent survivors game with lots of characters, tons of weapons, and a cool items / level up system. There are a few issues with spelling or poorly explained items, but the game is very fun to play, and that's what matters most. Absolutely worth the price.  Gameplay loop is fast and aggressive, if unbalanced at times.  Art design matches it well and feels very Paper Mario-esque.  Characters, weapons, and items are all unlocked via account level-up gacha (surprise surprise) so higher difficulty runs feel night and day to hour 1, so mileage may very.
Does exactly what it says on the box, turn off your brain and soak in the bright colors Good Unique Survivors game. Has an outer ring like in Apex or Fortnite that slowly closes as the wave goes on. The Devs are great and not only push updates but actually respond to posts on the forums and patch the game according to player feedback.

<IXOYE>< Gacha, without paying irl money
10/10 Vry cool game, chill, cute, very colorful and fun *-*
Updates that enrich the game Addicting. cute and fun!

name: Midnight Manor
short_description: A short, spooky pick-em-up platformer.
reviews:
It's a fun little game that I knew nothing about going in. It has a eerie/spooky vibe that I liked.

Maybe it's a bit too short? You can replay for multiple endings, but it's a little repetitive because it doesn't really branch a lot and the first part is really the same, I still haven't found one of them.

I just have a few minor criticisms:
- Controls can't be changed? The default keyboard controls are spread out with arrows+tab/q+w+e+space, I usually remap to wasd+hjkl(and/or surrounding keys) layout. I even looked and there's a save.json file, but nothing about keys, unless I'm missing it.
- The platforming has a lot of jump-through platforms that you drop down from with down+jump, and holding them doesn't seem to work so you gotta tap jump, and there doesn't seem to be any (or little if there is) forgiveness for early presses, which can be done by buffering the input.
- The music in one area loops often and it doesn't fade well, sound like it stops and starts over, I think it's the upper level.
 I do like this game. It's affordable and It is short but can be replayed. This is def a speed runner game (not a speed runner myself) so if you're someone who is an achievement collector, buy with caution. You may get frustrated or put hours of replay into it. There are no save points since the game is intended to be played in one sitting and there are no guides or walkthroughs to the under 8 minutes achievements, which is frustrating. I do think with practice it can be achieved. I am not sure if the timer starts again after the first stage even though the timer does continue it's count. It feels impossible to get the under 8 minutes achievement but again I am not a speed runner, this may be different for those who are. Small, but lovely game with some secrets

I enjoyed this game, this is the type where you can fing all endings (and a secret scene?) just doing exploring and trying some ideas. Controls are nice, 2d retro atmosphere, a lot of achievements.
Game is short, but it is making easier to find all endings. ENG:
This pretty good, has a bit of platforming and puzzle, but with very little difficulty, the pixel art looks nice and the music although somewhat repetitive gives good atmosphere, the negative point is that it does not have to save the game so you have to pass it in one attempt, and this for each final, so you have to pass it 4 times.

ESP:
Esta bastante bueno, tiene un poco de plataformeo y puzzle, pero con muy poca dificultad, el pixel art se ve lindo y la m√∫sica aunque algo repetitiva acompa√±a bien la ambientacion, el punto negativo es que no tiene para guardar la partida por lo que hay que pasarlo de un intento, y esto para cada , por lo que hay que pasarlo 4 veces. A nice little game with excellent pixel graphics and polished gameplay. For a price low as 2 EUR, I can only recommend it!

name: Smell like a puddle
short_description: ‚Äî Each of us fell into a puddle. And everyone knows that you can find yourself after that... in a strange place from which there is no escape. Didn't it happen?.. Well, it's nothing ‚Äî it's going to happen soon! You will have to explore your new home... and become a part of it. ^-^
reviews:
Whenever there is an indie game that gets very popular, it almost feels like it creates its own subgenre in a bubble, in this case we have these psychological visual novels, but more specifically games with a sense of existentialism, and maybe a touch of melancholy. Sometimes they can come across as cheap imitation or clones, sometimes they put enough of a spin on it to make something different. I still have not played the progenitor game so I don't know how they compare, I just thought this game was okay for $2, at least compared to other similar games.

It's only about 30-minutes, seems to have 2 endings, one of them being abrupt, if there is another one I am not sure, I got 3/3 achievements so I assume I am done. There are a few small things that can be missed if you don't take the opportunity to click on everything, but beyond that it does not seem like the dialogue choices were that important (outside of that one abrupt ending)

The story has a relatively common theme, you find yourself in a place from which you can't get out, a world in the puddle, or I suppose a mental block, something these games tend to explore a lot. I don't think it's a particularly creative idea, too many games do it, but overall I think the writing wasn't too bad, somewhat playful and a little though-provoking, especially if it's translated from Russian which does not always work that well. On a personal level I wish you added a few other elements to the story beyond its metaphor for a mental state, because like I said, I think too many games go for it, and I wish you had something else going for it.

The art panels were not too bad actually, considering the game is only $2, there was some effort to create a few unique effects and scenes, I actually didn't even think it would go that far after playing a certain Bread game. It still feels like you are going for a similar presentation, but overall not too bad, I think the pacing and the narrative of the game works well enough.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]

(+) For $2 I thought the art panels were decent, I like that you trying to add some weird effects and interactions (not all games do it), and the writing actually wasn't too bad, similar to other games for sure, but it still works for what it is

[h1]Feedback:[/h1]

- Did you intentionally not translate the last part of the game, it's Russian in English and English in Russian

- I was playing with the headphones and I actually found the analog text effects and music a bit painful, I was able to just lower it and work around that way, but just something to keep in mind, that ambient tone you going for isn't bad, just be mindful of it being potentially hard on the ears 

- It's okay to take inspiration from the games you like, but I personally would advice you to separate yourself even further, the games don't seem that similar on a surface, but I personally wish you had a few more angles to the story, something outside of the metaphor for being in a hole

[b]Overall Thoughts: 6/10[/b]

Obviously there is a touch of imitation somewhere there, many games do it, but I still see some nice things, the writing is interesting but I would recommend detaching yourself further from those Milk adjacent games, do something that is fully yours, and that thing you do with interactions and mini games, keep that going, most games won't do it. Also I think adding a few more characters probably would help a lot, I think that interaction with the person at the end was probably the better part of the game.

[code]Niche, obscure and underrated games: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/31294838-Hidden-Gem-Discovery/ [/code]

name: ASSASSINATION STATION
short_description: ASSASSINATION STATION is a dastardly difficult stealth pixel shooter featuring procedurally generated levels, a sky-high skill ceiling, competitive scoring system, and frenetic, smoke-smooth gameplay.
reviews: This game is sooo addicting and is a great time killer. One of my favorite modes is the rodeo mode (currently holding he high score.) The game is not easy either which is good. It does not hold your hand and wants you discover the tactics and the different ways to succeed in each level . The challenge is a great way to change things up and you simply can't get enough of it! The levels were great too I never saw the same map and enemy's in the exact same place. I hope to see more added in the future and great job!

name: Firefight
short_description: Firefight is a World War II real-time simulation game similar in style to the old Close Combat series but brought up to date with better AI, individual soldier modelling, a faster frame rate to give more intense and realistic combat and an easy to use command interface.
reviews:
Great game here. Hard but very fun and has some surprising layers to it. this game is great the dev is still adding and fixing stuff I grew up loving Close Combat, this is better! Much revamped version of the old Sean O'Connor game very much in the vein of the classic "Close Combat" series, but without the same campaign structure and instead offering a series of individual battles and custom battles. Easy breezy controls but with a bunch of mechanical depth and some neat (for a top down, 2D game) ballistic physics. 

There's admittedly some things I miss from the original Firefight, like the generated, linked campaigns, but I understand that it's probably not something that can be so easily done with this engine and higher fidelity maps. Plus the original is still out there, if you know where to look. Coming from Close Combat, I had some difficulty getting used to the different camera system. But now I've put more hours in this game I definitely think this has the potential to be the better game.

I really like the blue indicator to move your infantry troops, it works so well to quickly spread them out. When you zoom in you can really notice how they look for good cover positions.

My favorite moments are when an enemy team is holed up in a house. I pin them with 1 unit and storm the house on their flank with another infantry unit. It all works so well and the firefights are pretty damn cool. Unlike CC, your units can move pretty fast in hurry mode, I really like that.
Often you see a few enemy soldiers panicking and retreating and they get shot as they run away. The AI can be impressive at times.

Definitely worth it for it's price. worth every cent, perfect game and developer is always adding something new very good Very fun and easy to learn but also difficult and requires strategy to do well. Huge amount of content with 27 maps and 8 scenarios for each. Lots of vehicles and different units. This is a great game in principle and ha some really nice attention to detail, but the pathfinding and unit logic leaves a LOT to be desired. This makes matches significantly more difficult because your units die needlessly. For a game of this price, especially one that has been around this long, I really expected it to be more polished and honestly think I'll be refunding unfortunately. 

- Units default to 'careful' movement logic. Commanding a unit to move somewhere doesn't result in them moving there if there's even the slightest amount of action near to them. The only way to make them move is with the 'hurry' command. However if they take too long to move away from the action, the 'hurry' action times-out and they're again stuck there. If I tell a unit to move somewhere, I expect them to do so. This is a game where you are commanding the units but they seem to ignore your commands the vast majority of the time which is incredibly infuriating. 

- Enemy units should at very least ALL be highlighted once engaged. Instead they go invisible and show up and disappear again completely randomly making it very hard to strategise what to do when you have no idea the enemy force size or where they are. Ideally you'd be able to see where the enemy are at all times because currently the first round requires you to send a bunch of infantry out to be ambushed so figure out where the starting locations of enemy are - otherwise your tanks will all be destroyed by the hidden tanks and AT teams - then you restart the match and play normally.

- Mortar teams fire absurdly slow and take multiple rounds to get even remotely close to the designated target. By the time they start getting accurate (5+ minutes of firing at a rate of around 1 round a minute) the targets have moved already. Yet the enemy mortar teams are able to fire off 5 rounds at one time with amazing accuracy. Of course they're invisible though so you'll end up half your infantry destroyed before you can deal with them since they start mortaring you from across the entire map and your own infantry keep ignoring your move commands or moving only when it pleases them, at a snail's pace. 

- Same deal with artillery, takes an age for it to get accurate and the strike itself is not very accurate. 

- Tanks constantly favour targeting infantry even when there is a much bigger threat of another tank right in front of them. This results in you losing a lot of a tanks completely unnecessarily. For some reason they always travel with the turret facing the complete random direction to where the action is as well...why?

- If you slightly adjust your tank's position, it might move, it might not, or it might do a 20-point turn, reverse and drive all over the place to readjust, depends on how random it wants to be. 

- You have zero idea of a unit's effective range. If you command an 'open fire' order at a particular target, you have no idea if the LOS is blocked, or it's out of range etc. Yet enemy infantry manage to snipe you from all the way across the map when your own infantry can't seem to see anything unless it 10 metres in front of them.

- This game has no built-in guide or tutorial other than a brief overview of the controls. When an infantryman gets injured, can he be treated? Is he out of action? Why do tank crews bail out but are then completely uncontrollable? What does the house icon mean on some infantrymen? The tanks constantly fire at enemy infantry in buildings - can they actually cause damage or are they just wasting ammo? Sometime you get reinforcements in the middle of the game, is that because the crews made it back or because they were scheduled? No idea...and the game doesn't tell you.... Rebirth of the old close combat games - its a work in progress but it has real potential

name: Character: Naotora Ii
short_description: Download this to use Naotora Ii in Dead or Alive 5 Last Round. *The Azuchi stage shown in the screenshots cannot be used in this version of the game. *You must have the latest update installed in order to use this content. ¬©2015 Valve Corporation.
reviews:
she has a great combo She's fine af I can't lie This character is very fun to play. Picked up Naotora Li for more strategic options when facing off versus the rest of the roster. She's a competent combatant whom uses mostly flashy kick combos. Ironic considering she wears bladed fighting gauntlets. (Which deceives you into the wrongful assumption she is more of a boxer-type instead. Then you notice the additional blades protruding from her boots. By then it is probably too late!) 

Overall

+Cute and "hawt".
+Humble nurturing personality.
+Apologetic and kindhearted.
+ Comes with a really sexy "beast girl outfit" and a few other alternate fashion choices so if you are happy with that there's no need to buy the more expensive expanded wardrobe bundle.
+ Holds up well with the rest of the roster. (Is not over-powered nor under-powered.)

Got her during a lunar sale for $3.20 with tax. She's a worthwhile addition but obviously being the OG I am I would have preferred it if she was an in-game unlockable. There's historical context connected to her origins and she made her debut in Samurai Warriors 4.

Oh,and Tecmo Koei? I wish we could make female characters look this beautiful in games like Nioh 2. Have the more realistic character customization for those whom want it but also throw in just a few in-game "sexy" options as well. You know and I know a Nioh 3 with expanded "hawt husbando/hawt waifu" avatar choices would sell like hot-cakes. Look into the pre-orders of Stellar Blade if you need further confirmation! No Momiji How cute, Naotora li apologizes for winning!

name: Lulu's Temple
short_description: Lulu‚Äôs Temple is a mysterious action-adventure about an archeologist venturing deep inside a horrifying pyramid with only his torch and gun to protect him.
reviews:
A short 45 min - 1.25 hr game that is a very competent and difficult at times platformer. It is built around a strong central mechanic and utilizes its limited toolset to its full advantage. Very strong recommendation. This game is charming, fun, casual, and just the right amount of challenge.

There's your gun, and your torch. You can throw your torch and use it to light torches. You can upgrade both and use as multi-purpose items as the game progresses. You go through a mini-platforming game where you solve mild puzzles using your tools.

It's balanced, it's broken up into mini-areas with checkpoints which makes it great for short sessions if you prefer. The mechanics gradually expand as you go, and it's paced well. The sounds, graphics and animations are well-done and cool and appropriate. New monster types and hazards appear as you proceed.

It is a small game, limited in scope. But it also knows it's limits, is crafted with a delicate touch, and nothing overstays it's welcome. It was a refreshing experience. Check out the free game this dev made - it is lovely as well.

This one is worth asking price. Personally I want this dev to have my money. Seems to have received a lot of updates since release, but as of June 12, 2024, Lulu's Temple has received its final update! This makes it a quick and fun ride, lasting about an hour of high-tension exploration and platforming. Using both a gun (that you can charge for a burst of bullets) and a torch (that you can charge to throw at your enemies or to light distant wall-mounted torches) is more fun that you might expect, since you have to juggle between the two to illuminate your surroundings, kill enemies and toggle traps from afar. Having only one life point is a bit rough, but checkpoints are frequent enough that it's never too much of a problem - except for those ninja mummies which can and will get you every single time!

Absolutely recommend getting it, Agelvik does some great short games and deserves more support. It's frequently on sale too :) my game I grew quite fond of the little games of "Agelvik", and "Lulu's Temple" is a solid and somewhat visceral package of a fairly challenging pixel-action-adventure that can be beaten in 1-2 hours.
The darkness-mechanic and the constant use of light sources really sets the tone and the gameplay and works really well. 
Worth some bucks and an easy and short recommendation for genre-fans!
[spoiler] And the derpy face of the archeologist at the ending screen is priceless! [/spoiler] This is a really solid game.  Nice bite-sized levels, very good music, and a fantastic aesthetic.  Well done to the authors.  Looking forward to the next one. short but enjoyable platformer with some combat. Keeps up a good pace and ends in about 2 hours. works great on Deck
 A fun and short adventure that anyone can complete in 1-2 hours and is absolutely worth the $5 asking price. I was pleasantly surprised with the game! fun enough and brief, but incredibly weird tonally. 

game culminates in an offensive last boss which is impossible to overlook in how gross it was. It's neat, short and sweet so not too much to expect. The whole lighting gimmick is neat, though starts to feel more annoying towards the end. Since it's so short it finishes before being a real frustration luckily. Grab if you want a quick little dungeon platformer with a neat gimmick.

name: Angry Birds VR: Isle of Pigs
short_description: Join Red, Chuck, Bomb & the Blues to save the stolen eggs in Angry Birds VR: Isle of Pigs, an immersive VR adventure! Discover the island where the greedy pigs vacation, slingshot your way to defeat Dr. Frankenswine & create/share/discover an infinite number of levels with the online level builder.
reviews:
epic Fun, and Fun, and Tons of Fun. Fun game I've lost count of how many times this game's progress has vanished and I need to start from the beginning again. 
Really destroys the fun out of it. IT HAD MY BRAN EXPLODE Angry Birds VR: Isle of Pigs is one of the best mobile to VR conversions that I've played. Putting Angry Birds in 3D does so much for the gameplay, and the level editor is a completely unnecessary but fantastic edition. Resolution Games genuinely cooked with this. It's baffling that I'm saying this about an Angry Birds game, but this might be one of my favourite VR games. I had a few of the Jenga licensed Angry Birds Star Wars sets when I was younger, and Isle of Pigs feels a lot like playing with those did.

The third dimension adds a lot more variables to collisions and physics than the original Angry Birds, which does make some levels feel a little bit like RNG, but this is basically my only issue with the gameplay. I didn't aim for 3 stars on every level, so this didn't bother me as much as it might've otherwise.

Technically, the game runs great. I played it at 220% res on my RTX 3060 (because why not) and maintained a consistent 90FPS throughout. It's an incredibly simplistic game visually, but the art style is really nice.

My only technical gripe with the game is that the level editor floor appears somewhat hazy, because an effect applied to this floor isn't mirrored correctly between both eyes. This doesn't massively detract from the experience though, and isn't present in the main game at all. The level editor is really impressive and intuitive regardless.

Isle of Pigs is somewhat pricey for its length, but every VR game seems to be now. I think it's worth the price that it often goes on sale for, but I got it even cheaper than this due to the fact I had Acron: Attack of the Squirrels from a Humble Bundle. it doesn't matter how many times you play angry birds,you always play with a smile on your face and chuckle to yourself. One of the all time great games, so simple yet sometimes so hard. Good for when you have a spare ten minutes. 10 out of ten You have a slingshot and you shoot birds with it at green pigs that live in forts. Not much else to the game as far as I can tell. My only complaint is that the birds don't seem very angry. They wave at you kindly before you smash them against various building materials. The pigs are the angry ones since you're firing high velocity birds at them. It should be called Angry Pigs.

 I've gotten this game awhile ago, but still love to come back to it once in a while. This game works great with the minimum requirements (GTX 970), and had a blast! Would recommend. ITS A DREAM COME TRUE!!!!!!!

best game oat

should get goty for the next 10 yrs

Hope this hekps ;} Funny German Dinos. The attention to detail and historical accuracy is surreal, some of the best I've seen. I even dug up my great grandfather to show him and even he approves. Great Job Devs!!! Very fun! Most Authentic WW2 Shooter
10/10 historically accurate I Fully recommend this game

its 13 years old but its a bloody classic

as of time of writing its on sale for 90% off.

if you want some fun with freinds id get it VERY GOOD GAME, i RECOMMEND Super dead game now but get it with ur buds and play for a good week or two. Super fun, classic old valve source engine vibes with plenty of classic stock sounds and sick visuals. Also I get heavy nostalgia from watching people like TheGamingBeaver play this game right around its peak back in 2014-15 Hervorragendes Spiel, sehr empfehlenswert.

name: Sherlock Holmes Consulting Detective: The Case of the Mummy's Curse
short_description: The London Times started it all ‚Äì calling the murders the work of an ancient Egyptian curse. I accused the tabloid of capitalizing on the superstitions of the populace. Yet, three men were dead, with the wrappings of a 4000-year old mummy binding their fates together.
reviews:
great game! loved it. I wanted to like this game, as I'm a fan of anything Holmes and enjoy old FMV games, but there really isn't much of a game here. It's an odd game that rewards you for playing as little of it as possible. You get a better score the less "clues" you need to solve the case, which functionally equates to you NOT following every lead or interviewing every suspect / expert. This might work well for the board game, but makes you feel like you are skipping most of the video game to get the best score (and the associated achievements).

If you can get past this, many of the FMV scenes are charming and the costuming is nice. But you can easily finish this "game" (more of an interactive movie, really) in well under an hour. I would only recommend picking it up on sale or as part of a bundle if you're curious, but it's a pretty shallow experience overall. Not much here, but for a Sherlock completionist, might be worth a couple dollars just to see what it's about. really enjoyed the FMV scenes, and found it overall very charming! but the game itself leaves a lot to be desired, very short and the solution is obvious. 
 Check it out if you enjoy Sherlock Holmes or cheesy FMV games but i wouldn't really recommend it for anyone outside of that demographic  ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø I have to give it a negative review, because of the subtitles not working and some other bugs. In this game you have to pay good attention to what is being said by eyewitnesses and suspects. The sound quality isn't good enough to hear exactly what names are being mentioned; so subtitles are really needed to find the next person you want to interview. There also seems to be quite a lot of side stories that are ignored by the game and where you don't get any satisfying answer to what was going on. I really appreciate having these episodes of early 90s FMV available on a modern platform and wish I'd played them earlier.
Are they perfect games? Not at all. Without the achivements popping up when you find the required clues, figuring out the optimal solution would be very tiresome. Typical 90s extending the gameplay through trial and error.

But it is worth it to explore the different performances and cute little side stories. I give the games a lot of credit for letting you follow useless clues way further than you need.
Tho I see no real reason to split it up into 3 games, and thus will review them as one.

[b][u]The Case of the Mystified Murderess[/u][/b] - 
By far the strongest of the offerings, even if the solution is very silly.
It has more complex storytelling and avenues to explore, and the actors you talk with in this one are some of the strongest performances. You also get to solve both crimes related to the case.

[b][u]The Mummy's Curse[/u][/b] - 
In the middle, it has the least requirements to solve the case, and leaves out one of the biggest clues from the required scenes.
It also keeps bringing up a side-plot that goes nowhere and has no resolution (tho we can assume who the culprit is). But it relies on context clues and reading the newspaper more like a puzzle, and the murderer is pretty fun.

[b][u]Tin Soldier[/u][/b] - 
I find this the weakest of the 3 cases for 2 main reasons - we solve it not through dialogue but through exploring an empty room, and getting to that clue is a massive reach. Second we just completely ignore a 2nd murder that is directly related to the first. I guess it is not technically required to solve the case, but it is unforgivable that even if Holmes does visit both [spoiler]Matin[/spoiler] and [spoiler]the Count [/spoiler] and is told straight up [spoiler]Vladimir killed Matin to get the ruby back[/spoiler] he never reports it to anyone.
I do appreciate that we are allowed to visit all the surviving lottery ticket holders, and will give it credit for having probably the most grounded motive of the 3.

I reccommend these 3 episodes to anyone interested in FMV games and schlock, and wants to play just to experience all the different performances and actors. It is not worth it at all if you want to play just to get a good score. Everything plays out well in this game except the scoring system. Recommended overall not my kind of game style First of all - remember this is a 6 year old game, utilises videos and text instead of animation, and covers a single case!

Now that's out of the way... it's short, but not bad for a single session of gaming.  If you enjoy the board game (221B Baker Street, etc) or the interactive movie version of Clue, then you'll enjoy this one.  It's a lot of reading, picking out the relevant names and following up only on those.  As it's 'demerit point' based, you want to have as low a score as possible - so visiting the cheese shop is really unnecessary (yes, I went to the cheese shop!).

Is it as good as the other SH games?  No - I liked animations and various dialogue options.  But that's not to say that it's not worth playing in its own right, as long as you think of it as a board game with videos (which are coming back in vogue, I  hear...) Great fun, more complex than I expected. You just need to not worry about your score.
They have made real effort re mastering thre video. No. Just no. I have hard times calling this a game, but whatever. Flaws in it are multifold, lets just go down a list.
First, there is no handling of physical evidence. Everything is done by dialogues.
Second, there is no hint of action. Be it chase, escape from locked room or trap, fight with perpetrator... These are part of Holmes universe! Yes, I know, the whole budget was consumed by shooting FMV sequences with live actors, I have no problem with that. But that leads to most catastrophic flaw: The goal of this game, inasmuch there is one, is to solve the crime with least possible amount of actual investigating! If you go around and interrogate people in your directory, you are presented with extremely condescending end, calling you "armchair detective". Which is EXACT OPPOSITE of what it should mean!
A.C.Doyle created Sherlock Holmes as tireless investigator, going around days and weeks, investigating, interrogatin and staking out suspects and witnesses, and closing cases with severe sleep deficiency and physical exhaustion. Here, the "correct" end is closing case without any work done!  Speedrun of this game would take literary seconds! I believe the game can be finished with maybe dozen mouseclicks (did not try). 
I am sucker for all things Sherlock and this has NOTHING to do with this character. I am going back to games from Frogware.

name: Rocksmith¬Æ 2014 Edition ‚Äì Remastered ‚Äì Green Day - ‚ÄúWelcome to Paradise‚Äù
short_description: Play "Welcome to Paradise" by Green Day on any electric guitar or bass. This song includes a new Authentic Tone.
reviews: it good

name: Killistar
short_description: Killistar: A 2D/3D sci-fi shoot-em-up remake of the classic arcade game Sinistar.
reviews: This game's going to be worth it if you like arcade style games.. and the soundtrack is really good.. If you are into chasing the #1 score on the leader boards than grab this game.. I challenge you to rank higher than me.

name: Cibele
short_description: Cibele is a game about love, sex, and the internet. You play as a 19 year old girl who has become close with a young man she met in an online game. Her relationship with him heats up, becoming more and more intimate with each phone call and private chat.
reviews:
I don't think it lives up to its own potential, but I still appreciate it for what it is. Another reviewer remarked on the game making them reflect on their own experiences growing up with online gaming, and I felt the same way. It can't be denied that it is at least somewhat compelling, but I feel that it could have done more.

This is less of a "game" and more of a "minimally interactive movie" / "short story told through the medium of 'video game.'"

It's worth checking out, but don't let expectations drag your experience. It's an artistic expression of a very real and vulnerable experience which its composer brings her full Self forward to perform and express, and this takes far more courage to perform than any courage it takes to drag it all down in an anonymous review. not good It's important to know what you're getting into here. This is a very different sort of game. I had wanted to to play Cibele for quite a while after writing an essay on 'Tacoma' in college which Nina was also involved in. Quite simply, Nina Freeman has made an absolute work of art in 'Cibele'. While short, it is sublime. I think she has a lot to be proud of in this title. A marvellous game and I hope to find many more like it. If you are open to becoming immersed in a story of great quality, go for it. Nice little indie game. this is a very special game. it's awkward in all of the right ways to really show what falling in love for the first time in your life looks like at this point. play it if you enjoy vignette style narrative design. voice acting is a little one note though :/ It's more of a short story told through an interactive format. You play as Nina who wants to [spoiler]be in a relationship with some internet loser who has sex with her and then dumps her[/spoiler]. There is minimal gameplay which consists of playing a game within a game which is really just clicking. The entire game consists of clicking and looking at things to let the story unfold. I will not speak to whether or not I recommend this game because it depends what the user is looking for in terms of expectations. It is a pretty odd experience, but I do appreciate that video and photographic elements are incorporated into the piece as it adds an element of authenticity and vulnerability in a unique way. It's not really a "game" but more of a "short movie" with minimally interactive parts. The story does not branch, so the interactive part doesn't change anything because there are no real choices to make. It's a single, linear story that takes about an hour to complete.

I bought it on sale for $4.49 and I felt that was still a little high for what I got. meh I love that indies make such *weird* stuff. This game is definitely unusual.

It's a walking simulator, except, instead of walking setting the pace, beating up grindy mobs in an MMO sets the pace. So, as the pacing mechanic, each act has you control your character to team up with your romantic interest to kill multiple small mobs, in order to be able to attack a boss, which you have to fight three times in each act to kill it. While fighting, you also hear the audio of voice chatting with them as you play together.

Interspersed with this are text messages, emails, and images sent to you by friends. Through this multimedia approach, the story is told. It's not a great or deep story. It's just the story of someone's first online relationship, banal as that might seem.

There are reviews saying this is the worst game people have ever played... and I can totally see that, if they were expecting a game. It's not a game, really, any more than any other walking simulator. So as a game, it's utterly lousy.

But, as a story, it's also a genuinely lousy, tedious, bland, banal story. 

The plus side?
1) It's relatively short, maybe a couple of hours of clicky grind at worst.
2) It's an interesting approach to storytelling by an indie game dev, and I love how out of the box the thinking was with it, even if the implementation was pretty awful; bland, tedious and buggy. There's no "save" option, and when it crashed in the middle of the third act, and I restarted it, it had be restart from the beginning of that act.
3) It's allegedly a "based on real life", and I felt that believable. The art, photos, dialog, etc feel "real" (because they are without exception utterly crap, as real life typically is), as if the developer just took images from that time from their hard drive, and used them as the game's graphical assets. That makes the game feel somewhat voyeuristic, like poking around someone's hard drive or email. That, the "slice of real life" aspect, is what just barely redeems it.

So, it's a terrible game, used to deliver a terrible story, with terrible assets (apart from the music, which is not my thing, but at least not technically awful). A lot of its sales are probably from the "nudity" tag (there's no significant nudity: a little cleavage but no nipples or genitalia). It's about as devoid of eroticism as a soap opera, and I don't mean the fun Latin-American kind, I mean EastEnders on its most boring days.

AND YET... I don't regret the time I spent playing/watching this, because from a game design point of view, it was a really interesting idea, and because it felt like someone telling a simple story about their own life, in a heartfelt way. Sure, it's not a "five stars, 95%, must play" game. But it's also not a "700 hour commitment" game. It's a casual, indie narrative game, and within that niche, it's more "okay" than "bad".

So, cautiously, I recommend the game. I have mixed feelings about this game. On the one hand, I'm glad it exists. It's cool to see different kinds of games, different stories. I'm always in favor of pushing on the boundaries of what games are and what kinds of stories they can tell. As others have mentioned, it's a very cringey game, but that's sort of the point. It feels very real in that way.  

On the other hand, there's not much here. It's a very *small* story, and one that at times lacks depth. It feels like a first draft in many ways. Some interesting ideas, well-delivered, but incomplete. 

I'll tenatively recommend Cibele as a game that tries something different. Is it ultimately successful? I'm not sure that it is, but I think this is a place where it's worth rewarding points for trying.

name: MIBT
short_description: Help the government agents in black thong to end the alien threat and the invasion of the machines. 1 or 2 players. Individual and cooperative. Gamepad compatible. Demo available.
reviews:
Game that has kept me entertained in the last hours, that parodies the MIB saga. In reality each stage is overcome in the same way, obtaining 20 X, which are thrown by enemies when falling. But each stage is different, with different traps, and different enemies are added, that shoot, that move faster, with shields ...
It can be played in solo or cooperative mode.
7.5 / 10
