name: Tales of Kenzera‚Ñ¢: ZAU
short_description: Wield the dance of the shaman. Reclaim your father‚Äôs spirit. Brave the beautiful and treacherous land of Kenzera with the God of Death in Tales of Kenzera‚Ñ¢: ZAU, a metroidvania-style adventure crafted by Surgent Studios.
reviews:
What a fantastic and emotional game.

Tales of Kenzera: ZAU does a lot to make itself stand out from a lot of similar games. First and foremost, the world is wholly unique, influenced by African (specifically Kenyan, if I am remembering correctly, apologies if not) culture, land and people. I can count on maybe one hand and a finger the number of games that fully embrace and wear these influences so loudly and proudly and as a result anyone going into this game should find the world refreshing and new, something vibrant and loud and intensely personal.

It is a beautiful game, letting colors splay proudly across it. As a smaller game, it will not have the most top of the line graphics but aesthetic and art direction have always and will always be more important than how realistic something looks. The environments are varied and colored wonderfully and the portrait art is absolutely gorgeous.

The story is going to be quite emotional; the creator has stated outright it was made in dealing with the death of his father and whoo boy, can you feel it. But even if you were to divorce the impetus and reasoning for it's creation from it, it tells a wonderful story with great characters and story beats. I have to give credit where due, the voice actors knocked it out of the park. So much of what works with the story is because the people voice acting the characters had so much range and emotion. While I cannot comment on the original Swahili language I have little doubt it is just as excellently acted due to phenomenal voice direction.

Gamewise, while it has much in common with Metroidvanias, I honestly think it has more DNA with platformers. Sure there's leveling, abilities and slowly unlocking areas because of them but there is definitely a strong concentration on movement and making difficult twists and turns in areas. Even in combat, movement is extremely important and you have a ton of ways to do so. I'd say that movement is incredibly satisfying, as you learn abilities and open up more ways to leap and run. Controls are responsive and for the most part I can't think of any issues around floatiness or missed inputs.

It's a shorter experience but I'd rather a game didn't overstay it's welcome if it did all it needed to do in the time it had. Heartily recommend this game, well worth the experience. I'll give the game a recommends because this was not a horrible experience. This is probably a wait for sale kind of experience though. It is a metroidvania-light. Kind of baby's first metroidvania. The core elements that make a metroidvania are there but in their most rudimentary form. It is an extremely short experience with more of a focus on its narrative. It's overall not fundamentally bad but there are some frustrating design choices that really drag down the experience. 

I am more of a gameplay andy and dont really care much about narratives. This was one serviceable to deliver the game, but by itself doesnt really bring anything that would make that a real draw to the game in my opinion. The protagonist is not really all that likable. The story elements are not overly intrusive though either so I didnt find myself wanting it to just go away and it has an overall good message in the end. 

The game play is decent with just some frustrating flaws. The combat in this game could have been really good. It suffers from some really cheap and borderline unfair enemy AI though. It also has a dodge with no animation cancel, something that just should be a sin in all game design IMO. This is made worse by actions with long wind up animations and/or recovery time between actions, all of which are fully interruptable by enemies. All of this leaves it feeling a little clunky and frustrating. They clearly want you not spamming buttons and making sure you truly want to press that button for every button press you do. The overall design of combat and enemies encounters all seem like they would be better served by a more fluid combat style though. 

Overall it is not terrible and could make for a decent quick palette cleanse between games. There is nothing overly special here though and it suffers from some design/execution flaws in the combat that drag it down. I've played a lot worse though and ultimately did enjoy my time with the game barring some periods of frustration with some of the cheap enemy AI and the "slower than they should be" attack animations. its really bad game the upgrades and fights is bad too bug with camera also from the start to the end its waste of money Zau truly touched me! I thoroughly enjoyed playing this game, having played other metroidvanias, Zau will always have a special place in my heart. A game truly slept on! I wish I could give this game more of an unqualified recommendation, because all of the art surrounding the game is impeccable. The story is well-told, the visuals and soundtrack are beautiful, and all the vocal performances are fantastic.

My big issue is with how this game plays. The combat feels good at first, but as more and more encounters pile on towards the latter half of the game and I start having to navigate enemies, traversal, and instant death traps all at once, the controls start to feel floaty, imprecise, and not altogether up to the task of sustaining even a game this short. Upgrades to each ability path feel insubstantial, the various traversal skills unlocked in each area feel too specialized to be exciting, and the last third of the game in particular is filled with combat rooms that lock until you fight two, three, four waves of enemies. These were perhaps my biggest annoyance by the end, as these kinds of combat rooms should be illegal on their own, but get all the more egregious when you're in a tiny arena and just manage to beat a wave of enemies, and then have a whole second and third wave spawn in when you think you're done. The repetition can get discouraging.

That said, I'm going to recommend this game regardless because the art and world are fascinating and unique, and I do hope this developer gets another shot at a game in this universe, where hopefully they learn to be much more intentional about the combat they decide to include, or even just get rid of it altogether. No game this short should have this many trash mobs, but even beyond that, a world this interesting could be so much better explored through means other than combat. Put more of a focus on traversal, solving problems, meeting interesting characters, and let your game and universe grow into its full potential rather than flounder against the creative limits of exploration through violence. Simple and short Metroidvania with good movement, graphics, story and music.
Movement provides a good sense of speed and flow.
Combat needs more variety and mask balance needs tuning. Blue mask is much more useful than red.
Played mostly on Steam Deck at 45 FPS with Steam Deck preset and XeSS Balanced. I came back to this game some time after they introduced Story mode, which is supposed to be more relaxed than Relaxed mode. But there is still a LOT of difficult, fast-paced fighting in it, which is very disappointing. Why do game developers put so much focus on violence and combat? Why can't we just explore, find things, talk with people and uncover the story without being forced to stop every few seconds to battle it out with fast moving enemies? I want to experience the Metroidvania side of the game but you're making me play Street Fighter. No thanks! Tales of Kenzera: Zau delivers an emotional narrative, elevated by captivating voice acting. The combat system is diverse and offers a compelling level of challenge that consistently keeps the gameplay engaging and enjoyable. Furthermore, the level design is vibrant (check out the backgrounds as you're walking back in most areas), featuring a rich variety of beautifully realized environments that are both visually stunning and narratively resonant. I have a few issues with this game, but most of them are minor. Even though it is a Metroidvania, there really isn't much backtracking too it, which I believe to be a very important part of the genre. When you reach a new area, you can finish that area before going to the next. There is no system for marking something on the map to check out again later. Also the performance is kinda bad for how the game looks, on Steam Deck I had plenty of FPS drops and eventually settled in on a 40fps cap just to keep it from dropping in random spots.

With all that said, the meat and potatoes of this game is not the actually moment to moment gameplay or deep exploration and discovery. Instead, this game is more about the characters and dealing with loss. I knew this going into it, and I was not disappointed. Having lost my father not long ago, I knew this game would hit me in the feels. And it did. But it was a wonderful experience and I definitely recommend the game.

8.5/10 Enjoyed it, fun game

name: Escape From Violet Institute
short_description: 2D sidescrolling 1st Person Survival Horror game
reviews:
This game is from 2020 and doesn't support inverted Y axises and key rebinding. People with disabilities cannot configure this game to a playable one. So sad; I really wanted to play the game as it looked really interesting.
Uninstalled after eight minutes of gameplay and set the "hidden" flag. I really, really want to like this game. The 2d portion shows a lot of potential, and the shift from perspective inside the game proper is well done and keeps you interested in whats going on. 

The game suffers from overly confusing sections during the 3d portion, I in particular had to speak with the dev twice due to getting stuck behind a plant and the game needing to have its collision changed, and another when a scripted event did not properly trigger to kill my character. 

Please dev, if you are reading this if you could post a text or video walkthrough or hint guide or some such it would make it much easier, and less likely for someone to get frustrated and quit because they couldnt figure out what to do.

(also please give a toggle to the bloom in the game, it tends to be overly blinding, and I need to mute the volume since the character walking is so loud.) After a couple of hours of trying and failing to make progress, I think the execution fails to live up to the idea. The 2D section felt quite like aimless wandering, and it was difficult to establish any sense of direction due to the similarity of every environment. The platforming mechanics were fairly rough on top of that.

I got bored before I even reached one of the 3D bits, and I think the disclaimer about the game's difficulty is a bit of a cop-out to make the poor mechanics seem deliberate. It just wasn't fun. I will recommend to play this game at the $15 dollar pricepoint solely because of the immersion. I wont put this on the game at all cause it may be my inability to work a keyboard in to play but it seems a bit rigid on the 2D aspect of things but aside from a few hiccups it does play pretty smooth as far as controls go. I was extremely hesistant and doubted the purchase going through the 2D portion as well but when you get into the 3D side of the game everything seems to click. The game gets that much more exciting (even after reviewing the trailer) and i cant hesitate when I say it gets that much more scary. It is a perma-death type game but i wouldnt let that stop you from checking it out. When the transition from 2D to 3D happened I wanted to know more of what was going on. https://youtu.be/p86FFC5HAQE Brilliant game! Very engaging with a tense atmosphere.

name: Coloring Pixels - Japan Pack
short_description: This Japan-themed book unlocks 20 additional levels for Coloring Pixels! All images are of Japanese icons or Japanese culture!
reviews:
My weeb dollars left my wallet before I even realized what happened... This pack is absolutely worth it, though! Loved this pack! Good pics! The first 10 or 12 images were nothing special. But the last 8 or so were well worth the effort! Overall, an average pack, but good enough to recommend. Another great pack with a large variety of images and colors in each image, with each image being detailed enough to get a lot of enjoyment out of coloring them in.  These are the kinds of packs I was hoping we'd start getting, and I'm glad we are getting them now!  Definite recommend! This pack is honestly crazy good.

It's all very varied, both in colors, shapes, sizes, all that stuff. The images all look really nice too, the art quality is astounding on this one. A lot of pictures also just have fantastic composition, even if they're smaller, which I think is really cool. I literally had fun with every image in this pack except for that one pattern. Point is, this pack is worth your money, easily.

Objective - 5/5;
Subjective - 5/5; Whatever forbidden juice was sipped to make these new packs, I want it. Hope to see more good packs in the future. Another great DLC with some really good pieces of art :)

name: The Dragons' Twilight II
short_description: The Age of Dragons draws to a close, and the ever meddling Elder Dragon, Kaia, won't stop until she rights the atrocities wrought by her own kind. The forbidden resurrection is nearly at hand. What could possibly go wrong?
reviews:
I've played this game before but never finished it.  It was tough but not impossible and I enjoyed it a lot.  I'm looking forward to the third installment of the game. üëç Just a  few days ago I finished the 1st part and now the 2nd.
This is one of those games where you would like to see more....but at the same time it is good that this story is finished.
The best part is that you don't need excessive grinding. apart from an atrocious UI a pleasant little game to wile away a few hours its a great old school rpg the kind i grew up with as a kid and i love the turn based combat Finished it, really liked it. Adapting gear, figuring out which spells work best, side quests, easter eggs... yup, I had a blast. Trust me, I got more than 0.2. Its a nice little party based JRPG. Add to your collection! A must get! 9/10 great story - interesting development  of story - loved the characters- some battles need a lot of strategy to be able to defeat main bosses- a guide would be helpful as would an overall map Not as good as number 1. Still entertaining though. It gets better after the first mountain level. This is a great game for all fans of good RPG-Maker games out there. Like Dragons' Twilight I it includes all you need: quirky characters, an interesting storyline, cute graphics, funny dialogues and fitting music. I especially liked the monster-designs, the crafting system and the myriad of weapons you can get by solving numerous quests. Most bosses are not too easy but not nervewreckingly hard. A little grinding is recommended, but it is minimal compared to other games out there (I hate mindless hour-long grinding, so this was a relief). The last boss is challenging but beatable. Just solve the quests and craft your own stuff mostly and you are good (don't forget to get those crystal keys) :) I enjoyed every minute of Dragons' Twilight I + II and am looking forward to playing 7th Deep. Kudos to the developer of those little gems. Sadly the good RPG-Maker games often drown in the mass of mediocre to outright bad games out there. I had to do quite a bit of digging to find Dragons' Twilight here on Steam. Long story short, I highly recommend playing Dragons' Twilight I+II if you want to have a good time.

Kurzfassung in Deutsch:)
Dragons' Twilight I+II geh√∂ren zu den guten und unterhaltsamen RPG-Maker Spielen mit witzigen Charakteren, putziger Grafik, passender Musik und fairen Bossk√§mpfen. Hervorragend f√ºr Nostalgiker geeignet, die haupts√§chlich wegen der Story spielen und sich nicht in stundenlangem zerm√ºrbendem Grinding verlieren wollen. Ich freue mich immer, wenn ich solche Perlen von kleinen Entwicklern finde, auch wenn man auf Steam manchmal an den Suchvorschl√§gen verzweifelt. Ich hatte auf jeden Fall eine gute Zeit mit beiden Spielen und hoffe Mr. Williams bekommt bald doch noch die geb√ºhrende Anerkennung, um ein weiteres Spiel wie Dragons' Twilight zu programmieren (7th Deep ist weniger RPG und mehr Dungeon Crawling). Spielt es mal an, ihr werdet es nicht bereuen :)

name: Retro Endurance 8bit
genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Racing, RPG, Strategy, Early Access
short_description: Retro Endurance 8bit is a unique retro game collection of 35 games where no two games play alike. It delivers fun reimagining of NES classics with a shuffler/randomizer story mode, an arcade mode, special gameplay events, challenge modes, and more!
reviews:
Requested a refund. I'm older and I love retro games, but this is like if Action 52 was worse and switched games every few seconds. I'm not downvoting it because someone may like it, but it is not at all what I want to play. Just give me the full games to play, if they even exist... So addictive! Could not stop playing, played 4 hours straight and then the evil spider boss showed me not to be so cocky! Would heartily recommend this mini game extravaganza, the dev is very active too, plenty of meaty updates A lot of fun for the current asking price. If you like WarioWare or NES Ultimate Remix, you'll enjoy this. Cool little time-waster with a ton of variety I love this game. it's like wario ware with retro-like games. plenty here for a early release and very impressive it's made one dev. it's a shame though that when you play the games without the "rush" you get a timed amount in which you could play them. would be cool if they were short games but had little endings. Similar to UFO 50, but this is much more fun than that title (IMO of course). It's a Early access game so it's limited and more content is sure to follow. The early Famicom music is spot on (Even that high pitchness of games like legend of kage). Game looks the part, my only complaints would be the control is either too stiff or slippery and the fact that the stand alone versions are timed because there are some bangers on there I wish were full experiences, but that's asking WAY too much for one person. To put it simply If you love 8 bit retro games and wario ware rush then you would be wrong to not get this. Even at it's current state, it's a lot of fun. I love NES classics and micro-mini game challenges, this is the best of both worlds. 

Almost all of the games are worth your time. At the time of writing there's 27 microgames currently available. Challenges inspired by Punch Out, Gradius, Zelda, Mario, Mr. Driller, Bomberman, Dragon Quest, and many many more keep everything feeling fresh after hundreds of runs. Eventually you can disable a few games, allowing you to tailor the experience a little. 

What's here is great. I can't wait to see what improvements the solo dev comes up with over time. Just so much fun! I don't think there is a dud in here! This is a very fun idea that plays better than the mini games have any right to. 
Wonderful on the steam deck as well. Very fun little set of games that also gets pretty challenging in the later stages. Cool idea seemingly inspired by NES shufflers. So far the ideas are well-made, if a bit floaty.

robot mommie

It has daily challenges and leaderboards which is dope.

Not it gets only one thumb up. Oh Boy...... This game is very simple and very fun. Great for relaxation until, however, it gets chaotic.

name: ESCHATOS
short_description: An alien menace has descended on Earth! Defend the world from UFO invasion in this superb arcade shooter from Qute. Use your weapons effectively, deflect enemy bullets with your shield, and recapture the Moon from alien infestation!
reviews:
Really fun shmup with some fire tunes. Leveling up for the extra options is my only peeve, but it doesn't really matter at the end of the day. One of my favorite games of all time <3 I don't know what it is about this shump. It's not ground breaking or really all that challenging. But I can never be in a bad mood playing it. In my opinion this is one of the finest shooters ever made. The balance and progression is so well executed, and the music is incredible. tbh i only bought this because the music is kickass as all hell but i forgot how much fun schmups are and i want to get into that genre some more Eschatos is a miracle "video games aren't art" mfers when they reach area 12: good soundtrack. i don't know what i'm doing! Shmups are an oddity of a genre. A niche genre known for having Dark Souls levels of difficulty and being all about repeatedly failing again and again until you've learned how to dance to the genre's at times maddening tunes. It's one of the oldest genres in gaming, having its roots in the arcades of the 70s. That arcade heritage where the genre got its obsession with extreme difficulty. 

A genre as fixated on being extremely difficult as shmups to the point that some of the games are described as "dodging a rain of death" or a "bullet hell" can be a little difficult to get into. So where does one start if they wanna give the genre a go? Well, Eschatos is a pretty good place. 

Eschatos is not a very lengthy game. A whole run through the game will take you less than 30 minutes. But there's the beauty in the genre. Even on the easiest difficulty Eschatos will give you a challenge, it even inches into bullet hell territory at times. But you'll get the hang of the dance. And when you do, there's higher difficulties waiting. There's alternate modes waiting. There's online leaderboards to compete with the world. You can dance to Eschatos' tunes again and again and eventually master it. 

It's also quite pretty. Visually, Eschatos looks like it escaped from the Dreamcast. A system that's known for quite clean visuals. There's a great soundtrack and a just cool arranged version of said soundtrack. 

In short, TLDR, ETC: A great gateway drug to the shmup genre. tl;dr: this game is the real deal, buy it. interested in shmups at all? buy it. recurring veteran in search of lesser-known games? buy it.


ESCHATOS is kinda an odd bird. First of all, it's a game made by a [i]healthcare company[/i] out of all things, and second of all, it's a port of an X360 game, well out of the shoot-em-up genre prime. So what gives? Is this shovelware? Certainly looks like it, right?

Surprisingly, no, because ESCHATOS was clearly made by people who really, REALLY know what makes shoot-em-ups tick. First, for a shmup to tick, it must have a great soundtrack - no exceptions - and Yousuke Yasui (the composer) cooked up an iconic soundtrack. Super catchy to the point where people who normally don't play shmups know about it.

Well what about gameplay - judging by the screenshots, it's some sort of bullet hell? No, actually! A lot of shmups at the time patterned themselves off bullet hells, but ESCHATOS is really not one - it gives you a shield that you can smash through any pattern that's too dense anyways. More than anything, ESCHATOS feels like it has the heart of a classic 80's Toaplan game (e.g. Truxton/Tatsujin) down to the high player speed, space-based excuse plot, stupidly catchy soundtrack, and memo-heavy gameplay.

As that would suggest, speedkilling enemies and midbosses by memorizing where they come from is the name of the game. Switching between your front and wide shot is a big part of the gameplay (enemies tend to come at you at weird angles, not just the top of the screen, so it's a pressing question at all times), but the real interesting part is the aforementioned shield. It pulls double duty as a super-damaging melee weapon and a tool to break through bullet patterns you can't dodge in between. Scoring well is a matter of not letting enemies go off-screen, which means (you guessed it) playing the game over and over again.

However, ESCHATOS is a game that I am more than happy to play over and over again. No checkpoints, no powering down after you die, no speed-ups (you can control your speed at will), and most of all, it's just plain fun. It's very easy to get into this perfect flow state dodging enemies and bullets: the mark of a great game.

The one thing that the game really lacks on is its 3D graphics. Allegedly, this game started as a DirectX graphics pet project before being turned into a commercial release, and uhhhhhh it shows. Very strange art direction with a lack of cohesion (I like weird art direction, but I want a little explanation as to why 1950's tin saucers are accompanied by biblically accurate angel midbosses), and at worst, when the game decides it wants a cinematic angle for its stage, it gets very hard to judge depth for some projectiles and even bosses that ostensibly appear to be background objects (That boss has CONTACT DAMAGE at THAT DEPTH????). I will admit that despite all of this, it [i]mostly[/i] works, and there's an impressive amount of scale and movement between areas for a budget studio's first 3D game.

The game's biggest selling point may be that it's a great game for beginners: if you're curious about the genre, [b]start here.[/b] The difficulty selection is well curated (an easy easy mode, how about that? plus a normal mode that isn't a slouch), and for people who really, really want to sink their time into this game, there's a nightmare-equivalent harder-than-hard mode that looks plain impossible, as well as two extra arrange-ish modes that offer cool takes on the basic game. The game does a good job at gently nudging you to get a 1CC (doing the whole thing on one "coin") which I like a lot: no disservice is done to the genre more than giving off the impression that these games have historically been impossible coin-eaters that only the deepest of wallets can see the end of. You can learn these, trust me!

All things considered, ESCHATOS is really the little game that could: a weird little 7th gen XBLA release that IMO belongs in the pantheon of all-time great shmups. Even at full price I'd say this is a must-buy. Go play ESCHATOS. Trust me when I say that this game is HARD. Even on the lowest difficulty setting, this game still gets pretty intense later on. Despite that, it's still quite fun and rewarding. ESCHATOS is by the same developer behind Judgement Silversword: Resurrection and as a result, it has similar gameplay mechanics. I do however feel that this game is a considerably better experience overall. The soundtrack is also amazing here. Overall, this is an easy recommendation for shmup fans.

name: Prodigy Trainer
short_description: A young warrior seeks to learn the ways of darkness. In order to do so, she must gain your trust and respect.
reviews:
60/100 This game does not work. Crashes every time you attempt to interact with anything in it. Scam. Sadly this game sucks, must be one of their first games. DO NOT waste you money, this is an abandoned game without patches or anything useful from the dev's other than cashing their checks. May the force be with you .. I am giving a poitive review while the game is at about 1.5$ or 1.5‚Ç¨, but it is in my opinion not worth more.
Buy it only if you are a Star Wars fan and want some fun out of the SW universe.

+ There are good traits of humor from the MC who is supposed to be a "dark side" lord,
* there is a pseudo storyline which you must grind through to progress, and NO IT IS NOT BUGGED ; you just have to do other activities, including training of your student/padawan, to let her progress in her (two) skills before your griding has further effect.
+ the face of the padawan/student is nicely done (at least for my taste) during the BJ and S‚Ç¨x animations, where she rolls her eyes, lean her head and do other sensual things making the animations more lively and attractive

- story IS short..
- most of the progress/events are just stills, images,
- you don't get any steam achievement, or galery, or other things you usually get with a renpy. I believe that game was made with Unity because of the way it looks, by a young unskilled but fairly creative and kinky developper..
- some of the protagonists you meet would deserve a bit of "action", but the dev didn't provide the option.
- when the story is full done, you don't even have a message that there is nothing else to do ; you knocked your padawan and she is pregnant and has max skills, then I did not find anything else after to do except to repeat griding for cash.
- if you are stuck with the password to find during a quest, either look in the forum discussions, or try any of the suggested words going back and forth (I won't write it here, no no, do your research.. it's not so hard),
- if you threaten the nighclub manager as Rake asks you to in the game, it will give one option to get BJ for free at night by Rake's slave but it locks away the option to have your student work as an exotic dancer in the nightclub.. you get no clue that this will have an impact on your options, neither do you later get an option to have your padawan work there anyway, even if you can buy the nightclub outfit.

In short, only buy when on sale as right now at 1.50$ its meh The references of a certain War of the Star is as subtle as an arrow to the knee... at Mach 9...

Basically a waifu raising game where you raise your "Dark not-Sith waifu" where you can either be indifferent, caring or just be a plain human garbage to her to prepare her to face the self righteous not-Jedi Master she used to train under.

Some of the seggs scenes are animated and there was no clear hints on how you should clear each mission. 

The VN game kinda bugged out on me since I find myself stuck after clearing the Final Mission. Without any hints on how to proceed from that point, Players might find themselves stuck in a loop of; send her to various jobs at day and do "things" with her at night, rinse and repeat the next day. This BORING loop is DEADLY for the pacing of this kind of adult themed VN game where this loop gets OLD, VERY FAST.

Well, I guess it's an okay adult VN game. Nothing bad nor noteworthy to make it stand out. Not all of the scenes are even viewable. The floor scrubbing never progresses past 2/4. I think this is a good premise with flawed execution. My mediclorians didn't really tingle with this one.
This is another great premise with lackluster execution.
Sadly not the chosen one that brings unbalance to my force.
If you think my writing is bad, you are in for a treat, this game's writing is worse. 
Also the game was buggy for me and the scenes didn't really feel stimulating on top.

My main char Darth Douche was more of pansy than the most powerful dark lord in the universe.
I miss choices, even meaningless ones that add flavour.

The attempts of humour are so shallow they almost work for a pornographic visual novel but I feel like the game is missing cheesy aggressive dirty talk and more action.
Example: Darth Douche has to convince a museum's librarian he is smart by solving her questionnaire instead of using his nigh unlimited dark powers to make her clothes disappear.

That and many more missed opportunities await you, should you play this game.
May the force be with you, it certainly wasn't with this game.

name: GENIE
short_description: Explore fantastic environments as Lula, as she journeys to discover the meaning of the Genie and fulfill her destiny.
reviews:
After completing Genie, I can say I have played every game Tonguc Bodur has put out. Every. Last One. I'm pretty sure I haven't given a single other one of his games a negative review, but I cannot recommend this one. The music, environments, and voice acting are all great. But the gameplay loop...gets repetitive and uninteresting after a couple of chapters, and there are 15 chapters. The fact that this loop involves looking into a blinding white light, a light that made me physically look away every time, was utterly terrible. I muted the game audio and watched a movie while trying to earn the achievements (I had to stop because somehow one of the chapter's game audio was playing despite the master volume and all other volumes being muted). I might have actually read more of the poems if the pacing was not so slow, and if the whole poem appeared at once like most of Tonguc's games. The story was just not engaging enough to warrant the tediousness and slow pacing. I got this on sale for $0.99 and I still feel like it wasn't worth it. The story was drug out far longer than it needed to be, and not in a meaningful or engaging way like most of Tonguc's games. Get it on sale if you decide to get it at all. Honestly, just check out some of Tonguc's other games, as many of them are actually really great. Just not this one. Bought this game as soon as it came out.  Hit a snag in chapter 2 that caused me to drop it for a while.  Picked it up again the other day, finished all the way until the end.  Game was tedious at times and too wordy, but I remembered the excerpts from the classic 'Drizzlepath: Genie'.  Was also entranced by some of the visuals this time -- places worth exploring.  Wish Chapter 9   was a whole game by itself, a few others.  Look forward to other titles by this same author, games do surprise me. It was this one winter day I opened Steam
Scrolled down my wishlist out of theme
Stopped my movement for once or two
Just to sneeze my nose due the flue
The list must have had games I no longer needed
Despite of this I further proceeded
It must have been more than a hundred games I passed
Appeared the thing which I waited at last
Tags of Walking Simulator and Atmospheric it wore
Bodur's name as its maker and price discounted

No longer I dared to wait
but slightly open my wallet for a coin or pair
Few moments I have spent to play it
Writing a poem as a review I see fit

Genie's gameplay value is medium as its best
But I'd be fool to decline it has put my mind to rest
So if you want to take a break and a moment of stop
Then Genie won't be a jiff destined to flop

However to make sure not praise the game too much and call it genius
For many can write a poem or a book of them and that should be obvious A must have for any Tonguc Bodur fan. This is one of the better ones! First, I'm a fan of this dev's games and have played and enjoyed many of them. 

Genie, as with all of Bodur's games, is filled with beautiful environments to explore. And as described on the game's store page, Genie is 15 chapters of traveling through different environments, collecting shards and then locating platforms where you stand and listen to the story in poetry form.

Rinse, repeat ‚Ä¶ 15 times.

The dev does give you the option to fast forward through the narration and by about midway I was thankful for that option. 

If you haven‚Äôt tried any of Bodur‚Äôs games, I would recommend most of them if you‚Äôre a fan of the walking sim genre and if you enjoy taking screenshots; Bodur‚Äôs games are filled with lots of excellent opportunities to capture some nice shots.

However, there are better options from this dev than Genie. The gameplay loop in this is simply awful. It consists of wandering around the small and often cluttered environments searching for crystals. Then when you have collected all the crystals you get to wander the environments again looking for these glowing discs on the floor. When you step on the disc you go into this black and white night vision mode where you get to search around again, but this time for a light. Stare into it. Go blind. Then get a narrated bit of prose for the narrative, which often seems nonsensical, as if it was put together for the sake of rhyming, but has no real meaning. It's bland, boring and repetitive. It's not fun on level 1. I wanted to stop before before I had finished the graveyard that is level 2. This atrocity repeats 14 times, as there are 15 levels!

The environments are pretty, but feel lifeless and empty. They don't feel like they naturally connect in any way either. I didn't feel like I was on a journey at all. I felt like I was being shoehorned from one tiny cluttered box to another tiny cluttered box over and over again. All the while the story is being told me. Show it don't tell it! This is a video game! The worst offender is the final level when you are at the genie. The discs that give the narrated text just keep appearing over and over. It's insanely drawn out. Shit or get off the pot! Say what you're going to say and then leave. Don't overstay your welcome, which this does. The music is all over the place too. None of it felt appropriate or added to the atmosphere. Playing through this was a chore. At 2.4 hours I beat the game and got all the achievements. There is no reason to replay this, not that you'd want to anyway. It's not worth a first play through. AVOID!!! I loved everything about this one except the mind numbing repetitive slog to hear each piece of poetry. I began to hate this game by chapter 5, I qave up in disgust by chapter 7. Find gems. Trigger checkpoint. Stand on checkpoint. Go blind. Read story. Repeat til chapter's end. Repeat until finished.

It's an ok walking simulator, but I'd have rathered find things on a path to unravel the tale than how it progresses here. The progression here actually got really boring for me by chapter two as well. Can't say a great walking sim if you want something with substance. If you want something to relax with before going to sleep or something nice to do with your child to help them nod off, Genie does make for a good interactive bedtime story

That said I can't really suggest Genie with so many other walking sims that exist and manage to pull you into the story far better than this does. I'm not sure why Drizzlepath: Genie needed a remake, but here we are. You "play" as Lula, who is some lady I guess. You wish you could run around the map as you look for some random crystals. When you find enough, you stand on some little magic stone thing that reads you "poetry." I guess the crystals are of the amphetamine variety because I don't know how else you could come up with those verses. There's scarcely ever an attempt at meter, the diction is embarrassing, and the rhyming is dismal: some of my favorites are "melodic/romantic," "true/true," and "kids/eccentric." The voice acting of all the poetry is a mixed bag. On one hand, she definitely read all the lines correctly. On the other hand, she sounded like she was narrating a cheap kid's show on Channel 4. I think that's the only channel they have over there, anyway, so I'm sure they play kid's shows.

The graphics and music are bog standard for a Tonguc Bodur walking simulator. If you like how those things are in any of his other games, you'll like them here, and vice versa. For the uninitiated, you are in for some really detailed environments full of licensed assets that don't make a whole lot of sense together. Here this game really shines through: about half the maps just look nothing like the rest of the game and make no sense in the context of what story there is. It appears that some of the maps were designed around certain asset packs, and not in a fun surreal way either. Oh, and you get a LOT of gigantic statues in the background because why not. The music generally sounds kind of bored, but at least the kind of music playing is switched up enough to not be completely mind numbing.

The story is what really gets me, though. I won't spoil the ending, though suffice it to say that those familiar with Drizzlepath: Genie aren't in for any shockers. Anyway, you play as Lula, who lives in a village run by shamans. They need to get to a genie before a wizard does in order to gain free will. The rest of the story progression is subtle, overwrought variations on banal family themes and Enlightenment ideas. Basically, the traditions and belief systems of the past are lame, and instead you should believe in nothing and start running civilization on the fuel of "just be good because." Life is important because it's an interesting coincidence and that's it. If any of the themes mentioned are interest to you, I suggest The Talos Principle or The Fall Parts 1 and 2, by the way.

Ironically, this game just completely convinced me of the physical reality of both purgatory and hell.

I can't decide whether I'm more grateful that there weren't any collectibles to get or disappointed at how the one shred of gameplay in most of these was stripped out.

TLDR: you only use WASD to move, one button to skip poetry slam cutscenes, and one button to interact. I got all the achievements and only used the interact button twice. It's fine I guess, a bit too repetetive though.

name: Exoprimal - Exoprimal Survival Pass Season 3: Premium Tier
short_description: These special rewards let you get more out of the wargame!
reviews:
[h1]The worst Pass to this day[/h1]

Please Capcom, stop allowing devs to get help from their chidren to choose colour-schemes for the skins in this game. Most of these look straight out of a 12yo's sketchbook, and I swear I have seen chimpanzes in the internet having a better notion of colour harmony. And don't even get me started on the another golem-looking skin for Bruma. C'mon these look absolutely horrible. And I'm not even asking for gooner skins here, just put a wig on her to make good use of this fancy particle system RE Engine uses for hair rendering, or straight up remove all her armor leaving only the m3th-head looking base exo-skeleton, or something like that idk.

The only actual non-lazy nor dumb looking skins are the Murasame Hoplite, that looks badass af. The Zephiro lvl 1 tier skin, that finally answers the question of: "What if Vergil was a furry?". And Vigilante's 50 tier skin due to ~reasons~. And yeah of course I'm recommending it. Stupid people buy and recommend stupid things. [h1]This game is way more fun than Helldivers 2![/h1]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3163805980
Exoprimal is truly underrated and certainly deserve more attention.
Legit one of the most insane, most fun and innovative game I played in recent years.
If you enjoy fast paced non stop action and co-op then Exoprimal is a must have.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3164536395
The skins in this season pass are not the best but I still bought it because this game is worth my time and money.
Anything I can do to support this game, more people should play it.
I played this game for almost 180 hours so far and I still discover new missions modifiers !
There‚Äôs nothing like it on the market and I genuinely have way more fun playing it than Helldivers 2.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3166287506
Exoprimal goes on sale frequently for 29,99 and I think it's an absolute steal at that price point.
Give it a try, you won't regret it if you enjoy fun and fast paced co-op games. Not my favourite pass so far but still some cool rewards and supporting the game!

name: Pengun
short_description: Pengun is a 3rd person shooting, defense, survivor game. shoot down threats in Antarctica. and survive as long as possible.
reviews:
Third person shooter in which you manage and upgrade your weapons, crush boxes with your anvil, and utilize your beacon to bring presents to your block of ice. Very fun and addicting.

name: Cyber Clutch: Hot Import Nights
short_description: Immerse in a multiplayer world where high-speed racing blends with intense vehicle combat. Choose from a variety of uniquely armed cars for strategic battles across vivid cyberpunk cities, focusing on skillful driving and deep customization.
reviews:
Look I know this game is early access but my god there‚Äôs Xbox Live arcade racing games that have more content than this and on top of that I don‚Äôt think trophies are unlocking cause I didn‚Äôt unlock any. I really like the concept and the look of the game, but there are a few things that would make the game better to a point i would recommend it.

-there needs to be more content, right now there are not enough tracks and playmodes

-the customization is good though i find it sad that you cant change the color of the parts, would make it more individuell

-the screen moves to much while you drive, you may get dizzy from it

Things that i like are:

-the concept (it is barely touched upon and is in need of a good game)
-the combat system (items/weapons), im not sure though if its balanced enough.

-the looks of the cars and the world

Keep it up and i believe this could be a good game once it is released.



 Look I'm all for inclusion, I don't care if you hire mentally challenged people. That doesn't mean your whole team should be mentally challenged.

name: Depth - Digital Artbook
short_description: Browse through concept art both old and new that helped make Depth what it is. Includes never before released sketches, concept art pieces, and mesh renders for divers, sharks, weapons and more from Depth.
reviews:
26174816 cool art Even though some people might think this is just a waste of money, it is honestly pretty cool. It shows you the thought process on making the cosmetics and characters and in my opinion, is good for it's price. It also helps the developers work more on the game! How do You even use this? how do you get the artbook?
 It's a nice litte bunch of pictures, but to be honest for this price it should have a LOT more content than just a few concept arts and sketches... good game totally worth the 5 bucks The little content there is in this is really nice. Unfortunatey it's very short and without any insight from the devs. I'm sure the devs have so much more content lyign about their computers they could throw in there. Good to have it when it is at 75% off ha ha.... the art in this book is awesome! Even if the Artbook itself isn't worth the money, the $5 you paid helps the game itself. Just some food for thought.

[/h1] ‚†Ä
Countershading, or [b]Thayer's law[/b], is a method of camouflage in which an animal's coloration is darker on the upper side and lighter on the underside of the body. This pattern is found in many species of mammals, reptiles, birds, fish, and insects, both in predators and in prey. When light falls from above on a uniformly coloured three-dimensional object such as a sphere, it makes the upper side appear lighter and the underside darker, grading from one to the other. 

This pattern of light and shade makes the object appear solid, and therefore easier to detect. The classical form of countershading, discovered in 1909 by the artist Abbott Handerson Thayer, works by counterbalancing the effects of self-shadowing, again typically with grading from dark to light. In theory this could be useful for military camouflage, but in practice it has rarely been applied, despite the best efforts of Thayer and, later, in the Second World War, of the zoologist Hugh Cott. 

The precise function of various patterns of animal coloration that have been called countershading has been debated by zoologists such as Hannah Rowland (2009), with the suggestion that there may be multiple functions including flattening and background matching when viewed from the side; background matching when viewed from above or below, implying separate colour schemes for the top and bottom surfaces; outline obliteration from above; and a variety of other largely untested non-camouflage theories. 

A related mechanism, counter-illumination, adds the creation of light by bioluminescence or lamps to match the actual brightness of a background. Counter-illumination camouflage is common in marine organisms such as squid. It has been studied up to the prototype stage for military use in ships and aircraft, but it too has rarely or never been used in warfare. The reverse of countershading, with the belly pigmented darker than the back, enhances contrast and so makes animals more conspicuous. It is found in animals that can defend themselves, such as skunks. 

The pattern is used both in startle or deimatic displays and as a signal to warn off experienced predators. However, animals that habitually live upside-down but lack strong defences, such as the Nile catfish and the Luna moth caterpillar, have upside-down countershading for camouflage. 

The [b]Streisand effect[/b] is an unintended consequence of attempts to hide, remove, or censor information, where the effort instead increases public awareness of the information. The effect is named for American singer and actress Barbra Streisand, whose attorney attempted in 2003 to suppress the publication of a photograph showing her clifftop residence in Malibu, taken to document coastal erosion in California, inadvertently drawing far greater attention to the previously obscure photograph. The effect exemplifies psychological reactance, in which the attempt to hide information instead makes it more interesting to seek out and propagate.

name: Infested Nation
short_description: Infested Nation is a fast paced and brutal top down shooter. Outnumbered and outgunned, you will need to rely on your wits and reflexes to make it through each situation alive.
reviews:
Always double tap Ok what can I say...I havent completed this yet but I Played enough to say : This is a good game if your into dying in one hit, kinda like Hotline miami but with zombies. The game is simple beat a stage collect fuel in stage use fuel to buy weapons between stages and rinse and repeat ive seen a new type of zombie and there are more weapons to unlock the further you progress into the game. I give it a thumbs up but please buy it on sale. Liked the idea, played it a bit, as you see.

+Not a bad idea
+Needs some skill since you die in one hit
+Ok electro-ish music

-Zombies can kill you through doors
-Inconsistencies: 1) Cannot (always) shoot through doors
                             2) Sometimes it's 1 headshot, they die, other times 2-3+ shots are required to kill (same weapon)
                                  That makes it annoying, when it comes to judging movement and shots needed.
                             3) Sometimes hitboxes are a miss, zombies seem to hit you even seemingly not being on you, also they seem to magically hit you between knifing delays, even if at a distance.

OVERALL: Not bad, but these inconsistencies make it frustrating. It's not about the low price (Winter sale), it's about the value, and I think it's not worth it. You might enjoy it, even despite these flaws, as it's not a bad game.

name: Prizma Puzzle Prime
short_description: Tile-based puzzle game with smooth and addictive gameplay, old-school isometric graphics and excellent music. The player's task is to connect nodes which have various functions.
reviews:
I look back on the Prizma Puzzle games fondly as great puzzlers with solid gameplay that's easy to get into, which this one also is, but I cannot recommend this game for two reasons.
1. "enhanced graphics, visual and sound effects." Enhanced to the point they become distracting. There are frequent flashes, shakes, and sometimes lightning strikes, to the point that playing this game may get headache inducing. This was not a problem with the Flash games which had cool visuals, but the effects were not annoying.
2. The 10 achievements are lame and easily unlocked. The third game introduced achievements which had to be legitimately earned (complete levels, get a high enough combo, earn stars, reach a high score). Here they are just tutorial tasks and failing the level, with no in-game awards to help incentivize players to push themselves either. You can't even see your best score and max possible for a level when hovering over it, which was the case in Challenges, making it a clear downgrade.

name: Zen Space Flight - VR Showcase
short_description: This is a unique down-tempo Flight VR experience. Listen to your favorite music and enjoy the flight in space.
reviews:
[h1]Experienced on Windows Mixed Reality[/h1]

You can view my gameplay & review here: https://youtu.be/s9rtxvZjQKM

This isn't a bad VR music visualizer. There's just better ones (even some free ones). I would have recommended this game / app, but one of the major listed features on the store page no longer works. YouTube music integration doesn't work and hasn't worked for quite a while with no response from the dev. As such, I can't in good conscience recommend this game. 

You can still play your own music. I believe it does have to be .mp3 format though. I know that .wav format did not work at all. Adding your own music is very easy and can be done within the app. There are three different environments and four different visualizations. You can also vary the levels control, particles, color length, base & treble height & sensibility.

Even though I only paid .99 cents, I just can't recommend this app where there's a major feature that's advertised on the store page that just doesn't work, especially with no response from the dev. Also, there are better free music visualizers. This isn't a bad music visualizer though. If you're looking for one where you can fly around and where you can easily add your own .mp3, then this may be right for you.

[b]Rate 4.5/10. I would have given a positive recommendation and a 6/10 if YouTube integration worked. [/b]

[i]p.s. Vision VR and Cosmic Flow: A Relaxing VR Experience are both free and much better IMO.[/i] I actually love this, I would make it so the user can move the menus, they get in the way when playing songs and you have to close it, inconvientant if you want to record it.  I would make instructions clearing on making the graphics do what you can do with them.  I'm trying to figure out the controls and it's not easy as far as moving the scene graphics around.  I can't figure out how to fly around, the review says you can but it doesn't move for me?  Also I can't seem to get it to play .wav or m4a formats?  If you will fix these small issues, this would be super awesome and let me know and I will do a review for you on Linkedin to my 15k followers!

name: Ultra Bushwick
short_description: An indie twin-stick shooter set in Bushwick, Brooklyn, made by one guy from Queens. Fight wave after wave of your gentrifying neighbors for the money you need to pay rent. Also, herd some cats for power-ups.
reviews:
My man, I've only just started (sorry), but this game already rules. One quibble: needs more half-rulers, mind you. This game is awesome! No boring moments; to pay the rent you need to keep it moving! & The art style is really cool! Wow. Really fun and visually stunning for a 5 dollar game. Killer pixel art, but with so much on screen its a little tough to find the enemy's in the chaos. A simple outline of the enemy's would help. Otherwise this game rocks, and is well worth the asking price.  This was made by one guy? Hell I have played TS games that were made by a huge team of programmers and were not nearly as fun, one guy made this? Good job man. WHERE BROOKLYN AT?!?!? GREAT GAME!!!
 What a super fun game! Reminds me of fun retro NES and SNES games with the look of it but updated for modern times. The game seems easy at first, but you have to be quick and hit all the enemies before the spawning gets out of control! A fun way to pass the time. Fun little secret in the game - get close to a DJ (a guy with a boombox) to see an animation! (Reminds me of old games like Breathe of Fire and seeing Chun Li!)

name: Elementary My Dear Majesty!
short_description: The king's daughter has turned into a man-eating monster, and either you find the cure, or it's off with your head!
reviews:
In which Dream Dale, wanting to make a 3-D hidden object game but low on budget, ended up reusing assets from Magic Ball/Smash Frenzy 3 and 4.

Pretty fun time waster with a pretty strange story, Seriously Alawar, you're missing out on all the money you could make on releasing all 4 Magic Ball/Smash Frenzy games (including the spin-offs of Magic Ball/Smash Frenzy 2) on Steam, at the very least remaster all four of them like Gamigo is doing for WildTangent's FATE! [h1]Ryan George Style Pitch Meeting for Elementary My Dear Majesty! (feat. Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson)[/h1]

Publisher: So, you have a hidden object adventure game for me?

Game Designer: Yes, sir, I do!

Publisher: Alright, hit me with it.

Game Designer: So, Elementary My Dear Majesty! is this wild hidden object adventure where you play as a detective named Felix. Your mission? Solve the mystery of a princess who was totally normal at a tea party‚Äîuntil she turned into a giant, man-eating monster.

Publisher: Oh my god.

Game Designer: Right? So naturally, the way to solve this is by clicking on a bunch of random objects that have no logical connection to the case whatsoever.

Publisher: Oh, well, that sounds frustrating.

Game Designer: Super easy, barely an inconvenience! Players will be totally fine once they accept that none of this makes sense! Like, at one point, you repair a hot air balloon with a single piece of tape.

Publisher: Wait, how does that even‚Äî

Game Designer: Hey, shut up!

Publisher: Oh, okay then!

Game Designer: The game is full of these moments! Like, oh, you need to power a spaceship? Easy, just find a watermelon in a tree. You need to get past an obstacle? No worries, just launch a sheep from a catapult.

Publisher: That‚Äôs not how anything works!

Game Designer: But see, that‚Äôs the fun! Nothing makes sense, so everything makes sense.

Publisher: That doesn‚Äôt make sense.

Game Designer: Exactly! The game is a mystery, so the real mystery is why anything in it happens at all!

Publisher: Wow wow wow. Wow.

Game Designer: And now here‚Äôs where things get really exciting‚ÄîSherlock Holmes shows up!

Publisher: What? Sherlock Holmes is in this?

Game Designer: Well, not in the game! No, no, no. He just shows up during this pitch meeting for no reason at all!

Publisher: What?!

Game Designer: Yeah! Just totally unannounced, doesn‚Äôt help with the game, doesn‚Äôt contribute in any way. He‚Äôs just here now, sitting there, looking mysterious, drinking tea, offering random observations.

[At this exact moment, Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson dramatically step into the room, as if they‚Äôve been listening from the hallway.]

Sherlock Holmes: Elementary, my dear Watson.

Watson (nodding gravely): Indeed, Holmes. Most elementary.

Publisher: WHAT THE HELL IS GOING ON?

Game Designer: Exactly! That‚Äôs the reaction we want! You‚Äôre confused, right? You don‚Äôt understand what‚Äôs happening?

Publisher: Not even a little bit!

Game Designer: Perfect! That‚Äôs what makes it tight!

Sherlock Holmes (sipping tea): Ah, yes. A most peculiar situation indeed.

Watson: Though I dare say, Holmes, it is not nearly as peculiar as that time with the left-handed chimney sweep and the trained ferret.

Sherlock Holmes: Ah, Watson, I fear the ferret was merely a red herring.

Publisher: I‚ÄôM SORRY, ARE WE JUST IGNORING THE FACT THAT SHERLOCK HOLMES AND WATSON HAVE MATERIALIZED IN THIS PITCH MEETING?

Game Designer: Yup!

Publisher: Why?!

Game Designer: Mystery!

Publisher: But they‚Äôre not even in the game!

Game Designer: Exactly! That‚Äôs what makes it extra mysterious! The game isn‚Äôt about Sherlock Holmes, and yet he‚Äôs here! Which means there must be a reason!

Publisher: Is there a reason?!

Game Designer: Nope!

Publisher: WHAT?!

Sherlock Holmes: Ah, my dear sir, sometimes the absence of a reason is the most intriguing reason of all.

Watson: Well said, Holmes. Truly, a puzzle wrapped in an enigma, with a side of tea.

[Sherlock sips his tea thoughtfully. Watson nods, satisfied. The Publisher rubs his temples.]

Publisher: Okay, so... are they just gonna be here for the rest of the meeting?

Game Designer: Oh, absolutely. They‚Äôre just part of the vibe now.

Publisher: And they don‚Äôt... do anything?

Game Designer: Nope!

Sherlock Holmes: Quite right. Our presence is purely incidental, yet inexplicably essential.

Publisher: Oh my god.

Game Designer: I know, right? So anyway, back to the game! The whole thing is super silly. At one point, you defeat an enemy by distracting them with a dancing bear.

Publisher: Why?

Game Designer: Because!

Sherlock Holmes: A most elementary tactic. The bear is a diversion, the diversion is a strategy, and the strategy is victory.

Watson: Indeed, Holmes, most astute!

Publisher: WHY ARE THEY STILL HERE?!

Game Designer: Because it‚Äôs fun! People will be so baffled by Sherlock‚Äôs presence, they‚Äôll totally ignore how nonsensical the game is. Instead of asking, ‚ÄúWhy does fixing a balloon with tape work?‚Äù they‚Äôll be like, ‚ÄúWhy was Sherlock Holmes in the pitch meeting?‚Äù and boom, we‚Äôve created intrigue!

Publisher: That doesn‚Äôt make sense!

Game Designer: Exactly!

Sherlock Holmes: A brilliant deduction, my dear sir. Confusion is the key to curiosity, and curiosity is the key to engagement.

Publisher: You know what? Fine! I don‚Äôt even care anymore. Let‚Äôs just get this over with. What‚Äôs next?

Game Designer: Oh, just one more thing.

Publisher: Oh no.

Game Designer: I wrote a strategy speech inspired by Sherlock Holmes, wanna hear it?

Publisher: Do I have a choice?

Game Designer: No!

[Game Designer dramatically clears throat.]

Game Designer: This mustn't register on a logical level. First, introduce randomness. Then, distract with inconsequential details. Counter any logical objection with more nonsense. Discombobulate. The confusion will cause mental hesitation. They will attempt to rationalize. Block with misdirection. Weaken resolve. Now fracture expectations. Break any semblance of coherence. Traumatize sense of reality. Dislocate all reasoning entirely. Heel kick to cognitive stability. In summary, brain spinning, logic dismantled, three assumptions shattered, four paradigms broken. Concept of linear storytelling: hemorrhaging. Capacity to understand why Sherlock Holmes is here: neutralized.

Publisher: WHAT DID I JUST LISTEN TO?!

Game Designer: A flawless business strategy!

Sherlock Holmes: Elementary.

Watson: Indeed, Holmes.

Publisher: I need to lie down.

Game Designer: Great! So we‚Äôre all set for release!

Publisher: Okay then.

[Sherlock and Watson tip their hats, finishing their tea as they fade mysteriously into the ether.]

Publisher: Did they just vanish into thin air?!

Game Designer: I don‚Äôt know!

Publisher: I hate this job.

Game Designer: Great!

[hr]

[h1] Dishonest Trailer for Elementary My Dear Majesty![/h1]

[EPIC TRAILER VOICE]

From the minds behind... well, something, comes a game that asks the bold question: What if a detective solved a mystery using absolutely zero detective skills?

Get ready for Elementary My Dear Majesty!, the hidden object adventure that takes logic, throws it out a castle window, and replaces it with sheep catapults, watermelon-fueled spaceships, and repairing a hot air balloon with tape!

Step into the stylish boots of Felix, a detective who doesn‚Äôt detect anything and instead helps a cursed princess by clicking on whatever shiny object the game tells you to. Think it makes sense? Think again! Your brain is now hostage to the whims of a game that treats physics, reality, and common sense like a suggestion at best.

‚ÄîNeed to fix a broken machine? Find a fish!
‚ÄîObstacle in your way? Just lob an animal at it!
‚ÄîLooking for a clue? Why not check under this pile of completely unrelated nonsense?!

With graphics that look like a fever dream from 2012 and animations so stiff you‚Äôll wonder if the characters are held together by sheer willpower, this game is pure chaotic nonsense from start to finish!

And just when you think you understand it, Sherlock Holmes randomly appears in the pitch meeting to remind you that nothing makes sense anymore!

So if you love mysteries but hate solving them, click your way through the most baffling adventure ever made!

Elementary, my dear‚Ä¶ something!

[END SCREEN]
"Click to play! Or don‚Äôt. Honestly, we have no idea what‚Äôs happening anymore."

[hr]

 [h2]Elementary My Dear Majesty![/h2]

Has a total of [b]6[/b] trading cards. :o!  This is pretty good for a rather cheap game.  ^-^

It doesn't make you motion sick whilst you try to rotate your camera/search for stuff and it has humor to it as well!  The hero's mustache is so skinny and long...  It looks all wrong...!  But that's how it's designed.

So if you played Cats in Time or Hidden Paws...  This is rather similar.  It DOES have a cat...  Pretty sure it's the same black one though.

Right well...  You go from floating scenery to floating scenery and do quests.  The people are rude and have crazy tasks for ya.  That's normal.

There are also parts where you can catapult stuff...  Those are fun...

Of course not everything is great.

- The cannon may get stuck and that's the ONLY trajectory you can fire it at.  Especially during the "Pandas destroy the Great Wall".
- Items are sometimes (very rarely) so small or so damn hidden you can't freaking find them without a hint.  Snow level.  *cough*
- Some mini-games are a beep to play.  Looking at you "copy my dance moves".  Ancient temple/the "two robots/space" levels.

I hadn't run into any other weird problems, so I call it good!

Overall it's a nice distraction and humor, despite being ridiculous...  Which is the point...  Is actually not bad at all!

Bur really...  Let's face it...  IF I were to dye my cat?  I would be the one dyed...  In a very delightful shade of dark crimson.

Woo...  Hoo...?!

Thank yous!!  :3 =) :> I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you. This game is a really fun game. Its humorous and is fine for all ages as far as I can tell. Elementary My Dear Majesty! is a mobile app-like low poly family friendly point-and-click adventure game with numerous simple hidden object and physics puzzles and minigames.  There's a somewhat nonsensical fairy-tale themed story with a lot of iPhone screen tapping to step along through the simple storyline.  Collect enough fruit for this, collect enough cogs for that, play a crane minigame to put this over there, that kind of thing.  Shallow, not all that interesting for a PC game, but it might have done well if the developers launched this on mobile app stores instead of Steam, which isn't for mobile apps. 

From a technical perspective, the game doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.

The game features lazy low-polygon "retro" assets, making this look like a barely functional 3D game from the mid 2000s.  It's unclear why the developers weren't able to arrange high quality, high polygon count contemporary assets for the game, and also irrelevant... what matters is that this looks bad as a result of their decisions, a compromise PC gamers shouldn't have to put up with.

The controls can't be customised because the game has such a dumbed down, simplified interface that it's just iPhone screen tapping stuff.  The fact that the interface is this dumbed down might be seen as a problem in itself, however... this is a fairly shallow experience if you're the kind of gamer that likes to play games with deep, rich control schemes and interaction.  You'll get none of that here.

This looks and feels like a mobile app, but I wasn't able to find it on the app stores.  Maybe it was removed, maybe it was rejected by Apple and Google (they do have more rigorous quality standards than Valve does for Steam, after all).

Regardless, for all intents and purposes "Elementary My Dear Majesty!" might as well be a mobile app, it has the same limitations and dumbed down qualities.  It's impossible to recommend such a game to PC gamers.  We don't spend all this money building gaming rigs so we can pretend they're iPhones and play games that might as well be mobile apps.

These technical defects push this game below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.

Reviewing SteamDB to check how popular this game was with players reveals a surprise... there's a very healthy spike in player counts for the game.  But this only appears around the same time that trading cards were applied to the game... so this is just card idlers getting their cards and moving on.  A closer look at the numbers shows the game just has a couple of players every week running up the game and idling it for cards, then deleting it.  We must ask how it benefits gamers for there to be so many games like this, with no merit as a serious game, that only generate sales from people idling and selling the trading cards.

Elementary My Dear Majesty! is relatively cheap at $2 USD, but it's not worth it. Given the defects and quality issues with the game, coupled with the unrealistic price, and the questionable ethical nature of the developer and/or their associates (as outlined above), this is impossible to recommend.  Because this is the kind of game you can just play for free on mobile phones, it's impossible to recommend anyone should pay money for the same experience on Steam. You should try it if you're into hidden object games. nice game 10/10

name: Jump, Dodge, Die, Repeat
short_description: Jump, Dodge, Die, Repeat is a rage fueling, adventure game, filled with unpredictable obstacles. Help Isani complete his impossible task, a task that was given to him by his maker at the moment of his creation.
reviews:
Indeed a challenge to go through all the obstacles. Gotta have a good memory man, otherwise you're screwed,lol.
It's a game that takes you way back, even though it came out this year. Reminds you of the simpler times of video gaming. 
I recommend you to try it out, just so you can feel the good times hit you back, I promise you'll know what I mean.
P.S. Might rage a bit, if your memory sucks. GL & HF. I sometimes play this game to relax after working in customer support 10/10 Gameplay
10/10 Soundtrack
10/10 Drip
10/10 Memes
Hardest Boss:
Banana
