Zeus Reviews[/b][/url][/quote] You should get the other German skin pack unless you really really like the Kingdom of W√ºrttemberg –ü–æ–∂–∞–ª—É–π –ª—É—á—à–µ–µ –¥–ª—Å –≤ –∏–≥—Ä–µ –∑–∞ –≤—é—Ä—Ç–µ–º–±–µ—Ä–≥—Å–∫–∏–µ –∏ –±–∞–≤–∞—Ä—Å–∫–∏–µ —Ñ–æ—Ä–º—ã —Å –∫–∏–≤–µ—Ä–∞–º–∏, –∏ —Ñ–æ—Ä–º–æ–π –≠—Ä–≤–∏–Ω–∞ –†–æ–º–º–µ–ª—è I bought this just for the Hitler stache Like the expedition pack, this one is solely for the german faction and frankly adds to the already diverse selection of uniforms they have. While not as exotic as the cold weather/stormtrooper variants, this one includes region-specific uniforms from germany who would've been seen as specialty or veteran units, the uniforms are also much brighter and crisper than the standard issue ones with regional marking on their collars. Overall a good pack, I am especially a fan of the Bavarian Telefonist Engineer that just exhibits everything I like about an engineer uniform. Really solid pack and doubled with the expedition pack make Germany the most diverse for uniform selection. Adds W√ºrttemberger and Bavarian uniforms to the German Empire Faction, what more could you want? 


SÃ∂aÃ∂xÃ∂oÃ∂nÃ∂ Ã∂uÃ∂nÃ∂iÃ∂fÃ∂oÃ∂rÃ∂mÃ∂sÃ∂ Ã∂oÃ∂fÃ∂ Ã∂cÃ∂oÃ∂uÃ∂rÃ∂sÃ∂eÃ∂.
Pls add uniforms for Schwarzburg-Sondershausen next. Cavalier Pipe we all bussin' on the alpine front I really appreciate the devs sicking to historically/aesthetically appropriate DLC packs.

I bought this pack to support the WW1 series as they have an excellent track record of delivering solid multiplayer games that do not use excessive monetization tactics like loot boxes or season passes. I was a huge Insurgency fan and was very disappointed to see the Insurgency Sandstorm devs allowing excessive cosmetic DLC packs to get too flashy and inappropriate for that games setting and make it hard to distinguish what team the player is on. This makes me very appreciative for solid, simple, and fun multiplayer games like Isonzo.

All the WW1 games have also included a way to play the game solo against bots with custom difficulty which is a feature I think is essential for any multiplayer game to ensure that the game will still be enjoyable after the player base inevitably moves on to something else.

Keep up the good work Blackmill!

name: Amaranthine Voyage: The Obsidian Book Collector's Edition
short_description: Enter the role of Eve Glover, one of the best CCPP's agents, sent to investigate the lack of radio communication from your scientific team on Iceland, researching harmonium radiation.
reviews:
excellent This 4th entry in the series is a step up from the 3rd, but still not enough to be a good game.

The story is more exciting‚Äîalthough it's still confusing; who are these characters exactly?‚Äîand there's more polish to the design and animation. But the gameplay can be frustrating as often the point-and-click adventure puzzles have no logic at all. You'll end up having to just try using all objects in your inventory with everything in the world until something works, and even then you'll be left scratching your head as to why.

Will Eipix ever be able to restore the charm of the 1st entry in the series, [I]The Tree of Life[/I], or are we stuck with these confusing and illogical sequels? (Spoiler: it does not get better...)

One very weird aspect of this game is that one of the characters has a face that looks exactly like human buttocks. I can't even. It is a fun game.

name: Shadow Man Remastered
short_description: He is coming, stalking criminals in the spirit world and the real world. A possessed man is coming, a voodoo mask in his chest and lines of power in his back. Shadow Man is coming, trailing evil from Liveside to Deadside. To stop an apocalypse. To save your soul.
reviews:
I'm late to the Shadow Man party but if I had played this as a kid then it for sure would have been a childhood favorite. The Soundtrack and vibes are off the chart. Exploration is a bitch, but if you're used to soulslikes or retro games, you should fair pretty well.

If you're stuck, talk to an NPC. my fav game of all time ever Atmospheric and fun. It's an old game so be prepared for dated gameplay, but its not about that. You're playing because its a weird freaking game that gets very, very dark and disturbing. You'll have weird dreams. You might have unusual feelings in liminal spaces. Have fun! absolute nightmare of a game Nightdive does it again with another perfect remaster, clearly done by people who loved the original game. You know how the flaws in a piece of media become the signature by which that type of media is recognized? I'm talking about VHS scanlines, technicolor oversaturation, handycam shaking, lens flare, tank controls, inventory management, static camera angles, low polygon count, etc.

Shadow Man feels like it lurks on the cusp of becoming its own modern style of game.

It's part collectathon, part third person max-payne-style dive-shooter, part metroidvania, part rpg. And for all it says DARK SOULS in its script, I'd honestly put forward that it's part Dark Souls with its large mazed environments and unlockable shortcuts and its environments carrying half the weight of its storytelling.

Shadow Man also has some unique jank to it. You're kind of expected to have read the (unfinished) Garth Ennis Valiant Comics run to know any of what the characters are talking about at the start of the game, but the script's also not so deep that you'll get lost if you haven't. The controls are not true 360, and the camera pans to specific axis around the character---this makes jumping forward pretty dang fragile, you'll often approach a ledge head on only to fling yourself sideways as you try to microadjust your angle during the leap. The game handles a controller well (god knows how they crammed this thing onto an N64 cartridge, but it *was* there at some point) but not perfectly---I had to remap lock on away from the shoulder buttons because the triggers next to them are how you shoot and I only have so many fingers.

Lastly, it's big.

Nightdive did a damn fine job with their restoration, not just remastering but returning cut content and fixing bugs (most of them---the asylum ledges can softlock you if you haven't talked to your girlfriend and your snake before jumping on them,) and this has only further cemented that Shadow Man is a large game. I'm going to come back and update my review periodically, so don't treat my playtime as indicative of the overall size, but expect a full featured game here.

Also a note should be made here about the voice performance. Everyone is on full scenery chew, it's great, but the script sort of wobbles in quality. A lot of the lines (which I'm guessing are from the comic, so go figure) feel like they're meant more to be read than spoken. The sound design is excellent, but sometimes background tracks and ambient sounds fade into the line reads in weird ways. High quality indie jank---the kind of thing you could deliberately build a game about. You have to be ready for it, but it's not bad.

Overall, I think this is kind of the definition of a cult classic. If you like late 90s / early aughts gothic media, you like platformers and collectathons, you like self-serious schlock, and you like games where a ton of care has been put into them---twice---you should really check out Shadow Man. And if you're of a game designing inclination, consider lettings its funk guide you into fleshing out a new subgenre.

Edit: I was an idiot. There's no softlock bug in the asylum. You can only grab ledges when you do not have both weapons drawn. This is a level of technicality that more modern games avoid due to frustration, but it really does connect you more with the deliberate feel of this thing. Also I started poking around the first of the restored areas unique to the remaster and it is gigantic and complex and challenging. A+ work by both the original dev team and the remaster team. There's a lot of game in this game.

2nd Edit: THERE IS A LOT OF GAME IN THIS GAME. It's also extremely flexible with how it lets you explore it. And I've now been to the second of the restored areas. The vibes are immensely evil. If you like liminal environments you'll love Shadow Man. This game is a treasure.

3rd Edit: There are some absolutely nonsense hidden areas on the game's critical path. The map is also, as is tradition in a metroidvania, as unuseful as possible. It feels great to explore areas for the first time, but there is SO much stuff to revisit for. Fortunately there's a ton of guides since this game has been out for a quarter of a century, but unfortunately it's really hard to give simple directions that will walk someone through all the BS nooks where the game tucks a plot-critical doorway or dubiously interactive switch, dial, or shootable engraved door. Even knowing how to interact with a given thing can take some guesswork. Those doors in the temple of fire that look like pushblocks, you're supposed to shoot them. The big cubes with the glowing orbs on each face that look shootable, those you're supposed to push.

4th: Average Shadow Man BGM be like *squeaky toy* *dentist's drill* *baby laugh* *woman screaming her lungs out in agony* *squeaky toy*. Sometimes you forget this is based on a Garth Ennis comic and then you're like "oh, yeah, this is based on a Garth Ennis comic."

5th Edit: Rolled credits at around twenty hours. It really feels like a marathon. The number of collectibles you need to get to the endgame is pretty dang close to 100% of the total number of collectibles, and that's plus the five mandatory retractors, three mandatory l'eclipser pieces, and five or so mandatory equipment pieces. Combat is also not this thing's strong point. It's about atmosphere first, secret hunting second, platforming third, and combat dead last. However. If the pacing doesn't put you off, this is a really rad title. Especially play it if you're thinking of getting into game design. It'll show you as many mistakes as moments of genius, and really hammers home the lesson that there's no one right way to make a thing. There's just you, your vision, and whatever steps you need to take to reach that vision. Do NOT choose "The Horror" difficulty for your first playthrough! Great creepy voodoo fun! The sisters awake?!

name: Mino Saga
short_description: Mino Saga is new type of puzzle game, it's evolutionary concept for playing pentomino type of games. Mino Saga is mix of two worlds, bringing best of Pentomino games and fast game play.
reviews:
The game relies HEAVILY on coins to purchase more resources to get through the puzzles
Developer forgot to include the microtransaction server where coins were most-likely meant to be purchased with real cash

Yet another non-functional $teamy one - this site has turned into the interweb's Wal-Mart toilet and no one's even bothering to come back to flush

name: SMILE GAME BUILDER Modern City Resource Pack Vol.1
short_description: This resource pack themed of a downtown in the U.S. contains office buildings, shops, desks, computers, sofas and more.
reviews:
I would have to say this DLC is a really good one in my opinion. SGB is new if you didn't know and has very little assets to begine with.
That being said the DLC is a little bundle of relief the assets are of quality and worth it becouse you get alot more materials to work with when creating your game.

Pros- More assets and terrain to work with in your SGB project which is a releif
      Quality assets you can tell they really tolk some time and effert into puting the 
      DLC together.
Cons- Only one vehical design for the cars the other car models are just painted diffrent
      No 2D graphics for the 8 modern character models.
      
 Good quality assets in the G-Style pack. Not a huge collection, but all very good quality, equal to or better than the assets which come with the core product. 

A fairly western-sh city theme with plenty of street furniture and interior items (office, school, hospital etc). Could have done with some general household interior items but many of the included items could double up in a house setting, but I suspect the developer is saving them for another DLC.
This DLC is essential if you want a modern theme, and you can't create your own 3D assets. It includes animated characters, floor tiles, wall tiles, several building models, doors etc.

There is an included test level for you to play with which you can wander about in and wonder why everyone is driving on the left in what looks like an american city with a british telephone box, and the assets import into your own project with one button click. A nice way of delivering the DLC.

Reasonably priced fair value for money. The developer has done a nice job and the contents are sensibly thought out. Great little DLC pack for Smile Game Builder - chock full of modern 3D objects, ground/wall textures and with 8 adorable, bravely default-esque character models included.

The building models are especially useful for creating large, varied modern city maps and the smaller objects are nicely made and cover a wide range from office essentials to hospital equipment, vending machines to washing machines. Honestly, considering these are fully textured, often animated 3D models, the price is pretty great too.

I really hope we see more DLC in this style soon as I just can't get enough!

name: Diesel Power
short_description: Diesel Power is inspired by classic arcade racers and brings their gameplay to VR. Best described with the words: Raw. Challenging. Enraging. Satisfying. One more round! The goal is simple: Get to the end of the track The challenge: There is no track
reviews:
10/10
Great little game. Fiendishly adictive and really really difficult. Must try this. The lack of a checkpoint or save feature is a really poor decision on behalf of the devs though as it makes the game too time-intensive to complete. i love arcade games and finaly some are available for vr. diesel power is mega hard but i am loving it so far. not easy to get into a fluid driving style at first. feels like i failed 2000 times before seeing the night section. installed steam to buy it as i couldnt find it on oculus home i love this game. finally classic gaming in VR. i forgot how tough games can be.
it took me a while to control the asteroidish car and to be able to look around to spawn the track. 
looks way easier on the video.
frustrating at first but became very satisfying once i got further on the map.
so far very replayabe and unbelievable challenging.
great vr game! My personal top 3 hardcoregames ;) You are prepair to die ;)

name: Fade to Silence
short_description: Fade to Silence is a single-player and co-op survival adventure set in a post-apocalyptic world that is frozen in an eternal winter. Snow and ice have shaped a merciless landscape. Nature is corrupted. Monstrous creatures out of an Eldritch horror dream roam the frozen wasteland.
reviews:
Bad. Awful. Clunky. Ugly. How do you fuck up gamedev this badly? I have very mixed feelings about this game. I give it a recommendation because I did enjoy it. I got it on a good discount and thought it was worth the money I spent on it. But it has it's issues and you have to be patient with it. It doesn't live up to it's full potential and that is disappointing.

Fade to Silence is set in a frozen post apocalyptic world where the player and a handful of other survivors that you find must struggle to survive in a harsh world filled with eldritch monsters and a deadly cold. You are constantly haunted and berated by a wraith figure who torments you and resurrects you when you die to continue the torment. You build a refuge with the other survivors and have to defend it against periodic and increasing attacks from the monsters. You constantly need resources to survive, and these resources are permanently depleted as you gather them, forcing to the player to push further into the frozen wilderness to get what you need to survive. You need to drive out the monsters to gain the resources they guard, having to capture strongholds from them so you can get even further into the frozen environment. You eventually discover the mysteries of the wraith and what caused the apocalypse.

This feels like it's 90% of the way to a really good game, but just didn't cross the finish line. As if the development was cut short without putting the finishing touches on it. There a lot of low level bugs that would have simple fixes that the player will encounter frequently. You will be inconvenienced by bugs, you will lose loot because of bugs, you will take damage because of bugs and you will die because of bugs. They seem to have fixed the really game breaking bugs that I've seen others report, but there's still a lot of little ones all over the place and you will experience them from time to time. Stuff like: cutting down a tree and seeing flying up in air due to dodgy physics and sometimes not coming back down, getting stuck in terrain and being unable to move, loot being tossed into unreachable places, a few loot items on the map are spawned in unreachable places, game sometimes not accepting movement input for 1 to 2 seconds after you exit a loot container or destroy a hive (lethal if the trash moon is dropping cars on you), taking damage and even being killed while a cutscene is playing (trash moon dropped cars on me when I found a wolf. I thought it was funny seeing the cars hitting all around during the cutscene of Ash reuniting with one of his lost wolves, but when the cutscene finished I was dead).

And it's not just the bugs that make it feel unfinished. There's also a lot of simple quality of life improvements they could implement but just haven't. There's a bunch of issues with balancing. The base attacks never felt like a real threat, just a minor annoyance that made me return to base at specific times. There's a conflict with how the story is given through dreams that you get during resting while the game mechanics pushing the player forward to get more resources as soon as possible disincentivise resting. This can cause you to miss most of the story content. The story finishes abruptly with a cutscene without any real final boss or showdown with the wraith which I found disappointing. I was hoping I'd finally get the extreme satisfaction from destroying the trash moon after it's been dropping cars on me all game, but sadly it doesn't happen.

There's some highly questionable design choices as well. For example there's a high level enemy called the stalker that excels at ambush attacks and is hard to escape from. They are a good enemy for the later areas as they keep you on your toes. Someone thought it would be a good idea to put a couple in the starting area. This honestly feels like they only put them there to troll new players and force early deaths. They are the kind of enemy that feels impossible to fight until you figure out how they work, but until then you will die to them a lot. Early players will often be outright killed without even knowing what's happening or even properly seeing the enemy that killed them, just a black mist zooming through them. I'm sure there are people who have rage quit and uninstalled because of this.

The combat is decent, but it's got it's issues. The lock on mechanic is good when fighting a single enemy, but against groups it gets annoying. The camera zooms in too much and you can't move it while locked on, so it makes you at risk of other attacks, like other enemies or the constantly spawning bombs that are near hives or the trash moon dropping cars on you. The enemies feel challenging at first, sometimes even unfair, but they each have a strategy that makes them easy to beat. Once you figure that out, they do start to become repetitive, but there's often other factors, like groups or the trash moon showing up, that complicate things enough to stop it getting boring. It could use a few more common enemies for variety.

The early game feels very difficult at first with a constant strain on limited resources and trying to survive in the harsh world, but this difficulty doesn't persist through the game. It drops off around the start of mid-game. You get plentiful resources and can craft decent (namely copper) equipment and good consumables, even more lives if needed. You've figured out the most common enemies mechanics so combat is not as dangerous and you don't die as much. And while there are harder versions of the common enemies late game and more of them, they don't really scale well with your equipment level, making it a bit too easy. The only things that will kill you at this point are bugs, recklessness and the occasional new enemy until you learn how they work.

Which gets me to the last issue: permadeath. This game is supposed to be built around this concept and references cycles repeatedly. You find many bonuses in the form of shards which improve your stats and boons that let you choose from some powerful bonuses. The catch is that they only apply after permadeath. The idea is supposed to be that you make it so far before the environment grinds you down and you come back stronger and get further each time. But because the difficulty drops off around mid-game and you steamroll to the end, you don't really experience this. It kinda ruins the idea and most players will try to avoid permadeath at all costs to avoid losing game progression when the permadeath is supposed to be a part of the game progression. The mechanic needs a bit more work to flesh it out so players are pretty much forced to get the permadeath boosts in order to progress. The wraith is supposed to be tormenting you with endless cycles after all and there are plenty of people who finish it without ever experiencing permadeath which defeats part of the point of the game.

All that said, the game is enjoyable to play. The environment feels great. You really feel like you're in a post-apocalyptic world struggling to survive. The blizzards are a real threat and the game mercilessly punishes recklessness and lack of preparation. The story and characters are immersive and there is a consistent theme of moving on from loss and past mistakes. The narrative is dripped out slowly keeping up the mystery very well. The trash moon looming over the world is very imposing and having to dodge the cars it's dropping down on you from above is an experience, especially when it can show up at inconvenient times. The threat of permadeath does make dying more consequential and the threat of defeat more real, rather than many other games where you can just reload at a checkpoint.

Overall I would rate it about a 6 out of 10, with the potential to be a 8 or even 9 with a bit more work by the developers to fix the bugs and other issues to bring out the game's full potential. A good pickup if its on a sale if you want a post apocalyptic survival game that is a bit different from most and are willing to be patient with it's issues. Not the best co-op/multiplayer experience, but a fun game all the same. Not my style of this genre of games.  

I've played 7D2D, Long Dark, Icarus, etc.  This seems to have an interesting story but it just... I don't find the game play worth it.  I tried and tried - over 20 hours - and I just don't care for this.  Maybe co-op but not like this. i like the game, for full price idk if its worth it for a casual player, but its challenging so that is a nice breath of air. needs some more momentum and help off the start. i read through the in game notes and they are lacking to say the least. the things you get to keep after permadeath are extremely lacking. i probably wont put in anymore time since the achievements are only available through permadeath mode. i do not hold that against this game though as it is how its intended to be played. unplayable game so many bugs The game was good (compared to most games we get now days) but I recommend this game more because I want to see an even better game like this in the future. The first part of the game was really fun. Discovering the mechanics and world. But after some time I saw more and more thing that I didn't like.
Combat is very easy at its core. This was made for controller 100%. What made the game hard was actually the character movement. So slow to start running, rolling, hitting. 
Then looking at the items, just a handful of them, and you don't even need to use all of them to finish the game. 5 types of enemy = you get used with them very fast.
Limited backpack space. Why? So you spend more time running back and forth. 
Collect 1k gems. Why? You don't need them but you spend more in game time. Reminds me of collecting posters in Far Cry = boring. 
Moving trough zones step by step like Shadow of Mordor, so you can build your character is no a fun thing. Having a more openworld like Witcher 3 or Gothic would have made the game so much better.
I hope they make a second game. With more focus on the story, character development, openworld. And less of repeat the same over and over just so you spend more time.

Story just ignore it its garbage

Eg. finite resources, Permadeath, and a slilly sequence full of jank where you have to risk everything on jumping from ledge to ledge right at the end of the game! name: The Space Bar
short_description: Play as Alias Node, a human detective working on planet, Armpit VI. Your assignment? Catch a shifty criminal, wanted for grand theft and murder, before whatever it is, escapes to another world!
reviews:
Extremely thankful this came out on steam in a seamless format. No ISO switching, audio is not buggy, runs great compared to the ScummVM version i tried a while back. Exceptionally underrated and difficult point and click game that is truly unique. EDIT2: tl;dr: this is a deceptive, buggy release with a game-breaking bug. DON'T buy.

My review is mainly in regards to this Steam release, as I would stil absolutely recommend you to play this game. Yes, like other adventure games (Edna & Harvey: The Breakout comes to mind regarding this game; this game's Empathy-Telepathy is compareable to Breakout's "Tempomorph" feature, the whacky characters and well-placed fourth-wall-breaks being other similarities), The Space Bar is VERY cryptic, but it makes up for it on style, humor and ESPECIALLY immersiveness. This release, though I am happy that it is available digitally, is just not up to my standards with one aspect ABSOLUTELY making me mad @ Jordan Freeman Group and detering me from recommending anyone from buying this Steam release.

1. First of all, the game has a few issues. The Steam Overlay doesn't work and even if it did, you would have to rebind the screenshot key since F12 quits the game and you can't remap anything there (not that you would need to otherwise). In addition, the game runs at VGA/480p. Not a problem by itself, that's just the game, but scaling it to a resolution like 1024√ó768 would make any overlay more usable; Windows Game Overlay barely works and the AMD Adrenalin software is unusable at 480p.

2. There are several bugs in this version. There is one graphical option in the game regarding "Perspective Correction". For some reason, it is not turned fully to the right in this release by default. Even if you do, you have to do it every time you play the game since it doesn't save that setting. Probably it doesn't save any of the other settings as well! There were two crashes, but they weren't too bad. What is really bad is that the game freezes sometimes at certain points. The Vildroid flashback briefly froze on me several times in the locker room for example. What's worse: In several instances, the game freezes while skipping dialogue. This means the "CHAT" option with Fleebix in the Thud flashback straight-up exits if you select anything and to this day I have only heard half of the "FINISHED" option when chatting with My and Ty. A shame since that line seems to be one of the many well-placed fourth wall breaks. I suspect this has something to do with the included D3D9 wrapper that also seems to cause problems on the Steam Deck.

EDIT: It actually gets worse. I just finished the Fleebix flashback, that has numerous occurrences of freezes with line skipping around the Quantelope Lodge! The first one is having Thud press the blue button in the clocktower, which is not that bad. What is bad is that the audition introduction is skipped with a freeze, as is everything but the first few words of the congratulatory message after completing the audition! In addition, I have noticed another bug of this version, also most likely wrapper-related: Rarely, bottom text disappears within a second, meaning you can't read it unless you take a screenshot (not possible through Steam, remember). This happens when picking up drinks ordered from the DrinkVendor 2000 and it also happens when you try to go underwater in the Moist Grotto. I have only ever finished the Fleebix and Thud flashbacks in their entirety, so it's VERY likely there are numerous other bugs of these sorts in the game.

EDIT2: Cilia's flashback also freezes on me frequently, especially when being catched by the Akro Mati regime. Deven-7's flashback freezes even more often, in particular when a negotiating team returns. This is quite bad as you basically have to look up the results separately all the time. Even worse still, and this might be a game-breaking bug (!), if you suceed, you are somehow unable to progress. You can select "CHAT" with Deven-7 in the bar, but there are no options and you can only exit the conversation by hitting escape. I haven't found a way around this yet, meaning you CAN'T COMPLETE THE GAME. You need the high frequency jammer from him and you can only get it by betting with him after completing the flashback successfully!

3. I paid 14,99 EUR for The Space Bar. Not unfair by itself, that's what I paid for my physical copy and you get cloud saves, easy install and no disk-swapping. It has since been reduced to 14,79 EUR, the same as on the ZOOM Platform. Only problem is that the ZOOM Platform release features extra goodies such as Concept Artwork, Magazine Ads and so on. And I get it, Steam wants a cut, but what I don't like at all is that the ZOOM Platform release includes the OST. On Steam, you don't even get it as purchasable DLC as with other games.

4. This release is supposedly the "Digital Edition" with, according to Jordan Freeman Group, "higher-quality cutscenes and audio" from an unreleased DVD Edition. As far as I can tell, this is at the very least dubious, probably just a straight-faced lie. The intro of the game (LOGO3EX.SMK, found on the first Disk), is 103 MB in the original CD release I have. And in this supposedly enhanced new release? 103 MB. Not that you could tell that many differences at 480p. So either these files from the "unreleased DVD Edition" (whose existence I am highly doubtful of) are exclusive to the Super Digital Deluxe Edition exclusive to this ZOOM Platform, which would be a real slap to the face since there is no clear indication and that one was cheaper right after release, or the Jordan Freeman Group made it up.

14,99 EUR for that, Jordan?!

EDIT: I really appreciate the positive feedback guys! In regards to Sentry, if they have even admitted that these "higher-quality cutscenes and audio" is bonus content, than there is no other way to put it: They have been deceptive on purpose. In the venturebeat.com article about the then-upcoming re-release, Jordan Freeman himself says: "It is with sheer joy we digitally present the previously unreleased DVD edition of Boffo Intergalactic Games‚Äô The Space Bar, with higher resolution cinematics and improved audio. [‚Ä¶]". There is nothing ambiguous about that statement, it CLEARLY indicates this is the supposedly previously unreleased DVD edition with higher resolution cinematics and so on, not these things being secretly exclusive extras. To this day, the bonus content on the ZOOM site is listed as "Concept Artwork, Lossless Theme Music, Magazine Ads, Signed Poster Scan", not a word of "higher-quality cutscenes and audio", indicating that it also should be in the Steam release. This is unacceptable, even if they apparently further reduced the price to 9,75 (I should have waited!), especially for a release riddled with issues.

EDIT2: Even the game-breaking bug notwithstanding, this is an unacceptable release. It seems instead of fixing it, Jordan Freeman Group or whoever is upvoting the two positive reviews. By people who barely played the game, one of them only having posted a review of another Jordan Freeman Group-published game. For some reason that alludes me, one of those reviews is listed as "most helpful overall", even though it has the same number of upvotes and far less comments than this one.

name: Suits: A Business RPG
short_description: Corporations control the entire global government. Injustice has inspired a revolution in Suits City. Follow the journey of a businessman's descent into corruption...
reviews:
It's like old Pokemon games [i]Originally posted on [url=https://www.dragon-quill.net/chistmas-steam-games-2024-pans/]Dragon Quill.[/url] Comments are enabled there.[/i]

This was an astoundingly vapid and empty game. I‚Äôd say it reminds me of low-effort Flash games from the aughts, but honestly I think that would be an insult to them. At least they had a modicum of originality. This game is just a string of dumb dadaist non-jokes (plus a lot of ‚Äújokes‚Äù that consist entirely of ‚ÄúWe made a reference!‚Äù) interspersed by generic RPG Maker gameplay that consists of ‚Äúpress Attack to win‚Äù. I have no idea what the developers were even trying to do, and even more baffled why this has so many positive reviews. I refunded it despite it costing less than a dollar, because I literally don‚Äôt want to give these hacks a single cent.

I have to say, I think at a certain point these corporate chic parodies reinforce corporatism more than they criticize it. Capitalism is not a force of nature that does things for no reason, but capitalists are very invested in making you [i]believe[/i] it is because that makes it harder to question. Regurgitating that propaganda, even satirically, is doing their work for them. (I‚Äôm reminded of Disco Elysium, which in fact [url=https://space-blue.tumblr.com/post/771289170540920832]made this exact point,[/url] because despite also being an absurdist dark comedy it uses anti-capitalism as a genuine belief instead of an aesthetic.) i got stuck in an area because whenever a random encounter occurred the game would crash This started out kinda neat but it ended up being a lot more frustrating than fun. For 99 cents, I can't complain too much. Ultimately, it went from interesting to mid to meh to "why is this combat system so ass?" nice little rpg maker game. Incredibly mid, it's a RPGmaker game without good RPG combat. 
Story sucks too.
Visuals are really nice but thats all it has going for it A Business RPG features quirky humour, unique hand-drawn art, a capitalist dystopia and classic combat. [h1]Intro[/h1]
Suits: A Business RPG asks us the question that many other RPGM games had asked: what if I made a RPG Maker game that is very fucked up?

In that regard, Suits does manage to hit the mark. Clearly reminiscent of hit pieces like OFF, this short little game brings us through a fucked up story line about how capitalism can destroy a society from the inside and gut it from the inside out. While the positives are very positive, the game still has some errors that holds it a bit back from its full potential as a true Fucked Up RPGM Game classic. Let's dive in a little bit.

[b]TL;DR:[/b] A solid 7/10 game on the Fucked Up RPG Maker Games with great inspiration from OFF. An overall good experience only held back by too many silly 420 jokes and some unpolished and unbalanced gameplay that can feel a bit frustrating at times. At 4 hours of playthrough without going 100% (althokught it's possible) it's a great value for 1$

[h1]Positives[/h1]
Let's start with the wrapping. Art-wise, this game clearly drinks from cult classic OFF aesthetics: hand drawn, black and white and grotesque. Still, it manages to have its own vibe and tone, setting the game as colorless from the beginning instead of having the colors fade and making the hand drawn, pen on paper style very clear. The simple pixel art for sprites contrast with the intrincate designs of sprites in combat.

The OST hits the mark with its dark and industrial ambient [spoiler](save the song about dinosaurs)[/spoiler] that is unsettling enough for us to never feel comfortable in any part of the game. Pitched up or down versions of some song can be heard in combat, adding to the strange eerines of the whole ambiance. Overall, a great work form the composer to make us feel like we don't truly belong here.

Finally, the narrative and story in the game is compelling enough for me to keep going. It helps that my anarchist ass also wants to see capitalism crash and burn under it's own weight, so I might also be a bit biased here. Still, it has some shortcomings that I will go into later.

Summing it all up:
[list]
[*] Good stilistic and art choice
[*] Pretty well made OST
[*] Interesting plot points and little secrets
[*] Overall narrative feels compelling to follow
[/list]
[hr][/hr]
[h1]Negatives[/h1]
Starting where I left it on the positives, the narrative is held back by the insurmountable amount of 420 and scatological jokes. Don't me wrong, I love weed jokes as much as the next guy, but when you have this game trying to tell you a complex story about how capitalism is a soulless machine feeding the meat of discarded workers back to them, it takes you off a bit when there are constant clocks at 4:20 or you find "a dank bag of oregano". I get it, but it feels a bit too much at times.

On that note, some scenes and dialogues feel weirdly too sexual. Again, I'm not against it in a pearl-clutching puritanical way, but more like "why is this here". Especially [spoiler]on the 5 minutes wait section at the bank (which, btw, pretty funny on its own)[/spoiler] it really felt uncomfortable at times, since I literally can't do anything as a player to move away from the situation. As much as a I get that is a dark game with dark comedy and all, in this specific case it felt a bit unnecessary.

Finally, let's talk gameplay. Usually a RPGM game is gonna have, well, RPG elements, specially turn based combat. Ignoring the shortcomings that may occur just by the fact of using RPGM as an engine, the combats themselves seemed unbalanced, specially with the addition of Jerome. Seeing that obtaining the one and only party member of the game feels like a secondary quest that can be missed, It's not hard to imagine that combat could get frustrating fast as a one man army. But with Jerome, having the chance of paralysing enemies from 1 to 5 turns to do whatever you want, some boss battles are incredibly trivialized, including the final boss battle, which takes away most of the dramatic charge of the encounter.

Additionally, random encounters, especially in the Undercity, feel way more powerful than their boss counterparts. Farming for some upgrades felt complicated and a bit hard on resources, since save points don't recover HP/MP, but then getting said upgrades and leveling up felt like overkill for certain bosses, since there is a real chance of perma stunning them for the whole combat.

Summing it all up:
[list]
[*] Narrative and overall dialogue is held back by a bit too much of weed and sex jokes
[*] Gameplay lacks polishing and balancing
[*] Jerome feels simultaneously too strong because of paralysis and too weak because of low damage output
[*] Lacking a heal on save mechanic strain too many resources on healing items
[/list]

[h1]Conclusions and final notes[/h1]
Suits: A Business RPG is a love letter to the classics and an overall enjoyable experience if you are used to games on this vibe. With a final personal score of a 7/10, I'd say it's a good entry point in the subgenre of Fucked Up RPGM Games at 4 hours of game time for 1$.

Great references to Mortis Ghost and the Batter, by the way. Got a chuckle out of me Definetly worth it for a dollar or less.
I mean you can fight a guy who is literally name "Wife beater Peter", what else could you desire from a game?
full of easter eggs and funny references There is a short sequence in this game that I can only describe as "unwanted sexual advances"

It was a pretty neat game.

name: Rorschach Plus
short_description: Rorschach Plus is a precise, experimental puzzle platformer where you use paint to reveal your surroundings.
reviews:
I really had a lot of fun with this platformer and for the price, you really can't complain. I don't want to give too much away. If the pictures make you curious, then give the game a chance. Rorschach's journal: January 19, 2021

On Tuesday night, a new video game got released, based solely on my true existence. You can paint the levels like how I painted my face. This will be the riddle to solve the clues behind Pyramid's corrupt organization. Like in all games and movies, there's good and there is evil, and evil must be punished. Even in the face of Armageddon. Never compromise. Never back down.

Rorschach's entry, of the video game "Rorschach". Signed by Rorschach himself
Good joke. Everybody laugh.
*roll on snare drum*
*curtains* cool idea cool funny Disclaimer: My scores/reviews are almost always based on having bought the game at close to the "lowest historical price" on steam at time of purchase.

Quick score: 3/5

Notes: Pretty basic platformer with a decent art style and a visual gimmick. Unfortunately the gimmick isn't really used in any interesting ways and is just kind of a pre-level chore you need to complete before actually playing the game. Difficulty is maybe average or slightly below and the game can be completed in about 30 minutes without any real replayability.

Wouldn't recommend playing the game with a controller, so avoid if that is your intent.

Also another annoyance worth mentioning. For some reason rather than have a variable jump button, you have 2 seperate jump buttons for short and long.

Not great but not bad. 
For .49 cents sure why not. Annoying to play with a controller. Using the button is a mini hop. You have to press up on the joystick to actually get a proper jump. Feels awkward because when you're moving to the side and trying to jump it's sort of this over and up motion which doesn't feel right. Can't think of any platformer that I've ever played that had that.

Other than that, I found it way too trial and error right from the start. Ease the player into the game with the hidden mechanic. I really don't feel like grinding from 1 minute in. Super Cable Boy and Charge Kid are a couple I'll recommend for others to check out. Those are fun, challenging and have a nice difficulty progression. Cute little game and at such a low price! It has some pretty interesting mechanics that make it a nice spin on the precision platformer genre. Challenging but really well crafted and the sound design and palette work is really cute. That being said I would like some adjustments or additions in the future, like the option to pick a palette, adjustable controls (I prefer arrowkeys and z over wasd), and maybe even like a little crt filter and some extra levels, heck I'd even pitch a couple bucks towards a deluxe edition upgrade or sequel with those adjustments. That being said I do get stuck on some levels due to the puzzle design (the fall guys level is takin me quite awhile, wish it was maybe towards the tail end of the levelpack), but overall I think for 99c, sometimes 50c on sale, there's no way you can go wrong with a purchase. i played the game This is a very fun retro platformer with an original twist at a bargain price point. There are many precision platformers on Steam and this one manages to add something new. A must buy for fans of the genre. Platformer where most of the map is covered up, and you have a limited number of 'splatters' to reveal parts of the level. Not particularly challenging but still fun, and considering how cheap it is, it's worth picking up.

name: ROGUE-FP
short_description: A blend of old school gameplay and new school controls. Experience a classically styled roguelike in a way you never have before!
reviews:
Quite unique take on a classic rogue-like, liking it! [b]I like ROGUE-FP.
I recorded my progress in ROGUE-FP, as well as some observations & thoughts.
Please take a look if you prefer a more audio / visual format.[/b]
https://youtu.be/JCIjBNmouNQ

ROGUE-FP is an Indie, turn based Roguelike Dungeon Crawler that is First Person.
It is Rogue, in a more accessible, striking first person perspective.
Would you like to know more?

[h1]A More Accessible Take on Rogue?[/h1]
Yes.
ROGUE-FP has the random dungeons of Rogue, made with Procedural Generation, but rendered in a striking, ASCII inspired, first person style, massively improving the immersion in the dark, yet simultaneously vivid and eye-catching dungeons.
ROGUE-FP feels very Matrix like, yet fantasy, and not everything is green, with a lot of brightness, spaced in-between and against very dark backgrounds, if that helps explain it better.
It‚Äôs really one of those things that must be seen.
I like it.

Plus, ROGUE-FP has 5 difficulties; available right at the start; good.
I‚Äôm playing on Medium here, because hunting for secret doors all day is not fun‚Ä¶
Thankfully, the gameplay is.

Controller Support is present, as are rebindable keys, but I found the inventory navigation with the gamepad not great, only able to use items, not throw or drop them; not great.
Thankfully, good old Mouse and Keyboard control is present, and very good, so that is mostly what I used in the above video.

While I did enjoy my time with ROGUE-FP, I did find many areas where it would be even better.
Please let me know if any of this is off-base, but I find directness works best here. 
I will try and keep this organized.

[b] Tech / Bugs:[/b]
[h1]1: Bug: Listen To The Controller Game![/h1]
After alt tabbing out, then going back in, it takes a bit before I can look around again with the controller.
This can easily get you killed, as it seems you must move around with the gamepad a bit to get the game to remember it is being used.

[h1]2: Bug: I Found a Secret Door, on Medium‚Ä¶[/h1]
Intended?
I thought those were limited to the highest difficulty?

[h1]3: Scale That Inventory Window![/h1]
Having to Mouse scroll the tiny thing every time I open it, rapidly gets annoying.
Simply scale it so everything in it is visible at once if the inventory is opened; that would be much more user friendly.

[h1]4: MY EYES![/h1]
Ouch.
What a painful title screen.
It looks good when you‚Äôre not trying to do anything on it, but if you are‚Ä¶
I found the frequently moving screens very distracting; and it hurts my eyes when I‚Äôm trying to go through the game options.
I strongly suspect this will really bug others as well, so please pause the constant screen looping when the options screen is open.

[h1]5: Which Should I Choose?[/h1]
Dig Dungeon? Classic Mode?
What does that mean?
The simple action of starting the game should not generate confusion‚Ä¶
This represents a failure on the first screen.
I strongly recommend replacing the current options with a simple ‚ÄúStart Run‚Äù or something, then another window, with a pop-up message explaining the difference between the 2 options.

[b]Gameplay Suggestions:[/b]

[h1]6: It‚Äôs Black on Black![/h1]
Should really warn the players when they walk out into the blackness, as the pit fall will kill them, yet it can be very difficult to see, given that the floor and walls are also often black!

[strike][h1]7: Fast Throw Badly Needed![/h1]
Having to open inventory, mouse scroll down to select your darts / shurikens, then RMB over them in order to throw one feels slow and terrible!
A hotkey for fast throwing is needed here; badly![/strike]
[b]Edit: You can directly equip and throw the arrows without a bow[/b]
I did not think to equip and throw the arrows; just so use to needing the bow.
Now I know.
This will make handling snakes much less toxic to my muscles!

[h1]8: Jump Please![/h1]
I‚Äôm an athletic Fighter-man, not a squishy wizard-man, let me run and jump!

[b]Edit: Don‚Äôt need bow; can just throw[/b]
Would still like a bow
[strike][h1]9: At least Start Me With a Bow Man![/h1]
Let me range those snakes, and put my starting 24 arrows to use!
It‚Äôs just a tease otherwise!
Plus, those strength draining snakes are brutal![/strike]

[b]Not Strictly Rogue Gameplay Suggestions:[/b]
I gave this one its own category, as I understand the idea here was to cleave as closely to Rogue as possible, while putting your own spin on it, but basic Rogue feels very limited today.

[u]The addition of more player choice here would only help the game, while allowing an opportunity to more sharply delineate the differences between the classic mode, and a game that is Rogue like, but not strictly rogue in first person, plus monster bits.[/u]

[h1]10: Starting Absent Any Healing Feels Really Bad.[/h1]
We have no pocket prayers, no starting healing potions, or spells to help us out; if we get poor luck, we just die.
We are an extremely unprepared, poorly equipped, fighter wanna be, sent down here to die.
These abilities, added to roguelikes like the excellent NetHack, classic ADoM, or ToME, present tools the player can use to offset and survive terrible RNG: that these features are not present here really hurts the gameplay, reducing it to RNG map luck, and knowing to avoid fighting certain monsters like snakes unless they are sleeping.

[h1]11: No Choice on Lvl Up?[/h1]
The total lack of player choice concerning lvl ups from Rogue and Nethack, paired simultaneously with the lack of depth with the complete removal of any classes here, does much to remove much of the possible depth of the game.
This results in runs that feel very similar.
This is bad.

[h1]12: Let Fighter-mans Learn![/h1]
Listen: I know he‚Äôs not smart: he can‚Äôt even read!
[i]I bet those scrolls are actually written in common; he‚Äôs so ashamed![/i]
But he can learn!
It‚Äôs not his fault!
Just give him a chance!
At least give this man an Int score!
Let him try!
Maybe with enough Int, he can learn to read?!
Maybe even learn some magic from spellbooks!
Anything to be more than just another dumb fighter!

[h1]13: % = Down Stair?[/h1]
Why not >?
That % was really throwing me.
Yes, it looks like an escalator (how deluxe), but just used to the greater than.
Maybe add an option to swap them in options?

Anyway, my many critiques aside, I did enjoy my time with ROGUE-FP.
ROGUE-FP is an Indie, turn based Roguelike Dungeon Crawler that is First Person.
It is Rogue, in an accessible, striking new look.
Watch? This is an updated version of Rogue (1980) its got a fresh coat of paint, the swap to first person, and time only taking effect when you perform an action. 
There are two game modes available Dig dungeon and Classic mode.
Dig Dungeon is the developers own little twist on the classic with more unique level generation and the addition of monster bits occasionally dropped by slain enemies that provide small bonuses.
Classic mode is as close to a faithful recreation as possible to the original for better or for worse. Awesome game, true to the original. This is a rather remarkable version of Rogue, and I'm inclined at an early stage of engagement with it to state that it may very well be the definitive version of this storied, honored, and hugely influential classic- especially for modern audiences. The first person perspective totally works and importantly, it still feels 100% like Rogue. Veterans of the game will feel a strong sense of "home" with it, while also enjoying the change in format. The hybrid ASCII/3D graphics are BRILLIANT, capturing Rogue's unique atavism and abstraction without sacrificing  modernity. I love the monster bits, which add a fun set collecting angle to equipment upgrades. Again, it's a feature that wasn't in the original game but feels absolutely true to the spirit of the core design. While it doesn't have the ludricous depth, lore, or complexity of Caves of Qud and similar modern roguelikes, there is an elemental simplicity here that is both charming and appealing. The tutorials are excellent and non-obtrusive, and the UI is uniformly excellent and easy to navigate. For five bucks, this has got to be one of the best bang-for-the-buck purchases you can make here on Steam. A respectful but innovative edition that should have a higher profile among today's game players. Two things I should mention first: 
1. In the grand scheme of things I've barely touched this game yet, so I'll sink in a few more hours into it, then maybe edit this review if necessary. 
2. I have never played the original "Rogue" but I have a combined total of well over 1k hours in rogue-likes in general.

So far, this is really, really good! Time only moves when you do, or when you do an action like equipping a different weapon or something, so you have the time to strategize and plan your next move. The art style is seriously phenomenal too, although I can see why some people wouldn't like it. Falling down a pit can kill you if your health is low enough (I think), but otherwise you just go down a level, and I think that's neat. Enemies drop "Monster Bits" that you can use to slot into your armor, and some of them can even be eaten if you don't have an alternative source of food. The game also doesn't feel as punishing as some other rogue-likes, and some of the monster bits even up the chances for finding specific stuff in the dungeon like wands or weapons or whatnot.
Also, you can actually use explosives to break down the walls of the dungeon, opening new pathways.

I don't really know what to say other than it's well worth the full price, and that YOU SHOULD TRY THIS GEM!!!!! TLDR: An amazing re-imagining of a classic dungeon crawler that many, like myself, have never been exposed to. Highly recommend for everyone who is a fan of dungeon crawlers, modern or traditional, and rougelike fans. This game is insanely fun and an instant classic. 10 Emus out of 10!!!

OH MY GOD THIS GAME IS SO FUCKING GOOD!!!!! I'm a huge sucker for dungeon crawlers that take place in a single dungeon so I already loved the idea of this. Then I come to learn that this is a twist on a game older than me!! Did some more digging and learned that this is basically that very same game but with a modern angle!! This game is great, even though im having a tough time getting past floor 7 on Rouge difficulty, its still super fun to play. 
If you're a fan of dungeon crawlers than this is the game for you!! 

It has a tab in the main menu title "How To Play" and it does seem a little overwhelming at first glace because of the amount of information, but I promise you it's not that bad and if you're familiar with games like this then you'll catch on pretty fast. It also helps that a more active tutorial is available as soon start your first dungeon dive. This gives you a shortened, more hands on approach of the tutorial and even mentions that the "How To Play" tab will have more detailed information. However, if you're like me, you'll click that first before entering the dungeon for the first time. The active tutorial teaches you things as you encounter them as well which is a great way to teach someone.

There is also a "Classic Mode" which emulates the original Rouge's dungeon layout. This mode is a little bare bones compared to the normal dungeon, but it's still a fun experience. Same enemies and random drops as far as I can tell from what I've played of the classic mode. I usually play this mode as sort of a "speed run" mode just because of how flat it is. That's not a knock either, it's still really fun to run through and it's neat that players can experience what the original game was like to some degree.

During my googling I had also learned through a reddit post that this is the creator's first game and I have to say I'm really impressed. So I just wanted to take the time real fast and say thanks for recreating a classic that I had no idea even existed before this game. I also want you to know that I will also be purchasing a GOG copy so I can be sure to have this game forever.  I really enjoyed playing the original rogue but it was always difficult getting back into it cause of how dated the game is. That being said I am thoroughly enjoying Rogue-FP , the developer put in a lot of love into revitalizing this classic game while adding their own subtle touch to it. One of the best games I own. Period.
 While not having the entire featureset and depth of the original Rogue (and especially not Nethack, the gold standard in my eyes), this game is a brilliantly done reinterpretation of Rogue with cool graphics option (will always prefer the funky ASCII/textured environment option) with loads of deadly twists and turns with two game modes to explore.  Excellence.

name: Wolf or Boy
short_description: Wolf or Boy is a simulation game in which you can experience a physiological battle between humans and werewolves. Hearing a rumor that horrible murders are repeated in a village in the middle of nowhere, you decide to visit the site. Apparently, how they got killed is not a human beings doing. There are werewolves amongst the villagers..
reviews:
Lets get the verdict out of the way: *MISSED OPPORTUNITY!*

That being said, let me explain why the above has been determined after close to an hour of playing this game.  This game has a poop show of misleading sales pitch in the ‚ÄúAbout‚Äù section of the games store page.  Quite literally every single point that is made on the ‚ÄúAbout Page‚Äù uses a kernel of truth, that is worded in a way to bloat your expectations.   Let me start by explaining the features point for point:

*This game is based on the popular table game ‚ÄúAre You a Werewolf?‚Äù*
	Should have been a trigger warning that you based this around the bargain bin version of ‚ÄúThe Village‚Äù.  While not an inherently bad problem with the game, it is a symptom as the game itself seems to miss the most important part of the table top that makes that game so much fun‚Ä¶  The player interactions.   You have literally no legitimate character interactions in this game.  Every ‚Äúchoice‚Äù you make just triggers unintelligible random numbers to determine if you are dead or alive each day.

*You and the rest of the participants bring his or her partner to the game.*
	Excuse me?  This is worded as if you are playing a multiplayer game, is that on the forecast for updates to the game?  Its features like this that lead me to believe this is a early access title that is being marketed as a full release game.

*Each partner can use a unique ability which can be used to determine who are werewolves or protect yourself against their attacks.*
	While this is technically true, it is so poorly implemented.  Despite having abilities that should have saved me, I was still executed without reason or logic.  Sure you have abilities.  They don‚Äôt matter.  I will explain this a little later.

*You partner can become better at executing this ability as you win more battles.*
	This eludes to a leveling system in the game, where you can grow stronger/more powerful as the game progresses.  An hour into the game, and I can see absolutely no relevance to the ‚Äúcharacter level‚Äù at all.  Zero, none, nada, so either this feature is broken completely, or like many other gameplay mechanics, they don‚Äôt matter cause the AI can decide to arbitrarily kill you with no logic or reason.

*You are free to customize your partner‚Äôs character*
	These options are so limited they might as well not be there.  The developers descriptions keep eluding to a story, but there is nothing here.  Your choices for your partner don‚Äôt matter, and the partner itself does quite literally nothing.  What exactly is wrong with simply making the partner, your character?  It makes no sense, and amounts to nothing gameplay wise, or narrative wise.  Side note: Character voices sound like straight mumbling, and there are no English voice overs.  Even in Japanese the voice overs are snippits and unintelligible.

*You don‚Äôt know how the story runs every time you play, you can enjoy playing the unique game forever!*
	You don‚Äôt know the story cause there is no story.  You cannot claim there is a story, when you provide no interactable characters with unique personalities, no instances of communicative dialogue/decisions that have any impact, and no narrative reason for anything to happen.  The game is literally the same game each time, crafted as if the developers straight ripped off the rules from ‚ÄúAre you a werewolf‚Äù without ever playing the game to get inspiration.  

Those features amount to a general state of false advertisement in this game (including the trailer).  The game moves through the motions of the table top, but it leaves out all of the interactive story telling/narrative possibilities that simply interacting with characters would provide.   There are no characters in this game in its current state.  James, stein, marvin, etc etc, don‚Äôt matter.

You get to ask 1 of 4 questions each day.  The ‚Äúcharacters‚Äù will randomly provide no information, or an answer and all of the possibilities end there with no relevance.  Soon as the choice is made, random numbers are rolled and you get to find out if you die or not.
If you don‚Äôt die, you get to use an ability to your ‚Äúclass‚Äù, but after an hour of playing the game, I never got to use a single ability as ‚Äúknight‚Äù, ‚ÄúFortune teller‚Äù or ‚Äúpriest‚Äù.  Maybe it‚Äôs a random chance based on your level that your class will get to use the job?  Game gives no indicator, like all other aspects of the game, it literally gives you zero information about how to play, what things do, and when you can use them.  Even after an hour, amassing 44 coins, I was never able to use the shop which merits extra experience for classes.  The whole experience leaves me feeling like this game is not finished.

Even if the intent of designing this game was to straight rip off the board game in an effort to cash out, the developers managed to some how leave out 75 percent of what makes the board game it was based on fun.  (How the flip does that happen if you are interested in your craft?)

Don‚Äôt be a loser like me, don‚Äôt buy this game.   Its not worth the dollar asking price.
In closing, there is no story in this game.  There is no real gameplay in this game beyond straight random number generation.  There is no value in this game.   I would be curious to see if this game is still in development, and if it is, then get your shit properly represented devs.  Stop being dishonest, its not necessary, and you do have a possibly interesting title if you gave it some actual effort.

Yet again, another shitty werewolf title on steam.  Maybe one day I will stop buying these and temper my expectations from ‚Äúdesperate consumer‚Äù.

name: Pixel Maze
short_description: The game fills the color with a digital cue, all the numbers are interlocked, and each step must be patiently calculated to finally break the maze. If you like puzzle games, want to challenge difficult, and have a lot of time, come play!
reviews:
give me more There's an absolutely massive amount of content for $1. If you're a fan of minesweeper/nonograms or similar logic-based puzzles then this is a great title to pick up.

There seems to be a save bug where if you save a puzzle, close the game, open it, and load the puzzle, then you won't be able to save the puzzle again properly. So you either finish it in the second session or lose your progress. The other reviews here seem to see that as a deal-breaker, but it's really not that hard to just finish a puzzle within two play sessions...It would be really nice if the developer had fixed it some time over the past year though.

I've almost finished the game and have yet to see any other bugs related to the saves or anything else. The UI is smooth and responsive, and I haven't had any issues with it either. [b]2024 edit:[/b] price went from $1 to $4 in october 2023, years after the game came out, but still no patches or fixes. despicable.

a very difficult fill-a-pix puzzler with color images. you get a blank canvas with a bunch of numbers and a 3x3 cursor, and you have to figure out which square gets which color. the result is a picture and a sense of accomplishment, as guessing is not necessary.

216 levels from 8x8 to 59x59, no timer, no ratings, zoom in/out, and it used to be unbelievably cheap even at full price until 2023, but that's all there was on the positive side, with several things outweighing it on the negative, unfortunately.

first of all, the game starts up in chinese, have to change it in the settings (unless you know chinese, of course), where you can't find any volume sliders, just on/off for music and sound, but since it was made in unity and the launcher is enabled, resolution options and windowed mode are available on startup.

there are a lot of typos, and it's got nothing to do with not being a native speaker, it just reeks of laziness when there are no spaces where they should be and half the level names start with capital letters while the rest don't. I posted a somewhat better english translation in the [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1806310561]guides section[/url].

the worst thing and the major dealbreaker is how saving and loading works, or most of the time doesn't work. if you quit a level, [b]it doesn't save your progress, you have to do it manually[/b] to one of the 3 slots, which is something you can get used to, and at least there's more than one slot. if you want to continue, you can only do so by going back to the main menu and load ('read') that puzzle, because if you simply open it again from level select, it's gonna get reset.

this would all be tolerable, especially for such a low price and such a huge amount of content, except [b]saving and loading is buggy as hell[/b]. the only thing that works is the save getting deleted when you solve the level. you might be able to load your progress from the last session, but even then it's not sure if you can save it again. if you do each puzzle in one sitting, it's not an issue, but for some reason I find this game really difficult, and I normally do fine with nonograms and the like, so even a 15x15 level can take a considerable amount of time, and I have no idea how long (and with a limited amount of time, how many sessions) a 50x50 would take, but proper saving and loading is essential in any video game anyway.

there's a hint button that solves a 3x3 square, but it can only be used once per level (twice for bigger puzzles), though it resets if you load the level again (if you can, that is), so if you're really desperate, there are ways to get more hints.

and while it's not a huge deal for me, achievements are also iffy. I finished the first 3 pages, loaded the first level on page 4 and I still only had achievements for the first 2 chapters, 3 and 4 only got unlocked after reaching page 5.

as levels go by, their size increases, and while zoom is an option (and most welcome, especially when playing in windowed mode), moving the picture around easily is not. another huge oversight. there is a button that lets you cycle through incomplete numbers, so you can click that a few times, zoom in, etc. but it's awkward and there's no way to center the level after that at all.

I really wanted to recommend this game, but in such a broken state, and with only a single patch a few days after release, so no real chance of it ever getting fixed, I simply can't. I hope more similar games will come to steam eventually, there are a few link-a-pix titles, and of course plenty of nonogram/picross games, but nothing like this. Flipped my review after further playing. The underlying mechanic (basically fill-a-pix) is great, a step-by-step pure logic puzzler with lots of pretty colors. The interface, however, is a mess. The English translation desperately need a thorough edit; the color palette behaves in lots of odd and non-intuitive ways; it's far too linear; and the level save is not only clunky, but eats saves. 

I desperately wanted to make it work, as I love the mechanic and there's very few similar games on Steam, but after struggling to get through a bottleneck and then having two level saves eaten simultaneously, I give up.

Runs great on Steamplay (Mint 18.2, Nvidia proprietary), which is only good thing I can say about it and most of that credit goes to Unity3d.

short_description: You wake up in a strange place reduced to a six-toed foot load of enemies are trying to wash you! FIght them by wall jumping and shooting your extra toe at them, while you try to find your way out.
reviews: Amazing game. Simple, yet challenging. Makes me wanna play more and see what's next. Music and audio effects made it so much better, looks cool, and those little foot thoughts made me feel like I really am that sad foot and we have to get out. Overall I love it! :D

name: Nightmare Reaper
short_description: Progress through the cursed depths of a nightmare while finding an arsenal of powerful weapons and improving your abilities along the way. This retro-inspired FPS with looter shooter and rogue-lite elements breaches the wall between classic and modern gameplay.
reviews:
A game where you fight your inner demons-- literally.

Nightmare Reaper is a boomer shooter with rogue-lite progression. Every map is separated by three sequential levels, where you can collect gold and topaz for which can be spent minigames for permanent stat upgrades. Jade is the third currency, acquired through playing arenas. 

Hundreds of weapons, dozens of enemies and gallons of blood await in the depths of demon-infested caves, cities, mines, dockyards, prisons, ruins, and wherever else you may be needed for extermination.

The game's only 25 bucks but it definitely gives more than its money's worth in a bloody good time. Boom shoot good Yeah, it's pretty good.  You flush a toilet, turn the light switch a lot.  Um...I remember petting the dog and slaughtering hordes of demons with a bug gun.  Also grappling hooks.  And multiplayer is being worked on.  So that's neat.

Many secrets.  Good for long gaming sessions or short one off runs.  Unlockables are endless until they end. It's a Boomer Shooter, and a Roguelite! What is not to love? This game is amazing This game is awesome! I would highly recommend this game to anyone who likes boomer shooters and likes a lot of variety in weapons to choose from. I think this game is a hidden gem that deserves more attention. Nightmare Reaper is a must play for fans of boomer shooters, FPS, roguelites, or all of the above. This game sat in my library for so long unplayed, but the second I hopped in playing, I put in about 16 hours before playing anything else. Outside of running / controlling perfectly on steam deck, the game does exactly what it says on the box: provides a classic boomer shooter experience updated with modern game design elements such as loot drops and skill trees. I won't spoil anything, but the skill tree system in this game is incredibly smart and engaging, and the loot system is present but not impactful on gameplay in a negative way (i.e. there's no meta to follow or Destiny-esque power level grind, simply find some weapons you like, use them, rinse and repeat). Narrative is present and handled creatively, with small dripfeeds of story and exploration. All weapons come with alt-fires that change the way they can be used in combat, and enemies are varied to a point where it does impact the way and order in which you engage them.

I've played (and loved) games like Project Warlock and Forgive Me Father, but this game just got its hooks in me like no other game in its genre recently has. Definitely worth a few hours (or days) of your time! A celebration of all things retro with excellent sound design, kick-ass sound track and a compelling setting. 10/10 10/10 CLUTTER SIMULATOR I'm just going through a personal issue in life. And this game was helpful. REALLY.. helpful.

I got all the achievements cause this game is actually GREAT and addicting. The new game plus keeps you invested.

But my only complain is the 500 powerups achievements. NO WAY a sane person would spend that much time to get all this through normal ways. Aside from that, Great game. Great flow. Dev did a great job and Andrew too (with the badass music).

name: Sophica - Temples Of Mystery
short_description: Sophica: Temples Of Mystery, is a First Person, Puzzle Platformer. You wake up in your bed, look outside to see that you are among the clouds. „ÄäIs this a dream?„Äã You continue forward to see what this is about, the mystery lies ahead... Easy to play, but hard to master.
reviews:
Spent about 5 hours with this game. I'm not gonna say stay away from it, but expect to get what you pay for.

The jumping is something I've seen complained about, and I completely understand why. This is one of those platformers where you need to time your jumps right, and watch what's above you, especially in level 4 when scaling up the wall. Failure is absolutely punishing. I can't complain about this, I'd rather my mistakes be my own fault so I can learn from it.

The brightness. Why the fuck is there not an option to turn it down? Only thing I have to say about that.

There's really not much else to it...This game is well...yeah...If you have 3$ to burn, might as well try it out.

I recommend this, but if you have sensitive eyes like I do, I don't. The brightness will strain your eyes. Please be cautious. pretty okish would recommend for tree buck It feels very peaceful at the start by soft colors and music but after a certain point, game becomes really hard for casual platform gamers. It gives the same feeling as "Getting Over It", some people may enjoy but not me. [h1]Video (gameplay + commentary):[/h1] 
https://youtu.be/y4_wZO2b90o

[h1]Review:[/h1]
Up front let me say that I don't totally dislike this game and I hope it improves, at which point I would love to switch this "not recommended" rating to "recommended." I think some of my issues below are even covered in the developer's post-release roadmap and I'm looking forward to seeing how that all goes.

Bottom line: At the moment, I don't think the game is particularly fun as a platformer.

The game has some good things going for it: some very pleasing visuals, very soothing music, and some low stress environments where you don't feel like you need to rush your platforming.

All that being said, the platforming levels themselves as well as the overall feeling of movement leave much to be desired. Jumping is very floaty and feels like you're gliding on the moon. Likewise general movement feels slightly like you're skating around, and also your momentum is hard to stop if you're trying to change direction in mid air. None of these things to me are issues individually, but combined it leads to a lot of situations where you're overshooting small platforms and falling either into a bottomless pit (where the game kindly sets you back more or less where you were when you fell), or far more punishing, you fall all the way down to the very base of a series of platforms you were slowly but surely making your way up.

Which is also part of the issue I think: a lot of the platforming is simply scaling a multitude of platforms to get to the top of something, be it to collect items needed to reach the exit, or to get to the exit itself. This is both not particularly interesting and feels severely punishing if you fall after climbing 30+ platforms only to have to do it all again.

There are some deviations to this formula, but they too I think could use some refinement. As an example, one puzzle has you picking up colored cubes and putting them on colored platforms which can only be reached by carrying the cube while hopping over platforms suspended over a bottomless pit. The issue here is the cube covers half your view. Ultimately it just makes platforming feel cheap and frustrating as it feels like the game blindfolded you rather than tested any actual measure of your platforming skill.

This was my general impression from all the stages I played. Again, the game looks nice and sounds nice, but handles not great and the platforming elements just weren't very exciting. And again, I'm hopeful the game improves. I think it has a lot of potential and I'd love to come back and relax with the game's soothing music and hopefully upgraded platforming.

I also wanted to mention -- though I'm confident this will get fixed pretty quickly -- I ran into a showstopping bug about 5 levels in where after falling into a bottomless pit, it respawned me somewhere without platforms, and thus I was stuck in an infinite loop of falling. Even restarting the game couldn't fix this. Again, I'm sure this'll get fixed fast, but worth noting until it does.
