name: Tube Be Continued
short_description: Prepare for a tube-based, puzzle-filled, HAM-PACKED VR adventure with our charismatic hamster leader: The BOSS. Here at TUBE Industries we provide the puzzles, and you provide‚Ä¶ the brains. No shady business here!
reviews: It's a so far cute and fun game, the game is well polished so far and has a good mix of puzzles and mini games with some customization. It seems to stutter when using the manual movement otherwise runs fine.

name: War of Bellrook
short_description: Go forth on a text-based, choose your own adventure where you can choose your role and embark on adventure as various different people who tread different paths.
reviews:
In less than 30 minutes I have played through twice now.  Once I died in the second battle, and figured I'd try again and see how far I could get.  The second play saw me win the second battle, and... the game was over with a win.

Not worth $3.99, unfortunately. Not bad.
Good narration.

Simple, well written stories that do not require too much brain stress.  :-)
*Pass the beer and pretzels. Heh! Pretty good little CYOA stories.  Fully voiced as well, which is neat.  Check out the Peasant story for at least one really amusing option.

name: Fantasy Grounds - D&D Basic Rules and Theme
short_description: A custom theme derived in the same style as the Player's HandbookRandom tables for rolling background bonds, flaws, ideals, origins, etc.Equipment tables containing items that can be dragged to character sheets, treasure parcels or NPCs for ease of reference, encumbrance calculations and ease of disbursement.
reviews: Theme keeps crashing when seleting items and maps. Gives a display error. This is for the latest build. This is a conversion of the free PDF available on Wizard's website. You may be wondering why this is not free as well... What you're paying $3 for is the incredibly useful ability to drag and drop and auto-populate data into your character build. If you've ever attempted to build a character by hand in FG you understand that it is quite time consuming, requires constant reference to the Player's Guide, and a there's a lot of room for human error. If you're new to FG, or just can't drop $50 on the Full Core Class Pack, this is an excellent purchase for experimenting with character builds (w/ limited selection of Races, Classes, Backgrounds, equipment, etc). Got this mainly for the Theme, but the theme doesn't appear to show up and I really se no difference from the core application.

name: Mechanics
short_description: Creatively use a combination of mechanics to get to the end of each level in this isometric puzzle platformer.
reviews: This game slaps tell ya mother This game rivals AAA titles for creativity and difficulty. Worth the price, great music. first IBS simulator. really felt like i had IBS the whole time

name: Mortadelo y Filem√≥n: Una aventura de cine - Edici√≥n especial
short_description: The return of the adventures "Two sloppy cowboys" and "Terror, horror and fear" in a special edition that is the best and most modern work of the Spanish studio Alcachofa Soft in the franchise.
reviews:
6/10 Estoy escribiendo esta rese√±a en espa√±ol y en alem√°n (los dos idiomas con los que crec√≠). Cuando vi por casualidad que este juego estaba disponible en la tienda de Steam, tuve que comprarlo inmediatamente. Cu√°ntos recuerdos de mi infancia. Aunque crec√≠ en Alemania, consum√≠ mucha m√∫sica, series, pel√≠culas y libros espa√±oles debido a las visitas a la familia en Barcelona.

Yo describir√≠a el juego como la versi√≥n espa√±ola de Edna & Harvey. Algunos rompecabezas son sencillos, otros son enrevesados, pero en general es divertido. 

_________________________________________________________________________________

Ich schreibe dieses Review mal auf Spanisch und auf Deutsch (den zwei Sprachen mit denen ich aufgewachsen bin). Als ich irgendwann mal durch Zufall gesehen habe, dass es dieses Game im Steam-Store gibt musste ich es direkt kaufen. So viele Erinnerungen an meine Kindheit. Auch wenn ich in Deutschland aufgewachsen bin habe ich durch die Besuche der Familie in Barcelona sehr viel spanische Musik, Serien, Filme und B√ºcher konsumiert. 

Ich w√ºrde das Game als die spanische Version von Edna & Harvey beschreiben. Manche R√§tsel sind einfach, manche sind verworren, aber im Gro√üen und Ganzen macht es Spa√ü.

name: Invasion Machine
short_description: Modern-warfare RTS/sandbox game inspired by the real conflicts in the Middle East. Fight a counter-insurgency war, protect the civilian population, casevac your wounded and decide how the world sees your struggle. And remember - no one gets left behind.
reviews:
The AI IS SO BAD. I have NEVER in my life seen AI so bad. Running pointlessly in circles, running into burning HUMVEE wreckage, weird pathing issues, crouching and panicking without taking any cover first, it's ridiculous. The game is very unfinished and doesn't seem to be actively developed. unfinished dead game I understand this is EA, but i cant recommend it for 18.99. I havent been able to functionally leave the starting area in an hour of play time. The UI, pathfinding, and AI is pretty abysmal. Its clunky. Units and vehicles get stuck on everything and my guys shoot like they are blindfolded with arms made of jello. Updates are very infrequent. Its an awesome concept of a game, and I hope to see it further its development, but it needs too much work to recommend in its current state. Unless you're going to actively contribute to the game via feedback/testing and communicating with the dev, this game is currently frustrating in its current state.

-AI will get stuck on parked/disabled cars.
-Current missions are given out right at the start of the game that might be overwhelming if you're starting out.
-There's too much micro management, I wish this was more squad based controls/instructions and maybe controlling individual units when you want something specific.
-UI is also frustrating, I have to move medics away from a wounded/disabled person after stabilizing to pick them up, since your pointer focus will always go to the medic instead of the wounded person. Its been about 5 years, while this type of game has a ton of potential. I cannot suggest buying it as it has been virtually unsupported in that time, and when updates do come out it fixes one thing and breaks another lol game's as good as dead and very unfinished Cannot possibly recommend.

     The pathfinding is absolutely dire. I have lost count of the number of times men and vehicles have gotten stuck. The AI is a joke, both enemy and friendly. The UI keeps breaking, with the sub-missions overgrowing the unit orders panel, forcing you to use the contextual command wheel. The contextual command wheel thing is awful and will take years off of your life, I honestly just wanted to turn it off the entire time. And worst of all this is one of those games that confuses "realism" with being as pedantic as it possibly can. This is one of the most tedious RTS games I have ever played. As an example, to build a building you have to;

1. Send a truck to the off map HQ
2. Wait a minuet for it to get there
3. Manually order it to load with building supplies
4. Order it into a convoy
5. Pick out the driver
6. Order the convoy to to return to the AO
7. Wait a minuet for the truck to get back
8. Order the truck to the build site (remember to watch it the whole way or else it WILL get itself stuck!)
9. Order the truck to unload the building supplies
10. Order a soldier to build the building (you WILL need to keep an eye on him or he will just give up half way)
11. Realize that the largest cargo truck you have doesn't carry enough materials to finish the building, so you are going to have to repeat the process!

     It is a similar process for Evacuating wounded, taking prisoners, and supplying locals with aid. Does this make the game feel more authentic? No. Does it make the game harder, Not really. Just really really tedious. When a game spawn camps you and forces you to restart multiple times without even being able to leave the starting area, one must wonder if it is a skill issue or a game issue.

Clearly a skill issue, I should've dodged the RPG fire right out of the gate and smoked the 40 insurgents and growing with my elite team of 8 Not worth your money:
Doesnt get regular updates
Not in anyway optimised 

Really good concept but at the minute lots of things are broke and its been in early access for ages. 

Ive tried playing a few times and its meant to be an insurgency type combat however it just spawns hordes of enemies and its a constant attack on my troops before they can even do any of the humanatarian missions or projects..

Dont waste your money

name: Halloween Stories: Horror Movie
short_description: Four friends are pulled inside a movie where the special effects are all too real!
reviews: Although it's only three hours in length and has no bonus game, the quality of this title would justify picking it up on deep discount. The art work is beautifully realized and the story is interesting. This game is awful.  I got it on sale, so I am not too upset with the loss. / 5 stars. I enjoyed the spooky vibes and pretty graphics in this game a lot! It was a fun diversion .

name: Pixel Puzzles 2: Halloween
short_description: Pixel Puzzles 2: Halloween is a traditional style jigsaw puzzle game in a spooky style.
reviews:
It is another puzzle sim on the Pixel Puzzles 2 engine. This one is based around that heretical celebration or something.

The main problem is that half the pictures are just ugly. If it was released today, you would claim it's AI generated.

There's no 4:3 support in a stupid 1d game, so i cannot have a tray, which is not working in widescreen. They game runs in letterboxed just fine. Achievements are working.

I actually don't like a half of these pictures. As good as the other jigsaw puzzles from the pixel puzzle group.
The only complaint I have is there is no base picture to work from.  The only option provided is a ghost picture overlay which requires continually clicking the button to keep on the screen and feels a lot like cheating. [h1] AT A GLANCE [/h1]
[list]
[*][b] Game Name: [/b] Pixel Puzzles 2: Halloween
[*][b] Original Release: [/b] 2019-10-21
[*][b] Genre Tags: [/b] Casual, Puzzle
[*][b] Estimated Playtime (Campaign): [/b] 4-6 hours
[*][b] 100% Achievements Playtime: [/b] 4-6 hours
[*][b] DLC Required for 100% Achievements: [/b] N/A
[*][b] Multiplayer Aspect: [/b] None
[*][b] Replayability: [/b] None
[*][b] Recommended To: [/b] Achievement Hunters, Puzzle Lovers
[/list]
[h1] REVIEW [/h1]
[b] Pixel Puzzles 2: Halloween [/b] is a casual, puzzle game.  
[h3] STORY [/h3]
There is no story, background, or setup to the game.
[h3] GAMEPLAY[/h3]
All of the puzzles follow traditional puzzle building mechanics. The music and atmosphere are set to the theme of the puzzles. In this case there is no music on puzzle screens, just horror sounds like screams, rattling, and other ‚Äúspooky‚Äù noises. All of the puzzle pieces float around in the side panels and you can place them or move them as needed. There is a rotation mechanic that can be turned off in the options. You can view the puzzle picture for a quick moment with a key press. There are a total of 25 puzzles to solve.
[h3] PLAYTIME [/h3]
The early game is not very complicated however when you get to the third and fourth tier puzzles you are looking at 220, and 350 piece puzzles respectively. Play time is ~4-6 hours to get all achievements and complete all puzzles. 
[h3] COMPLAINTS [/h3]
There is nothing specific to complain about for this game.
[h3] REPLAYABILITY [/h3]
There is NO replayability on this game as there is no end game mechanics or puzzle randomness.
[h3] RECOMMENDATION [/h3]
I recommend this game to anyone that likes puzzles, people looking for holiday themed games, and to achievement hunters when the game is on sale. When I finally completed this game a sudden horrifying feeling crept over me as I had come to realise that there was NO STEAM BADGE!

Also some of the images were low res and the music was annoying but the shocker at the end there got me good. The same game as the other Pixel Puzzles game just with different art, and I have enjoyed playing through these puzzles. I bought it cheap in the complete bundle so it was good value. Some fun and spooky puzzles to complete near Halloween! I loved this franchise ever since it came to steam.
Sure, there's a couple of flaws in the core design.
You simply can't snap individual pieces together.
And you sadly can't use your own pretty images.
Therefore: You are stuck with the default puzzles.
Everybody really knows these flaws at this point.
But I honestly do love these jigsaw experiences.
It simply feels great to finish every single puzzle.
During a discount it's definitely worth a purchase.
Also: I really like playing Pixel Puzzles: Ultimate.
I thought this game might give me a DLC for that.
The older Pixel Puzzles games did give the DLC.
But unfortunately: This game just isn't doing that.
Don't buy this if you are expecting that free DLC.
I still enjoyed it, but I was a tiny bit disappointed. I love the soothing sounds of screaming in the middle of July <3 Recommended. I'm honestly really disappointed with this one.

I love Halloween and its whole aesthetic, and I enjoy the gameplay of pixel puzzles games. This game just feels so lazy tho, like compared to pp zombies which had cool sometimes, genuinely creepy artwork, this game has just photos. and they're mostly pretty lame photos too. pictures of cookies, pumpkins, graveyards, ect. it's not terrible imagery and as puzzles they're mostly fine,  but it's far from exciting. I have similar issues with the pp ultimate halloween dlc packs but at least that's not a full game 

there's also the issue of limited profile features meaning that this game, though easy to 100%, doesn't count at all to your steam profile. It's a small issue and obviously steam achievements and profile completion are meaningless but it just gives even less reason to care about an already kind of mediocre puzzle game. This one's got the Pixel Puzzles mechanics, which are good. Too bad they did so little with the theme as these deviate wildly into just horror instead of Halloween. The major issue though is in the sound design, or lack thereof. The only music is at the title/puzzle select screen. Otherwise, its just random horror noises on a loop. After finishing this game, I can say that it was disappointing in more ways. Two of the largest puzzles were not challenging in a fun way, but rather frustrating due to muddled details in a field of similar pieces.

name: No1Left
short_description: Before purchasing, please note that this is a hardcore survival game and it is currently in an incomplete, early alpha phase. Some things might not work properly or the way you might expect them to.
reviews:
There is no1left to work on this game. It has been abandonned. Buying this was a total waste of my precious money. It was 16 Euros at the time when I bought it. I could have done a lot nicer things with that money. Like buying a pizza, a coke or a sky veteran medal. F*ck this game. needs some work as low content, until this has further updates I would avoid. Given no updates since feb i'm not happy. There is good material here for a futur gem, and here some of what i think should be added, or improved.

To add :

-Skill tree, experience gain and level up.
-Events on the map
-More zombie types (maybe zombie dogs and cats too)
-More detail on the map, variety (different sorts of trees, nice grass, lots of new objects, broken cars in the streets, etc etc etc)
-More weapons, especially snipers (with scope), rocket launcher, flamethrower, grenades.
-More energy for the character by default, to be able to run more.
-Night and day cycle
-Better procedurally generated system (some zones are empty).

If the dev adds already all this, the game will become fantastic.

Oh and for sure, cards and achievements too.

<3 Keep up the good work !! the first minute i played this i wanted a refund
 [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x5axmA3qPIc] Even for alpha, this is pretty omega... [/url] 

Short version: DON'T buy this right now. It's got a lot of work that needs done on it before it's playable.

Long version: As a concept, a top-down voxel zombie survival game with RPG elements sounds pretty cool. This game is far from being anywhere NEAR a game.

Graphically, it's a decent looking game for being in alpha. That's about the only thing going for it, though.

Sound-wise, it's completely lackluster. The zombies are acceptably voiced, but the lack of any background music makes it a dull experience. The controls are a bit iffy, having to aim your mouse in the direction you want to go WHILE moving WASD in the same direction. It would be a hell of a lot better if W was forward, S was down, etc.

Gameplay is incessantly difficult. To pick up anything, you have to go to no less than two menus. This makes it extremely difficult to pick anything up if there's even one zombie on the screen. At that, you can't even use weapons at this point in development. So, unless there's some engineering things to do, you're pretty much screwed.

Honestly, I wouldn't buy this game. It's too early to have been released for anything but a free alpha demo. Don't be like me and blow nine-and-change on a barely functioning game. Give it a few months and revisit. 1. You can't pick anything up, you have to open up your inventory to see what's in the proximity so you can move it over to inventory.
2. You can't enter any buildings, but you can enter vehicles with no gas to drive anywhere.
3. Moving around is slow
4. Boring

name: Samsara
short_description: "Help Zee escape Samsara! Drop blocks of different shapes and properties into a realm of two mirrored dimensions, in this beautiful, reflective puzzle game with a twist‚Ä¶‚Äù
reviews:
fantastic puzzles Increasing puzzle difficulty and new mechanics as levels progress.  Fun little game, totally worth the price. Love it. These puzzle brain games are the best. It took a little bit to know what to predict for some parts of the puzzle like the vines -they didn't always perform the same way so that wasn't great for a strategy but other than that it was a lot of fun trying to figure it all out...great brain workout on the upside-down mirroring stuff. Nice little puzzle game. Not very long, not very complicated, but enjoyable, Awesome puzzles! Deceptively simple. Gets more interesting in the second area. Do NOT buy this game at full price.

Well if you read the first sentance you might think this game is awful,well it isnt.The biggest problem this game has is thats for the majority easy or casual puzzler so if you exspect a challenge you will find only a half a dozen brainteasers.
This game could do so much more with the ideas and mechanics and thats the main problem.
Wonderful art style and very relaxing music.
For me this games pricetag is way to high when you take that the game offers little challenge.
 Clever and sometimes fiendish puzzle game, that keeps introducing game mechanics at a pace that doesn't become overwhelming, but builds on what you've learnt. Definitely recommend. Brilliant puzzle game, may become leader of the field within innovative puzzle games. Beautiful gameplay. The early levels are sweet and simple but soon enough you will start pulling your hair in frustration. Strong recommendation for this game if you're into braingames! Surprisingly good puzzle game, it was very satisfying to beat the later levels but never frustrating. Anyone who enjoyed games like Braid, Limbo, The Bridge etc... this is for you.

My only criticism would be that there were too many trivial instant-solve puzzles before reaching the challenges. 
Also, lack of music. A beautiful and engaging puzzle game. The game are engaging and thoughtfully designed and the various themes and audio provide a meditative backdrop for some fiendishly original and rewarding challenges. Highly recommended if you love beautiful, hand-crafted puzzle games to bend your mind.

name: Ace Pilot Pacific
short_description: Dive into ‚ÄòAce Pilot Pacific,‚Äô an arcade-style air combat game set in the WW2 Pacific theater. Pilot one of six distinct aircrafts through combat-intensive maps, engaging enemy fighters in high-speed dogfights. With your wingmen, rise as an Ace.
reviews: Be aware that this game has no "cockpit" view.  The only view is from above the "board/map"with the aircraft on it.   The game can only be played with the keyboard or a controller.  A "controller" does not include joysticks.  My x56 joystick and throttle are useless.  So, you may or may not like this game depending on your style of flying.  In my case with no cockpit view and no joystick it will not work for me.

name: Elijah and the Out of this World Adventure
short_description: A sci-fi action game that explores the great sites of Ohio!
reviews:
It took a bit, but this game really warmed up to me the more I played.  Not sure what to compare it to... perhaps Zelda I and III on NES/SNES as you get multiple tools to help you in your quest and are encouraged to re-explore areas.  I played most of this on the steam deck and had zero issues though the top info bar and some text may be difficult to read.

The story is simple, but engaging.  Gameplay is simple too, but it's not just about recognizing patterns of your enemies, but keeping track of the buildings you enter, what you get, did you get stuck because of a missing item and need to come back later? 
I liked how there were multiple ways to obtain items or make things in buildings easier to deal with whether it be through brute forcing things, charming people, hacking computers, or just outright buy the item.

Some people might not like the art direction.  It looks like something out of Windows 3.1 or classic Flash games on Newgrounds.  But hey, that screams to me "Retro" and "Old School".
Some may find the adult humor a bit much, but I found it hilarious.

Two things I didn't care for - 
1) No real way to pause the action.  If you take a break, make sure you are on a screen with no enemies nearby (usually as you enter a new area), go to a safe building, or enter a dialog.
2) Walking off frame a bit is enough to respawn enemies.  Be careful.

Some Tips:
* Make sure you read the manual (shows up as additional downloaded content) for some good tips which I wish I noticed before jumping in.
* As the manual states, activate the cell phone tower when you can (talk to NPCs, they'll tell you what to do and where it is).
* Charisma attribute points can't be bought so work on this through level ups.  This also allows you to charm NPCs and lower costs.  Strength also can't be bought in the store, but there's a gym you can go to.  As the manual states, the Mind Attribute will be important but there are items that can help give you a boost.
* In each city there is a building with a bed.  Look for them and memorize where they are, you'll use them a lot.

All of this done by one individual, PDS.  Very impressive.  I'll be playing Daisy Flies to the Moon as it appears everything in connected in some way. You can kick yourself through walls. It's exactly as Ohio as I remember. 10/10 I haven't beaten those yet but so far it's been very enjoyable. I've actually gifted it to several friends. Classic sandbox game with beautiful old school graphics. Well written and very funny. Good amount of game play and open world exploring. Combat is simple and fun and the games not terribly easy. Great classic style game. i would've checked this as a non-recommendation if not for my desire to see them fix the control scheme and make a good final product. please developers, think about what you've done to the poor poor control scheme... it's a goddang war crime. like seriously even with a controller, it's just far too much of a drag and i personally can't play it like this. I love this game for it's retro look and feel, If you like Nes/Snes titles this game maybe right up your alley...I will say, the map in the game is rather large, once you leave the starting area and find your brother A fun game with an interesting story. Lots of dialogue. 

https://youtu.be/FyrpHJ0SWYs I gifted this game to a friend whose name was Elijah, lived in Ohio, and looked like the titular character in the game. I really enjoy playing this game and expect great things from this game in the future as updates and improvements start rolling out

Keep up the great work!

name: Patterna
short_description: Patterna is a logic puzzle game for people who think that HexCells is far too easy. It features a highly customizable random level generator, a level editor, more than 70 levels, and an enchanting minimalist soundtrack by Alex Cottrell.
reviews:
Patterna is a wonderful logic game in the vein of Tametsi and Hexcells, but its rules can be a tad harder to grasp and the level design can be brutal.

If you thought the Hexcells series was difficult, you might want to skip this one, although to be fair I think that you can assess the game's approach to level design already by playing the demo.

Having progressed a bit into the game, though, I have to say that you CAN get better at it once you get the rules embedded in your brain, and the presence of a "what if" mode (accessible by pressing TAB) ensures that even in the worst cases you can try chipping away possibilities.

So, yes, Patterna is definitely on the tougher end of the difficulty scale for logic games, but that doesn't mean in any way that it's a bad game. I will also add that the game is sold at a low-ish price considering the amount of levels (not to count the randomly generated ones and the workshop ones). Delightfully devilish! If you dare brave the two circles of graph theory minesweeper hell, you'll come out with a surprising intuitive mix of several puzzle genres. Not for the uninitiated. Just wayyyy too convoluted and complex to be any fun.

Even if the mechanics are similar it's nothing like Hexcells or (most of) Tametsi. You go through the tutorials (which are like half the levels in the game) mostly fine, then the actual levels begin and you immediately hit the wall.

Every. Single. Level. You open it and basically stare at it for hours because there's bloody nothing you can do to progress at all. I feel like I must figure out and solve the whole level at once simultaneously every time. This includes making assumptions based on assumptions based on other assumptions to see if there's a pattern.

There's no drawing mode like what Tametsi has though. I've been "solving" levels by drawing over screenshots in MS Paint for a long while and it's simply not fun at all. Even when I do manage to understand and crack a level it doesn't feel rewarding at all. Because you click the next level and instantly run into another wall yet again.

Since nodes are not made of grids but rather graphs it is often incredibly hard to really understand what connects to what in the puzzle overall. I just find it next to impossible to truly perceive. And when one-way connections are involved it's basically kiss your gaming goodbye. Like, I code for a living, I know graphs, I've beaten Hexcells trilogy + Globesweeper + majority of Tametsi, yet here I spend most of the time just looking at an MS Paint screenshot slowly getting more and more sad and irritated. I don't see why I should endure it anymore or recommend anyone else to go through it either.

You probably came here because you want more of Hexcells or Tametsi. But it's not gonna be that. It's so, so much worse in terms of difficulty and fun. If you only played Hexcells you are not even remotely ready for this, and only if you totally breezed through Tametsi you might stand a chance. It seems that many people who left positive reviews didn't even remotely progress deep into the game either - except for a niche couple people who are clearly the target audience. But you aren't. :) Refreshing logic game, wish I found it sooner! Patterna is an enthralling logic puzzle game that captivates players with its unique blend of sophisticated challenges and an enchanting minimalist atmosphere. This gem pushes the boundaries of the genre, offering an experience that stands out from the crowd.

From the moment you begin, Patterna's charm is evident in its elegant and deceptively simple design. Each level presents a network of nodes that must be carefully analyzed and manipulated to progress. As you delve deeper into the game, you'll quickly realize that Patterna is a true test of logical reasoning, offering a refreshingly cerebral experience for those seeking a more intellectually stimulating puzzle game.

One of Patterna's standout features is its highly customizable random level generator, ensuring that players never run out of fresh challenges to tackle. With over 70 handcrafted levels to conquer, there's no shortage of content to keep your mind engaged and entertained. The inclusion of a level editor further extends the game's longevity, allowing players to design their own diabolical puzzles and share them with others.

Accompanying the cerebral gameplay is an enchanting minimalist soundtrack by Alex Cottrell, which perfectly complements the game's serene and contemplative atmosphere. As you progress through the levels, you'll find yourself fully immersed in Patterna's mesmerizing world, losing track of time as you focus on unraveling the intricacies of each puzzle.

In conclusion, Patterna is a must-play for fans of logic puzzle games seeking a fresh and invigorating challenge. Its unique blend of intricate gameplay, endless replayability, and captivating atmosphere make it a standout title in the genre. If you're ready to put your problem-solving skills to the test, look no further than Patterna ‚Äì an experience that promises hours of brain-teasing enjoyment. Stupidly complicated.  Maybe I'm just too dumb for this but I played Hexcells and Tametsi well and really tried with this one.  I feel I understand the rules completely based on the tutorials but then you get hit with a level and suddenly the rules don't seem to work anymore.  The rules are basically so complex that they can't even keep up with them enough to make them clear.  F*** this game. It's fun. There's tons of customization. The randomly generated puzzles are quite pleasant, and at max difficulty they can get pretty tough. Bonus points for the accessibility options, I was able to set all of the colors to be very easy to distinguish. I have to give this an upvote because it's a game and it works and that's really how low the bar is for these things. This game is honestly not that good. I'm almost all the way through the non-random puzzles and this game doesn't have any of the charm or appeal of Hexcells or Tametsi.

Play it if you enjoy puzzle games, but this is not even close to 'The Dark Souls of Hexcells'. This game is very... adequate. It's definitely not particularly good. Only get it if you found Hexcells too easy. [u]In short:[/u] Patterna is a challenging hard-logic puzzle game with a steep learning curve. The mechanics are varied and the replayability infinite, but it is very rough around the edges with poor and sometimes frustrating implementation. If you have a low tolerance for bad UI, stay away. If you can stomach that and are a seasoned veteran of logic games, Patterna is well worth buying at full price.

[u]In long:[/u] The developer himself compares Patterna's [b][u]mechanics[/u][/b] to Hexcells, and one can immediately see the inspiration. But Patterna is far from a knock-off, does its own thing and expands gameplay well beyond the scope of Hexcells. Nodes may be revealed or not, may be part of a pattern or not, may carry information about nodes around them up to a distance of 3, may describe the length of the chain they are part of, may have up to 4 colors, may be unlinked, linked or directionally linked, etc. The complexity is smart and truly awe-inspiring, but comes at a cost:
The learning and [b][u]difficulty[/u][/b] curve is very steep and almost nothing about the game seems intutive at first. Minesweeper and Hexcells have a simple elegance that is completely missing in Patterna. Right out of the gate you are inundated with new and abstract terminology ("pattern nodes" vs. "non-pattern nodes") and the tutorial is lacking. From my understanding there used to be a more concise tutorial, but after expanding the game it has been spread out across several level packs. To me it appeared slow, disjointed and partly out of order. To be fair, the game offers pretty much every assistance you can think of: You can mark up to four nodes, which tints all nodes affected by them in different colors and you can switch to a planning mode, where you can temporarily mark nodes. These tools are almost required to use, since especially directional edges tend to produce some counter-intutive results.
The [b][u]levels[/u][/b] are a bit of a mixed bag. There are dozens of pre-made levels (took me about 12h to clear), organized in several sequences, but they mostly left me cold. A good chunk was very easy tutorials, a few were smart and fun and the rest were either focussed on mechanics I didn't enjoy or giganting sprawling mazes of directional edges, which basically required trial and error in planning mode, because there wasn't enough information to solve them step-by-step. But as even the developer has acknowledged on the forums, the pre-made levels were never intended to be the core of the game - the random level generator is! In fact, there are several different ones, which produce different kinds of node graphs. All generators are highly customizable in terms of size, difficulty and mechanics. It is actually incredibly impressive, how much variety and challenge they can produce. My only gripe is, that the difficulty settings are just very rough guides. Even low settings can occasionally produce incredibly complicated relationships requiring several minutes of high level reasoning. But in general the level generators are definitely one of the best I've ever seen and in over 50 hours of playtime with them I've never had the feeling anything repeated or that I had already seen all patterns. There is also a level editor, but Steam Workshop support is partly broken and years after the release there are a grand total of 6 levels published.

Which brings us to the implementation, and here arguably the game starts to fall apart quite a bit.
The [b][u]graphics[/u][/b] are barely passable, albeit completely functional. The Unity loader takes care of resolutions and windowed mode (window can also be drag-resized). I really like the [b][u]sound[/u][/b] effects and the music is decent (although naturally it will get old after 10 hours).
The [b][u]horrible UI[/u][/b] is one of the game's biggest weak points though. It is needlessly complicated and very overwhelming to someone who starts up the game for the first time. The main menu is just an overlay over the gameplay, which leads to strange behaviour, like being able to zoom the main menu background. Functionalities you'll often need are buried as deep in menus as ones you'll never use. Double click doesn't start a level, only the "play" button does. There's a neat graphical statistic at the end of each level that stopped working as soon as I started with randomly generated levels - but it still shows the meaningless data from dozens of hours ago everytime I beat a level. The ingame statistics keeping in general has very little useful data (level times seem to count intro and outro animations, some achievement related metrics are never shown, etc). I disagree with a lot of default choices, but the vast settings menu allows for amazing customization, from marking colors and depths to reversing controls and turning off certain animations. It took some time, but I was able to satisfy a lot of my needs. Some problems remain: If a hint is completely done, the game kicks you out of having it marked (jarring, but helpful), but does not automatically grey it out (why?). Every level starts and ends with a drawn out animation of every single node flying into and out of the screen. While neat at first, I found it to be enormously frustrating being forced to stare at the screen for 15 seconds for the literal 1000th time, when I just want to play the next level.
Speaking of staring at the screen, there are a few pretty bad [b][u]bugs[/u][/b]: Every half hour or so the game just freezes up for 10-20 seconds and becomes completely unresponsive, before continuing as if nothing happened. And after finishing a pre-made sequence you are kicked back to the main menu where a "continue level" button is still active, which reproducibly hardlocks/crashes the game. Together with the deprecated Workshop support, Patterna does not seem well maintained to me.

In [b][u]conclusion[/u][/b] this is a pretty classic example of a first release from a one-man operation. Patterna's developer definitely had a good idea and a firm grasp of mathematics/graph theory, but everything outside his skill-set, like graphics and UI, turned out to be pretty lacking if not awful. Still, the core gameplay is very solid and has infinite replayability. If you are bored by other logic games and you think you've seen it all, Patterna will rack your brain and keep you occupied for dozens of hours and the above-average asking price is very fair for that. Despite all its faults, I've had a lot of fun and don't regret my purchase one bit. If, however, you are new to logic games or if you value a polished experience, I cannot it good conscience recommend Patterna to you.

name: Frutakia 2
short_description: Frutakia is back and better than ever! 4K@120FPS.
reviews: Unplayable after an update.  I will revise my review once the issues have been fixed.  Do not recommend.

name: 100 vacas
short_description: 100 vacas is a bite-sized game about a cowboy defending one hundred heads of cattle from bandits and making every bullet count.
reviews:
I'm reviewing games in alphabetical order, and you can watch my review here: https://youtu.be/IIZl0K0Wx4M
Prefer to read?

100 Vacas is an arcade style, fast paced "twin stick shooter" where you play as a cowboy defending his farm from bandits. The game consists of a series of single-screen levels where every bullet matters because every dies in one hit, and your previous cows are likely to be shot by stray bullets. Precision and quick reflexes are key, and you will likely die a lot, but thankfully resets are fast enough that it's not painful.
This is a short and sweet experience, so don't expect a lot of depth here. It does come with a speedrun timer built for those wanting to put their skills to the test though!
I'd recommend picking it up on sale, as you'll likely get an hour or so of playtime from this one. Simple, satisfying, thematic and addictive. I feel like a cowboy. The "save all cows to restore health" mechanic is so cool and tense. Highly recommended! Isaac with cows except not really but its fun play it Buen arcade Fun and fresh arcade game with a completely ridiculous price (less than one euro, you have to buy it!). This is a simple and fun game. It's the kind of game that you can play while listening to podcasts, or whenever you have a few spare minutes to kill.

The gameplay is very polished, ensuring that the game never feels unfair despite being pretty challenging.

Considering how low the price is, it definitely gives you your money's worth. Really nice game. Easy to beat, but hard to master. The music, the graphics and the gamefeel combine in a wholesome experience. Its also fun and challenging. Would love it to include controller support. It is an incredible game, simple but challenging. I like the love with which all the details are made, music, effects, immersion, it does not even need a tutorial, you arrive and play, and it is part of the game.

I love it. This game totally worth every penny.

It's minimalist at all its sections: graphics, colors, ost, mechanics and duration.

But its playability is awesome, I really enjoyed it and has a well though-out level design. Nice ost too.

And when you finish it you want to improve and keep playing it. Lovely very well crafted challenging minigame. Give it a try !

name: TY the Tasmanian Tiger 3
short_description: CRIKEY! TY is back with a brand new adventure, in this fully remastered version of TY the Tasmanian Tiger 3: Night of the Quinkan. Pick up your rangs; pull on your shorts, and prepare to rescue the SOUTHERN RIVERS from a brand new threat - the QUINKAN...
reviews:
Classic 3D platformer that not many people got to play back in the day. As a person who got all Steam Achievements on the entire Quadrilogy, this was by far the hardest to get with this hardcore mode. What is missing is the extra hitpoint unlockable like from TY2 so you can take more damage before you die. It was a long journey but I highly recommend this game regardless of tone switch than games before It's more Ty 2 which is great if you liked that game.

Which means it continues on the poor level design decisions and all those flaws.

It does try to have a continuous story in this one and give more characters personality,but that can't save the boring gameplay. Also Dennis has a full on personality disorder in this game.

Both Ty 2 and Ty 3 make me sure that the devs were very confused on what type of game they wanted to make and with the level choices being the absolute worst in my platformer/collectathon history this series I am confused why it has so much positive reviews other than nostalgia I don't know what you could see in anything,but the first game. TY The Tasmanian Tiger Easily the weakest in the trilogy, but I went with a recommend in the end but only if you like the first 2 games and can get it on a good sale.

[olist]
    [*]The Good
[olist]
    [*]The platforming is the same as the other games, which is fun.
    [*]It was mostly fun - I had a good time
[/olist]
    [*]The Neutral
[olist]
    [*]Boomerangs: while the new system with stones is interesting, it needs improvements; it does not feel rewarding to get stones as it did to get completely new boomerangs like in the first game - I did not personally like the melee since it did not involve the boomerangs at all (throwing wise or the stones)  so it took away that core part of the game.
    [*]Graphics/Animations - same old, same old
    [*]Voice Acting
[/olist]
    [*]The Bad
[olist]
    [*]Bugs: 1 time the game froze for no reason; some of the maps you buy to find items do not work properly (you have to get close to the item or it will not show on the minimap)
    [*]Story: it does not make sense and goes back and forth between points very fast - might be what they were doing for but it did not feel right - characters are under utilized
    [*]Camera is bad
    [*]Too much padding and the world is boring - all the areas feel the same - too much focus on the mechs
    [*]The final boss sucks hard - it is the most boring boss fight I have played for awhile - in hardcore mode, you have to use the invincible rang or it is impossible since the melee sucks.
[/olist]
[/olist] I have played about 40 goofy minutes of this mid game. The story is nonsensical and they seem to have taken notes from Jak 2. That is not a good thing. You can now do a generic 3 hit combo with the rangs. Unfortunately most of the enemies require melee to be defeated. Please don't buy this game. Stick to the second game. Only thing I'M going to give credit for is the music. This soundtrack bops pretty hard. I think Krome Studios were smoking crack when they made this

2 levels in and it was diabolical. If its that rough at the start, I hate to think what the rest of the game is like.
I'll just pretend they only made Ty 1 & 2 lmao

- Rushed graphic animations
- Voice lines sounded weird from sentence to sentence
- Game-play felt weird compared to Ty 2

Maybe I'll try again in future I thought I would be deluded by this third chapter by what I've seen and heard about it, but instead it was amazing for the most part, except that I have to agree that some characters were almost ruined. Aside from that, the first 1-2 hours were kinda meh, but after that it was for some things even more engaging than Ty 2, I loved meleeing enemies and going around blasting everything and collecting with the crab mech on the roads, even if its jumps were a little unstable. I loved that the water mech, my favourite, came back even more powerful. And above all I loved that this game made the fire boomerangs relevant again, since in the second game they became kinda irrelevant and even counterproductive and I hated that.
But, even with their highlights, all the bosses [spoiler](aside from the one in the sky)[/spoiler] sucked for the first phase, in the sense that they were difficult in that phase because it was badly done for hitboxes and such, while their second phases were well done and they were objectively fun and challenging. So for what regards the full 3d games of Ty the Tasmanian Tiger, the second chapter has definitely the best bosses overall.
But this is still a very cool and interesting 3d platformer like the first two personally I don't mind the darker theme of the game, at least it didn't get the same treatment as jak 2 did. It's still a ty game. Some parts of it are good, some parts are weak. Overall this is a mixed bag for me. It may be the weakest of the trilogy, but i do recommend it to those who loved 1 and 2. And krome plz release this on consoles for those who can't afford a pc shit ahhh my child. it may have been crappy but its my crappy.

name: theHunter: Wayfarer Starter Pack
genres: Action, Adventure, Free To Play, Simulation, Sports
short_description: theHunter Wayfarer Starter Pack includes 3 months premium membership including full licenses to hunt All animals, access to All reserves and unlimited basic ammo. Items included: 12 GA Pump Action Shotgun, .44 revolver, 2x20mm Handgun Scope, Wind Indicator, Boone & Crockett Cap, Pheasant Caller, Camping Supplies and a tent.
reviews:
Guarante! If you don't have the time for stealth hunting, you don't know what your missing. its god ofer now!!! Rather of not of recommended the game at this time but had to choose to post.

Game is okay if you want to relax with a cup of coffee and get a little feel, just upset that you get in game, get a feel for how to play, then really can't hunt a varierty of animal that might be present in the area, becaues although you can put the free weapons with this pack on,  due to weight restrictions, you can't put in the ammo. Need certain ammo type in shotguns for different creatures, and if you add shotgun with your rifle, you wont even be able to add the pistol.. so the point of these weapons is pretty moot/meh. Pnce you get experience i guess you can get a backpack, but i think you have to pay more... 

Expect more investment and tons of cockblocks from what i can tell so they can milk in money from a cash shop done poorly..

One more tip, i didnt realize.. is you can have more than one mission... just friggan activate them all.. so stupid you even have to activate them Game is good, but the DLC does not work... FIX THIS, or give me a refund. i wouldend ask for a refund if i bought it and didnt like it, but it just simply does not work, no matter what i try wont work i am maD PAID MONEY FOR IT     GLAYMON Worst add filled game I have ever paid for and played. i bought theHunter: Wayfarer Starter Pack and i still playigng as aguest ??
 Just purchased, Did not receive any thing ? Any help appreciated thanks.
 Received nothing.

name: Adverse Effects
short_description: Judith has been having issues sleeping, so her solution was to see her doctor. The doctor prescribed her some new sleeping pills that have some Adverse Effects. You play the recipient of these feelings; what will you do when her normal affections turn into something more?
reviews:
story is great so far and i doubt it'd disappoint new people who buy this but above all i like how in a way the mc is almost like a self insert of the dev cause the dude works on one of the emi games and releases it in the story which i thought was cool but i also have reason to believe the dev is a dragon ball fan just be some noticeable details here and there and anyone whose a dragon fan and makes good content is A-OK! in my book As others have mentioned, the game is short but sweet. 

The story was actually kind of cute, and surprised me. 

I especially liked the fourth wall breaks, they got a genuine giggle out of me. 

I'll be checking out CellStudios' other work! very short but decent great game. The story is excellent and the models are beautiful. Short and sweet but cheap! I like the option for body hair since the bald ones all look the same to me. Run time is probably 45 to 90 minutes, depending on how distracted you get.

If the price stays under $3 bucks then I'd say it's worth it! 7.9/10. I'd rate it higher if it were longer. Idea has potential. Unfortunatelly the game is extremely short and linear, definiely below 1h. Could be bought only with a huge discount. that's some good stuff, but i was expecting to see more of Emi, would be interesting to see how all of these stories play out much later in the timeline, like maybe the doc makes a cameo in the end of The Cabin.

enjoyable, for sure. 7.4/ 10.0 ...just the fact that it is short and less of a harem situation going on than i prefer.

[h1]Synopsis[/h1]
Adverse Effects is a RenPy visual novel.

[h1]Story[/h1]
You live with a 41 year old woman, she is working two jobs to put you through college. She's always had trouble sleeping, but now it is getting worse. You make a doctor's appointment for her and she qualifies to be part of the clinical trial for a new sleep aid drug.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
You start the game by setting the name of the main character, Desmond by default. Next you set your surname, Carter by default. Next you set the name of a woman laying on a bed, you have no idea who she is supposed to be in relationship to the main character, her name is Judith by default. Next you set your relationship to the female character, Landlady by default. Switching the two around would probably be a better idea. Next you set your relationship to the female character, Tenant by default. Next you get to set the pubic hair style of the female character, your options are none, some, and full. You are then informed that this selection only applies to this female character.

This game is strictly about the landlady and tenant. There are only a few other characters mentioned, but you only actually see one other character, the doctor.

The scenes allow you to switch positions, it will require multiple playthroughs, or reloads, to view all of the content. Most of the time you are allowed to select where you finish.

[spoiler]At the end is a "bonus" scene with the doctor. That doesn't really relate to the story. If you selected to impregnate the landlady, you can do the same with the doctor, but there will be no warning this time.[/spoiler]

[h1]The Gallery[/h1]
There is no Gallery, which is probably the biggest downside of this game, as you will not know if you've seen all of the content or not. You can use save game slots to bookmark any content that interest you.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
A very good game featuring a landlady and her tenant. Multiple, selectable, positions for each scene and most allow you to select where you finish. Multiple playthroughs required to see all content.

RAM: G.SKILL Trident Z5 Neo Series (AMD Expo) DDR5 RAM 64GB (2x32GB)
Video: ASUS TUF Gaming GeForce RTX 4080

short_description: UPDATED! Embark on a new adventure: Assemble powerful decks of Heroes to invade rival dungeons and engage in epic PvP 3D battles--then, use the loot from your conquests to customize your own dungeon and put together a powerful deck of bosses and minions to defend your riches at all costs.
reviews:
"when we are ready we will make a proper marketing push to add players and improve matchmaking. we thought being in early access made that obvious. it apparently does not."
That was 4 years ago.
 More abandonware. So far: the controls are super clunky. The deck building makes almost no sense. Character movement is pointless as there is no way to keep your characters away from damage. Cards don't do what they seem to say they should, making all initial battles confusing and nearly impossible to succeed in. Mostly your characters stand around until the enemies launch 20 attacks for every one of yours and kill you. 

Really regret investing in this mess. The game is alot of fun . i really love it ..but radaghar the hordecaller seriously guysplease make him less OP

1st everyone uses him its getting extremly annoying , second its nearly inpossible to kill him when they have the skills put up that you start again 8 minions when you kill 1 another one spawns and more and more minions are coming that you cant even tough radaghar since he gest 1 armor per minion he gets.
in the last hour ive been gaming ive had lest say i did 16 battles orso 15/16 where radaghar and i could only beat one with alot of luck from the cards i got .

Like please make him less OP its just not even fun ive started to just quit match whenever its a radaghar.

for the rest the game is amazing and i love it tonnes but PLEASE DO SOMETHING ABOUT THE OP RADAGHAR!

Thank This game started ok in EA, but i really disslike the store page and how everything turns into a grindfest. "Getting your ass kicked has never been so much fun or rewarding."

Extended review on this game. My impression is overall, very positive. I'll explain why. This review will not cover the specifics of the game itself, aside from my experiences with various aspects of it that I feel was noteworthy.

Prior Experiences and Expectations
- Paying member of Solforge, Hearthstone, Cabals TCG (dropped hundreds of bucks over the years on these. No regrets).
- Play alot of hobby board games across a wide range of genres. 
- Banner Saga: Factions. Enjoys tactics game that have a simple core design and are not RPGs. Hate RPGs actually. As little management as possible is best.
- Injustice Mobile (you'll see why this actually becomes relevent).

What drew me to Labyrinth
- Diehard need to scratch the "miniatures wargaming" itch. And I mean, small scale, tactical battles that is NOT JRPG, anime-ish or Warhammer. What I really wanted was the D&D miniatures wargame. Something I admired, but never played. 
- Labyrinth, visually and mechnically, resonated with this desire and need.
- Progress reports. You can tell right away that the developers are very market-oriented and open to the public at large. They keep us up to date, they respond to our questions- and they have an Early Access Game that is SOLID.

The Mechanics
-Still learning new things even though I've must have played over 10+ casual battles by now. The mechanics becomes clearer and clearer and I am astounded at how well designed it is. Initially I ignored the ticks entirely, feeling that it's extraneous, but now I am starting to pay attention once I figured out the relationship between "how many cards I can play in a turn is dependent on whether I get moved behind another unit in tick, or I stay ahead of the enemy in ticks- which pretty much determines both initiative and resource usage." Mindblown, I mean, technically, there is no such thing as a turn. The elegance is astounding. I love how the mechanics show you clearly what everything does- I don't find myself needing to look for additional information, through inference, I am understanding the depth of the game.
-Once you've built a Boss Deck or Two, you start grasping the underlying principles of how the Bosses work and you could then build better Heroes.
-The way they choose to present the information is very functional. The ring of health around each unit, and the TCG nature of utilizing keywords are useful. If you've played any kind of TCG/CCGs before, it's simple. And that's one of the things that set this apart. Alot of "tactics" games are badly disguised RPGs with alot of random chance and too MUCH STATS. Labyrinth has none of this problem. There is little to no RNG (and if there was, the cards tell you clearly), everything is clearly labeled, and you juggle with 3-4 stat types at most, with keywords. 


The Multiplayer
- Raids are addictive. You just want to keep fighting. And when you're heroes died one turn away from total victory, you feel burning vengeance but also shame because it was entirely your own fault. So far, I always lose because I made a tactical error or I suddenly realize my Hero decks wasn't appropriately geared for fighting that specific Boss strategy. This game is not easy actually, and I wouldn't want it any other way. It teaches me better tactical awareness- and the fact I am aware exactly why I lost is very humbling and makes defeats have value, rather than feeling arbitrary. If you are after winning, you won't enjoy this game as much. But if you want tactics, this game oozes with it. 
-I had thought the whole "passive defence multiplayer" thing might be sketchy and wouldn't draw me in (even though I play Injustice Mobile. And Dungeon Keeper Mobile, which has exactly this kind of multiplayer), just like I had assumed that the tick system wouldn't click with me (pun intended), but they actually did it pretty well. The main joy is from devising a good Boss Deck to stomp Heroes when you're offline- since multiplayer is automated for the defender. The key I think, is synergy between the Boss's passive and the deck, but each boss has a Dual Nature, so you can access deck types of other bosses, in addition to unique ones.
-So far, I have a ramp Boss (some freaky Mayan death goddess, can't spell her name) that gets stronger the more turns has passed. So her entire deck is freezing the enemy until you ramp to godhood.
-The other bossI have set up (the giantess) is a "everytime you play a non-attack card, you deal your attack to all enemies within 3 spaces" (paraphrase), so her entire deck is amping her base attack and drawing enemies closer. And just for kicks, I made her generate ludicrous amounts of minions as well.
-As a final note, asyncrhonous multiplayer makes it easy to drop in and drop out. No pressure. No waiting for people to take their turn. Quite casual and addictive. Like a crunchier Injustice Mobile (and we all know how addictive that is.)


The Store
-No premium currency. You get 10 gold per (casual) battle. Quests rewards 100 golds. 100 gold buys you a pack. 
-Again, like everything else, I thought I wouldn't be interested or care very much about the cards. Other CCGs have unique creatures and spells that are rich in lore and theme- those draw me in. But cards for attacks and spells for a couple of heroes and bosses? Bah? Boooring, right? BOY, Was I wrong. I actually care what cards I do get now. All cards can be crafted or disenchanted for crafting currency (forgot the name atm), so that's nice.
-Booster packs (keys) are priced nicely, and are consistently priced. Unlike other games that encourage you to buy more for more discounts, this game straight up has a 1:1 exchange rate in terms of packs per buck. This is actually really nice, as I don't have to constantly juggle with "delaying gratification" problems. I get 100 gold, I buy a pack right away. This isn't strictly true if you're paying money directly for the packs, as it is slighly cheaper (by about 0.32 per pack). 
-I have dropped something like $25CAD on this game. Both for the original early access price before it went F2P and for 10 packs just the night prior. Because it was worth it and I wanted to support the game. At no point did I feel that I was pressured to get "good cards", indeed, for a vast majority of my heroes, I feel the low-cost or basic cards are the strongest. Hearthstone feels like a grind for example. This game? Not so much. Having only 4 hero classes (so far) and multiple heroes that share those classes with overlapping cards reduces the grinding or "I lack essential cards" feeling that other games produces. This is a huge plus and makes collecting cards an option-expanding activity rather than a chore. 

Conclusion:
Overall, it has a minimalistic design philosophy that I really appreciate, both from the mechanics, and the economy. It fulfills a specific kind of niches for a specific type of gamer. It doesn't cheapen its brand by choosing to copy what everyone else is doing, but choosing to put thier own aesthetics and value on it. Of course, this may change as marketability changes, but for now I applaud their willingness to try something different. I look forward to what else this game has in store. Very unbalanced game. Be prepared to win 20 games you can't possibly lose and then start losing games you can't possibly win. Everything is fine and well, but when a tactical game like this says it has multiplayer mode, then I expect to figth concurrent matches against equal human opponents. However, this game only has player vs AI-controlled mode, the multiplayer content comes from other players being able to create card decks for AI to use.
It is unfortunate that this game has no true multiplayer, the system itself is good and I think it would work well. Being a player of hearthstone for almost 2 years, duelyst, chronicles, spellweaver i have to say that this game has impressed me. It is refreshing in this genre and it is very challenging. I thought fighting against other people's bosses was going to be boring because normally AI is just AI not human, but wow, great work there. I know it is still in early access but i have revised all the cards and possibilities that this game can offer and i have to say the potential is huge. Keep up the good work and I hope to see a lot of people playing this excellent game !! Lot's of great strategic mechanics that seem to fit well with the heroes and bosses. Very much like the adventure party and lair defense aspect. A gem of a game.

It's nice to find a game that expresses it's characters well through it's mechanics. Labyrinth has lots to offer the tactical gamer. Anticipation and countering are key aspects to the challenge offered, both in deck building, the progression of the battle, your heroes' turn. Heroes have specialties but you can build a balanced party nuanced how you want. Your lair defense is a fun and unique aspect, almost a game in itself. While I bought the game previously I am nonethelesss glad to see it go free to play as additional players refine the challenge. 

I had held off on my review because so much can be said about this game and I will likely add more (too busy playing it). Strategists I imagine will find this game very enjoyable and quite replayable.

name: Super Mustache
short_description: Super Mustache is a vintage styled platformer, filled to the brim with 8 bit pixel art juice! Join Captain Super Mustache in a journey to save the planet Uranus. If you enjoyed classic platformer games from the golden era of video games, then you‚Äôre going to love this.
reviews:
[h1][b]Not Recommended[/b][/h1] super garbage Nobody will read my review so I Will FInd 1 Friend For Every Like this gets.
 I do not recommend this game, but I didn't dislike it enough to try and get a refund. If it weren't on offer and less than ¬£1 then I would have been upset if it was full price. If you played a lot of mediocre platformers on Kongregate to scratch that itch , you'll have some idea of what you're getting into.
   If it was just mediocre I'd understand asking for a bit of money but the glitches and actual bugs make charging for this seem cheeky, especially so at full price. One such was losing ability to jump 3/4 of the way through a level. Another was having to use the default key to jump, yet all the other mapped keys working fine, during a spaceship level.
   Things I found odd/offputting but not gamebreaking: 
     - Health is not lost at 1 heart per hit. Okay, no biggy, it's damage, sometimes you can take more harm depending on what whumped ya. But lives?! Certain insta-death collisions such as water will deduct 2 lives from you, not 1. Go figure.
    - If you jump on a ranged enemy's head to kill it *before* it's about to fire, you lose health.
    - Spike blocks that fall from the ceiling which appear to have the same graphic as a standing block will hurt you. Basically anything that could hurt you even when dormant/spent will hurt you. (Boulder finished rolling after you? The whole rock will still hurt you even after it's tucked itself in to bed)
    - Insta-dying even if you haven't fallen into a pit. If you're jumping across platforms above a pit *near* to the bottom of a stage, make sure you overcompensate and double-jump because if you go anywhere near the *border*, you'll die.

Graphics, sfx and music were good (music was great on some levels!) and was it a fun timewaster? Yeah, that's the only thing stopping me feel bitter about it being a purchase. But it really feels like a free-to-play. 
    With some play-testing, polish and bug fixes then it's sale price is perfectly acceptable. I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you. This game kinda sucks. You could probably find 100 other games visually similar to this game right now that are twice as good.
