name: RPG Maker MV - KR Tuscan Seaside Tiles
short_description: The sea calls! Build a rustic Italian villa or a bright Mediterranean town on the ocean shore with Tuscan Seaside!
reviews:
These are my favourite tileset, the look, feel and colours of them will allow you to make something amazing. They match up with other tile sets well, while remaining unique. They have helped ad a much needed change in my game. Will easily be best town I have made. So many small touches and variations of items that make each part of map feel unique.

Disappointing they don‚Äôt have sample game to easy import, but once you have it all set they work great.

Would have been nice to have more sprites for all the fountains.

I highly recommend even at full price if your ok with setting up the tileset yourself.

name: Electronic Super Joy 2
short_description: Electronic Super Joy 2 is a brutally hard platformer, set in a world of brain-smashing electronic music. Run, jump, smash, & slice your way through 55+ weird & different levels, with giant monsters, swarming missiles & secret areas.
reviews:
Twice the joy! I loved the first game. Groove City was fine. This one has some cool ideas and overall is very enjoyable experience. I still do not understand how the base of this game which includes most of the levels is FREE. I hope we will see ESJ 3 one day. I bought both "DLCs", since I want to support the developers and in my opinion, the content is worth it. It's amazing, go check it out! :) I purchased the deluxe because I remembered the first ESJ being quite fun. This is like that, but with more abilities - very hard platforming and a solid soundtrack. ebin Hard & fun platformer, innovative new gameplay elements, but overall the first ESJ is better. Incredible platformer with lot of different mechanics and nice OST. 
The story is still as crazy as the first one, and on the top of that the game is f2p (which imo is a complet steal) Well, if you played the previous games and thought there would be improvements on this one, you'll be rather disappointed...

First off, level design tends to be is really poor. It doesn't feel you're progressing as you clear levels. Layouts are not so inspired or clever, though there are exceptions. It is really easy to get yourself killed by getting out of camera range and so on. Furthermore, constant sidescrolling segments and tons of enemies that shoot homing missiles give a sense that this game is about luck, not skill.

FPS levels are horrible. Seriously, they're near unplayable if you play with a joystick.

Graphics are ok. I think they fit really well with the theme. The only problem is that sometimes it is not clear if enemies can be stomped or not. Also, in some levels, the amount of glowing, moving stuff in the background makes the level harder than it should be. 

The level selection screen is confusing as hell. Whoever designed that must have failed all HCI exams...

There are some minor things that the programmer didn't pay attention such as not showing time/death the first time you open the level selection screen or showing power ups that you already have when respawning.

Soundtrack is excelent and basically the selling point. 

Now, to be fair, it's a free game. Despite many things that suggest the game was rushed, the soundtrack is awesome and can be entertaining if you're already familiar with hardcore platformers. If you never played Electronic Super Joy before, start with 1 instead of 2. Perfect sequel to a great game. I have no idea why it is free though! To start,I don't actually like this game, it feels like smashing your head against a brick wall hoping to break it down. I can't even get past the forth level. But that doesn't matter because the game is free. The reason this gets a recommendation is because the OST is fantastic. It's worth playing just to hear the soundtrack. When playing in puplic it is recommended to mute checkpoint sounds üíÄüíÄ

Really good platformer with hours of playtime for free.

Also has First Person shooter

name: Duke Nukem 3D: 20th Anniversary World Tour
short_description: Frag like it‚Äôs 1996 ‚Äì this time with even more asses to kick! Join the world‚Äôs greatest action hero in Duke Nukem 3D: 20th Anniversary World Tour as he saves Earth once again, kicking alien ass and saving babes across the globe along the way.
reviews:
good shooter game The 20th Anniversary version is the best looking Duke Nukem remaster in my opinion, with true 3D rendering, you notice it when you look up and down. However, the actual feel to the game has been ruined. The game's mouse look has a deadzone where fine adjustment is close to impossible. Everything you do seems to have an input delay, this is very noticeable in the game's movement, where running, stopping, or changing directions make you feel like you're walking on ice. Queueing weapon swaps are really janky, sometimes having you swap to the previous weapon instead of the weapon you actually want.  The whole experience is just not very responsive. If you plan to buy it, try eduke instead. I only recently started to play this franchise, and luckily somehow I got the Megaton version back in the days. But the 20th Anniversary version is the latest version isn't? So I played the Anniversary version for a few levels, and decided to go back and play Megaton version for reasons I myself don't really know. It could be because of the weird rewind feature (which is from the Xbox Live Arcade version which is also what the Anniversary version based on) or some other things just made me feels weird.

I finished the entirety of Megaton version + expansion packs without much issues besides some minor sound effect glitches  from time to time, and how the NVG works kinda bad. Then I played the fan made source port for N64 which I really like, the fan made source port includes a lot of QoL features which are pretty enjoyable. 

Then I came back to this to play Alien World Order and... it's just the worst. I had high hope for this actually, especially the flamethrower which is something I really like, it's a shame it wasn't featured in the final version of Duke Nukem 3D. 

So when I was playing the few levels in the first episode it was fine actually. i don't really mind the new 3D graphics (the ambient occlusion feels kinda weird though), I personally don't have the control issues as some others mentioned, though I do have issue with vertical mouse aiming as if there is some vertical acceleration turned on which are not shown in the option menu, but it's not thaaat bad. Also I didn't turned the developer commentary on when I was playing the first episode so I have no idea what they were saying in there. But I did turn it on for Alien World Order.

While most of these are going to be about Alien World Order, some of these issues are also in Anniversary version in general:

Pros:

1. It has the flamethrower, and it works quite well against regular enemies

2. New soundtrack isn't bad

Cons:

1. Firefly troopers shrink themselves and when they did that it is very difficult to hit them (if you can hit them at all). I don't think I ever killed one of those shrinked firefly trooper with hitscan weapons ever, it just feel kinda frustrating and drag the combat when some of them just refuse to come back to normal (or shrinked themselves again very quickly) and if you don't want to waste your explosive, you just have to stand there and wait for them.

2. Your flamethrower doesn't work underwater, but I think firefly trooper's does? One of them once splitting flame at me when we were both in the water and that damaged me, it just didn't lit me on fire I think.

3. The flamethrower doesn't show up in your "0" weapon slot if you picked it up using full HUD and it caused me some confusion when I was wondering where is my flamethrower went, and because of this you cannot keep track of your ammo for the flamethrower by looking at the full HUD.

4. These new levels in Alien World Order are... well I don't want to question Allen Blum's and Richard Gray's level design abilities, I know they were part of the original dev team and are experienced professional, but for some reasons they just really really love to spam alien hordes for you to fight in this new episode. I never feels this game on "Come Get Some" is that hard. But with so many enemies in a very high density, it just made combat a frustrating chore to get through. The bosses are made thing worse. I always feels bosses in this game are "strafe and hold down LMB at them for awhile" or "find a blind spot and hold down LMB for awhile" and since how they love to spawn them plus the mini version you have to do that a lot, and it gets old really fast. Many of those levels' layouts don't help it either as most of them are not really in boss arena (there are only like a couple of actual boss arena iirc), you can easily find a blind spot or stay far away and just "hold down LMB at them for awhile". And Yes I know such boss and enemy placement were in the original episodes as well but not this frequent and overused to the point it making me feels like I'm playing some troll mods.

5. The developer commentary on Alien World Order are... not very informative, 95% of the comments are like Allen Blum and Richard Gray saying whatever off the top of their head as they were playing the game. They probably talk more about their old maps though, I haven't listen to those yet so I can't be sure.

6. Bugs. lot of weird bugs. 

6.1 First thing I noticed is how pressing ESC will play a random sound effects for no apparent reason, these sounds consists of shooting, exploding, reloading, gibbing and Duke's moaning sounds etc. It confused me and made me thought as if I bind some weird functions to the ESC key but after checking and reset the key bindings several times it persists.

6.2 It is hard to use the keycard on the card slot. From what I heard it is because of interaction is now part of auto aiming now and it also effect pressing buttons. This caused me some confusion when I was playing L.A. Meltdown as I thought i didn't get the keycard and wasted some of my time to look for a keycard I already picked up. 

(Now I remember one of the reasons why I stopped playing Anniversary version was I cannot trigger a secret switch, I didn't know why back then so I just got frustrated and stopped and go back to Megaton version.)

6.3 The Rewind feature will randomly decided "you are died" for no reason. It's a minor annoyance compare to many other stuff but still it's a straw to the camel's back. It can be fixed easily by turning this feature off.

6.4 Sound effects missing or glitching, and it is so much worse than the Megaton version's sounds glitching. Drinking tap water has no sound at all. And some times a door make no sounds when open or from a misaligned source (No it was not a secret door), or the worst case, make horribly loud overlapping sounds that will tear your ears. I got jumpscared by one of these doors sound once and it became one of the major reason why I'm writing this negative review.

6.5 There are some vertical surface, like a very tall wall or cliff, if you move into it Duke will instantly flew onto the top of it as if it's a small step.

6.6 Bosses and mini bosses which the new episode really adores will turn invincible if they took too much damage from flamethrower damage.

Most importantly from what I heard many of these issues exist since day one, that means Gearbox has completely abandoned (or never really cared about) this game as they haven't fixed any of these in the past nine years.

7. The NVG still just barely works. 10/10 one of the best shooters and best games of all time. Sad that it doesn't include the official addons..oh well. 
 Hail to the king baby! YES!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

COME GET SUM!!!!! This version is okay Glad I finally got to play a Duke nukem game and it being this instead of forever. 

It‚Äôs tons of fun with the overtop action film parodies and ‚Äúwtf‚Äù humor and moments. I understand why people love Duke and want him to come back. 

Play it now to understand and love Duke and his crazy adventures now over forever! Rad! I would rather play this than Doom. I got his just for the nostalgia but ended up wanting to find everything. The old cheats do not work but typing GOD for god mode during gameplay still works. I suggest doing that while finding all the secrets and then going back without cheating to try to get a good time, or using a guide the first time because the amount of secrets I never knew existed and never would found, like never in a million years lol. The mod maps in the workshop are awesome also! No one is online but there might be a discord you can find people in. Get it if it's on sale. This game taught me how to treat women back in the day.

name: Aries
short_description: Space strategy gaming reimagined. Dive into fast-paced real-time planetary battles against the backdrop of a turn-based campaign that sees you build your empire in the stars. With hundreds of troops and ships at your command, can you forge an empire that lasts?
reviews: is the dev ever gonna update this?? No tutorial, couldn't figure out how to play, after forty minutes I gave up. Refunded, Ill pick it up again once It gets a tutorial It's space age Total War, which is perfect in my opinion! I will say though this game needs a lot of work, but I believe that the developer can and will finish making the game it's just going to take some time. So if a space age Total War sounds good to you then please support this developer by buying the game as every little bit helps. For now though I need to take a break from the game until the final release or after several updates. And when I return to this game I will actually write a full on review for the game. Anyways thank you for reading and I wish the developer the best of luck!

name: Empires in Ruins
short_description: The bastard child of Grand Strategy and Tower Defense, with a black humor infused plot, set in a grim, disillusioned world. Quell the rebellion, tame the Western Marches, disobey your orders and save your brandy. Not strictly in this order.
reviews:
Fun game, interesting writing with sometimes rather juvenile humor - I quite liked it. The tower defense part is solid, the resource management was sometimes tedious but not too bad. I had lots of fun until the end! I tried to play the game after leaving it for a while, it has some interesting aspects, but overall it is lackluster.  It seems that not much thought went into the UI and the game isn't good enough to make up for this.  To give an example, when you click to get to your research, it has to go to a loading screen and then you have to "Press a key to continue".  Why do I need to press a key to continue to just get to the research screen?  Just load the damn screen!! the only good thing about this bugged crap is that with its 0 graphics, it does not take a lot of time to reload after it crashes Very underrated TD game. Cool mechanics of towers and enemies you don't see around in other games. The grand strategy part of the game is good and not too overwhelming to get the hang of. Solid game, underrated af, but solid. Pretty boring game.  Lame for a TD, lame for a city manager, 'grand' is far too grand a word for this game.  
BUT BUT BUT
It's cheap, get it.  Better to have choices than not enough games.  Support developers. I wish I could give a separate thumbs up and thumbs down for the two parts of this game. The strategic province management side of things is well-written, has great art, and reasonably engaging gameplay. The tower defence side had much worse art and much less impressive gameplay that didn't really innovate on a genre that has way too many samey entries. Auto-resolving the tactical battles to avoid the boring tower defence generally resulted in my guys getting massacred, so I had to slop my way through them instead. Until I realized I wasn't having fun and just ended things. 

I wish I could recommend. The strategic level is really very innovative. It's just too bad it was yoked to underwhelming tower defence combat. Swap out the existing TD combat for something else, and you'd have a Total War style contender. A Yes to recommend this title in an overdue review, long after I gave up playing. The developer put forth a fine effort, but the design seems flawed in a way that doesn't seem surmountable - your towers can be destroyed. There are two ways in which you cannot keep up with this mechanic. 1. You physically cannot keep up with the demands of the action in later difficult missions. 2. You cannot keep up from a Resource standpoint as all your structures get damaged or obliterated while you simultaneously must build direly needed additional structures. All over.

The story and dialogue is excellent. Refreshing in an online sea of generic characters and homogenous speech. A Risk-style strategic map allows you to set the stage for the defenses you mount as well as the offensives you instigate to take more provinces for additional resources. There are persistent upgrades that unlock new assets and that apply subtle statistical boosts to those assets. But the re-building mechanic - when such is most critical - becomes insurmountable far into the game.

I had 2 paths to my castle - one from the West, one from the East. I could hold the paths, but get bombed into dust by enemy airships. Establish enough air defenses to thwart the airships, and the enemy overruns you on the ground. Fortify the West approach and defend against air, and the Eastern approach steamrollers you. Invest in early resource generation (on the battlemap) and you don't have enough early defenses to survive to benefit from them. Lots of interesting elements to play with, such as stationable troops on the actual pathways, but not much opportunity to play with them. Not at that point, in those difficult circumstances.

A great game which I had to decide I had gotten as far as I could in. A good developer who deserves attention, and who hopefully brings out more titles such as this in the future. 3/10

This game is TD+Global map strategy ( civilization, krusaders kings and etc)...but les detailed and userfriendly

Why i dislike this game:
1) Bribe for your warlords... is most anoying thing in game.,.you will hate it alot...if only there a button bribe all....but there is not button like this
2) Humor ....i thout it will be dark humor but it is complex of poo jokes and curses...nothing more 
3) Level of happiness....dear devs hope you never repeat it again...i spend 1 h with zero tax level and zero fist level...but it is not improved from 39 to 40...looks like it is almost impossible to compleate company by lidership....800+ deays and company is not finished...im done for this game
 Interesing tower defense that blends with grand strategy. It nots easy to mix genres, and this game certainly has its flaws, but it nails it enough. 
Gameplay wise. its kinda interesing tower defense because your tower needs to be built by worker that walks from the base and both towers and worker can be attacked an destroyed, a few replays may be needed to beat certain maps.
 The game is hard (if you decide to play the maps) and there are maps that feel a bit unfair, and maybe they are (looking at you, explosive fliying enemies). In certain sense it kinda helps the funny and colorful narrative of someone that has to do a shitty work. Towers have their skills, some are useful, some questionable, but you will use a tower at least once for certain enemies.
Enemies arent that varied as other tower defenses like Kingdom Rush, but they certainly represent a challenge once they start to appear more often in mixed groups and you dont have a good tower to fend them. You will end up hate them and celebreate when you take out all of em.

The grandstrategy part is nice, but it requires some polish, like selecting every mayor manually or every time its a new recruit or the lack of fast and simpel info from were you already sent reinforcements. This section is also a bit hard in diffuclty, because you need a decent mayor in certain towns to produce material wich you will need eventually. 

Storywise, wich is like half of the fun, its pretty much a unglorious story of political plot using other factions and how you are traped in this mess , wich you hate and dint want, but its your work. The character are fun to read, they have their quirks, the jokes are well made and you will probably save some responses to use in your work. The story will probably remind you of your time were you had to do some work/service/internisph that really sucks and hated but you had to do it anyway and the only thing helping your sanity was alcohol and black humor.

Overall, not a perfect game, but one that is fun enough and has quirky characters and some "nostalgia" for those who hated/hate their job. [h1]Funny and... Nothing Else[/h1]

This game's dialogues are hilarious and made me laugh out loud several times, which is very rare. But everything else about it is so-so at best.


[u][b]The not-so-good:[/b][/u]
- 9.7 hours were enough for me to beat the Campaign on Hardcore and the Sandbox mode once. After that, there isn't any real reason to play more. You can make a few different choices in the Campaign, to see how things turn out, but... why bother?

- The 4x facet of the game is nothing special. You build one structure after another, in towns, upgrade these, get more resources, more bonuses to attacking other territories, reduce rioting chances and that's it. You don't need to make specialized towns or anything of the sort, there is no need to put much thought into it;

- The Tower Defense aspect of the game, which should be its strongest suit, turns out to be pointless. You can automatically resolve every battle (other than the Campaign's final one) and doing so tends to yield much better results than playing it manually. You can automatically get a 3 star outcome (requires no damage whatsoever to your HQ) on a battle that you previously attempted manually, tried your best and got defeated in. So, you simply don't play the combat. [i]Ever.[/i] Which leaves you with a 4x-only game;

- If you decide to do battle manually, despite having no actual reason to do so, you'll find it rather annoying. There are some debris scattered over all maps, stopping you from building towers on some of the most logical places. What is really irritating, though, is that you need to send workers out to build and repair towers. When they go out, if they cross paths with enemies, they die. At the same time, some foes can [i]very[/i] easily damage and destroy your towers, and repairing them costs quite a lot. After a few waves, most of your resources are spent on repairs rather than on building or upgrading your towers, sending you into a downwards spiral as waves keep becoming harder. You also need to send in wave after wave, as fast as possible, to get extra gold, so enemies keep coming while you keep frequently trying to repair several towers at the same time. It's quite unpleasant;

- There's a fairly extensive research tree in the game, but all of it is combat-focused. Since you simply automatically resolve every battle, the whole research aspect of the game becomes useless. I don't even think having more techs unlocked influence in auto-solved battles, at all;

- There's this mechanic, Tributes, in Empires in Ruins. Every 30 or so turns, you have to pay a large amount of resources to the Crown. If you fail to do so 5 times, you lose the game. It's annoying, but at least it gives you some [rather useless] bonuses when you pay it off. You can turn Tributes off before starting a game and, if you do so, everything becomes ridiculously easy -- the Tributes are basically the [i]only[/i] thing that provides a little bit of a challenge (the combat might but, again, there's no point in fighting manually);


[u][b]TL;DR:[/b][/u]
Empire in Ruins' dialogues are hysterical -- it's potty-mouth sarcasm at its finest. It sounds cheesy but, honestly, it's funny as hell. The gameplay itself, on the other hand, is rather generic, bland, unbalanced and easy.

The 4x part is simple, while the Tower Defense aspect is thrown straight out of the window as auto-solving [i]every[/i] battle is [i]way[/i] better than actually playing them.

Once you know what you are doing, you can finish a sandbox game in 2-3 hours. If you remove Tributes, you might be able to do so in 1.

I've never seen or said this before, but the best -- if not [i]only[/i] -- reason to buy this game is to laugh at the dialogues.

The humor is like 8/10. Everything else, 4/10.

name: 2032: A New Threat
short_description: 2032 is an Indie game with unique features. By 2032, 50% of global vegetation had already been completely consumed by a pest called P-X. A world war arises for basic resources for survival. Spider, a renowned soldier of the armed forces is summoned.
reviews:
I mean it's kinda janky all the difference ebtween shooting types don't really matter. Rifle is the only one that works. Probably takes maybe 3-4 hours max, I fell asleep playing it. The last mission you can get soft locked so don't mash reload cause you lose the mag. 

It's auto-transcribed from POR-->ENG there are a few rough patches but nothing particularly bad solid 3/5

name: War of Three Kingdoms
short_description: This is a strategy type game, players can capture the city, the final one continent, in this process, players can collect hundreds of heroes, different heroes have different skills and abilities, you can also train the hero, build a strong army.
reviews:
This is an interesting game. Bears strong resemblance to some Facebook games of yore. While not intrinsicly pay-to-win, spending real money is likely to help.

Would suggest getting on discount. [h1] Not bad but ... need some work [/h1]

[b] Gameplay [/b]: You send troops to attack, it's similar to Plants vs. Zombies.
[b] Graphics [/b]: Really like the art style (that's why i bouhgt it), nice character's drawings (anime style).
[b] Ultra wide support [/b]: No and not even resolution options.
[b] Controls [/b]: Mouse is enough (i think).
[b] Recommended price [/b]: Maybe 1.99‚Ç¨ (4.99 after EA and if they remove the Microtransactions).
[b] Devs. activity [/b]: Yes they are present on forum.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Can't recommend this game because:

- Edited 06/01/19: Devs. made some translations but still need to be fully translated.
- Micro transaction's are not welcome in EA.
- Edited 06/01/19: Still no resolution options but you can put it on full-screen now (but still need more resolution options).
- Feel like mobile port (not going to check but it probably is).

name: Oriental Valley
short_description: Welcome to the weird and wonderful world where modern country life meets quirky simulation adventure! Here you'll immerse yourself in a laid-back lifestyle full of traditional customs, make a bunch of quirky new friends, and embark on bizarre adventures.
reviews:
It is a delightful game, but it is incomplete. I bought this on sale, despite negative reviews on YouTube.

The English translation is bad and there are bugs, but I'm still smitten with its goofy style. I'm always unlocking things by surprise, and for the weirdest reasons, and they keep throwing more and more on my plate that I can do or work towards. 

People don't seem to enjoy the humor in it, but it is very Chinese "nonsense comedy" a la Stephen Chow. If you've played "Song of the Prairie," it is similar in its absurdism, but Oriental Valley doesn't have quite as many head scratching moments.   Oriental Valley makes sense, even if just barely.

Pros: 
Weird and quirky with lots of at least somewhat unique systems that are introduced, often by surprise.

Nice graphics, even if they are Unity assets or whatever--it's a pretty game! 

Runs fairly well on the Steam Deck--some of the menus go off the screen, but I've been 
playing it entirely on the Steam Deck. It loads fast!

Being kind of janky, there are exploits where you can make more money than maybe the developer intended--to me that's quite satisfying.

Cons: You do need patience, and it is likely helpful to go in with the expectation that this won't be a refined experience. 

Some things you can only do on certain days which leaves you without much to do during the in-game week after you get to a certain point.

Some things aren't translated at all which makes it very difficult nearer the end. 

All in all I'm on the fence with this one. I'd suggest a purchase if on sale and you know what you're getting into. What are you getting into exactly? A fun, goofy, flawed game. One that I'm playing but don't know if at a certain point I'll have to leave it incomplete because I don't speak Chinese. I really enjoy this game way more than I expected. It's such a hilariously fun parody of normal farming sims.

Instead of playing someone trying to get away from the big city to live a peaceful farming life, you're playing someone desperately trying to get out. It really feels like you're this random college student trapped in this weird fairy land full of bizarre oddities and you're trying to survive long enough to go home.

It sounds weird, it plays even weirder, but it has a really fun, strange charm of its own!

Plus, you have a combat system, the world's most hilarious mining quest, a really fun series of quests to collect what's basically pokemon, a lot of really cool areas to open up and explore (with little side quests of their own), and some surprisingly decent farming action.

If you like farming games and want a twist on an old formula in a game that will probably take you about 30 hours max to fully complete, I would recommend this game (especially when it's on a good sale like its on now). I'm so disappointed. I was really looking forward to this game. 
The blank NPCs are definitely odd. I could have forgiven that but... You'd think that with all the time they saved not bothering to design those NPCs at all, they could have put that effort into the main NPCs. It doesn't feel like they did, though. One of my first interactions with the village chef is just him saying "I'm a chef!". The next day, he wouldn't speak to me, and I read a dialogue about him grumbling and staring off into space. Riveting stuff. 

Also, you'd think that the blank NPCs aren't important because they didn't bother to design them, but they have gifted me things and given me quests, sometimes with or without any indication that something meaningful would happen if I spoke to them. I found this out because I went around speaking to all the blank NPCs because I was so bored with the rest of the game. 

I know that I didn't play for that long. Maybe it gets better? Very cute farm sim graphics are great, a few translations are not fully complete but still manageable only noticed it in one quest line. Thankfully the things you needed to complete it are still translated. Not for everyone this game does have only a few actual npcs and the rest are stick men. Which is a design choice I find charming but others hate. 
The difficulty curve isn't too bad only issue is earning money really takes time the further you progress in the game.

*tip for easy money* 
If you are struggling to earn money a quick way I did alot of early game fundings was mining the red stone in levels 20-28 they sell for 200 each so it's not bad. You do have to unlock some upgrades but since you can get food from chests it's a fairly painless grind.
Overall I enjoy it unlocking new areas and the random events that occur during the month is fun.

* TLDR Overall Rating*
8/10 graphics
7/10 gameplay
6/10 translations
10/10 weird/funny scale I really enjoy this game and find it relaxing. avid farm/life sim gamer here i buy and play most games like this one and this one just isnt doing it for me. games like this are sposed to make me look up and notice ive wasted an entire day. this one i found myself losing interest quickly. no way to pin tasks to ur hud so u can easly forget what ur sposed to be doing. the farming is ehhhh  u very quickly dont need ur hoe anymore as u get a a frog u can kick across the field to plow for u. i would have like a strafing button to make watering / planting better as u can easly step forward to much and hit the wrong farm plot. as another guy pointed out the title would make u think ud be focus on chinese or other asian crops more but no just standard western crops u can plant rice in a paddy but that aspect feels so half assed cant even nicly line the rice up u just throw them . everythign from wat to do to how to advance feels kinda directionless u pretty much just have to do everything u can to advance the town . most the town town is made up of souless white maniquins and well i personaly wouldnt care as much if it was just that but the like 10 non white npcs are bout as souless as the rest of them no ones moves around everybody just stays were u find them for the most part. didnt even get past first month so i cant say wat comes next but even the months and seasons are weird the first month ur there calender at top just says this month. fishings just boring not rlly a mini game liek most others u just wait for a bite and keep clicking till u reel it in 
just a shame as soon as i saw this one on steam i wishlisted it hoping for well a lot bettre then this . this almost feels like a quik pump out a bare bones cash grab game This game is fun, but has a lot of issues. It isn't fully translated, some quests ask for one thing but actually require another (a fishing quest asks for chubs but actually means bighead carp), and certain things to progress really aren't clear (if you access the area with apple trees before unlocking the bamboo sea, there are no clues on how to get a broom. Turns out, you gotta unlock the bamboo sea path, and right before departure you get the broom in a vending machine after talking to the train lady. Also, to catch fish with your hands in certain places like the mudflats, you have to gift a character a star from the firefly place that I cant remember the name of).

Pros
-I really like the fishing and how there aren't any skill checks or annoying mini games for it
-The cooking is easy. You can read the recipe book and figure out the ingredients very easily based on shape alone, so unlocking new recipes is a breeze. I also like the function of making x1, x5, and x10 when in the recipe menu
-Farming is simple, as always. How the ground, plant seeds, water them, harvest. There is an agrispirit who can get the plots ready for you so you don't have to do it one by one which is nice.
-Quests are pretty easy to complete (when given the right instructions)
-You can get pretty cute outfits
-The companions are really cool. I want to collect them all
-There is a lot to explore! I have played about 12 hours and still have three locations to unlock, I believe
-The game is indeed pretty
-It is so easy to get engrossed and spend numerous hours at a time playing

Cons
-Fishing quest asks for chubs when it really means bighead carp
-It isn't fully translated. There is one NPC with little chicks in it in the back corner of the logging location, and the only English word in it is BEEF so I have no clue what to do
-Placing seeds and watering is a little annoying because it isn't the easiest to lock on to the spots
-You lose time searching for items (like a broom) when it is tied to a quest with no indication of it
-The harvest competition thing should have had a tutorial mode like it offers for the card game and farming, as it is very confusing to me (I failed miserably)
-The storage spots in the wagon to sell things is not enough. I fill it  a lot and it gets frustrating not being able to sell everything in one day
-Uses for some things is not clear, like the timid tomato and other vegetables similar
-The character design does feel a bit lazy since so many NPCs are just blank models

Overall I do think it needed more work before being released, but that wont stop me from playing. chaotic & weird farming game, quirky in a charming kind of way.
 super fun, like surprisingly fun I gave this game a chance and played it for 3 hours to see if it would get better, but it's just not enjoyable.
The graphics may look good at first glance, but most characters are simply blank mannequins with no unique features and they always say the same thing. 
The dialogues don't make sense at all, nor does the story. The farming is functional but very barebones, with no unique mechanics. Most of the game consists of fetch quests, but gathering resources feels extremely clunky or doesn't make sense, for example you need a broom in order to get apples from trees (?) and the game doesn't tell you where to get the broom and no shop seems to be selling it. There are so many amazing farming games available, I can't find any reason to recommend this game over another.

 WORST GAME EVER TOO MANY BUGS AND POORLY OPTIMIZED, XBOX CONTROLLER WON'T WORK WITH THIS GAME DON'T WASTE YOUR MONEY

name: Good Company
short_description: Good Company is an in-depth management sim about building a trail-blazing tech corporation. Assemble complex production lines, manage employee logistics, and sell high-quality products on the market to become the best company in the whole county!
reviews: Love playing this game its a good tough game makes you work for it i like it underrated game. not perfect but one of the best biz/production sims ive played since satisfactory I play mostly manufacturing games and it is my main way to relax. For some reason, Good Company scratched an itch i didn't even know I had. I enjoyed playing so much, it is one of the few games I wished had done better so there would be more content. Even though this game didn't take off, thank you Chasing Carrots for the time you spent making it. its a little confusing but fun Good game if you are in to logistics (I am) Good Company is an absolute gem!  If you're looking for a game that blends creative problem-solving with satisfying progression, look no further. I can sink countless hours into this game, and I'm still finding new and exciting ways to optimize my factories and build my business empire.  The learning curve is smooth, allowing you to quickly grasp the basics, but the depth of the gameplay is truly impressive.  There's always a new challenge to tackle, whether it's streamlining production, mastering logistics, or conquering the market.  The sense of accomplishment as you watch your meticulously designed factories churn out products and your profits soar is incredibly rewarding.  Good Company is a must-have for any strategy or simulation fan ‚Äì highly recommended! fun automation game Similar to other games in this genre. The game is actually enjoyable, but it's extremely buggy.  I'm encountering bugs that I've seen posted over 4 years ago.

name: Nightmare Collection: Telephone Call
short_description: Telephone Call is a short horror story about receiving strange phone call during a party.
reviews:
It's Fears To Fathom while stealing a scene and dialog from Scream and it's very boring.  If Nightmare Collection: Telephone Call want to hit you up and make you buy it even on sale do yourself a favor - hang up. Big thumbs up from me‚Äîthis is a very cool, short indie horror game. I really appreciate that the developer is responsive to feedback and issues reported. Hopefully, we'll see more fantastic short horror experiences from D B Productions in the future! Bugs, bugs, bugs and again bugs. It's been a long time since the game release but nothing has changed. Also, the jumpscare is an earrape. Its pretty meh. 
Also, its funny how the house is exactly like the one in Raycastly's game Clap Clap. I chose to stream this on my channel, and thought it was OK. I felt some parts dragged and I think it needed some work, because example: It told me to collect all bin bags, and then didn't tell me what to do next. Or it allowed me to collect 1, then next part would happen. 
I felt this game had a combo of Fears to Fathom and 616 Games, and it was a little spooky.
Either way, your game is at 03:20:00.
Link to my stream is here: https://youtube.com/live/6iifffLeVhk Big thumbs up from me. very cool, short indie horror game. Also, Props to the developer for responding to the issues reported. Hopefully we get more short, indie horror games from D B Productions.   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EvHqzp9fAcA&t=134s  Good on Sale! you kinda just like dont do anything. then the ending broke when I tried to get a better ending, refused to let me do anything different

name: Anime Girls Trample
short_description: Haven't you dreamed of being crushed and trampled by a beautiful anime girl? Would you like to unleash your macrophilia and foot fetishes? If your heart started to beat faster then this game is for you!
reviews:
its quite good except for the fact that stuff is kind of hard to get sometimes like the characters I finally found the meaning of life...I can die in peace now. Saw this game after searching for anime stuff. I quite like size roleplay and this had "anime girls" in the title. Was ¬£0.89 so i took the plunge.

I have a Ryzen 9 and it was running at 10 frames per second...
You can tell these game assets were not designed to be scaled up so much, so it's likely stock Unity game assets cobbled together with no optimisation techniques.
The girls are constantly in bikini and don't actually move. They stand there and do the same stomping animation (which can hit you even if you're far away from it.
Every time you get hit, you get sent back to the "girl selection" area (????) and have to spend the next 20 seconds running back to the middle of the island so you can be stepped on again. (You're also locked to first person, so you can't see anything)

There are no settings. You can't change the resolution, graphics settings, audio volume, difficulty, and neither can it decide on a control scheme. Sometimes you have to use the space bar to do something, then other things you have to press "E".

All you need to know is there's an achievement for playing for 10 minutes. And only 30% of players have gotten it.

Yeah this is so unfinished that it's not even a game. Its a template with Unity presets in it, likely with scripts written by an AI. I may have spent more time writing this review than PaulArts spent making this "game". No 3rd person view and you dead even when they do not even touch you. This game has POTENTIAL i would love to see added attacks, humiliation moves using different body parts, maybe even death scenes, im tired of some ecchi games that get so much story you just want to get to the fighting, o a way to fight back even if its futile or just to stun would be nice, it sucks you start to far away from the girls most of your time will be used walking close to them at first, im not sure if this game will continue but it definitely has potential. matrepipece Pretty basic game without any bells or whistles.  Good for a few minutes of laughs dodging giant girls, but not much point to playing more than that. 

Would be a lot more engaging if you could work up to different types of outfits and footwear for the girls as that would create a lot more variety.  At present the only play value is a huge number of points for the final achievement, but that's not a reason to play...not to mention you can only earn 3 points a dodge since there aren't anything like multipliers or other things you can invest points in to make the score go up faster.

Will give a thumbs up as it was a good laugh dodging giant girls for a few minutes as opposed to dodging bullets or other more normal game gimmicks. Very interesting game, not much to it honesty. 7/10- Nothing mind blowing but a cute, fun little game. the most laggy game i've ever played.

reviews: very good game Avvruk

name: Evenicle
short_description: In a world where the more a knight achieves, the more wives he can obtain, a young man sets off on an adventure with lust in his heart. Walk the land, sail the seas, fly through the sky! It's a sex-seeking, world-traversing RPG!
reviews:
I have NO IDEA why the sequel is not available on Steam.
This game's sequel is basically one of the reasons why I had to make a GoG account.

This is a GREAT Adult themed JRPG meant FOR ADULTS.
I even like the straightforward protagonist. Though, after seeing the events of the first dungeon, there were hints of how you can choose how to morally guide the protagonist in his... pursuits...

Not a fan of being forced to use a mouse or a keyboard to play this though. The only way I was going to give this a thumbs up was if the game gave me a decision to kill "Mother Eve" at the end of the game. You figure out pretty early on that she's a massive sphincter because she classifies fornication at the same level as murder and curses anyone who fornicates with a curse that doesn't allow them to mine, cook, raise animals, grow crops, or do anything else useful. Yes, this curse also applies to victims of rape. If you're cursed by Eve, your only options to survive are charity or theft. 

The H scenes of this game are F-tier. I didn't get hard once. The artists struggled to get basic human anatomy correct. Also, the MC is second-only to Eve herself in terms of insufferability. The writers are clearly shut-ins because their idea of rizz is to have Mr. MC walk up to a woman and say "ME WANT SEX. ME WANT SEE UR BOOBZ." And, of course, since all the women in this world are stilted sex robots, this somehow makes them swoon. Seriously, don't try this irl, you'll be hit with a restraining order.

What kept me playing was the Snakecrest conspiracy and the Evenicle mystery. Both plots ended up being a letdown. The revelations about Eve didn't change my opinion about her other than to make me hate her more for being a tyrant and a hypocrite. The revelations about the first ancestor were okay but they weren't worth all the H scenes I had to skip through.

All-in-all, there's too little story here to justify someone else purchasing this and there are a million more sexy games than this on the market. Give it a miss.

Finally, here's a list of additional things that annoyed me to drive home how awful this game is:
-Buddy canonically likes to chug piss.
-This game includes a scene where a child zombie sexually assaults her own dying father and then eats him. (get therapy if this is your fetish)
-This game includes a sex scene with a freshly dead corpse
-Mr. MC rapes a defeated enemy (he avoids Eve's curse because Eve's rules have been temporarily rescinded) which goes to show he has no principles and only follows laws when expedient. 
-Mr. MC dares to ask the question of if it's still gay to have sex with a man if you give him tits and replace his penis with a vagina (spoiler: yes, it's still gay.)
-Tio gave up her career as President to quite literally become a mommy bang maid. Calling all polygamists! Alicesoft's Evenicle may very well become your saving grace; The game certainly saved me. Evenicle is 60 hours of pure fun, packed with amusing, lovable characters, great side quests, one of the coolest fantasy maps I've seen, and plenty of unique enemies and gal monsters to find. Our goat, Aster, takes upon the daunting task of having multiple wives via a convenient law made along with the world...and so he fulfills his quest. Each wife is a joy to be around, and it shows. I've never seen a man who loves women more. Partially because of this, I could sit behind the screen for days on end playing Evenicle. It really is addicting.

Alicesoft is known for their gameplay, and I love Evenicle's gameplay. An improved version of Rance Quest gameplay, many people would call it too simple or easy, but who cares? It fits Evenicle perfectly, which wasn't supposed to be difficult like some games in the Rance Series. It's enjoyable, smooth and clean, and most importantly well balanced. It is very hard to miss things in the game, and I really love that. You won't get locked out of a CG, or miss an item, or any bullshit that happens with other Alicesoft games. A lot of love was put into Evenicle back in the day.

The story is...good? What? Yeah, the story is good. Its woefully entertaining with some of the most hilarious things I've seen in fiction. Funny H-scenes that will leave you rolling. Just pure laughs and fun that the whole family can enjoy. (maybe not) And while I would say this is a more lighthearted, adventurous Alicesoft game, veteran fans can expect to get ALL of the classic Alicesoft flair...who doesn't love a bit of Ham Bambaras running a train? Monster birth via haughty woman? They know just what to include. Of course, the 3D models, backgrounds and map are stunning and perfect for the game. Eroge never felt this good. The music? Some of the catchiest out there, I listen to it regularly. Evenicle is worth playing and I would totally play it again. No, annoying visual novel BS, didn't even make it to the H scenes.... game is expensive but the gameplay and art style are very good would like a sub just because its hard to read and look while im hard but other than that its a great game 
7.8/10 1000/10 Great story game, the naughty side is quietly funny and not too intense, great graphic and easy to play> hey, hey, people I really enjoyed this game.
MAIN PRO: RAMIUS
 Pretty good story, engaging character development and getting max level and 100% in everything never felt too grindy. Liked most of the artwork and the overall feel of the world. There were some rather uncomfortable parts and I didn't like there being child like ones, however, as far as adult games go this has been fun. Wish it had achievements. Its a terrible JRPG with grindy elements that are a nuisance. The H scenes are 3-4/10 at best (1 being some stick figures 10 being subverse). Over hyped game that I would recommend if you can get it for less than or equal to $5.00 USD.

name: Behind The Death Scenes
short_description: Contains various bloopers, notes and sketches.
reviews:
Buy very nice and sadistic >) Wow! There's a lot of interesting content here! You can even make an interesting video based on this alone! I bought it for support the author of this mod. Very nice project. I'm glad what he was came out in Steam. (Sorry for possible bad English..) If you enjoyed the mod series enough, this is really the least you can do by buying this.
Also the Halfquake Amen comic is awesome. A great way to tether this fantastic game to your account and support the developers at the same time. Every free game should have this. >) For old and hardcore fans, and for those who really cares.
There's a lot of interesting and unseen stuff. Experience that awesome atmosphere of mod-development today!

name: Steam Marines 2
short_description: Steam Marines 2 leaves you in charge of the I.S.S. Delhi, ready to take back your space station.
reviews:
NOTE: THIS IS AN EARLY ACCESS GAME IN NEED OF IMPROVEMENT. ONLY BUY WHEN ON SALE (WHY CANT WE JUST GIVE STAR RATINGS 1-10 OR SOMETHING?)

I give this game 5 out of 10 stars. If it were possible. I got it on sale its very good otherwise. Kinda like Space crusade space hulk and needs improvement. But its getting better. The missions are random and generated and so are the maps so no one game is the same. Pretty much.

I'll give a better rating later after its progressed. Didn't like the graphics but thought the game design and mechanics might be good. 
Well they weren't. 









 Big improvements from the first game. I enjoy controlling more than four marines and the new skill system gives each run more variance. The portraits you can assign to your marines are gorgeous and makes you more invested in them not dying. After a few hours of play I experienced one bug but it was minor involving a marines action points not displaying correctly after I started on a new planet and it was fixed after switching to another marine and back again.

There is a weird mechanic where opening doors has certain effects depending on the class of the marine that opened it. I think it's weird and not realistic but I found myself spending more time thinking about exactly hiw I wanted to move my team. This doesn't appeal to me that much but you can ignore it if you want all the door stuff is only beneficial to you.

The easy difficulty option is imo a lot easier than the easy difficulty from the first game. If you're not a beginner to tactics games I recommend starting a bit higher up.

Eager to see where this game goes in early access. This is still Early. I think The Guy not playing Steam Marines 1 will not be satisfied for Game Volume of current version on this price , I mean 25$ around. But you know , This is Early and Steam Marines is one of most success case of Early access and I was playeding Steam Marines 1 , So , I'm really exciting for this game and knowing What This game Aiming to. So I think , We must remind , What "Early Access" meaning. and you know I just really thrilling about if someone forget that. I'm happy to pay 25$ for this real countable game! But You guys must remember before buying this game , This is Early Access. And you must remember True Early Access meaning! you know. but this game will be great! I proud own this game in this moment, I meaning time and space! you know Really fun game with a lot of character customization, multiple classes with unique abilities/upgrade paths, and lots of different possible playstyles. I've played mostly on some of the lower difficulty levels, which probably allowed me to progress further than I would have otherwise thanks to permadeath. On lower difficulty, you can freely explore and blow up aliens and robots at your leisure, while learning the game mechanics and picking up tips that will save your bacon when you ramp up the difficulty (Oh, you used your last action point to move around a corner and ran into a Ripsaw? RIP. Hopefully your replacement marine will have learned from its predecessor).

Particularly enjoyed some of the features that I haven't really seen before in other games, notably, a unique class effect that grants different benefits upon breaching entryways, which gives a lot of additional complexity and strategic possibilities, and the randomized (and often hilarious) effect at the beginning of each turn which can give a much-needed boost, or wreck the delicate planning you had in place. 

The procedural generation yields lots of replayability (and some very odd/unique map layouts), and I'm looking forward to what the polished final project looks like, give it a shot, and leave some feedback for the dev!

name: Dungeons of Betrayal
short_description: Become a young hero and travel from dungeon to dungeon to regain your lost memories. While fighting your way through, you will encounter characters from your past. It's your quest to figure out if they are friends or foes. But be careful anyone can betray you in the Dungeons of Betrayal.
reviews:
[h2]Dungeons of Betrayal[/h2]

ÊàäÂØÖÂπ¥Áßã‰∫é‰π¶Êàø Dungeons of Betrayal takes you through dark, puzzle-filled dungeons with a story full of twists and decisions. You‚Äôll encounter characters who might betray you, adding to the tension as you explore. The game offers a classic RPG experience with weapon upgrades, stat management, and hidden areas to discover. It‚Äôs got a simple charm, but the unpredictable nature of who you can trust keeps it interesting. If you enjoy dungeon crawlers and decision-heavy gameplay, this one's worth checking out for its replayability and mystery. This game is strange. Structurally, it's sound, and very polished. It's fast-paced, and clearly, the developer cared a lot about making this a good game. There are SOME original assets. Not a lot, but there are some. The character portraits and battle backgrounds are original. My question is, if they're willing to do that much, why still include the basic default RPG Maker assets at all? Why not make everything from the ground up? That seems like a very strange decision to me. The gameplay is fun but it can get repetitive, and there's really not much else going on besides grinding and getting to the next level. That's fine, it's just not really my type of thing. It's a decent game, and I think it's quite decent, but it just doesn't go all the way in my opinion. Also the game is incredibly easy. Way too easy. 

6/10. It's a good game, but I don't really see myself coming back to it I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

name: Hero Academy 2
short_description: Sequel to the original tactical strategy game, Hero Academy 2 adds card collection, deck building, and real-time matches!
reviews:
Was taken out of early access and stated as final so they could abandon the game.
For a pvp based f2p game, that has in game purchases and zero support updates or content updates from the developer after going "Final".

Can't and won't reccomend this game to anyone.
Nor would i advise anyone ever give Robot entertainment any money for any of their new games if there are ever any untill they have been final are still supported after being moved out of Early access. This is my first steam game review and I thought it was neccessary for this game.  For a seemingly simple strategy board game this game packs a lot of punch.  

Firstly the pros: 
-Game looks beautiful, graphics are great and the effects look really great!
-Cross platform: Play on PC, Phone, tablet all under the same account..I love this! (Phone and tablet version free, PC version costs money but gives you way more value in terms of unlocking cards etc...worth it!)
-Strategy!!!! I love this game because of the hundreds of decks you can build.  The more you play the more strategies you uncover which is something that I love!
-Overall, great game and I highly recommend for beginners to deck building games and for experienced players.

Cons:
-Rewards system could be better...It takes quite some time to unlock legendary cards. I wish there were more ways to earn rewards apart from just dueling (after you beat the campaign) and waiting ever 4hours for a chest. It'd be better if it was similar to clash royale for this.
-Explanation of cards. I wish cards had a bit more of an explanation. Every once and a while you learn a new dynamic of how two cards work together. (The campaign helps for the basics and some) but every once and a while I learn that two cards don't work together....takes a while to get the hang of it....part of playing and learning i guess...not too big a deal!

Overall, I highly recommend this...since buying it I have loved customizing decks to make a perfect deck...Highly recommend...one that will be a perfect game for short sprints or long hauls. It's a good game, slighty diferent from the first but fun too. I hope they'll put the formers teams; the dwarf, the tribe, team fortress... I love turn based tactical games. Latesly Ive played everything from duelyst, to Tactical monsters, hearthstone and a bunch of others. I like this new hero academy the most. The graphics are great. I can play on my phone or on steam, both interlinked. Lots of cards. Never crashes. Lots of single player campaign stuff to do.

GET THIS GAME if you love turn based tactical. The game has 3 unique races and a plethora of neutral cards to enhance your decks. Each race has a variety of racial abilities to choose from. Up to two racial abilities can be chosen. The deck size is 30. There is no consequence to overdrawing from the deck like in other games. The fatigue is instead implemented by giving a direct damage spell every round after 12.

Every turn grants 5 mana. The max mana amount is 10. The amount of mana per turn and cap can change depending on what cards are in play.

The maximum hand size is 5. Cards are drawn until the hand is completely filled every turn. This means that card draw is never a problem for any deck. 1 card can also be discarded for a draw every turn.

The balance between the races/decks is very poor. Currently one race is extremely weak, one race is in a good spot, and one race is extremely overpowered.

There is a very wide variety of decks. No cards are extremely OP or game ending. There are no OTKs either. There are combos, but they need to be set up and planned. There is plenty of hard removal and ae removal along with a lot of interesting creatures with synergies between them. There are also a variety of themes that can overlap with each other to make a pretty dynamic deck.

Your health is split up among several crystals on the board. There are several boards each with their own configuration. You are given 24 health. A player can deploy one row up once any one crystal is destroyed.

Ranged units can't attack anything right next to them. This means that they can't return attacks when hit by melee.


I'd rate it as recommended or a very diverse landscape of decks. We can only hope that future balance patches will improve the meta as decks become feasible. Strategy??? Oh Yes, when you have all legendary cards but how to do that if even there is no daily mission? The only way to get card in this game is Bank Card, if not, you have to spend years to get the strategy of the game!
Summery: This game was created to get money! Complete upgrade from the first Hero Academy.

name: Obversion
short_description: Obversion is a challenging yet accessible abstract first-person puzzle platformer set in a vibrant universe of cubes.
reviews:
I am not too enthusiastic about puzzle platformers in general, since far too many of them are focusing on platform part, which become a bottleneck even if I could deal well with the puzzle parts. So coming across a game of the genre that has included an automove/autojump mechanism to deal with that annoyance certainly sounds promising.

And, well, that was the part I liked in the game and highly recommend other game developers to lift that. 

Now, the rest of the game: there's still the problem of first-person platforming that trying to get the cube creation/destruction to hit the point which you actually want to hit: eventually can be done (and if not, there's unlimited undo) but gives its bits of frustration. But even worse are the collectibles and secrets, which you are apparently supposed to just find in random. jump off the platforms in random directions, repeat and repeat and repeat. Destroy random cubes to see if there is something there, undo, repeat and repeat and repeat.
I wonder if there are some functions and commands I am missing here or am I really supposed to be doing that? Something reasonably simple like having a rotatable level selection screen would already make the game a bit more palatable. 
As it is, despite the promise in mechanics, I am just finding it annoying. Obversion is an outstanding and fiendishly difficult pure puzzle game. It takes one of the smallest movesets one can think of, i.e. mostly just the abilities to a) create a block or b) to destroy one, and builds an entire meaty game around them. Puzzle games typically introduce significant new powers over time to keep things fresh. Obversion opts for the more interesting approach of making only minor new additions to the moveset, while keeping the gameplay remarkably varied due to exceptional level design. (And as a neat aside, by centering the game around two opposing abilities, it neatly parallels its yin-yang motif.)

Level Design

Regarding that level design: the levels become much weirder than the first few might lead one to believe. And the puzzles constantly make you feel that "this is impossible". This is in large part due to the tight resource management (like in another excellent hidden gem, [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/MondSemmel/recommended/1581890]The Magic of Three[/url]): to use an ability, you must first find a pickup that lets you use it, and those pickups are not only very scarce but often also pretty challenging to find or reach in the first place.

Difficulty

The overall result is an unrepentantly challenging puzzle game. Just solving the levels is already hard enough, but each one also contains an optional yin-yang pickup, and obtaining those ramps up the challenge even more. I occasionally wished the dev had made an easier difficulty mode with 1-2 extra resources in some levels. Instead, you can get an optional hint for each level at no penalty. Those hints are good, but obviously there's a limit to how helpful a 1-liner can possibly be. Addendum: I ultimately figured it was a pity that the game couldn't offer more help if you got stuck, and thus wrote a hints-based [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2840818550]Steam guide[/url] for it.

Anyway, despite these tight resource constraints and the high difficulty, level solutions surprisingly aren't always unique - after 100%ing the game I watched a couple solutions by someone else, and at times the details of their solutions differed from mine.

Observation

A surprising amount of the challenge can be remedied by careful observation: the game lavishly rewards paying attention to detail. In particular, the level select screen provides an isometric view onto the actual level, so you can sometimes see pickups that might be obscured once you're in the level.

A few maze levels can be understood much better from the bird's eye view before entering them; the pyramid level does something really clever with regards to observation; and e.g. the final level is incomprehensibly complex in-game but much more comprehensible from the level select screen. Finally, I solved 2-3 levels by semi-brute-force, then discovered afterwards that the game had hidden tons of information around the level.

Other than that, the puzzles are also often cerebral enough, especially given the resource constraints, that they strongly benefit from taking some notes, which I enjoyed.

Accessibility

Putting the game's high difficulty level aside, it's otherwise surprisingly accessible: besides a robust undo-redo system, it optionally offers two powerful accessibility features: Firstly, with automove, if you point at a spot that would be reachable from your position with perfect control, you can make your character automatically move there at the press of a button. And secondly, autojump makes your character jump automatically if you move off a cliff or towards a wall. These two features let you remove all mechanical challenges from the game so you can concentrate just on the considerable cerebral ones. And these features also make the gameplay much smoother, e.g. stairs are faster to climb with autojump.

Conclusion

I highly recommend Obversion. I've played tons of puzzle games over the years, and this one was a favorite. Wonderful little puzzle game. By the end, there are some real brain busters, in terms of logical complexity. The procedural and mathematical art style is pretty, technically impressive, and compliments the gameplay well, and the philosophical musings scattered about give the whole proceeding a little more personality than it otherwise could have had. The accessibility features are definitely a nice touch, and let you focus on the puzzle aspect, which is the crux of the experience. The soundtrack is lovely and well-composed, though I would've probably liked some more upbeat tracks interspersed throughout to give the whole thing a little energy boost every now and again and keep things interesting. Some puzzles (usually the optional "challenge" ones) require some kind of esoteric movement or block maneuver that I wish was telegraphed more later in the main game, such that I could come back to them and re-ponder with new knowledge in tow. (though, full disclosure: I have not FULLY beaten the game yet, but have made it 20 or so levels in). Overall, the difficulty curve feels good - not to tough, not too gentle. Anyhow... long story short: this game is great for any fan of puzzles, and is criminally overlooked. Its a good deal for the money, even more so when on sale. Recommended for gamers of all skill levels and backgrounds. Obversion is a complex yet elegant platform puzzler. You can work your way through it without significant struggle or you can take time to ruminate on the puzzles. The difficulty does ramp up through the worlds and you may find yourself with a puzzle that requires more thought than blindly barreling forward.

The music is a special gem. I wouldn't want to spoil it for prospective players, but what I can say is that it compliments the levels and builds on itself as you progress.

The dev put a lot of thought into movement mechanics and it seems that the puzzles have been mapped out and thoroughly thought through. I found myself stumped in one place or another until I noticed a pattern or subtle hint.

I really love the undo/redo system. It makes messing up easily fixable and it enhances exploration.

All in all, Obversion is a Fantastic 3D puzzler that will give you challenge and Great Joy upon finding your Yin Yangs. A lovely, easy to learn, and hard to master puzzle game. A fascinating art style paired with fiendishly clever puzzles with multiple solutions, hidden objects and a forgiving undo system? A 3D platformer that has an optional jump mode that will auto-jump to a given location so you can focus on just playing? Absolutely. The game's difficulty ramps up as you progress through the 28 levels, each of which poses unique challenges. It's not hard to work through them, though: with mechanics that are easy to pick up on without explanation (except for controls, shown when starting the game), plenty of accessibility features (those being autojump, automove, and the undo/redo buttons) that can make it easy to traverse over obstacles, and a free hint that can be picked up at the start of every level, plenty of help is given for players to work through the rather complex nature of 3D first-person puzzlers. Observation, planning, and cleverness are key in order to reach the end of all of the puzzles made, even more so with the bonus yin-yang collectibles.

Overall, I would recommend this game for pure puzzle-solvers, for there is not much else offered besides a few philosophical quotes shown when passing through some transparent spheres found on a few select levels. This game is a abstract minimalist 3D Puzzle Game with First-Person POV controls.
I like these things.

The secrets are also a lot of fun to find/complete. A simple but well flushed out puzzle game around the mechanic of adding and removing blocks to reach a destination. Visuals are simple but with enough flair to remain interesting to look at. The mechanics evolve a fair amount, but remain committed to the same theme. There are surprisingly robust undo and auto-jumping systems. While I initially turned off auto-jump, I realized that it removed some of the frustrating platformer execution problems that this type of setting would normally create. 

As with many puzzle games there were a few levels that I found frustrating to solve, but that was made up for by the levels I really enjoyed. Each level has an additional, harder objective to complete which made some of my favorite levels really shine. I'm not a completionist and thus collecting all of them did not appeal to me. Each level was structured around a visual or structural theme, which kept levels feeling different. One side thing I look for in puzzle games is an interesting puzzle packed into a small design space, and some of the levels in Obversion particularly scratched that itch for me which was great. I'm not normally a puzzle game guy, but Obversion really hooked me. 

It starts off simple, with the basic idea of adding and removing cubes from a beautiful TRON like world to solve puzzles, but it quickly starts to remix its own concepts in a way that I found quite delightful. There's a level in the second world where I literally burst out loud laughing when I saw what the game was doing‚Äîunexpected but totally made sense within the rules that had been set up so far.

It's not an easy game‚Äîprepare your thinking caps‚Äîbut it is absolutely fair, so you really get that Eureka rush of insight when you finally figure out the solution to a puzzle. The whole undo system/auto jump/auto move is something I WISH more games had. 

Overall: strongly recommend it! If you liked games like Portal or The Witness then you'll really enjoy this! I have really enjoyed playing Obversion. It creates an atmosphere that gets me into a nice, meditative flow state. I really appreciate the time and effort put into creating the many different puzzles in the game, and I'm pleasantly surprised by the number of different variations on puzzles the developer found within the constraints of the mechanics of creating and destroying blocks.
The progression of the game through the different worlds has a feeling of slowly descending deeper into the depths of the analytical mind, and the shifts in aesthetic and mood as the game progresses have mysterious tone, like peering further into the void. The different quotes on duality peppered throughout the game are insightful and apropos. I highly recommend this game, especially if you are the introspective and inquisitive type.

name: American Truck Simulator - Western Star¬Æ 57X

The most advanced and innovative Western Star highway truck. Ever!

A free DLC that adds a new truck to the game, what is there not to like. GOOD JOB ILKE  KEEP GOOD WORK I highly recommend. Highly detailed semi-truck model both in interior and exterior, details are accurate to real-life.

9.5/10, I would recommend. A great truck with a nice design and lots of power! short_description: Age of History II is a grand strategy wargame that is simple to learn yet hard to master.Your objective is to use military tactics and cunning diplomacy to either unify the world, or conquer it.Will the world bleed out or bow before you? The choice is yours..
reviews:
I'm just a geography buff so like everything geography is a yes from me, so if you don's like strategy games or geography related content, this isn't the game for you Zajebiste polecam z serca
 got almost 600 hours on the game tbh for history/geo nerds its a perfect game its simpler than hoi4 but also with more of a creative aspect i recommend it to people like me. But fair warning u will end up making a million scenarios lol Even though AoH III is already out I would still like to post my experience with this game.
With the ability to choose over 100 countries (I don't know how many) this game never gets boring, endless possible ways to play this game.

I personally had the most fun playing with friends, even though it takes a long time to get to your turn and the game doesn't progress as fast as playing solo, it's still a very enjoyable way to spend your night fooling around a bit. Die Fahne hoch! Die Reihen fest geschlossen!

short_description: Wreck the Insects - An arcade-style shootem' up with a floral twist!
