I loved it. I couldn't stop playing it. I disconnected from it long ago, and then I purchased this version of the game. It's so bad. They re-interpreted everything, and the game is so glitchy. I hate to say this, but this game was born dead, with few fans. Don't bother, even the DLC packs don't offer discounts.

name: Warlords Awakening
short_description: Prepare yourself as you step into a world writhing in chaos. Warlords Awakening, a remastered MMORPG that will place you on a journey to become an Elite Lord with an action packed story and ominous monsters around every corner. Explore and conquer the world of Epheia together with the cute and dashing pets to choose from.
reviews:
absolute trash ahhh what sux. lol its have been shut down in 2019 shit 10/10 Game is no longer playable. Development abandoned. Servers were shut down. Apparently I forgot to write my review for this game....
I enjoyed it. 
I wish I played it more, but I only have so much time in a day.
Hopefully the assets for the game can open source as they gorgeous! This Game had fun game play, but they never had intentions of running it, this company was a scam. I REALLY WANT "SEA" SERVER SO MUCH!!! Oh boy, what can I say.

I should start with stating that I extensively played ELOA and followed the release before it came to America. I had really high hopes for the original American release rightfully so, the game had high potential.

Pros at the time
     Fluid Combat
     Creative Art style
     Relatively balanced pvp
     Good group content

Cons at the time
     Massive Payment wall for enchanting
     Unfair advantage in PvP from equipment
     No meaningful way to progress solo
     Raids were more dependant on Equipment to reach a DPS
     (Had to compromise when selecting members who paid for gear)
     Slow PAINFUL Boring grind to reach any content that is fun
     Max level increasing and all end-game content being locked to it
     (To continue to PvP you had to re-level again from 25/30/35/40 etc.)

To be fair that was all in the original release and I don't know what's all changed since.
All I can say is the grind was substantially worse than I remember it being aside from:
Cash shop seemed uninspired, lots of copy/paste no real improvements to changes.
Skills were totally messed up from the original game balance breaking certain things.

I can't say I tried any of the end-game content because by the time I realized they re-released this game the population was already dead and the game wouldn't allow me to progress past level 30 in the story line because Mud Swamp was completely glitched.

If you think you can make it through the mind-numbing grind to max level you will find a game that might be worth the PvP experience, but honestly I don't think the game is going to last long enough to give you a good enough try to get your moneys worth. Great potential, poor delivery in both instances. Doesn't run, gamegaurd maybe? Support asks me to turn my firewall and antivirus off and then allow remote assistance to "fix the problem" sounds like a scam to me.

name: Total War Saga: FALL OF THE SAMURAI ‚Äì The Saga Faction Pack
short_description: The Saga Faction Pack adds a new playable faction to Total War: SHOGUN 2 - Fall of the Samurai, previously only available in the Limited Edition, for use in single or multiplayer Campaign modes and Custom and Multiplayer Battles.
reviews:
I think you get it for free nowadays, but i remember paying for it. Nevertheless, the faction is not one of my favorites, but more content is more content:) Honestly a Amazing faction for the game, totally Artillery only is not a horribly broken strategy Parrot guns go pew pew and shatter enemy At a glance the Saga are very obviously one of the most enjoyable factions to play in Fall of the Samurai and this is very much true. The Saga start with a great starting location and buffs that support a huge economy, navy & the best units in the game ‚Äì modern artillery. 

The Saga starting location is very good. They start with Nagasaki that has a smuggling den and trading port that can be quickly made into a foreign trading port. They start near the French and British trade nodes, and are on the bottom of the map and so they can easily protect their trade. They also start off already trading with these powers netting lots of early game income. The Geisha agents from the smuggling will net tens of thousands of Koku over the course of the game while garrisoned and the foreign adventurers from the port will make armies extremely elite & counter most other agents. Next to Nagasaki is the coal rich Hizen province that the Saga can fully exploit with their 20% bonus to industry income. These two provinces are on their own peninsula and can be easily defended from land and building a navy should be no problem with their solid starting economy. The nearby island of Tsushima has a gold resource that can be used to fund industry. 

The most obvious strengths of the Saga are their bonuses to artillery and their navy. Naval strength is everything in Fall of the Samurai due to the ability of naval bombardments to destroy coastal cities, and ports. Navies are also extremely expensive so a -10% recruitment and upkeep bonus goes a long way. With their foreign port the Saga are well positioned to get the first steam ship and steamroll every other navy, destroy enemy cities and support land armies with naval bombardments. They also have no reason not to use lots of overpowered modern artillery as theirs is made even accurate for no cost. 

The Saga are a great faction with really no downsides. They are well positioned to fully embrace industrialization and a modern military. They have the best faction stats and a great starting position, but not the best starting position so there is still some challenge. 
 Who would win? 

A) A caste of swordsman, with skills honed over hundreds of years
B) Gun. The Only interesting DLC clan in FOTS,

artillery spam is actually viable for this clan + gg I say, what what? So far the game is interesting and enjoying using 19 century weaponry. It plays at a slower pace. THERE ARE GLITCHES WHERE I'VE WON BATTLES AND HAD TO FIGHT THEM AGAIN. I read about glitches in reviews written when it first came out...seems they still haven't been fixed. I'll carry on playing but this is a disappointment and wastes precious time!

name: Ian's Eyes
short_description: First days at school are usually tough, but they can be even tougher if you‚Äôre helping a blind 8-year-old boy named Ian who doesn't know the terrifying dangers that lurk around in every hallway. You play as North, Ian‚Äôs lifelong canine companion. Can you help him escape alive?
reviews:
Great Idea, TERRIBLE execution. The only thing this game has going for it is the neat story of a blind kid needing to get around an apocalyptic school. But then the awful tank controls, spotty checkpoints, one-shot/inconsistent enemy aggro ranges and down right stupid dialogue tanks that concept and pile drives it straight into the ground. Just save your money and buy something else. Really bad voice acting. Really boring gameplay. Really cool idea, but bad, and i mean just awful execution. i feel bad. i REALLY wanted to like this game but it just ended up not working out. the death counter just makes it seem like its meant to be hard. i wouldnt know ill never finish it. again i wanted to like it but it just wasnt meant to be. The controls are really bad.. You can't move the camera angle and you walk with the arrows on the keyboard. The ''Use'' button is ''S''. On the steam controller you walk with the arrows and the ''Use'' button on the controller is the joystick that you have to move around until its interracting with the item. Well, this is certainly something different: a Unity-made stealth-horror game which ISN'T in first-person, and even dares to look a bit "spooky-cute"! Unfortunately, the dissimilarity to a lot of other (frequently sub-par) Unity product ends somewhere around there. Perhaps it's best we get a little rant out of the way before I proceed any further:

   WHY IN GOD'S GOOD NAME DO YOU EUROPEAN INDIE DEVELOPERS INSIST UPON DOING YOUR OWN VOICE ACTING WHEN YOU CAN'T EVEN SPEAK ENGLISH? AND WHY WOULD YOU WRITE DIALOGUE WITH WORDS LIKE "CENTENARY" BEING REPEATED OVER AND OVER AGAIN...WHEN YOU CAN'T EVEN PRONOUNCE THE WORD "CENTENARY" PROPERLY, FOR FUCK'S SAKE?!

   Okay, rant over. Apologies, but I did need to get that off my chest (which I've done a few times before, but one can only live in hope that someday someone might actually LISTEN)! When all is said and done, though, this would all be forgivable enough if we were talking about a stealth game where the stealth actually works. Regrettably, it doesn't. There's little consistency to how the A.I. will behave, meaning that learning from your mistakes still has about a 50/50 chance of biting you in the butt, and then it's aaaaaall the way back to a checkpoint five minutes prior to do it all over again (with varying results to the last time, no doubt).

   I couldn't help but be reminded of the legendary Bad Rats: fantastic premise (blind boy dodging zombie schoolkids with the aid of his guide dog), but the gameplay is so inconsistent and unpredictable that merely trying to repeat what worked for you the last time is a crap-shoot at best. The Resident Evil-style camera angles don't help much either: creeping around trying not to bump into uglies is no mean feat when one could be literally two inches in front of you, and you can't see or hear the fucker until you stumble headlong into them.

   I applaud the devs for the premise, I truly do. This had the potential to be the freshest horror game since Among the Sleep, but unfortunately the execution is severely lacking. This game might LOOK a bit like a three-dimensional Limbo, but trust me, it doesn't play like one. Limbo has an exemplary difficulty arc in which new mechanics are slowly introduced and extrapolated upon, whereas this game is insanely hard by about the thirty-minute mark.

   I dread to think what awaits beyond the hour-and-a-half I was willing to give it, because even slightly more challenging than what I've played so far is a little too close to "impossible" for my tastes. Unless, of course, you're one of those people who enjoys doing the same tediously pedantic bits over and over and over again, with absolutely no guarantee of success even when you plan things out to the nth degree. If so, you're in luck, 'cause someone made a game just for you.

   This really is one of the most heartbreaking reviews I've ever had to write, 'cause I sincerely had high hopes for this one. If ever a game cried out for a more competent remake, this'd be the one. The premise actually has "hit" written all over it, and it could no doubt appeal to a wide audience well beyond the established horror community. But the version we have here would need soooooo much work to make it even half of what it could be, so I sincerely question whether the devs should even bother. Restart from scratch, and give the new product to all the people who bought the first one for free; that'd be the best-case scenario in my book.

   Oh, and for fuck's sake: GET SOME VOICE ACTORS WHO SPEAK THE QUEEN'S LANGUAGE next time. There's this thing out there called the INTERNET, and not everyone on it speaks Pidgin English.

   Full marks to the devs for having the vision and determination to make this game, minus about 5.5/10 for the actual execution. Consider my heart partly broken, but my faith in human courage partially restored. Better luck/judgement next time.

Verdict: 4.5/10.

(PS If you enjoyed this review, feel free to check out my two Curator pages: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/9284586-ReviewsJustfortheHELLofit/
http://store.steampowered.com/curator/10868048-Truly-Horrible-Horror-Games/?appid=398210
Cheers!) good gameplay but bad ending Don't let the trailers fool you.  This game may seem like a fun game to play, but you will get frustrated over and over again.  There are some good qualities to the game but also bad ones, unfortunately.

[u]Pros:[/u]
The graphics certainly catches my attention.  It kind of looks like the stop-motion animation or a CGI that looks like from Jimmy Neutron (bad example, sorry).

Another positive is that they have full controller support.  That is always a plus.

Also, check points are nicely spread out.  If you progress enough to another screen, the game may save from there thus avoiding many frustrations.  This also may be a bad thing for those who want a challenge but then again, there are many challenges a plenty for this game.

[u]Cons:[/u]
Voice acting needs a lot of work.  The voice actor for the principle doesn't seem to be putting any effort in the situation.  He seems to be reading from a script.  The voice acting for Ian was alright but sometimes certain situations doesn't match his enthusiasm.

Another problem is controls.  I can't speak for keyboard/mouse since I didn't use it for this game.  "Freeze" barking and "attracting" barking should've been on separate buttons.  Double tapping for the freeze bark is brutal.  It is difficult to utilize each bark properly because you are constantly running around avoiding zombies while trying to go for the freeze bark.  Sometimes I end up attracting the zombies instead.  The developers should've separated these two barks in two different buttons.

Map design is a big problem with this game.  Most sections in the game don't scroll like a bigger map.  They just stay fixed, so you are just moving from screen to screen.  This becomes a big problem because when you are moving to the next screen, sometimes you automatically bump right into the zombie.  There is no way of knowing that the zombie was right in front of you.  Also, the map angle changes at times.  When you are running from zombies, I sometimes end up walking back to the previous map.  I even sometimes run right into a wall or zombie that I was trying to avoid.

[u]Overall:[/u]
This game was meant to be frustrating and you are meant to die a lot; however, I felt most of the frustration is "out-of-game" rather than "in-game".  I felt I was more frustrated with the controls and bad camera angles which allowed me to die so often compared to the zombie layout.  I would've enjoyed the challenge of strategically maneuvering around zombies with feint barks but again controller issues and map design ruins it for me.

If I were to recommend this game, it would be for those who love a challenge.  For casual gamers, they should avoid this game.

I still give this game a thumbs up despite the many frustrations.  Developers do put a lot of effort in making this game.  The concept was good.  Story was okay.  CGI is nicely done.  Decent length of game time.  I just wish that the controller and map design were done better. Ian's eyes is one of the worst games I have ever played. It‚Äôs complete bull crap, but let‚Äôs start with the story first.

You play as Ian, a young blind boy starting his first day at a new school; everything is going okay, till the Principal shows an old slideshow to the school, which makes them into zombie. So it‚Äôs up to Ian and his dog North to escape.

Now let‚Äôs start with the good first. I liked the music and the idea for the game is interesting too. Now for bad. The story does not make one bit of sense. 

Hell even when you hear how all most all the school became zombies it still does not make sense. Then there is the protagonist Ian, he is one of the most stupidest people. 
Like when he gets to the Principal‚Äôs office, the Principal tells him to get a key from the library, and Ian does that. Even those he is blind and there are zombies running around.

Or when Ian gets hurt and asks his dog to get something for the pain, again, he asks his dog to get something for the pain. Now for the enemies. They are unpredictable and unfair in annoying way, what I mean by that is that you must get past them to get to safety/get to the next area.

But they are so unpredictable and even those there are blind, if you get to close to them, even if you are behind them they can still get you. Then there is the art/graphics style. Now to me, I don‚Äôt really care about that as long as there is a good story with some good characters. 

Hell I think it show you don‚Äôt need the best art/graphics style to make awesome and beloved game. But this game it show it art/graphics even the animation still needed some work. Voice acting too.  And the worst thing about this game is it had an interesting idea but completely screwed it up.

So with all that being said don‚Äôt get this game, even those I got this on sale, I still feel like I got ripped off. This game is not exactly what you'd expect it to be from looking at the trailer. 

You play as a blind kid, which in itself is an interesting premise. However, the game throws in 'zombies' that you have to avoid. This could be awesome were it not for the fact that the controls are incredibly hard to handle and that there is no true method to avoid being detected. This makes this game very frustrating to play. The enemies are unpredictable and no amount of stealthiness can avoid them seeing you. I didn't last 20 minutes before I got too annoyed to continue.

I was lucky to have gotten this game at a discounted price because it definitely isn't worth the full price. I guess you should check it out if you want a good rage game and you have a way to get it at a lower price. If you are thinking on buying it, i advise you to DOWNLOAD the Demo first!
It looks like a neat and interesting game, but the mechanics are really bad.

Controlling two chars gets frustrating, considering you will get caught pretty easy.

Sorry Devs. I asked for my refund. It's shit and I'm disappointed.

The concept is cool but the bad voice acting, bad story, and game mechanics ruined it (seriously if they didn't use voice acting at all would be better somehow). The controls are awkward like when you play as a dog you can't bark and move quickly to dodge the enemy.

I could ignore the bad voice acting and the bad story, but man... the enemies.
The enemies are unpredictable in unfair annoying way, like you can't tell whos that enemy that stand still or the one that stand still also but will attack you without a warning when you get close to him and not avoidable. Or enemy that patrols and ignores you if you walk by him or the enemy that patrols and suddenly chases you once you're close to him which it is not aviodable after. And sometimes when you use the dogs to check them out they wouldn't chase it, but when you move fucking Ian they suddenly attack him then.

Oh yeah, not to mention the enemies that works as a wall but you can't tell because they look like the others who would attack you. Because they all use random models and not giving them any unique appearance.


They expected you to die alot that they even bothered to make death counter for it.

name: Wild Baffo
short_description: A humorous but challenging retro arcade point-and-shoot with a bizarre story set in the old Wild West. Take out wacky foes and eccentric bosses to become the best shooter in Baffoland.
reviews:
Shoot 'em knives. That's how you get past the pink WOKE, whatever that is. I can't help but be dissapointed because it took me 40 minutes to figure out. That and play this with anything othe than a mouse. Frankly if you play this with a gamepad, I fell sorry for you, and also for me at 5 minutes in the game. Now I am finally in the second level, after trying stupidly to hit the pink WOKE vs hitting the knives that pink WOKE was hurling. 

Deep breath. This is a really nice shooter that doesn't take itself too seriously. Like westerns? Play this. The cartoons are so stylish that look more to painted targets in a shooting range rather than actual humans. So if you don't wanna shoot at people, which is completerly understandable, think of them as paper targets. Having said that, the mechanics there, aka "hitting the knife also hurts the knife thrower, so you don't need to shoot at the knife thrower, just the knife" are very arcadey, so actually don't take this too seriously. Just shooty fun at painted cards in a shooting range.  Or outside a circus. No need to reload guns or reframe paper targets. Just fun, fun, fun. Especially when you get to shoot at the pink WOKE...  DON'T. JUST SHOOT AT THE KNIVES HE THROWS. REALLY. THIS KEPT ME IN THE FIRST LEVEL FOR 40 MINUTES. [h1]SUMMARY[/h1]
"Wild Baffo", more like "Wildly Baffled".

This railshooter is a western-themed shooting gallery. Enemies are designed to look like cartoonish cutouts, the environments are somewhat interactable, and the music levels are stereotypically on point. Where it fails is in the details, unfortunately. The gameplay has a few neat little features, such as shooting the knives of enemies and it goes right back at them, killing them, or shooting the bottles of alcohol thrown at you, stunning enemies in a radius where you shot it. Unfortunately that's about as involved as it gets. There's no reload mechanic, there's no alternate weapons, the levels are short and end up recycling themselves when you get to the bosses...

Which, speaking of the bosses, that is my biggest peeve with the game. It's not enough that they move and shoot faster and faster as you damage them, but their healthbar is fucking huge. So much so, my finger actually began to get fatigued from how much I was clicking on him. Sorry, but I'm not straining myself to beat a "Wild Baffo" boss.

On top of this, the premise of the story is eye-rollingly stupid. You're in search of a moustache to be a real gunslinger...Wow...Lock this game up and throw away the key, please.

[h1]OVERALL SCORE[/h1]
Not Recommended

[h1]REPLAY VALUE[/h1]
Below Average quintessential game for anyone that thinks facial hair is a personality This is the worlds best game. So much good life advice too. For example, if I knew the best way to get a cooler gun is to shoot a weird hat guy 10 times, I would have finished that time travel machine by now and beat John Wilkes Booth to the punch. This is a fun little point n shoot target practise kinda game with great music, nice art, and a fun story

name: Prime Arena
genres: Action, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Early Access
short_description: Prime Arena is a combination of MOBA and survival gameplay inspired by PUBG. This dynamic deathmatch arena is free of forced socialization and thus of toxic atmosphere found in MOBAs. Victory fully depends on players skill and reaction speed no teammates, no cry!
reviews:
awful I've tried to get into a game many times only to recieve a "connection error" message having to restart the game and the queing process. The one time I did howver manage to make it into a game the server was completely populated by Ai aside from myself.. and needless to say the lack of a in-game tutorial really came into play as I died to the very first NPC camp of mobs I had found. Cool concept, horrible game. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Us2pGxaWDYQ
[h1]Nival Cashgrab[/h1]
Firstly, all of the heroes, terrain, assets are taken from their previous game Prime World and they didn't bother adding any new assets, even the fonts are the same. This should've been a game mode in prime world instead of its own standalone game. While the concept of Survival MOBA is rather neat, everything else is lacking - bad ping, boring & unbalanced characters, Sounds/Music are subpar, Graphics are outdated (Prime World came back in 2014)

There is not even proper menu or tutorial for the game. I ended up just getting qued with bots too, nobody is playing the game and i don't see why anyone would if it was Free To Play. Save your precious money by dodging the bullet with this one. I really enjoy this game, but it is a very niche product. If you enjoy the character variation of MOBAs (lots of characters with different passive/active abilities, ultimates, gaining items, etc) and you also like survival games with permadeath (first death = you're out of the match), then you'll enjoy this and it's at least worth the price of entry to check it out.

I am looking forward to future development of the game and seeing the population grow more. But definitely check this one out if you like MOBAs and survival / Battle Royale type games. Good game, but the lag is insane. Absolute dogshit

name: Moonscars
short_description: Push the limits of your combat skills, and master new abilities to progress through an unforgiving nonlinear 2D world. Face off against the relentless darkness that seeks to destroy you. In Moonscars, every death is a lesson learnt‚Äîand as you overcome each challenge, new truths will be revealed.
reviews:
[h1]Fun metroidvania title[/h1]
Very good world settings and character design but the story narration [strike]is bad[/strike] can be improved. (I skipped the dialogues and searched youtube for "Moonscars STORY EXPLAINED" ü§£)

Very good design on the Ichor mechanic (attack >> restore mp >> cast heal), it is nicely implemented and this is the key component that convinced me to buy and play the game.

[h3]Some Rants[/h3]
In case dev is going to make a sequel:
- I manage to complete 100% achievements but could be easier if the game let me choose which slot to save game
- Superdash is kinda weird, please make it simpler
- Enemy corpse should not stop Superdash (seems like a bug or oversight)
- Also, even living enemy should not stop Superdash
- The weapons for Special Attack should not be random, preferably craft-able or collect-able
- Weapon Rite is very jebaiting, lol (I wasted many Glands early on)
- For Clay Rite, can be reworked for improvement (so far, I only choose +% Gland drop)
- The spells are fine BUT need rework and better design for sequel
- From my experience, I just need 1 more spell slot: 
>> Burst for opening doors (kept at Lv1 for low cost)
>> Chain Boulder 3 to deal with flying enemy
>> Extra spell slot for situation / preferred playstyle, i.e. Stone PIllar or Doppleganger
- Also, need to pause and swap for different spell is not good and breaking immersion (suggest to make all spells usable via pressing Spell key + arrow key; give player the freedom to choose which node on the techtree to modify the spell effects, etc)
- Spite bonuses would be perfect if I can reroll indefinitely, without dying. (i.e. upon maxed, Dark Mirror has the option to choose 1 Spite Bonus to discard it) Monotonous visuals, contrived story convoluted just for the sake of being "mysterious", sloppy and floaty combat that ends up in life-shortening hit trades as well as spams from flying enemies, since your attacks don't even stun foes. It feels like the parry doesn't even work half the time with the short timing window and issues fighting enemies occupying the exact same space as you. Just frustrating. I enjoyed this game a lot and even got all of its achievements. To me this was a 9/10 game, especially since it is an indie title from a very small developer. In fact I was surprised how well executed the overall game design was, many larger studios fail in delivering a similar high quality in comparison. Given the small number of people that worked on the title and probably the limited budget there is hardly anything I can criticize about the game.

(+) There are no annoying game play elements. No fall down damage (except if you fall in spikes etc.), save points are near boss encounters, no stupid character-being-stunned effects, no annoying enemies that can shoot you while you can't shoot back etc.
(+) The controls work flawlessly. I did not encounter any bugs and I intuitively understood the controls.
(+) Combat works flawlessly as well and is challenging. There are even some optional upgrades and spells that allow some experimenting on a preferred combat style.
(+) For a soulslike, it has a good story and artistic direction. As one would expect, the story is hard to follow and doesn't even make sense but that is part of the discovery process/art style of these kind of games. I enjoyed it, especially since it focuses on explaining the minimal necessary, without wasting your time with nonsense storytelling. The same is true for the artistic direction: The game is mostly black and grey with some red and yellow here and there. For a short soulslike that is not only sufficient but atmospheric. I didn't feel that more biome were needed, especially since there were different areas, like a forest, castle, underground and castle pathway.
(+) Very fair price. Depending on how skilled one is with these kind of soulsvania games, one should have between 15-25 hours of fun.
(+) There are optional quests and upgrades in the game.
(+) Soundtrack and audio is really good and fits the game/genre well.
(+) The game overall has a good length. Being longer wouldn't make the game better, since it is an indie title with limited gameplay elements. And for these elements, there are no unnecessary parts in this game which would just stretch the content into more hours of playtime.

The only improvements that I could think of:

(-) No dubbing of dialogue. But that is ok, there is not much dialogue anyway.
(-) The last two bosses very significantly harder than all bosses before them. Only a minor annoyance and I could still learn the bosses, it just took longer than what I was used to from the earlier parts of the game.

This game is an example on how games with a limited budget should be made. The focus was on gameplay and art direction that fits well into a reasonable game length and no experimenting in areas where you would need a larger team to deliver an excellent experience. I can only recommend to people who enjoy this soulsvania genre. A relatively short but highly enjoyable 2D metroidvania experience! Whilst not a particularly challenging game, mastering dodge and parry timings really does allow one to play incredibly aggressively, which is something I have always relished in doing (tehe Bloodborne influence). 

In a similar vein, I also enjoyed experiencing the game's intentionally cryptic story. The themes of identity, purpose and what it means to be human shine through the strongest via a multitude of characters ‚Äî each offering their own take on the matter. This was only reinforced when I played through the game for a second time to get 100% achievements, armed with the knowledge granted by the final 1/3 of the game.

This is further complemented by Moonscars' excellent soundtrack, with the stage tracks in particular oozing atmosphere and mood that emphasise the core theming of the overall game. Would highly recommend!

 My eyes are really pleased by this art style, the way animations smoothly blend into each other feels uniquely natural to me
The combat & weapons are fun, looking forward to find more since I haven't finished the game yet
Story is pretty fine until now
Would definitely recommend this one for those who love diving into 2D immersive worlds
 77/100

Art design and  'in-game animations' are so good, with stunning scenery and atmosphere. It's a solid Metroidvania game, though it certainly doesn't qualify as a souls-like.

Could have been much more impressive if they invested more care into the story presentation. Writing and storytelling are mediocre at best. Following the narrative is challenging, and it rarely manages to captivate your interest. While there are a few bright spots in, they either lead nowhere or get abandoned too quickly.

Combat mechanics remain stagnant throughout the game, leaving you with no real sense of progression. You can purchase and use two active skills from a skill tree, but this doesn't add meaningful variety to gameplay. Most skills in the tree feel pointless and lack the appeal needed to encourage players to experiment with different builds.
Map design is inconsistent - brilliantly crafted in some areas while tediously repetitive in others, with some unnecessary sequences clearly added just to pad the game length. Boss encounters are disappointingly few, with only the final two bosses showing truly impressive design while the rest feel generic. Soundtracks are good but unremarkable.

I can only recommend this game to dedicated metroidvania fans who have already played through the genre's standout titles. If you haven't yet experienced games like Hollow Knight or The Messenger and are considering this one, I'd strongly suggest trying those superior titles first. This project was created out of love for the soulslike genre. Short 2D game immediately captivated me with its dark and atmospheric style.  Moonscars utilizes a minimal color palette. A muted range of dark grays accented by red, creating a unique charm. The game's artist drew inspiration from the oil paintings of Old Dutch Masters like Rembrandt.  Each frame of animation was hand-drawn, resulting in highly detailed pixel art.

The protagonist, whom we play as, is Grey Irma. She is a knight of a special order. The game has good combat with an emphasis on parrying. There is standard attack, strong attack, special attack, skill, a dodge roll (dash), amulets, and various buffs. The healing system is quite unique: dealing damage to enemies fills a mana bar, which can then be used for spells or healing. This makes the gameplay dynamic and encourages an aggressive playstyle. Instead of bonfires, there are mirrors; instead of souls, there's bone dust. There are not many bosses, but each one is unique and interesting. Almost everyone has a second phase. Frequent deaths will trigger a Blood Moon, increasing enemy damage ‚Äì a hardcore modifier of sorts. But it can be dispelled using hearts scattered throughout the levels.

Moonscars is about a Lost Soul searching for its creator and the meaning of its own existence in this world. Each death serves as a lesson. We break and rise again, putting ourselves back together piece by piece. It's a story of betrayal, suffering, and revenge; a journey of trials and tribulations to become a great warrior. As Osho said, "To rise, you must fall; to gain, you must lose."

I had fun fighting under the moonlight accompanied by atmospheric music. 
It's a shame the project lacked a bit of time and funding.  
I'd give it an 8/10.
 What a special game. I feel lucky to have found Moonscars. It seems not to resonate with everyone, but something about it really sings to me.

To put everything I love about this game into one idea, Moonscars has [i]vision[/i]. 

To be more thorough... the art style and animation are like nothing else I've seen: liquid pixels, like living paint on an ancient screen. The combat is fun, fast, and variable. If you like parrying, this game is a must-play on the strength of its parry alone. The story is beautifully told, full of bold world-building, confident philosophy, deep currents of character-driven love, betrayal, and conflict. The translation can be a little wonky and confusing, but even that works in Moonscars' favor, I think, because it fits alongside the impressionistic visuals and haunting music to present a cohesive, rare experience.

I love this game. I played it through PlayStation's subscription service some years ago, and I'm delighted to have purchased it for Steam Deck. It really should be verified, it runs great and has full controller support. (The default controller layout is really weird though, and I recommend remapping the buttons to your own preference. I basically made it as close as possible to Hollow Knight.)

If you are willing to take this game very seriously ‚Äî to learn its combat, scour its map, and listen closely to its characters ‚Äî you too might find yourself in love with Black Mermaid's strange and moving game. I will be thinking about Grey Irma and her companions for a long, long time. It is a good game. I liked the story and Biblical annotations. At the same time, the game is quite imbalanced closer to the finale. The bosses are much more difficult. If you die and lose your bonuses you gained beating clay dudes, you'll be screwed. To research map was nice. But I think the backstory and more lore is required for each of them. Like in Salt & Sanctuary as an example. Anyways, even though did not like it more than Ender Lillies, I think this project is worth playing as it resembles that one. Moonscars is a hidden gem if I ever found one. Fairly short, but really enjoyable experience. I probably didn't have so much fun with a metroidvania since playing The Last Faith, which was like 5 months ago (I think). Although as mentioned before, this game is much shorter than The Last Faith, or other metroidvania goats like Hollow Knight, Blasphemous or Nine Sols. I would give it solid 9/10

Now if you want more specific information, almost every aspect of this game is really well done
Visuals are probably the best, although I heard some people say it's too bland due to being mostly black and white. I personally found it beautiful, and oddly enchanting that the only colors present are shades of grey, black and white, and red.
Combat in this game is also great, especially bossfights for which they clearly went with quality over quantity. Every single boss was really enjoyable, despite the final boss being kinda underwhelming (which is a running theme in most metroidvanias and soulslikes as I noticed)
Exploration is also great, with every area being filled with breakable walls and other secrets. Also, finding items feels rewarding, and the game never drops junk loot at you
NPCs are pretty well written, and many of them have grown on me, especially the cat
Achievements require almost no grind there is only one collectible achievement (which can be done in like 2 hours if you know what are you looking for), one relatively complicated questline, and either 2 playthroughs or a backup save. I can't say whether it's good or bad, but I like my 100%s being less grindy so I like it
Really only aspect where this game falls a bit behind is the music, which while fitting the atmosphere isn't something I'd listen to outside the game (bear in mind that I listen to video game OSTs on daily basis). Still, I could see myself listening to it while doing something relaxing, or maybe on a foggy night walk

name: Cyberside Picnic
short_description: Cyberside Picnic is a eulogy for the cyberian commonplace that just eluded us. A love letter to a lost future of alternative video games, delete and overwrite.
reviews: I liked it, for I enjoy artsy things. However, I am a dimwit and am unable to grasp the full message. Game was cool tho. It's a collection of intentionally bad text games and mini-games meant to tell some kind of surreal mini-story.  There isn't much interesting to do here unless you happen to be a chimpanzee (literally).  The bird game has kind of a neat aesthetic but even in the 80s it would have been rejected.  If you feel like getting another perspective on computer games (like I did) try it out, but otherwise it's not something for most people. The idea for the game is good. Returns to childhood. This game will appeal more to the adult generation than to children. a strange genre. A lot of text. For fans of xassic text quests . I didn't play much because I didn't quite figure it out and I found it boring. A simple game about the fact that you solve games one after another to find out the hidden truth A lot of different puzzles, I had an interesting time solving various kinds of problems atmospheric Great game to play in the evening. Atmospheric, just what I like The game is so simple that it amazes with its unusualness. Good game to spent a couple hours to chill

name: Saints Row - A Song of Ice and Dust
short_description: When a crippling ambush decimates the Dustlanders, it‚Äôs up to fierce rivals Bossonius and Gwendolyn Firebird to join forces and defend The DustFaire from the Frostlanders, paintball by paintball.
reviews:
DLC After the events of the Dustmoot and the crowning of King/Queen Bossonius of all the Dustlands, the forces of House Sandy Kraken and House Phoenix are both devastated. In an effort to rebuild strength, the leaders of both Houses must join in LARPing matrimony... But that is quickly threatened as a new threat to all Houses and the DustFaire emerges. The Frostlanders.

A Song of Ice and Dust is Saints Row's third expansion and continues the storyline of one of my favorite parts of the base game, the Dustmoot arc in five new missions set in the Vallejo district of Santo Ileso as well as three new weapons, an assortment of vehicles, cosmetics, a new skill, HQ collectables and more.

Available after finishing the entire Dustmoot arc with "Unto the Breach" A Song of Ice and Dust features a well structured and decently lengthy story compared to other DLCs in the Saints Row series, packing it with more fun jokes about LARPs, RPGs and even a dig or two at MMO quest structure and the stereotypical fetch quests within.

Outside of the story however, A Song of Ice and Dust doesn't add anything new to do in the Vallejo district or out in Santo Ileso itself unlike Heist and the Hazardous with the Kaijuice Wingsuit events which does wear down any kind of replayability the content this DLC offers aside from making a new save game.

However as you complete each story mission within A Song of Ice and Dust, you'll be drip fed a multitude of rewards. Looking for some new toys to bring pain to the field of LARP? Try the new Frostlander Axe melee and Frostlander SMG, a fully automatic addition to the Dustlander weapon collection. Want to completely smite your enemies and feel like the LARPing version of Thor? Wield the new Special weapon, the Ban Hammer. Weather you beat enemies with it or throw it and watch it bounce off multiple enemies, this devastating tool gains charge to unleash a shockwave slam attack that deals incredible damage. 

Take to the skies in the new Galitrax helicopter, a Thompson that comes with an assortment of parts to make it look like a dragon. However i'm a little sad that it doesn't come armed with some form of rocket/fireball launcher from the mouth of it. Or if you prefer to keep to the roads, there's the Frost Chariot, an entirely unique model of Palanquin golf-cart that can't be altered to the civilian model. Looking for an armed response? The Frosty Grandad and Sandy Grandad are available, both are variants of the Grandad from the base game that can be stripped down to their civilian appearances, but it won't get rid of the paintball gun turrets mounted on the backs of both the Frosty and Sandy.

Where the store page says that four LARP skills are added, three are given to you to while running the story which are all skills from the base game. The only actual addition is the Frostnade which acts as a new throwable that both damages and slows enemies impacted by the grenade.

On top of all of that are a selection of new customisation options for both the Boss as well as Neenah, Eli and Kev.

If you enjoyed the entire Dustmoot arc with Eli in the base game, you'll get an absolute kick out of this DLC. If you didn't, then you can skip this. But personally? I think this is Saints Row's best DLC and i couldn't recommend it any higher. Alright Who Let Out The D&D Theater Kids Run The Streets For Today? Honestly was quite enjoyable with some quite fun easter eggs here and there. Was one of the first times I started noticing all the easter eggs and references hidden around [spoiler]ELIIIIIII JEEENNNNKKINNNSSS.[/spoiler] Was honestly quite impressed it seemed [i]so[/i] well done despite, I believe, being the last DLC they released followed by shortly after receiving the Axe from Embracer Group. 

Also, brings back in a character that [i]definitely[/i] deserved more screen time in the main story line; [strike]DommyMommy[/strike] I mean Gwen.

Obviously the Larping isn't everyone's cup of tea but, as a nerd, found it quite enjoyable and was very pleased with this addition to the story. Made the Larp in the main story not feel so... Random and out of place.

Rip Volition, didn't deserve to get the Embracer Group curse.
I'll forever miss y'all and will forever enjoy seeing all of y'alls pets included in Radar's Den :luv: This game has already ruined my life, so I'll just eat a spoonful of cinnamon for every like this review gets
 Best DLC in the game. Honestly, I think the story, as short as it was, is better than the main game. Only real complaint I have with it is I wish there was more of it. This DLC is by FAR the best one. You not only get a tonne of unlock-ables including a new weapon, clothing items and a vehicle. The story is extremely fun, as are the missions that pair with it.

If you didn't enjoy the LARP missions in the base-game, you're going to hate this; however if you enjoyed them this takes the gameplay of those missions and improves in every area.

For example, in the LARP missions you couldn't use perks but in this you'll gradually learn 4 of them. Granted, only one of these perks are new and the others are ones from the base game; but they all work perfectly within the rules.

You will also eventually unlock an outfit that looks good! So you can completely ditch the, albeit humorous, cardboard box outfit and use the unlock-able one in it's place; if you're the kinda person who dresses up in LARP gear.

I didn't count how many missions there were, because I was just enjoying the DLC. However I believe there are 5 or 6 missions, each of them are extremely fun and filled to the brim with the LARP-y cringe we've all enjoyed. 

I would HIGHLY recommend this DLC to anyone who enjoyed the LARP stuff in the main game. The price is outstanding for everything you unlock, and the story is a blast. This must be the BEST dlc for Saints Row. It has a lots of interesting cars and storys. This DLC Adds
5 New Campaign Missions
A Ban Hammer LOL
A New AXE And SMG
A NEW HELICOPTER!!!!?!
3 NEW CARS!?!?!
4 NEW SKILLLLZZZ!!!!!?
5 NEW OUTFITS
AND 17 OTHER COSMETICS!?!?!

FOR ONLY $7.99!?!!?
For all the content id say its a decent deal Best of all the DLCs for this game in my opinion

name: World Racing '95
short_description: Race like it's 1995! Classic arcade racing action with split-screen support, a single player story mode packed with 30 tough missions and a cross-country highway with branching routes makes this one of the meanest racers around.
reviews:
-Weird hover car on ice driving/sliding feel that eventually becomes boring, slow, uneventful gameplay once you get used to it.
-Car sometimes 360 spins in place when hitting other cars.
-No options whatsoever, no way to change controls. Only manual gears. No Pause button.
-Lengthy fade in/out between menu screens. 
-Speedometer/Gears display on left side instead of right like in every other racing game. 
-Unknown save file location in case you want to save unlocks and progress for future use or between PCs.
-Pointless annoying tune plays after every checkpoint which makes it sound like there's music fading in and out constantly. 
-Linear career mode were you'll get stuck on the dumb and annoying mini-games such as the road being invisible or hitting enough snowmen before time runs out instead of actual racing. Reminds me a lot of Hot Wheels: Stunt Track Challenge for the GBA which is one of my favorite styles for racers lol so if you like that game you will ADORE this game! Visually, WR95 is somewhat similar to Virtua Racing Deluxe on 32X. I wouldn't say it plays anywhere near as well as that game, but the driving mechanics are still decent. Collision penalties are the biggest issue right now, but the developer has promised to improve that aspect of the game in a later update. All-in-all, it's a nice little throwback arcade racer with a very palatable price tag.

Update: Collision penalties have been reduced. No more spinning out upon any contact whatsoever. A game where you can't find where the controls are, except you try all keys of your keyboard but then the race is over cause it's time restricted.
Very frustrating and completely lame the dev hasn't included the control layout or keys so you can play without being so frustrating the first second.
Also the drive controls are something very anoying cause when you hit an opponent your car spins around so you lose a lot of time.
The graphics are ok for a '95 game (almost as good as the first Nascar Racing game from 1994, no wait almost as good as stunt driver from 1990.

So it's a big NO for me, sorry ! Fun so far. Love the aesthetic! Though I wish this game had achievements... Also, the generic wreck physics are... frustrating. I agree with the other guy, this game is really good for the price. A great game for its small price !

name: Valzar
short_description: Explore an uncharted land and recover the pieces of a broken amulet. Valzar is a tough arena action platformer with roguelike elements.
reviews:
This game has mostly solid stylized art, intereting ideas and a solid concept, but the game almost completely misses the mark.  It's not terrible, but I believe that at 10 dollars it is a waste of money.  Wait for a sale or something.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LdBfAytZSzc

This game is a combination of action platforming and roguelite.  Being a fan of roguelites I was excited to get my hands on this game, as the art style looked really cool, but it falls short in so many areas that make it hard to recommend.

First, platforming is paramount in this game.  That's perfectly fine, as I loved Risk of Rain and platforming is very important there, too.  However, Valzar's controls are sluggish at best.  You feel as though you're walking in molasses which makes traversing through the environment an absolute chore.  The worst part is that you have to trek your butt back to the exit door at the end of each room, and when you find yourself at the bottom of a pit having killed the last enemy, you curse the fact that you have to painstakingly climb your way up with the slow and clumsy movement.

Second, the combat, while initially fine, quickly devolves into chaos with unavoidable damage.  You move in molasses while your enemies fly toward you.  I've had enemies get knocked up then track me perfectly as they fall.  I've had enemies shoot endless strings of homing bullets that move faster than me.  I've been hit by so many things that I couldn't really understand than I could count.  Combat in these games is supposed to be fun, but in Valzar it is a chore.  A barrier in your way that you have to chip at for 2 billion years through many lives.  It could drive a man mad.

Third, the game seems indecisive on what it feels like it needs to explain, mechanics-wise.  For the most part it's okay, but there's moments when you have to make a choice to keep your spells as they are or or replace it with something else.  You can test it out there, but sometimes the text is ridiculously vague, leaving you to make a blind choice.  You can always go back to the room, but that wastes valuable resources and time, forcing you to enter each room (rooms are moved to from a world map in a adjacent tile kind of system) even if you've already cleared it.

Finally, on the nitpicky side, the UI and control scheme is just awkward.  The START button on the controller is unmapped, but Left Bumper opens the inventory.  What?!

Valzar's ideas are there, but the execution falls way short in the most important categories.  Unless there's massive patches to combat unavoidable damage or make platforming less infuriating, this game will be little more than frustrating. It's like developer's just assume proc gen makes a fun game.  This is nothing like Rogue Legacy as a few people claim it seems like.  Rogue Legacy was fun to bash monsters in.   This, is a complete mess.  Controls when attacking monsters are a mess.  You will get hit most of the time attacking anything because your just a small group of pixels running into another group of pixels with a pathetic weapon.  The spells really don't explain what they do.  There are barely any gear drops early on from what I saw.  The appearance of the game coupled with the simplistic gameplay is NOT worth 10 bucks imo.  The whole game just screams simplicity.  The dev probably thought, "I'll throw procedural generation and the term roguelike on there and people will buy it."  He was right. Really nice background art but the characters are really simple and lacking.  Really they look like the most basic pixel art you can imagine.  Animations are ok.  The platforming controls are ok for the most part but it's hard to control your jump height.  The level design isn't very thought out.  Obviously its randomly generated so that may be part of the problem.  It's also very frustrating when you die from an unavoidable hit and then you have to start ALLLLL over. This game is really good. Scratches that "Risk of Rain" itch really well. The spells, classes, auras, companions and weapons are all swapable and change the play style. The difficulty cure is spot on.  The mood and setting are also really compelling. It's hard to recommend a game like this after playing Rogue Legacy.  Both games are sidescrolling roguelikes but this one seems to be much more centered around upgrades and loot while the gameplay and controls are really lacking.  I really like the art style and I'm having fun but the game just isn't grabbing me the way games like Nuclear THrone and Binding of Isaaac do.

name: Xheres
short_description: Either FPS or TPS, choose your play style and survive the apocalypse on your own or with your friends. But one must know for sure it ain't gonna be easy, there are hordes waiting for you. Not even considering tough ones... Nevertheless it's gonna be fun.
reviews:
The idea here is quite promising, but I cannot recommend this at this time.

The gun play isn't horrible, but it needs improvement. The inventory system is buggy and not intuitive or easy to use. I got about 40 minutes into a mission to only fall through the world. The movement seems sluggish and clunky at times. I would consider calling this game very, very early alpha. It has quite a bit of potential but the updates are very lack lustre, it would almost seem abandoned but I cannot tell whether or not it actually is. For the time being I would leave this one out of your library. I recommend it to all gamers, firstly it can be felt you hard. but as you get used to very enjoyable to play.

name: Lethal League Blaze - Galileo the Funky Saxman outfit for Candyman
short_description: Galileo the Funky Saxman outfit for Candyman
reviews:
team reptile was so real for this i love making beautiful jazz from a corpse juggle 10/10 skin It doot when you ball FUNKY AS HELL! tururu it gud The doot is all I need in life doots when you hit the ball
10/10 It doots when you hit the ball best dlc skin it doots

name: Chorus Original Soundtrack
short_description: The award-winning Chorus soundtrack. Immerse yourself into an epic, atmospheric, emotional journey.
reviews:
Overall: 8/10

This is a pretty cool soundtrack overall. It‚Äôs 26 tracks, clocking in at around 44 minutes, and the quality is consistently high across the board. There‚Äôs a nice variety here too: some softer, ambient tracks that lean peaceful and atmospheric, and others that are full-blown, high-octane combat instrumentals. Each song sounds impressive and cinematic.
That said, while it's [i]good[/i], that cinematic nature is a bit of a double-edged sword. On one hand, it makes the music feel epic and polished. On the other hand, it‚Äôs not exactly the kind of music most people would throw on in the background while browsing the steam store or just hanging out. It feels like it‚Äôs always building to or accompanying something big, which is awesome in-game, but less versatile, and slightly off-putting at times, outside of it.
So do I recommend this soundtrack? Yes, but probably not at the full $8 price. It goes on sale [i]all the time[/i] for under $2, and at THAT price, it's definitely worth picking up. Even if it doesn‚Äôt become your most-played OST, the quality alone justifies making it an addition to your collection. My opinion on the soundtrack: its good, and captures the idea of the game. The game's just not my type. Pedro Is an actual chad. He did the Star Citizen soundtrack too.

name: True Abstraction: Rewind
short_description: Solve puzzles in a secret, Lunar facility, while trying to not get killed by whatever nightmare still roams the chambers.
reviews: Random jump scare made me refund this. Arbitrary unavoidable jump scares are the lowest form of horror and you don't get my money. Haven't finished it yet, but it seems pretty good so far. It gives some Portal vibes, but still is unique and has some interesting concepts. Overall, in my opinion it's completely worth the price.

name: Star Crafter
genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Simulation, Early Access
short_description: A space survival crafting mining base building and star system building game. Craft rockets to create planets and Dyson Rings, mine and craft advanced materials, terraform the terrain, manage electricity, farm food, and more as you watch the star system evolve into stunning, ever-changing views.
reviews:
To much grind no play. I've played 3 games of this same developer and there's still no change to the UI, progression system and tech tree. I respect this guy's consistency of using the same mediocre tech tree all the time. This makes the player feel like the dev is neglecting the playerbase and only sees them as dumbass money makers. I didn't look at the developer before buying, so my first reaction when I opened the game was "Oh not again.". This taught me a lesson, which I need to take a look at who developed the game and if it's tbjbu2 stay away from that game. I'm not trying to undermine the dev, but he needs to give much more effort to the games he's making. 

To summerize, I don't recommend this game or any other game of this developer until he gives decent effort on his games. Have a nice day.

Edit: I refunded this game successfully. I LOVE this game. I play games to have fun. I am not an engineer. I own Dyson, Satisfactory and Stationeers, and find this game a refreshing change. I love the simplicity of the user interface, the bright colours, the feeling of accomplishment as I create Dyson rings, and now a moon. I can fly to the moon on my spaceship (which I also created), and harvest resources from the moon. I see that planets will also be created. Eventually I will also have a whole solar system. I am tired of games where stamina is always depleted, thirst kills you, etc. etc. In this game there is no stamina or thirst, just hunger. Also the setup allows you to change the rates of hunger, resource gathering, etc. So far I haven't learned how to create a base, I hope that will be possible. I learned pillars but don't know what to do with them. I see that there are farm plots in the tech tree so I will be able to grow my own food in the future. I would like to see two things that I have not seen yet in the game. The first is an easy way to build neat sloping paths into the underground. As the game is voxel based, I can mine, lower the levels of terrain, raise the level of terrain, and flatten the terrain. However, I haven't yet been able to make a neat sloping pathway. The second thing is that I like to build a base to store my equipment. I don't want my machinery sitting on the grass. I hope this will be possible. Overall however, I really think this game is wonderful for someone like me who loves the idea of reasonably easy survival (although you can crank up the difficulty), no stamina issues, a voxel based system, the ability to create a whole solar system in time, etc. etc. Sorry, but it's a trash knock-off of Dyson Sphere Program... No actual longevity play-ability. i feel i got my monies worth Ladies and Gentlemen. Welcome to Karagon 4.0, you can just look in the files and the .exe is called Karagon. This "indie developer" claims people like me are the reason indie games are dying, when in fact he's the reason indie games are dying. Just flooding Steam with asset flips to make a quick buck....er I mean not this "developer" he doesn't need your pathetic amount of money since he's now rich with crypto. Probably all thanks to Trump as well. 

Now yes, I did only play this game for 1 minute. Steam says 0.1 hrs, but that's being generous. In reality, I only need 1 minute to realize that this is just Karagon, er I mean Grand Emprise, er I mean World Crafter TD. er I mean Star Crafter. The exact same assets, exact same layout, exact same slop.

Now, you're probably wondering why I decided to spend $30 of my cold hard cash and give it to some twat like this "developer". Well it's because I wanted to go out of my way and give this game a negative review because why not. It's an asset flip, it doesn't deserve a single ounce of praise. Now im not saying indie developers unlike this guy is allowed to use assets from the marketplace to make their game. You can but to use the exact same ones for the fifth game in a year in a row? Really shows the kind of circus this "developer" is living in.

Now, I know this guy is gonna leave a comment and be all aggresive and say some mean shit. Oh shimber me timbers. But truth be told, no one loves you, it's a fact. And for the people who fallen for this crap and will "harass" me. Save your soul not for me, or if you even got one that is. I know the "developer" doesn't.

Well anyway, enjoy your slop, enjoy your depressing life. There's lots of evidence of each game being abandoned for two reasons. 

1. Game is 100% complete (Which it really isn't)
2. No one wants to play this game anymore because it's crap. It is seriously flawed, I remapped  movement keys to the arrow keys and the work in the opposite direction, graphics are horrible in full screen, this is more a demo (and a bad one at that) than a full release. Great game. Has major potential. It's like a simplified dyson sphere. Lots of fun, hope they add co-op keep developing Good game For being in early access, the game plays well. There are many QoL things that are missing that would normally be expected from this type of game. I do have concerns with the asset similarity to other games released in rapid succession, but I will wait to see if the dev listens to the community with their next update. Hopeful, as the game has potential.

name: Monster Hunter World: Iceborne - MHW:I Monster Figure: Girros & Great Girros
short_description: A monster figure you can use to decorate your room. Decorate your room to your heart's content!
reviews: crocodile but snake Without reason is Monster Hunter

name: Never Forget Me
short_description: Love stories don't end with marriage...can you reach your happily ever after? Sequel of the popular Always Remember Me, in this dating sim you play the married couple life. Can you stay together until the end?
reviews:
i really like this game, it's defininetly worth buying if it's on sale.
Amy is really relatable, her relationship with Hugh is my favorite one
all the routes are fun to play and discover the different endings (one ending in particular... i was shook lol)
i highly recommend playing the first game before playing this one
unfortunately the achievements are not really syncing with Steam and this is the only thing annoying me about this game :'( This game is about couples that shouldn't have married.

Everyone is trash people in Hugh's route (including MC and Hugh) and his plotline makes me wanna puke.
Everyone is painfully insecure and incapable of communicating in Aaron route.
Eddy's plotline just makes me angry.
Lawrence deserved better. Better plotline, better parents and better wife. Also, Eddy is such a prick in this route.

And why literally every woman except MC is an enemy? Even MC's friends portrayed as villains - they want you to get divorce after all. And Bechdel test? Don't know her. It's kind of...misogynistic? 

Honestly, I just feel dirty and exhausted after reading this vn. If you played the first game and enjoyed it, I would generally recommend skipping playing this one. Instead turning to your own imagination or the fan fictions out there if you want to see more these characters and their stories. You will probably be happier that way. 

The first game left a lot of things left up in the air with the writing, but the sequel does so more. You are forced to make many decisions on things you MIGHT have saw or read about in game but most likely haven't. Like many other games where players get to make decisions with a voiceless MC, it can be difficult to make the decision you meant to. Since we regularly don't know the tone the FMC will take until we commit. 

Gameplay isn't about blind faith, trust, and putting other characters first all the time, this isn't a criticism just a statement. Probably a good sprinkle of reality for the players of this game who are newer to such relationships. Much of it is about the FMC speaking about her own needs, which seems to be a valuable lesson for a lot people. People who tend to switch into people pleaser mode with the people they care about. Relationships are a two way street.  

Overall, I found this sequel pretty cynical and depressing for a sequel to an otome game...Despite what it may or may not teach the players about. When playing this game, you should assume that if you, as the player, don't have the FMC talk about certain issues in the moment that they are not discussed in unseen moments when it may be more appropriate and productive to have those conversations. Which is something I don't particularly love about many VNs, the whole not having a proper discussion at a better time thing (as it is rather unrealistic storytelling wise), not important things happening behind the scenes thing. }}

The new game mechanic takes some getting used to. But it is fine. I preferred the game mechanic from the first game. While it does feel like there is more writing in this game than there was in the first, other areas were a bit of a let down. Unless you play in VN mode, you spend about half of the game looking at a boring screen rather than art. TLDR; I do NOT recommend. In every story either the MC is terrible and/or the guy is terrible. Lawrence's story is the only one that didn't leave a terrible taste in my mouth. So if you absolutely must play one just choose Lawrence and skip the rest, thank me later.
Maybe the stories were meant to be more realistic but if that's real I want NO part of it.
Think assault, possible roofies, infidelity. And that's just one story! 
[spoiler]2 stories have affairs, 1 has messed up priorities, and one has mother issues.[/spoiler]
Lawrence is still my favorite but his story had the least number of catastrophic relationship issues.
Honestly, I only finished it because I try to have 100% achievements. I really enjoyed this game. The main character comes across as very human. Her job varies depends on who she's married to and the various issues vary. All of the stories are interesting. 

I didn't play the stat building part of the game, just the straight up visual novel so I can't comment on that. Had fun with this game, wish the game play was more like the first game tho BIG CW for sexual assault and romanticized sexual violence.

There's a lot of exciting ideas in this game's blurb: the very notion of vn/dating sim sequel that focuses on an established relationship makes me tingly all over. But I'm not sure what I really expected beyond that.

There's the obvious sexism and the barebones gameplay. There's the sense that I've been tricked into playing a game based on a presumed attachment I had to Always Remember Me. There's the inconsistent art style and the bizarre characterization of--everyone. It's really hard to find something positive to say about this game right now and I think a lot of my troubles can be summarized by the Hugh route, where Amy is literally assaulted by Luis but the route takes pains to make it seem like...................that's a good thing? She enjoys being sexually harassed because she feels neglected? What am I supposed to make of this? If I'm feeling totally crazy I can maybe throw some darts at a board and come up with an argument that says something like "Uhhhhhhh...........Amy's dealing with her severe self-esteem issues while working in an industry that puts bodies on display like so much cattle so here's a thinly veiled takedown of a fantastical representation of said industry and uhhhhh there's some internalized misogyny that makes her feel like potentially getting roofied could be a romantic come on........and uh..............................the floss-thin connections between scenes are really just phenomenological representations of her sense of her alienation from her marriage????"

I don't know. Sounds like hooey. Sounds like excuse-making for a game that really wants me to be like "wow good on Hugh for NOT blaming the victim" just as the internal narration is explicitly like "uwu wow assault makes me feel so good this must be a secret wish of mine how exciting to be ~desired~". This is a great example of why the current vn renaissance is so important: this kind of BS shouldn't be the norm anymore.

Honestly, what the hell is this. This game doesn't seem to know what it wants to be . Or, maybe, this game knows exactly what it is: a good idea dressed up with flimsy streamers to convince someone to waste their money on it. Do yourself a favour: if you feel even just NEUTRAL toward Always Remember ME and are like "damn I'd love to see where these bizarre-o relationships go", write yourself some fanfiction. You as a player are infinitely more capable of showing more respect to these characters than Winter Wolves did. For those who don't belive in "Happy ever after. The end".  Game about that "Your happily ever after" needs a lot of hard work.  In this dating sim you play the married couple life. Will you stay married or divorce?

+Adult relationship/
+You can choose between visual novel version and raising stats.
+Not too long for those who don't have much time for visual novel.
+Visual novel about more adult stuff.

-Great graphic difference between characters from First Game and Second one.
-Too short for those who likes complicate stories. Just a nice way to kill time and enjoy the story laid out before you. A little tedious on the weeks screen but otherwise I really liked playing this game. The soundtrack is lovely. And it's a lot better than Always Rememer Me. It's one of the few VN which ACTUALLY talks about the struggles after a happily-ever-after and how hard it is to make relationships work. Probably my favourite Winter Wolves VN. Did I mention it has an amazing soundtrack?

name: In The Shadow Of The Truth
short_description: First person shooter,puzzle,psychological horror video game. by 7TPGAMES
reviews:
This game has potential, but nix the murderous, running a-hole with the shovel, please.  I had to ditch him in the swingset several times and he was right on my 'a', so it was difficult.  Also, make the batteries easier to pick up and the flashlight last longer.  An english-fluent editor would help.  I generally hate games that do not have the ability to save anywhere/anytime, but this one is short.  The video walkthrough is about 22 minutes to complete the game.

It is a dark and rainy and has a few pop-out type scary moments.  If I did not have two walkthroughs to guide me, I would have hated this game because I would have had to restart it from the beginning many times due to the a-hole mentioned above. It's ok for one buck in a sale. Alright. I've played for.. A couple hours now apparently. The game is poor in my opinion, sadly as I wanted to give it a fair go. The puzzles are obscure, with no real hints as to where you are supposed to look for information, I solved the second one completely on accident, the third I literally started spam clicking after wasting half of my battery, and the fourth one took most of an hour wandering around to get. 
The puzzles require somewhat random trivia know,  and only for the first do you get any aid as to the solution. 
Language wise, it is clear that the developer doesn't speak English primarily, but also clear that they didn't have the help of an English speaker to translate, but instead seemed to rely on dictionary translations. 
The enemy I encountered in my time playing was also very poor. There is a somewhat jarring cut scene, which leads to you being attacked by a random guy for no discernable reason. However, it is -very- easy to hang the AI up on pathing issues, and I eventually got fed up with trying to solve the puzzle with him chasing me so I stuck him on the swings in the playground and left him to rot. 
The game has promise, but it definitely needs help and polish. *subject to revision if I can ever get out of the first damn room.

- The build on the english store boots in Turkish

- You can't pick up the glowing red keys on the table at the start because the light isn't turned on (there is also a glowing red bottle on the desk which I can't pick up yet & an achievement for getting 5 batteries so I'm guessing this is going to be one of those games that won't let you pick up anything until the game wants you to, not necesarily when a player would find it on a natural playing path).
Also, you click into notes & inspect objects with LMB but you have to press ESC to back out of them, which is annoying.

- The notes are in Turkish, there is broken english subtitles, but only the first time you open a note or click into a 'zoom' event like the computer password.

- I tried all the text in the room that would fit into the computer password screen & nothing worked; don't know if it is broken or if one of the notes is a puzzle written in Turkish.

- The whiteboard in the office has a bunch of code on it, I don't know if that is a puzzle or it is literally an odd bug; who knows with this so far.

It could be good, I don't know, maybe I'll never know.
I kind of half want to recommend it so that someone might tell me the password so I can leave the first room; until then, no.

name: Dungeon Rush
short_description: Dungeon Rush is an absolutely beautiful and colorful fantasy bow VR shooting game where you have to protect your castle from hordes of undead warriors.
reviews:
Cool tower defender VR game.

7.5/10 No, is not great. Early VR implementation and not a great amount of content. It's a great solo game. It looks good to me. It has campaign and survival modes, 4 different bows and no story whatsoever. For 4$ it's a great buy. Fun game but the only problem i have with it is that your firing trigger stays the some when you change hands, your firing trigger should change bast on what hand your holding the arrow, or even better put in a setting where we can chose there the firing trigger is and where we want to hold the bow and arrow, other was its confusing. While the game is solidly made, the wave shooter scenario where you stand at a fixed point get old really fast. Couldn't play it longer than a few minutes before becoming bored.

Not recommended. I liked the minimalistic design and how it doesn't try to distract you with non-interactive clutter. It's sorely lacking in more levels and variability within/between levels, where map 1 felt too small and map 4 and 5 were too big that it was too hard to get the arrows far enough to hit the enemies. The patterns are the same between levels, so round 1 is always middle lane, round 6 is always ranged only, etc. Encountered a bug I couldn't reproduce after restarting the game - the trigger to load and release arrows got switched to the bow hand, which was hilarious, but couldn't fix in game without shutting my VR down completely and restarting. Allowing you to physically move away and dodge enemies projectiles was a brilliant touch. Critically, though, the bow upgrades gives you essentially the same effect in three different colors, so that was also a little lackluster. 

I also love how cute the skeletons are and how they give you your personal space even when they surround and attack you.

Overall, I got it on 40% off at 5.39 CDN, it doesn't give me motion sickness like some other titles, and the controls were intuitive, so an easy 7/10. One points off each for - could use more campaign levels or adding a mini plot for why you're defending these areas, missing level editor/mods compatibility for replayability, and definitely could have done a little something more for the bow upgrades (I.e. shoot further, increase projectiles, add more effect to arrows, etc). If the devs are actively working on this title, they could easily bring it up to an incredible wave defence game worth two or three times as much as they charge now. 8 / 10

This is a fun wave shooter. Much better than a lot of the other wave shooters out there. I recommend this. DO NOT GET WITH MIXED REALITY HEADSET

Since the games entire concept is to fire a bow which requires placing your hand outside of the effective tracking area it really doesnt work.  The concept is definitely fun but without the aid of a push to shoot or a pullback requirement slider (so you could shoot full strength with a unrealistically short pull) it really doesnt work.  I wouid love to experience more of the game as the concept is amazingly fun but without a htc vibe it isnt really playable.

Other ways to resolve could include conventional difficulty settings, pullback strength indicator (so you can establish consisency with a unnatural 3/4 pull) or aim crosshair.  When the pullback hand exits the field of view it is considered static resulting is incorrect vector calculations for aim since the near hand position cannot be accurately determined. This is a fun game. The graphic style for levels and characters is fun and bright. The waves of enemies are well programmed and by the 8th wave things are busy. The archery mechanics are good and sound effects are good too. 

This game needs: 
[list]
[*] Accuracy Reports
[*] Does Health do Anything?
[*] Boss Fights
[*] Gold and gems and a shop
[*] Enemies could make more sounds and add humour. More bones. 
[*] Enemy powerup Drops
[*] Disco Unicorn

Thank you for the great game!

 This is a blast to play.  Loading the arrow can be problematic and you would think that would be a deal breaker in this kind of game but being in a dungeon skewering wave after wave of  mobs  is just so much fun.
